synonyms:
chronic maxillary atelectasis (cma)
chronic atelectasis of the maxillary sinus
chronic maxillary atelectasis is a descriptive term that is characterised by a persistent decrease in the maxillary sinus volume due to inward bowing of its walls.
on this page:
article:
terminology
classification
treatment and prognosis
references
images:cases and figures
terminologyit is not considered synonymous with - but can include the term silent sinus syndrome, typically when there is also spontaneous enophthalmos, hypoglobus, and/or mid-facial deformity in the absence of complaints related to the nose and paranasal sinuses 1.classificationchronic maxillary atelectasis may be classified into three successive clinicoradiological stages:
stage i: membranous deformity
stage ii: bony deformity
stage iii: clinical deformity
treatment and prognosisintervention may depend on a number of factors, such as symptoms, with some suggesting it is better managed in a two-step manner. it is first mandatory to relieve the obstruction of the maxillary sinus and restore its normal ventilation. this is usually achieved via functional endoscopic sinus surgery.
references
1. mangussi-gomes j, nakanishi m, chalita mr, damasco f, de oliveira ca. stage ii chronic maxillary atelectasis associated with subclinical visual field defect. (2013) international archives of otorhinolaryngology. 17 (4): 409-12. doi:10.1055/s-0033-1351679 - pubmed
2. kass e s et.al. chronic maxillary atelectasis. (1997) the annals of otology, rhinology, and laryngology. doi:10.1177/000348949710600204 - pubmed
3. hens g et.al. chronic maxillary atelectasis. (2020) b-ent. doi: - pubmed
4. clotilde de dorlodot, stephanie collet, philippe rombaux, mihaela horoi, sergio hassid, philippe eloy. chronic maxillary atelectasis and silent sinus syndrome: two faces of the same clinical entity. (2017) european archives of oto-rhino-laryngology. 274 (9): 3367. doi:10.1007/s00405-017-4622-8

entities.name: "CHRONIC MAXILLARY ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Chronic Maxillary Atelectasis is a descriptive term characterized by a persistent decrease in the maxillary sinus volume due to inward bowing of its walls."

entities.name: "SILENT SINUS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Silent Sinus Syndrome is a term that may be associated with Chronic Maxillary Atelectasis when there is spontaneous enophthalmos, hypoglobus, and/or mid-facial deformity."

entities.name: "MAXILLARY SINUS"
entities.description: "The Maxillary Sinus is a location where the atelectasis occurs, leading to the decrease in volume and inward bowing of the walls."

entities.name: "FUNCTIONAL ENDOSCOPIC SINUS SURGERY"
entities.description: "Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery is a therapeutic intervention used to relieve the obstruction of the maxillary sinus and restore its normal ventilation."

entities.name: "HYPOGLOBUS"
entities.description: "Hypoglobus is a condition where the eyeball is situated below the level of the orbital rim in the eye socket."

entities.name: "MID-FACIAL DEFORMITY"
entities.description: "Mid-facial deformity refers to an abnormality in the facial structure, typically involving the middle part of the face."

entities.name: "THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTION"
entities.description: "Therapeutic Intervention refers to actions taken to improve or maintain health, often involving medical treatment or therapy."

entities.name: "VENTILATION"
entities.description: "In the context of the maxillary sinus, ventilation refers to the exchange of air to maintain proper pressure and oxygen levels within the sinus cavity."

entities.name: "OBSTRUCTION"
entities.description: "Obstruction is a blockage or barrier that restricts or hinders the normal flow or passage of air or other substances."

entities.name: "RESTORE"
entities.description: "To restore means to bring something back to its original or normal condition."

entities.name: "RELIEVE"
entities.description: "To relieve means to alleviate or lessen the intensity or severity of a symptom or condition."

entities.name: "PERSISTENT"
entities.description: "Persistent refers to something that continues or endures over an extended period of time."

entities.name: "DECREASE"
entities.description: "Decrease is the act of reducing in size, amount, or intensity."

entities.name: "INWARD BOWING"
entities.description: "Inward bowing describes the curvature of a structure that bends or curves towards the interior or central area."

entities.name: "WALL"
entities.description: "In the context of the maxillary sinus, the wall refers to the boundary that separates the sinus cavity from surrounding structures or tissues."

entities.name: "SPONTANEOUS"
entities.description: "Spontaneous describes something that occurs without external influence or stimulus."

entities.name: "CLINICAL FINDING"
entities.description: "A clinical finding is a symptom, sign, or manifestation observed during a medical examination or evaluation."

entities.name: "EYEBALL"
entities.description: "The eyeball is the globe-shaped structure within the eye socket that houses the sensory receptors responsible for vision."

entities.name: "ORBIT"
entities.description: "The orbit is the bony socket in the skull that houses and protects the eyeball and associated structures."

entities.name: "FACIAL STRUCTURE"
entities.description: "Facial structure refers to the arrangement and organization of tissues, muscles, and bones that make up the face."

entities.name: "THERAPY"
entities.description: "Therapy involves the use of medical interventions or techniques to treat or manage a condition or improve health."

entities.name: "EXCHANGE"
entities.description: "In the context of ventilation, exchange refers to the process of replacing stale air with fresh air to maintain optimal air quality."

entities.name: "AIR"
entities.description: "Air is a mixture of gases, primarily nitrogen and oxygen, that is essential for respiration and maintaining life."

entities.name: "PRESSURE"
entities.description: "Pressure is the force exerted on a surface per unit area, often measured in millimeters of mercury (mmHg) in medical contexts."

entities.name: "OXYGEN"
entities.description: "Oxygen is a vital component of the air we breathe, necessary for cellular respiration and energy production in the body."

entities.name: "SINUS CAVITY"
entities.description: "The sinus cavity is a hollow space within the skull that is lined with mucous membranes and helps regulate air quality and pressure."

entities.name: "PROPER"
entities.description: "Proper refers to something that is correct, suitable, or appropriate according to established standards or norms."

entities.name: "ALLEVIATE"
entities.description: "To alleviate means to reduce or lessen the severity or intensity of a symptom or condition."

entities.name: "INTENSITY"
entities.description: "Intensity refers to the degree or strength of a symptom, sensation, or condition."

entities.name: "SEVERITY"
entities.description: "Severity indicates the extent or seriousness of a symptom, disease, or condition."

entities.name: "EXTERNAL"
entities.description: "External refers to something that is situated or occurs outside of a particular structure or boundary."

entities.name: "INFLUENCE"
entities.description: "Influence is the capacity to have an effect on the character, behavior, or development of someone or something."

entities.name: "STIMULUS"
entities.description: "A stimulus is a signal, event, or condition that evokes a response or reaction in an organism or system.")<|COMPLETE|>

synonyms:
cicatricial atelectasis
cicatrisation atelectatic change
cicatricial atelectasis change
cicatrization atelectasis
cicatrization atelectatic change
cicatrisation atelectasis is a form of lung atelectasis which occurs as a result of scarring or fibrosis that reduces lung expansion. cicatrisation atelectasis is classic in tuberculosis. the term is closely related to cicatrisation collapse when an entire lobe is collapsed from the same process.aetiology
granulomatous disease especially tuberculosis
necrotising pneumonia
radiation fibrosis
silicosis
scleroderma
idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
see also
cicatricial collapse - considered a more advanced form
references
1. woodring jh, reed jc. types and mechanisms of pulmonary atelectasis. j thorac imaging. 1996;11 (2): 92-108. pubmed citation
2. collins j, stern ej. chest radiology: the essentials. lww. isbn:1451144482. read it at google books - find it at amazon
3. w. richard webb, charles b. higgins. thoracic imaging. (2010) isbn: 9781605479767
4. richard b. gunderman. essential radiology. (2019) isbn: 9781588900821

entities.name: "CICATRISATION ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Cicatrisation Atelectasis is a form of lung atelectasis resulting from scarring or fibrosis that limits lung expansion, commonly associated with tuberculosis."

entities.name: "GRANULOMATOUS DISEASE"
entities.description: "Granulomatous Disease, especially tuberculosis, is a known etiology for Cicatrisation Atelectasis."

entities.name: "NECROTISING PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Necrotising Pneumonia is listed as an etiology for Cicatrisation Atelectasis."

entities.name: "RADIATION FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Radiation Fibrosis is identified as a potential cause of Cicatrisation Atelectasis."

entities.name: "SILICOSIS"
entities.description: "Silicosis is mentioned as a possible contributing factor to Cicatrisation Atelectasis."

entities.name: "SCLERODERMA"
entities.description: "Scleroderma is linked to the development of Cicatrisation Atelectasis."

entities.name: "IDIOPATHIC PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis is implicated in the occurrence of Cicatrisation Atelectasis."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease can lead to Cicatrisation Atelectasis due to air trapping."

entities.name: "ASBESTOSIS"
entities.description: "Asbestosis is associated with the development of Cicatrisation Atelectasis."

entities.name: "HRCT"
entities.description: "HRCT is a technology used for imaging and diagnosing various pulmonary conditions."

entities.name: "BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Bronchitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the bronchial tubes, leading to coughing and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Tracheal Stenosis is a narrowing of the trachea, which can lead to breathing difficulties and other respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "ALVEOLAR OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Alveolar Oedema is a type of pulmonary edema that affects the alveoli, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs and breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "ALVEOLI"
entities.description: "Alveoli are tiny air sacs in the lungs where the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide takes place during respiration."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY SYSTEM"
entities.description: "The Respiratory System is a biological system responsible for gas exchange in the body, involving organs such as the lungs, trachea, and bronchi."

entities.name: "CHRONIC BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Chronic Bronchitis is a long-term inflammation of the bronchial tubes, resulting in persistent cough and mucus production."

entities.name: "LUNGS"
entities.description: "The Lungs are vital organs for respiration, where oxygen is taken in and carbon dioxide is expelled during breathing."

entities.name: "BRONCHI"
entities.description: "The Bronchi are the main air passages in the respiratory system that branch off from the trachea and carry air into the lungs."

entities.name: "GAS EXCHANGE"
entities.description: "Gas Exchange is the process by which oxygen is taken in and carbon dioxide is expelled in the lungs."

entities.name: "TRACHEA"
entities.description: "The Trachea, also known as the windpipe, is a tube connecting the larynx to the lungs, allowing air to pass in and out during breathing."

entities.name: "OXYGEN"
entities.description: "Oxygen is a vital molecule for respiration, being necessary for cellular metabolism and energy production."

entities.name: "CARBON DIOXIDE"
entities.description: "Carbon Dioxide is a waste product of cellular metabolism that is expelled from the body during exhalation."

entities.name: "LARYNX"
entities.description: "The Larynx is a part of the respiratory system located in the throat, containing the vocal cords and serving as a passage for air."

entities.name: "CELLULAR METABOLISM"
entities.description: "Cellular Metabolism is the set of chemical reactions that occur in cells to maintain life, involving the production and use of energy."

entities.name: "ENERGY PRODUCTION"
entities.description: "Energy Production is the process by which cells generate energy from nutrients to carry out various functions."

entities.name: "MUCUS"
entities.description: "Mucus is a sticky fluid produced by the respiratory system to trap particles and protect the airways."

entities.name: "COUGH"
entities.description: "Coughing is a reflex action that helps clear the airways of mucus, irritants, or foreign particles."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL NARROWING"
entities.description: "Tracheal Narrowing is a medical condition where the trachea becomes constricted, leading to breathing difficulties and other symptoms."

entities.name: "BREATHING DIFFICULTIES"
entities.description: "Breathing Difficulties refer to any discomfort or impairment in the process of inhaling and exhaling air."

entities.name: "FLUID ACCUMULATION"
entities.description: "Fluid Accumulation is the abnormal buildup of fluids in tissues or body cavities, which can lead to various health issues."

trachea, which can lead to breathing difficulties and other respiratory symptoms."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""ALVEOLAR OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Alveolar Oedema is a type of pulmonary edema that affects the alveoli, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs and breathing difficulties."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data of oxygen and carbon dioxide takes place during respiration."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""RESPIRATORY SYSTEM"">      <data key="d0">"ANATOMY"</data>      <data key="d1">"The Respiratory System is a biological system responsible for gas exchange in the body, involving organs such as the lungs, trachea, and bronchi."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHRONIC BRONCHITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chronic Bronchitis is a long-term inflammation of the bronchial tubes, resulting in persistent cough and mucus production."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNGS"">      <data key="d0">"ANATOMY"</data>      <data key="d1">"The Lungs are vital organs for respiration, where oxygen is taken in and carbon dioxide is expelled during breathing."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHI"">      <data key="d0">"ANATOMY"</data>      <data key="d1">"The Bronchi are the main air passages in the respiratory system that branch off from the trachea and carry air into the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""GAS EXCHANGE"">      <data key="d0">"PROCESS"</data>      <data key="d1">"Gas Exchange is the process by which oxygen is taken in and carbon dioxide is expelled in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEA"">      <data key="d0">"ANATOMY"</data>      <data key="d1">"The Trachea, also known as the windpipe, is a tube key="d0">"MOLECULE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Oxygen is a vital molecule for respiration, being necessary for cellular metabolism and energy production."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""CARBON DIOXIDE"">      <data key="d0">"MOLECULE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Carbon Dioxide is a waste product of cellular      <data key="d1">"The Larynx is a part of the respiratory system located in the throat, containing the vocal cords and serving as a passage for air."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""CELLULAR METABOLISM"">      <data key="d0">"PROCESS"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cellular Metabolism is the set of chemical PRODUCTION"">      <data key="d0">"PROCESS"</data>      <data key="d1">"Energy Production is the process by which cells generate energy from nutrients to carry out various functions."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""MUCUS"">      <data key="d0">"SUBSTANCE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Mucus is a sticky fluid produced by the respiratory system to trap particles and protect the airways."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""COUGH"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data id=""TRACHEAL NARROWING"">      <data key="d0">"CONDITION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheal Narrowing is a medical condition where the trachea becomes constricted, leading to breathing difficulties and other symptoms."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <node id=""BREATHING DIFFICULTIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data <node id=""FLUID ACCUMULATION"">      <data key="d0">"CONDITION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Fluid Accumulation is the abnormal buildup of fluids in tissues or body cavities, which can lead to various health issues."</data>      <data key="d2">5d98e5f9dd40691f884656a8bcf26395</data>    </node>    <edge source=""BRONCHITIS"" target=""TRACHEAL STENOSIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data entities.name: "BRONCHOMALACIA"
entities.description: "Bronchomalacia is a condition characterized by excessive tracheal narrowing, potentially leading to symptoms like difficulty breathing and coughing."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Tracheal Stenosis refers to the narrowing of the trachea, which can result in breathing difficulties and other respiratory issues."

entities.name: "DIVERTICULA"
entities.description: "Diverticula are abnormal pouches that can develop in the lining of the trachea or bronchi, potentially causing symptoms like inflammation and pain."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the lungs, leading to symptoms like shortness of breath and chest pain."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE (ILD)"
entities.description: "Interstitial Lung Disease refers to a group of lung disorders that affect the interstitium, causing symptoms like coughing and shortness of breath."

entities.name: "LYMPHOID INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA (LIP)"
entities.description: "Lymphoid Interstitial Pneumonia is a rare lung disease characterized by abnormal lymphocyte infiltration and respiratory symptoms like cough and fatigue."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition in which air leaks into the space between the lungs and chest wall, causing lung collapse and symptoms like chest pain and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by abnormal widening and scarring of the bronchi, resulting in symptoms like recurrent infections and coughing up mucus."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease is a progressive lung disease that makes it difficult to breathe, often caused by long-term exposure to irritants like cigarette smoke."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart, leading to symptoms like shortness of breath and chest pain."

entities.name: "SARCOIDOSIS"
entities.description: "Sarcoidosis is a condition characterized by the growth of inflammatory cells in various organs, commonly affecting the lungs and causing symptoms like coughing and fatigue."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the lungs, often linked to smoking and leading to symptoms like persistent coughing and chest pain."

entities.name: "FOCAL LYMPHOID HYPERPLASIA OF THE LUNG"
entities.description: "Focal Lymphoid Hyperplasia of the Lung is a medical condition involving an abnormal growth of lymphoid tissue in the lung."

entities.name: "PULMONARY CHONDROMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Chondroma is a type of benign tumor that originates in the lung tissue."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HAMARTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hamartoma is a non-cancerous lung tumor composed of an abnormal mixture of cells."

entities.name: "PULMONARY MESENCHYMAL CYSTIC HAMARTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Mesenchymal Cystic Hamartoma is a type of lung tumor characterized by cystic spaces filled with connective tissue."

entities.name: "PULMONARY SCLEROSING PNEUMOCYTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Sclerosing Pneumocytoma is a rare benign tumor of the lung with distinctive histologic features."

entities.name: "PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Metastases refer to the spread of cancer from other organs to the lungs."

entities.name: "CANNONBALL METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cannonball Metastases is a colloquial term for metastatic lung lesions that appear as round, well-circumscribed masses."

entities.name: "CAVITATORY PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cavitatory Pulmonary Metastases are metastatic lung lesions that present with cavities within the lung tissue."

entities.name: "CYSTIC PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cystic Pulmonary Metastases are metastatic lung lesions characterized by the presence of cystic spaces within the lung tissue."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER SCREENING"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer Screening refers to the process of early detection and diagnosis of lung cancer in at-risk individuals."

entities.name: "LUNG-RADS"
entities.description: "Lung-RADS is a standardized system for interpreting and reporting lung cancer screening results."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER STAGING"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer Staging involves determining the extent and severity of lung cancer to guide treatment decisions."

entities.name: "IASLC (INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LUNG CANCER) 8TH EDITION"
entities.description: "IASLC 8th Edition provides updated guidelines for the study and management of lung cancer."

entities.name: "IASLC (INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LUNG CANCER) 7TH EDITION"
entities.description: "IASLC 7th Edition is an older version of guidelines for the study and management of lung cancer."

entities.name: "1996 AJCC-UICC REGIONAL LYMPH NODE CLASSIFICATION FOR LUNG CANCER STAGING"
entities.description: "The 1996 AJCC-UICC Regional Lymph Node Classification provides a system for staging lung cancer based on lymph node involvement."

entities.name: "LUNG ADENOCARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Lung Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer that originates in the cells lining the alveoli."

entities.name: "LUNG SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Lung Squamous Cell Carcinoma is a type of non-small cell lung cancer that begins in the flat cells lining the airways."

entities.name: "SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Small Cell Lung Cancer is a fast-growing type of lung cancer that typically starts in the bronchi."

entities.name: "MESOTHELIOMA"
entities.description: "Mesothelioma is a form of cancer that affects the thin layer of tissue that covers the lungs and other organs."

entities.name: "LUNG BIOPSY"
entities.description: "Lung Biopsy is a procedure in which a sample of lung tissue is removed for examination under a microscope."

entities.name: "BRONCHOSCOPY"
entities.description: "Bronchoscopy is a procedure that allows a doctor to examine the airways in the lungs using a thin, flexible tube."

entities.name: "CT SCAN OF THE CHEST"
entities.description: "CT Scan of the Chest is a diagnostic imaging test that produces detailed cross-sectional images of the chest area, including the lungs."

entities.name: "PET SCAN"
entities.description: "PET Scan is a nuclear imaging technique that uses a radioactive tracer to highlight areas of high metabolic activity, such as cancer cells."

entities.name: "THORACOSCOPY"
entities.description: "Thoracoscopy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to examine the inside of the chest, including the lungs."

entities.name: "LOBECTOMY"
entities.description: "Lobectomy is a surgical procedure to remove one of the lobes of the lung."

entities.name: "PNEUMONECTOMY"
entities.description: "Pneumonectomy is a surgical procedure to remove an entire lung."

entities.name: "RADIATION THERAPY"
entities.description: "Radiation Therapy is a cancer treatment that uses high doses of radiation to destroy cancer cells."

entities.name: "CHEMOTHERAPY"
entities.description: "Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to kill cancer cells."

entities.name: "IMMUNOTHERAPY"
entities.description: "Immunotherapy is a cancer treatment that helps the immune system fight cancer."

entities.name: "TARGETED THERAPY"
entities.description: "Targeted Therapy is a cancer treatment that targets specific genes or proteins to stop the growth and spread of cancer cells."

gamuts
compressive atelectasis refers to a form of lung atelectasis due to compression by a space-occupying process.some authors describe it as a subtype of passive (relaxation) atelectasis where the reduction in lung volume is greater than its normal relaxed state 1. whereas others describe it as the intrapulmonary counterpart of passive (relaxation) atelectasis due to an intrapulmonary mass lesion 4.pathologyaetiology

entities.name: "COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Compressive Atelectasis is a form of lung atelectasis due to compression by a space-occupying process, with various extrapulmonary and intrapulmonary causes."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is an extrapulmonary etiology of Compressive Atelectasis, leading to lung collapse due to fluid accumulation in the pleural space."

entities.name: "EMPYEMA"
entities.description: "Empyema is an infection of the pleural space, posing a risk for Compressive Atelectasis as a potential complication."

entities.name: "HEMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Hemothorax refers to blood collection in the pleural cavity, contributing to potential compressive atelectasis."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is the presence of air in the pleural cavity, leading to lung collapse and possible compressive atelectasis."

entities.name: "PLEURAL TUMOR"
entities.description: "Pleural Tumor is an intrapulmonary cause of Compressive Atelectasis, where a tumor growth can compress the lung tissue."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is an intrapulmonary etiology of Compressive Atelectasis, where the presence of cancerous growth can lead to lung collapse."

entities.name: "PRECNANCY"
entities.description: "Pregnancy is an abdominal-related cause of Compressive Atelectasis, where the growing uterus can impede proper lung function."

entities.name: "MORBID OBESITY"
entities.description: "Morbid Obesity is a risk factor for Compressive Atelectasis, as excess adipose tissue can restrict lung expansion."

entities.name: "DIAPHRAGMATIC HERNIA"
entities.description: "Diaphragmatic Hernia is an abdominal-related etiology of Compressive Atelectasis, where abdominal organs herniate into the thoracic cavity, compromising lung function."

entities.name: "ASCITES"
entities.description: "Ascites is an extrapulmonary cause of Compressive Atelectasis, as accumulation of fluid in the abdominal cavity can hinder proper lung expansion."

entities.name: "PLEURAL FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pleural Fibrosis is an intrapulmonary cause of Compressive Atelectasis, where fibrotic scarring of the pleura can restrict lung movement."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is an intrapulmonary etiology of Compressive Atelectasis, where fluid accumulation in the lungs can contribute to lung collapse."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL TUMORS"
entities.description: "Bronchial Tumors are an intrapulmonary cause of Compressive Atelectasis, as tumor growth in the bronchial tubes can impede proper lung function."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis, in general, refers to the incomplete expansion or collapse of lung tissue, with one form being Compressive Atelectasis."

key="d2">4e8a06c2f25c1368db384419491fb58b</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Edema is an intrapulmonary etiology of Compressive Atelectasis, where fluid accumulation in the lungs can contribute to lung collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">4e8a06c2f25c1368db384419491fb58b</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIAL TUMORS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchial Tumors are an intrapulmonary cause of Compressive Atelectasis, as tumor growth in the bronchial tubes can impede proper lung function."</data>      <data key="d2">4e8a06c2f25c1368db384419491fb58b</data>    </node>    <node id=""ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Atelectasis, in general, refers to the incomplete expansion or collapse of lung tissue, with one form being Compressive Atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d2">4e8a06c2f25c1368db384419491fb58b</data>    </node>    <edge source=""COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"" target=""PLEURAL EFFUSION"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Pleural Effusion can lead to lung collapse and subsequent Compressive Atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d5">4e8a06c2f25c1368db384419491fb58b</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"" target=""EMPYEMA"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Empyema, as an infection of the pleural space, can contribute to the development of Compressive Atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d5">4e8a06c2f25c1368db384419491fb58b</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"" target=""PNEUMOTHORAX"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Pneumothorax, with the presence of air in the pleural cavity, can result in lung collapse and subsequent Compressive Atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d5">4e8a06c2f25c1368db384419491fb58b</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

entities.name: "CHEST RADIOGRAPH"
entities.description: "Chest Radiograph refers to a radiographic image of the chest used for diagnostic purposes."

entities.name: "RADIOGRAPHY"
entities.description: "Radiography is a technique used to produce images of the internal structures of the body, including the chest."

entities.name: "PA"
entities.description: "Pa is a chest radiograph projection technique used for imaging the chest from the front."

entities.name: "LATERAL PROJECTION"
entities.description: "Lateral Projection is a chest radiograph projection technique used for imaging the chest from the side."

entities.name: "APPROACH"
entities.description: "Approach refers to the method or strategy used to address a particular situation or problem."

entities.name: "CONGENITAL HEART DISEASE"
entities.description: "Congenital Heart Disease is a condition present at birth that affects the structure or function of the heart."

entities.name: "ENDOTRACHEAL TUBES"
entities.description: "Endotracheal Tubes are medical devices inserted into the trachea to assist with breathing."

entities.name: "SWAN-GANZ CATHETER"
entities.description: "Swan-Ganz Catheter is a type of catheter used to measure heart function and monitor cardiac output."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition in which air collects in the space between the lungs and the chest wall, causing lung collapse."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by a blood clot."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is a condition characterized by the collapse or closure of a part of the lung, leading to difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "MEDIASTINAL SHIFT"
entities.description: "Mediastinal Shift is a radiologic finding indicating a shift of structures in the chest cavity, often due to pressure from a mass or fluid accumulation."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is the build-up of excess fluid between the layers of the pleura outside the lungs, causing chest pain and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "COPD"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a group of lung diseases that block airflow and make it difficult to breathe."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, causing cough, fever, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "FOREIGN BODY ASPIRATION"
entities.description: "Foreign Body Aspiration is the inhalation of an object into the airway, leading to choking, coughing, and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "RIB FRACTURE"
entities.description: "Rib Fracture is a break or crack in one of the ribs, often caused by trauma or injury."

entities.name: "ALLERGIC BRONCHOPULMONARY ASPERGILLOSIS"
entities.description: "Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis is a condition characterized by an allergic reaction to a fungus, specifically Aspergillus, affecting the bronchi."

entities.name: "WILLIAMS CAMPBELL SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Williams Campbell Syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by tracheobronchomegaly or widened airways."

entities.name: "CONGENITAL TRACHEOBRONCHOMEGALY"
entities.description: "Congenital Tracheobronchomegaly, also known as Mounier-Kuhn Syndrome, is a condition where the trachea and bronchi are abnormally wide."

entities.name: "PRIMARY CILIARY DYSKINESIA"
entities.description: "Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia is a genetic disorder affecting the cilia, leading to respiratory complications."

entities.name: "CENTRAL BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Central Bronchiectasis refers to the dilation or widening of the central bronchi in the lungs."

entities.name: "UPPER LOBE BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Upper Lobe Bronchiectasis is the dilation of the lung's upper lobe bronchi, leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "MIDDLE LOBE BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Middle Lobe Bronchiectasis is the dilation of the middle lobe bronchi in the lungs, often causing symptoms such as cough and chest pain."

entities.name: "LOWER LOBE BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Lower Lobe Bronchiectasis involves the dilation of the bronchi in the lower lobe of the lungs, contributing to respiratory issues."

entities.name: "TRACHEOBRONCHOMALACIA"
entities.description: "Tracheobronchomalacia is a condition characterized by weak cartilage in the trachea and bronchi, leading to collapsing airways."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Tracheal Stenosis refers to the narrowing of the trachea, often causing breathing difficulties and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE TRACHEAL NARROWING"
entities.description: "Diffuse Tracheal Narrowing is a symptom that indicates a widespread narrowing of the trachea, impacting airflow."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Bronchial Stenosis is the narrowing of the bronchi, restricting airflow and leading to respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE AIRWAY NARROWING"
entities.description: "Diffuse Airway Narrowing is a symptom indicating a comprehensive narrowing of the airways, affecting breathing."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL DIVERTICULUM"
entities.description: "Tracheal Diverticulum is a pouch-like structure that protrudes from the trachea, potentially causing airway obstruction."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL DIVERTICULUM"
entities.description: "Bronchial Diverticulum is an outpouching in the bronchi, which may lead to respiratory issues."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is a condition characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, leading to shortness of breath and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL EDEMA"
entities.description: "Interstitial Edema involves fluid accumulation in the interstitial spaces of the lungs, causing breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "ALVEOLAR EDEMA"
entities.description: "Alveolar Edema refers to fluid buildup in the alveoli, contributing to impaired gas exchange in the lungs."

entities.name: "CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema is caused by heart-related issues leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs, resulting in breathing problems."

entities.name: "NON-CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema occurs due to factors other than heart problems, causing fluid to accumulate in the lungs and impairing breathing."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE (ILD)"
entities.description: "Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) encompasses various conditions affecting the lung interstitium, leading to symptoms like cough and shortness of breath."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a malignant tumor that starts in the lungs, often associated with symptoms like persistent cough and weight loss."

entities.name: "NON-SMALL-CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer refers to a type of lung cancer that typically grows and spreads more slowly than small-cell lung cancer."

entities.name: "ADENOCARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that begins in the cells that line certain organs and can develop in the lungs."

entities.name: "PLEURAL INVASION"
entities.description: "Pleural Invasion indicates the spread of cancer cells from the lungs into the pleura, the membrane surrounding the lungs."

entities.name: "VASCULAR INVASION"
entities.description: "Vascular Invasion signifies cancer cells spreading to blood vessels, facilitating tumor growth and potential metastasis."

entities.name: "ASTHMA"
entities.description: "Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to symptoms like wheezing and shortness of breath."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a group of progressive lung diseases that cause airflow obstruction, leading to symptoms such as coughing and chest tightness."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, leading to symptoms like fever, cough, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition where air leaks into the space between the lungs and chest wall, causing lung collapse and chest pain."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by a blood clot, resulting in symptoms like sudden shortness of breath and chest pain."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease that occurs when lung tissue becomes damaged and scarred, leading to difficulty breathing and a persistent dry cough."

entities.name: "LARYNGITIS"
entities.description: "Laryngitis is the inflammation of the voice box or larynx, resulting in hoarseness, difficulty speaking, and a sore throat."

entities.name: "LUNG ABSCESS"
entities.description: "Lung Abscess is a pus-filled cavity in the lungs caused by an infection, leading to symptoms like coughing up blood, fever, and chest pain."

entities.name: "PLEURISY"
entities.description: "Pleurisy is the inflammation of the pleura, the thin lining around the lungs, causing sharp chest pain when breathing or coughing."

entities.name: "SILICOSIS"
entities.description: "Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, leading to inflammation and scarring in the lungs, resulting in shortness of breath and a persistent cough."

entities.name: "TUBERCULOSIS"
entities.description: "Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs, causing symptoms like coughing up blood, fatigue, and weight loss."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart, leading to symptoms like shortness of breath and fatigue."

entities.name: "BRONCHIOLITIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiolitis is an inflammation of the small airways or bronchioles in the lungs, commonly seen in infants and young children, causing symptoms like wheezing and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "ALPHA-1 ANTITRYPSIN DEFICIENCY"
entities.description: "Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency is a genetic disorder that can cause lung and liver disease, particularly leading to conditions like emphysema and liver cirrhosis."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPOPLASIA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hypoplasia is a condition where the lungs are underdeveloped, leading to respiratory difficulties, especially in newborns."

entities.name: "PULMONARY ALVEOLAR PROTEINOSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis is a rare lung disease characterized by the accumulation of surfactant in the alveoli, leading to breathing problems and a persistent cough."

key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis is a condition characterized by an allergic reaction to a fungus, specifically Aspergillus, affecting the bronchi."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""WILLIAMS CAMPBELL SYNDROME"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Williams Campbell Syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by tracheobronchomegaly or widened airways."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""CONGENITAL TRACHEOBRONCHOMEGALY"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Congenital Tracheobronchomegaly, also known as Mounier-Kuhn Syndrome, is a condition where the trachea and bronchi are abnormally wide."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""PRIMARY CILIARY DYSKINESIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia is a genetic disorder affecting the cilia, leading to respiratory complications."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""CENTRAL BRONCHIECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Central Bronchiectasis refers to the dilation or widening of the central bronchi in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""UPPER LOBE BRONCHIECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Upper Lobe Bronchiectasis is the dilation of the lung's upper lobe bronchi, leading to breathing difficulties."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""MIDDLE LOBE BRONCHIECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Middle Lobe Bronchiectasis is the dilation of the middle lobe bronchi in the lungs, often causing symptoms such as cough and chest pain."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""LOWER LOBE BRONCHIECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lower Lobe Bronchiectasis involves the dilation of the bronchi in the lower lobe of the lungs, contributing to respiratory issues."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEOBRONCHOMALACIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheobronchomalacia is a condition characterized by weak cartilage in the trachea and bronchi, leading to collapsing airways."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEAL STENOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheal Stenosis refers to the narrowing of the trachea, often causing breathing difficulties and respiratory distress."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""DIFFUSE TRACHEAL NARROWING"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Diffuse Tracheal Narrowing is a symptom that indicates a widespread narrowing of the trachea, impacting airflow."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIAL STENOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchial Stenosis is the narrowing of the bronchi, restricting airflow and leading to respiratory symptoms."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""DIFFUSE AIRWAY NARROWING"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Diffuse Airway Narrowing is a symptom indicating a comprehensive narrowing of the airways, affecting breathing."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEAL DIVERTICULUM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheal Diverticulum is a pouch-like structure that protrudes from the trachea, potentially causing airway obstruction."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIAL DIVERTICULUM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchial Diverticulum is an outpouching in the bronchi, which may lead to respiratory issues."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Edema is a condition characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, leading to shortness of breath and respiratory distress."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""INTERSTITIAL EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Interstitial Edema involves fluid accumulation in the interstitial spaces of the lungs, causing breathing difficulties."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""ALVEOLAR EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Alveolar Edema refers to fluid buildup in the alveoli, contributing to impaired gas exchange in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema is caused by heart-related issues leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs, resulting in breathing problems."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""NON-CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema occurs due to factors other than heart problems, causing fluid to accumulate in the lungs and impairing breathing."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE (ILD)"">      <data breath."</data>      <data key="d2">1bec1c189ced62804c6cc574be79eca4</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Cancer is a malignant entities.name: "STAS"
entities.description: "STAS (Spread Through Air Spaces) is a pathological feature associated with lung cancer, characterized by tumor spread through air spaces."

entities.name: "ACINAR"
entities.description: "Acinar is a non-lepidic pattern observed in lung cancer, indicating a specific growth pattern of tumor cells."

entities.name: "PAPILLARY"
entities.description: "Papillary is a non-lepidic pattern observed in lung cancer, indicating a specific growth pattern of tumor cells."

entities.name: "SOLID"
entities.description: "Solid is a non-lepidic pattern observed in lung cancer, indicating a specific growth pattern of tumor cells."

entities.name: "MICROPAPILLARY"
entities.description: "Micropapillary is a non-lepidic pattern observed in lung cancer, indicating a specific growth pattern of tumor cells."

entities.name: "MYOFIBROBLASTIC STROMA"
entities.description: "Myofibroblastic Stroma is a feature associated with invasive lung tumor cells, suggesting a specific microenvironment."

entities.name: "PLEURAL INVASION"
entities.description: "Pleural Invasion is the invasion of the pleural membrane by lung tumor cells, indicating an advanced stage of cancer."

entities.name: "VASCULAR INVASION"
entities.description: "Vascular Invasion is the invasion of blood vessels by lung tumor cells, suggesting potential metastasis."

entities.name: "PANCOAST TUMOUR"
entities.description: "Pancoast Tumour is a specific type of lung cancer that affects the apex of the lung and can involve nearby structures."

entities.name: "BENIGN NEOPLASMS"
entities.description: "Benign Neoplasms are non-cancerous growths in the lung that do not spread to other parts of the body."

entities.name: "MUCINOUS"
entities.description: "Mucinous is a pattern observed in lung cancer, indicating a specific growth pattern of tumor cells."

entities.name: "SIGNET RING"
entities.description: "Signet Ring is a pattern observed in lung cancer, indicating a specific growth pattern of tumor cells."

chunk:
ectasia (), also called ectasis (), is dilation or distention of a tubular structure, either normal or pathophysiologic but usually the latter (except in atelectasis, where absence of ectasis is the problem).
== specific conditions ==
bronchiectasis, chronic dilatation of the bronchi
duct ectasia of breast, a dilated milk duct. duct ectasia syndrome is a synonym for nonpuerperal (unrelated to pregnancy and breastfeeding) mastitis.
dural ectasia, dilation of the dural sac surrounding the spinal cord, usually in the very low back.
pyelectasis, dilation of a part of the kidney, most frequently seen in prenatal ultrasounds. it usually resolves on its own.
rete tubular ectasia, dilation of tubular structures in the testicles. it is usually found in older men.
acral arteriolar ectasia
corneal ectasia (secondary keratoconus), a bulging of the cornea.
vascular ectasias
most broadly, any abnormal dilatation of a blood vessel, including aneurysms
annuloaortic ectasia, dilation of the aorta. it can be associated with marfan syndrome.
dolichoectasias, weakening of arteries, usually caused by high blood pressure.
intracranial dolichoectasias, dilation of arteries inside the head.
gastric antral vascular ectasia, dilation of small blood vessels in the last part of the stomach.
telangiectasias are small dilated blood vessels found anywhere on the body, but commonly seen on the face around the nose, cheeks, and chin.
venous ectasia, dilation of veins or venules, such as:
chronic venous insufficiency, often in the leg
jugular vein ectasia, in the jugular veins returning blood from the head
== see also ==
all pages with titles beginning with ectasia
all pages with titles containing ectasia
== references ==

entities.name: "ECTASIA"
entities.description: "Ectasia is the dilation or distention of a tubular structure, which can be normal or pathophysiologic."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is chronic dilatation of the bronchi."

entities.name: "DUCT ECTASIA OF BREAST"
entities.description: "Duct Ectasia of Breast is a dilated milk duct, often associated with nonpuerperal mastitis."

entities.name: "DURAL ECTASIA"
entities.description: "Dural Ectasia is the dilation of the dural sac surrounding the spinal cord, typically in the low back region."

entities.name: "PYELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Pyelectasis is the dilation of a part of the kidney, commonly seen in prenatal ultrasounds and often resolves on its own."

entities.name: "RETE TUBULAR ECTASIA"
entities.description: "Rete Tubular Ectasia is the dilation of tubular structures in the testicles, usually found in older men."

entities.name: "CORNEAL ECTASIA"
entities.description: "Corneal Ectasia, also known as secondary keratoconus, is a bulging of the cornea."

entities.name: "ANNULOAORTIC ECTASIA"
entities.description: "Annuloaortic Ectasia is the dilation of the aorta and can be associated with Marfan syndrome."

entities.name: "TELANGIECTASIAS"
entities.description: "Telangiectasias are small dilated blood vessels commonly found on the face."

entities.name: "VENOUS ECTASIA"
entities.description: "Venous Ectasia is the dilation of veins or venules, often associated with conditions like chronic venous insufficiency."

entities.name: "INTESTINAL PSEUDO-OBSTRUCTION"
entities.description: "Intestinal Pseudo-obstruction is a condition where there is a failure of normal coordinated contractions in the intestines, leading to symptoms of obstruction without a physical blockage."

entities.name: "SPLENIC ARTERY ANEURYSM"
entities.description: "Splenic Artery Aneurysm is an abnormal bulging or ballooning of the wall of the splenic artery."

entities.name: "DEGENERATIVE LUMBAR SCOLIOSIS"
entities.description: "Degenerative Lumbar Scoliosis is a sideways curvature of the spine that occurs in the lower back region, often associated with wear and tear of the spine."

entities.name: "CELIAC ARTERY COMPRESSION SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Celiac Artery Compression Syndrome, also known as median arcuate ligament syndrome, is a condition where the celiac artery is compressed by the median arcuate ligament of the diaphragm, leading to symptoms such as abdominal pain and weight loss."

entities.name: "CORONARY ARTERY ECTASIA"
entities.description: "Coronary Artery Ectasia is the abnormal dilatation of a coronary artery, which can be associated with coronary artery disease."

tags:
medical student, uoe, summary
this is a basic article for medical students and other non-radiologistsatelectasis describes small areas of collapsed lung. atelectasis and collapse both describe the same pathophysiology, though atelectasis tends to be used to describe small areas of lung that are not fully expanded, whereas collapse tends to be used to describe larger more confluent areas.
on this page:
article:
reference article
summary
radiographic features
related articles
images:
cases and figures
imaging differential diagnosis
reference articlethis is a summary article; read more in our article on atelectasis. summary
epidemiologyvaries widely depending on the underlying cause
presentationusually breathlessness, but can be asymptomatic and presentation also depends very much on the underlying cause
pathophysiologycaused by:
adjacent compressione.g. a lung tumour, dilated aorta, large osteophyte
passive atelectasiswhen the lung relaxes away from the parietal pleural surface, e.g. pleural effusion, pneumothorax
dependent atelectasisin the posterior portions of the lung due to patients not fully expanding their lungs while lying for long periods
role of imaging
confirm atelectasisdifferentiate from air-space opacification
help to determine the cause (may need ct)
treatment
management of the underlying cause
deeper breathing if the cause is due to hypoventilation
advertisement: supporters see fewer/no ads
radiographic featureschest x-rayatelectasis is usually seen on chest x-rays as small volume linear shadows, usually peripherally or at the lung bases. the underlying cause (such as a lung tumour or pleural effusion) may also be visible. lobar collapse will have a more typical and appearance based on the lobe involved, whereas atelectasis can be more eccentric in position and appearance.ct chestct allows a more accurate depiction of the involved lung. the dependent lung can be affected by subsegmental collapse just because of lying down (particularly if the patient has been supine for a long period of time, or they are under general anaesthesia). this part of the lung is easier to visualise because it is hidden behind the diaphragm on a frontal chest x-rayct is often helpful to determine the cause or confirm that there is no proximal obstruction, though most cases of atelectasis are diagnosed and managed without ct investigation.

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is a condition where small areas of the lung collapse or fail to fully expand, leading to various symptoms and potential complications."

entities.name: "JEREMY JONES"

entities.name: "YURANGA WEERAKKODY"
entities.description: "Yuranga Weerakkody is listed as an author or contributor to an article on atelectasis, indicating expertise in the field."

entities.name: "LUNGS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis affects the functionality of the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties and reduced oxygen intake."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Atelectasis can sometimes be a complication of pneumonia, adding to the severity of the respiratory condition."

entities.name: "THORACIC RATIO"
entities.description: "Thoracic Ratio is a medical condition that relates to body proportions and can have implications for respiratory health."

entities.name: "PNEUMOMEDIASTINUM"
entities.description: "Pneumomediastinum is a condition where air is present in the mediastinum, potentially causing discomfort and complications."

entities.name: "SURGICAL EMPHYSEMA"
entities.description: "Surgical Emphysema is a condition that involves the abnormal presence of air in the tissues following surgery, which can lead to swelling and pain."

entities.name: "CONDITIONS"
entities.description: "Conditions refer to various medical states or ailments that can affect the body and cause symptoms or complications."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is a lung infection that can cause inflammation, difficulty breathing, and other respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "LOBAR COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Lobar Collapse is a condition where a section of the lung collapses, potentially impacting respiratory function and oxygen exchange."

entities.name: "PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Oedema is a condition characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties and reduced oxygenation."

entities.name: "HEART FAILURE"
entities.description: "Heart Failure is a cardiac condition where the heart is unable to pump blood effectively, leading to symptoms like fatigue, shortness of breath, and fluid retention."

entities.name: "SYMPTOMATIC PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Symptomatic Pneumothorax is a condition where air collects in the pleural space, causing lung collapse and potentially severe symptoms like chest pain and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Tension Pneumothorax is a critical condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing significant respiratory distress and potential cardiovascular compromise."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, which can compress the lungs and lead to symptoms like chest pain and shortness of breath."

entities.name: "COPD"
entities.description: "COPD stands for Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, a progressive lung condition characterized by airflow limitation and symptoms like chronic cough and breathlessness."

entities.name: "ASTHMA"
entities.description: "Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition marked by airway inflammation, bronchospasm, and symptoms like wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a serious condition where a blood clot travels to the lungs, blocking blood flow and potentially causing respiratory distress and chest pain."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a malignant tumor that originates in the lungs and can lead to symptoms like persistent cough, chest pain, and weight loss."

entities.name: "MESOTHELIOMA"
entities.description: "Mesothelioma is a rare cancer that affects the mesothelium, often linked to asbestos exposure and characterized by symptoms like chest pain and breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS (AND CF)"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a chronic lung condition where the airways are permanently widened, leading to mucus buildup and respiratory symptoms; often associated with cystic fibrosis (CF)."

entities.name: "TUBERCULOSIS"
entities.description: "Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs and presenting with symptoms like cough, fever, and weight loss."

entities.name: "PRESENTATIONS"
entities.description: "Presentations refer to the observable signs and symptoms displayed by individuals with various medical conditions or diseases."

entities.name: "BREATHLESSNESS"
entities.description: "Breathlessness is a symptom characterized by difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, often associated with respiratory or cardiac conditions."

entities.name: "COUGH"
entities.description: "Cough is a common symptom that involves expelling air from the lungs forcibly to clear the airways, often seen in respiratory infections or irritations."

entities.name: "HAEMOPTYSIS"
entities.description: "Haemoptysis is the medical term for coughing up blood or bloody sputum, which can be a sign of various pulmonary or cardiovascular conditions."

entities.name: "WHEEZE"
entities.description: "Wheeze is a high-pitched whistling sound produced when breathing, often indicative of narrowed airways or respiratory issues."

entities.name: "PLEURITIC CHEST PAIN"
entities.description: "Pleuritic Chest Pain is characterized by sharp or stabbing chest discomfort that worsens with breathing, typically seen in conditions affecting the pleura or lungs."

entities.name: "ABDOMINAL RADIOLOGY"
entities.description: "Abdominal Radiology refers to imaging studies and tests focused on the abdomen, used to diagnose and evaluate various gastrointestinal and abdominal conditions."

entities.name: "IMAGING"
entities.description: "Imaging encompasses various diagnostic techniques such as X-rays, ultrasounds, CT scans, and MRIs, used to visualize internal structures and detect abnormalities."

entities.name: "ERECT CXR"
entities.description: "Erect CXR stands for Erect Chest X-ray, a radiological study performed in a standing position to assess lung and chest abnormalities."

entities.name: "AXR"
entities.description: "AXR is an abbreviation for Abdominal X-ray, a diagnostic imaging test used to evaluate the abdominal organs and structures for signs of pathology."

entities.name: "US ABDOMEN"
entities.description: "US Abdomen refers to Ultrasonography of the Abdomen, a non-invasive imaging modality that uses sound waves to visualize the abdominal organs."

entities.name: "CT ABDOMEN"
entities.description: "CT Abdomen indicates Computed Tomography of the Abdomen, a cross-sectional imaging technique that provides detailed images of the abdominal structures."

entities.name: "KEY FINDINGS"
entities.description: "Key Findings are significant results or observations obtained from medical imaging studies or diagnostic tests, crucial for diagnosis and treatment planning."

entities.name: "PNEUMOPERITONEUM"
entities.description: "Pneumoperitoneum is the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity, often indicating a perforation in the gastrointestinal tract and potentially leading to severe abdominal pain."

entities.name: "BOWEL DILATATION"
entities.description: "Bowel Dilatation refers to the abnormal enlargement or distension of the intestines, which can be caused by various conditions like obstructions or inflammatory processes."

entities.name: "FAT-STRANDING"
entities.description: "Fat-Stranding is a radiological sign characterized by increased density around the fat tissues, commonly observed in inflammatory or traumatic conditions."

entities.name: "FREE INTRAPERITONEAL FLUID"
entities.description: "Free Intraperitoneal Fluid is the accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity that can be a sign of internal organ injury or inflammatory processes."

entities.name: "UPPER GI"
entities.description: "Upper GI refers to the Upper Gastrointestinal Tract, including the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum, often implicated in conditions like reflux, ulcers, and cancer."

entities.name: "OESOPHAGEAL CANCER"
entities.description: "Oesophageal Cancer is a malignancy affecting the esophagus, typically associated with risk factors like smoking, alcohol consumption, and reflux disease."

entities.name: "GASTRO-OESOPHAGEAL REFLUX DISEASE (GORD)"
entities.description: "Gastro-Oesophageal Reflux Disease is a chronic condition where stomach acid backs up into the esophagus, leading to symptoms like heartburn and regurgitation."

entities.name: "PEPTIC ULCER DISEASE"
entities.description: "Peptic Ulcer Disease involves ulceration in the stomach or duodenum lining, often caused by H. pylori infection or NSAID use, with symptoms like abdominal pain and bleeding."

entities.name: "GASTRIC CANCER"
entities.description: "Gastric Cancer is a malignancy originating in the stomach, with risk factors including H. pylori infection, diet, and genetics, presenting symptoms like weight loss and abdominal pain."

entities.name: "BOWEL PERFORATION"
entities.description: "Bowel Perforation refers to a rupture or hole in the gastrointestinal tract, which can lead to peritonitis, sepsis, and life-threatening complications."

entities.name: "SMALL BOWEL OBSTRUCTION"
entities.description: "Small Bowel Obstruction is a blockage in the small intestine, often due to adhesions, hernias, or tumors, causing abdominal pain, bloating, and vomiting."

entities.name: "INTESTINAL ISCHAEMIA"
entities.description: "Intestinal Ischaemia is the reduced blood flow to the intestines, leading to tissue damage and potentially severe conditions like ischemic colitis or mesenteric ischemia."

entities.name: "LOWER GI"
entities.description: "Lower GI refers to the Lower Gastrointestinal Tract, encompassing the colon, rectum, and anus, associated with conditions like colorectal cancer, diverticulitis, and inflammatory bowel disease."

entities.name: "APPENDICITIS"
entities.description: "Appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix, commonly presenting with right lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and elevated white blood cell count, requiring surgical intervention."

entities.name: "INFLAMMATORY BOWEL DISEASE"
entities.description: "Inflammatory Bowel Disease includes Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, chronic conditions causing inflammation of the gut lining and symptoms like diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fatigue."

entities.name: "LARGE BOWEL OBSTRUCTION"
entities.description: "Large Bowel Obstruction refers to blockages in the colon or rectum, often due to tumors, volvulus, or strictures, leading to symptoms of constipation, abdominal distension, and cramping."

entities.name: "COLORECTAL CANCER"
entities.description: "Colorectal Cancer is a malignancy affecting the colon or rectum, with risk factors including age, family history, and lifestyle habits, presenting symptoms like changes in bowel habits and rectal bleeding."

entities.name: "DIVERTICULITIS"
entities.description: "Diverticulitis is inflammation or infection of the diverticula in the colon, causing symptoms like abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits, often requiring antibiotics or surgery."

entities.name: "ANORECTAL DISEASE"
entities.description: "Anorectal Disease encompasses conditions affecting the anus and rectum, such as hemorrhoids, anal fissures, and fistulas, leading to symptoms like pain, bleeding, and itching."

entities.name: "HEPATOPANCREATOBILIARY"
entities.description: "Hepatopancreatobiliary disorders pertain to conditions affecting the liver, pancreas, and biliary system, including pancreatitis, gallstone disease, and biliary tract obstruction."

entities.name: "ACUTE PANCREATITIS"
entities.description: "Acute Pancreatitis is sudden inflammation of the pancreas, often triggered by gallstones or alcohol, presenting with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and elevated pancreatic enzymes."

entities.name: "GALLSTONE DISEASE"
entities.description: "Gallstone Disease involves the formation of gallstones in the gallbladder or bile ducts, leading to symptoms like right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and complications like cholecystitis."

entities.name: "ACUTE CHOLECYSTITIS"
entities.description: "Acute Cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, commonly due to gallstone obstruction, causing right upper quadrant pain, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers."

entities.name: "OBSTRUCTIVE JAUNDICE"
entities.description: "Obstructive Jaundice results from bile duct blockage, leading to yellowing of the skin and eyes, dark urine, and itching, often seen in conditions like pancreatic cancer or choledocholithiasis."

entities.name: "MALIGNANT BILIARY TRACT OBSTRUCTION"
entities.description: "Malignant Biliary Tract Obstruction is the blockage of the bile ducts due to cancerous growths, causing symptoms like jaundice, abdominal pain, and elevated liver enzymes."

entities.name: "GENITOURINARY"
entities.description: "Genitourinary conditions relate to the reproductive and urinary systems, including renal calculi, prostate cancer, and other disorders affecting the kidneys, bladder, and male/female reproductive organs."

entities.name: "RENAL TRACT CALCULI"
entities.description: "Renal Tract Calculi are kidney stones that can form in the renal pelvis or ureters, causing severe flank pain, hematuria, and obstruction of urinary flow."

entities.name: "PROSTATE CANCER"
entities.description: "Prostate Cancer is a malignancy of the prostate gland, common in older men, presenting with symptoms like urinary difficulties, blood in the urine, and bone pain in advanced stages."

entities.name: "VASCULAR"
entities.description: "Vascular conditions involve diseases of the blood vessels, such as aortic aneurysm, peripheral arterial disease, and other disorders affecting circulation and vascular health."

entities.name: "AORTIC ANEURYSM"
entities.description: "Aortic Aneurysm is the abnormal bulging or dilation of the aorta, posing a risk of rupture and life-threatening complications if left untreated."

entities.name: "PERIPHERAL ARTERIAL DISEASE"
entities.description: "Peripheral Arterial Disease is a circulatory condition resulting in narrowed arteries, typically affecting the lower limbs and presenting with symptoms like leg pain, poor wound healing, and leg ulcers."

entities.name: "BREASTBREAST CANCER"
entities.description: "Breast Cancer is a malignancy originating in the breast tissue, with risk factors including gender, age, genetics, and hormonal factors, presenting symptoms like breast lumps, changes in skin texture, and nipple discharge."

entities.name: "ABDOMINAL PAIN"
entities.description: "Abdominal Pain is discomfort or cramping in the abdomen, with various causes ranging from gastrointestinal disorders to organ inflammation or infection."

entities.name: "NAUSEA AND VOMITING"
entities.description: "Nausea and Vomiting are common symptoms involving the sensation of queasiness or discomfort in the stomach followed by involuntary expulsion of stomach contents."

entities.name: "JAUNDICE"
entities.description: "Jaundice is the yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels, often seen in liver or gallbladder disorders causing bile duct blockages."

entities.name: "PR BLEEDING"
entities.description: "PR Bleeding refers to bleeding from the rectum or anus, often linked to conditions like hemorrhoids, inflammatory bowel disease, or colorectal cancer."

entities.name: "LIMB ISCHAEMIA"
entities.description: "Limb Ischaemia results from reduced blood flow to the extremities, leading to tissue damage, pain, and potentially limb-threatening conditions like gangrene."

entities.name: "MUSCULOSKELETAL RADIOLOGY"
entities.description: "Musculoskeletal Radiology focuses on imaging studies of the bones, joints, muscles, and soft tissues, aiding in the diagnosis of fractures, arthritis, and other orthopedic conditions."

entities.name: "TESTS AND WHEN TO USE THEM"
entities.description: "Tests and When to Use Them refer to diagnostic procedures like X-rays, MRIs, and ultrasounds, employed based on clinical indications and suspected medical conditions for accurate diagnosis and management."

entities.name: "UPPER LIMB"
entities.description: "Upper Limb pertains to the anatomical region encompassing the arms, shoulders, and hands, often affected by fractures, dislocations, and soft tissue injuries."

entities.name: "CLAVICLE SERIES"
entities.description: "Clavicle Series involves a set of X-ray views of the clavicle bone, used to evaluate fractures, dislocations, or other clavicle-related injuries."

entities.name: "SHOULDER SERIES"
entities.description: "Shoulder Series comprises radiographic views of the shoulder joint, essential for diagnosing shoulder injuries, rotator cuff tears, or bony abnormalities."

entities.name: "HUMERUS SERIES"
entities.description: "Humerus Series consists of X-ray images of the humerus bone to assess fractures, dislocations, or other traumatic injuries to the upper arm."

entities.name: "ELBOW SERIES"
entities.description: "Elbow Series includes radiographs focused on the elbow joint, used to identify fractures, arthritis, or soft tissue injuries affecting the elbow region."

entities.name: "FOREARM SERIES"
entities.description: "Forearm Series comprises X-ray studies of the forearm bones, useful for evaluating fractures, dislocations, or other traumatic conditions involving the radius and ulna."

entities.name: "WRIST SERIES"
entities.description: "Wrist Series involves radiological imaging of the wrist bones and joints to diagnose fractures, carpal injuries, or degenerative conditions affecting wrist function."

entities.name: "SCAPHOID SERIES"
entities.description: "Scaphoid Series includes specialized X-ray views of the scaphoid bone in the wrist, crucial for detecting scaphoid fractures, which can be challenging to diagnose."

entities.name: "HAND SERIES"
entities.description: "Hand Series encompasses radiographs of the hand and fingers, aiding in the assessment of fractures, dislocations, arthritis, or soft tissue injuries affecting the hand."

entities.name: "BOTH HANDS SERIES"
entities.description: "Both Hands Series involves X-ray examinations of both hands simultaneously, useful for comparative analysis of bilateral hand injuries, bone abnormalities, or joint conditions."

entities.name: "THUMB SERIES"
entities.description: "Thumb Series comprises X-ray images focused on the thumb, essential for diagnosing thumb fractures, ligament injuries, or degenerative changes affecting thumb function."
