key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""PNEUMOPERITONEUM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pneumoperitoneum is the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity, often indicating a perforation in the gastrointestinal tract and potentially leading to severe abdominal pain."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""BOWEL DILATATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bowel Dilatation refers to the abnormal enlargement or distension of the intestines, which can be caused by various conditions like obstructions or inflammatory processes."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""FAT-STRANDING"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Fat-Stranding is a radiological sign characterized by increased density around the fat tissues, commonly observed in inflammatory or traumatic conditions."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""FREE INTRAPERITONEAL FLUID"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Free Intraperitoneal Fluid is the accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity that can be a sign of internal organ injury or inflammatory processes."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""UPPER GI"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Upper GI refers to the Upper Gastrointestinal Tract, including the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum, often implicated in conditions like reflux, ulcers, and cancer."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""OESOPHAGEAL CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Oesophageal Cancer is a malignancy affecting the esophagus, typically associated with risk factors like smoking, alcohol consumption, and reflux disease."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""GASTRO-OESOPHAGEAL REFLUX DISEASE (GORD)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Gastro-Oesophageal Reflux Disease is a chronic condition where stomach acid backs up into the esophagus, leading to symptoms like heartburn and regurgitation."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""PEPTIC ULCER DISEASE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Peptic Ulcer Disease involves ulceration in the stomach or duodenum lining, often caused by H. pylori infection or NSAID use, with symptoms like abdominal pain and bleeding."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""GASTRIC CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Gastric Cancer is a malignancy originating in the stomach, with risk factors including H. pylori infection, diet, and genetics, presenting symptoms like weight loss and abdominal pain."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""BOWEL PERFORATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bowel Perforation refers to a rupture or hole in the gastrointestinal tract, which can lead to peritonitis, sepsis, and life-threatening complications."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""SMALL BOWEL OBSTRUCTION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Small Bowel Obstruction is a blockage in the small intestine, often due to adhesions, hernias, or tumors, causing abdominal pain, bloating, and vomiting."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""INTESTINAL ISCHAEMIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Intestinal Ischaemia is the reduced blood flow to the intestines, leading to tissue damage and potentially severe conditions like ischemic colitis or mesenteric ischemia."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""LOWER GI"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lower GI refers to the Lower Gastrointestinal Tract, encompassing the colon, rectum, and anus, associated with conditions like colorectal cancer, diverticulitis, and inflammatory bowel disease."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""APPENDICITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix, commonly presenting with right lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and elevated white blood cell count, requiring surgical intervention."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""INFLAMMATORY BOWEL DISEASE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Inflammatory Bowel Disease includes Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, chronic conditions causing inflammation of the gut lining and symptoms like diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fatigue."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""LARGE BOWEL OBSTRUCTION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Large Bowel Obstruction refers to blockages in the colon or rectum, often due to tumors, volvulus, or strictures, leading to symptoms of constipation, abdominal distension, and cramping."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""COLORECTAL CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Colorectal Cancer is a malignancy affecting the colon or rectum, with risk factors including age, family history, and lifestyle habits, presenting symptoms like changes in bowel habits and rectal bleeding."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""DIVERTICULITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Diverticulitis is inflammation or infection of the diverticula in the colon, causing symptoms like abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits, often requiring antibiotics or surgery."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""ANORECTAL DISEASE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Anorectal Disease encompasses conditions affecting the anus and rectum, such as hemorrhoids, anal fissures, and fistulas, leading to symptoms like pain, bleeding, and itching."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""HEPATOPANCREATOBILIARY"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Hepatopancreatobiliary disorders pertain to conditions affecting the liver, pancreas, and biliary system, including pancreatitis, gallstone disease, and biliary tract obstruction."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""ACUTE PANCREATITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Acute Pancreatitis is sudden inflammation of the pancreas, often triggered by gallstones or alcohol, presenting with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and elevated pancreatic enzymes."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""GALLSTONE DISEASE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Gallstone Disease involves the formation of gallstones in the gallbladder or bile ducts, leading to symptoms like right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and complications like cholecystitis."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""ACUTE CHOLECYSTITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Acute Cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, commonly due to gallstone obstruction, causing right upper quadrant pain, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""OBSTRUCTIVE JAUNDICE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Obstructive Jaundice results from bile duct blockage, leading to yellowing of the skin and eyes, dark urine, and itching, often seen in conditions like pancreatic cancer or choledocholithiasis."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""MALIGNANT BILIARY TRACT OBSTRUCTION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Malignant Biliary Tract Obstruction is the blockage of the bile ducts due to cancerous growths, causing symptoms like jaundice, abdominal pain, and elevated liver enzymes."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""GENITOURINARY"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Genitourinary conditions relate to the reproductive and urinary systems, including renal calculi, prostate cancer, and other disorders affecting the kidneys, bladder, and male/female reproductive organs."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""RENAL TRACT CALCULI"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Renal Tract Calculi are kidney stones that can form in the renal pelvis or ureters, causing severe flank pain, hematuria, and obstruction of urinary flow."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""PROSTATE CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Prostate Cancer is a malignancy of the prostate gland, common in older men, presenting with symptoms like urinary difficulties, blood in the urine, and bone pain in advanced stages."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""VASCULAR"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Vascular conditions involve diseases of the blood vessels, such as aortic aneurysm, peripheral arterial disease, and other disorders affecting circulation and vascular health."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""AORTIC ANEURYSM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Aortic Aneurysm is the abnormal bulging or dilation of the aorta, posing a risk of rupture and life-threatening complications if left untreated."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""PERIPHERAL ARTERIAL DISEASE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Peripheral Arterial Disease is a circulatory condition resulting in narrowed arteries, typically affecting the lower limbs and presenting with symptoms like leg pain, poor wound healing, and leg ulcers."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""BREASTBREAST CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Breast Cancer is a malignancy originating in the breast tissue, with risk factors including gender, age, genetics, and hormonal factors, presenting symptoms like breast lumps, changes in skin texture, and nipple discharge."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""ABDOMINAL PAIN"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Abdominal Pain is discomfort or cramping in the abdomen, with various causes ranging from gastrointestinal disorders to organ inflammation or infection."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""NAUSEA AND VOMITING"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Nausea and Vomiting are common symptoms involving the sensation of queasiness or discomfort in the stomach followed by involuntary expulsion of stomach contents."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""JAUNDICE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Jaundice is the yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels, often seen in liver or gallbladder disorders causing bile duct blockages."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""PR BLEEDING"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"PR Bleeding refers to bleeding from the rectum or anus, often linked to conditions like hemorrhoids, inflammatory bowel disease, or colorectal cancer."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""LIMB ISCHAEMIA"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Limb Ischaemia results from reduced blood flow to the extremities, leading to tissue damage, pain, and potentially limb-threatening conditions like gangrene."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""MUSCULOSKELETAL RADIOLOGY"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Musculoskeletal Radiology focuses on imaging studies of the bones, joints, muscles, and soft tissues, aiding in the diagnosis of fractures, arthritis, and other orthopedic conditions."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""TESTS AND WHEN TO USE THEM"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tests and When to Use Them refer to diagnostic procedures like X-rays, MRIs, and ultrasounds, employed based on clinical indications and suspected medical conditions for accurate diagnosis and management."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""UPPER LIMB"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Upper Limb pertains to the anatomical region encompassing the arms, shoulders, and hands, often affected by fractures, dislocations, and soft tissue injuries."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""CLAVICLE SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Clavicle Series involves a set of X-ray views of the clavicle bone, used to evaluate fractures, dislocations, or other clavicle-related injuries."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""SHOULDER SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Shoulder Series comprises radiographic views of the shoulder joint, essential for diagnosing shoulder injuries, rotator cuff tears, or bony abnormalities."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""HUMERUS SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Humerus Series consists of X-ray images of the humerus bone to assess fractures, dislocations, or other traumatic injuries to the upper arm."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""ELBOW SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Elbow Series includes radiographs focused on the elbow joint, used to identify fractures, arthritis, or soft tissue injuries affecting the elbow region."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""FOREARM SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Forearm Series comprises X-ray studies of the forearm bones, useful for evaluating fractures, dislocations, or other traumatic conditions involving the radius and ulna."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""WRIST SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Wrist Series involves radiological imaging of the wrist bones and joints to diagnose fractures, carpal injuries, or degenerative conditions affecting wrist function."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""SCAPHOID SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Scaphoid Series includes specialized X-ray views of the scaphoid bone in the wrist, crucial for detecting scaphoid fractures, which can be challenging to diagnose."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""HAND SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Hand Series encompasses radiographs of the hand and fingers, aiding in the assessment of fractures, dislocations, arthritis, or soft tissue injuries affecting the hand."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""BOTH HANDS SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Both Hands Series involves X-ray examinations of both hands simultaneously, useful for comparative analysis of bilateral hand injuries, bone abnormalities, or joint conditions."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>    <node id=""THUMB SERIES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Thumb Series comprises X-ray images focused on the thumb, essential for diagnosing thumb fractures, ligament injuries, or degenerative changes affecting thumb function."</data>      <data key="d2">798c604ef5b28400a94581913f9c1859</data>    </node>  </graph></graphml>

entities.name: "LEFT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Left lower lobe collapse is a medical condition where a portion of the patient's lung collapses, leading to symptoms such as shortness of breath and chest pain."

entities.name: "RIGHT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right upper lobe collapse is a medical condition where a portion of the patient's lung collapses, resulting in symptoms like coughing, fever, and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "SHORTNESS OF BREATH"
entities.description: "Shortness of breath is a symptom experienced by patients with lung collapse, indicating difficulty in breathing."

entities.name: "CHEST PAIN"
entities.description: "Chest pain is a symptom associated with lung collapse, causing discomfort in the chest area."

entities.name: "COUGHING"
entities.description: "Coughing is a symptom associated with lung collapse, often accompanied by sputum production."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY DISTRESS"
entities.description: "Respiratory distress is a symptom experienced by patients with lung collapse, manifesting as difficulty in breathing and inadequate oxygenation of tissues."

entities.name: "INFLAMMATORY RESPONSE"
entities.description: "An inflammatory response is a reaction seen in patients with lung collapse, characterized by symptoms like fever, redness, and swelling in the affected area."

rounded atelectasis
round atelectasis, also known as rounded atelectasis, folded lung or blesovsky syndrome, is an unusual type of lung atelectasis where there is infolding of a redundant pleura. the way the lung collapses can at times give a false mass-like appearance.
on this page:
article:
epidemiology
pathology
radiographic features
diagnosis
history and etymology
see also
related articles
references
images:cases and figures
epidemiologyassociationsround atelectasis may be associated with:
asbestos lung exposure 3: most commonly
therapeutic pneumothorax in the treatment of tuberculosis 1
congestive heart failure 2
pulmonary infarction 2
parapneumonic effusion
pathologytwo theories have been put forward. the second theory is more favoured while the multifactorial aetiology suggests both mechanisms probably operate in different patients:
hanke and kretzschmar
underlying pleural effusion causes local atelectasis in the adjacent lung
a cleft or infolding of the visceral pleura will then form if the rate of pleural fluid formation exceeds alveolar air absorption
this then causes the lung to tilt on the cleft
the lung then curls on itself in a concentric fashion
fibrous adhesions suspending the atelectatic segment (and usually tilt the lung cranially) develop
as the effusion resorbs, the aerated lung fills in the space between the area of round atelectasis
organisation of the fibrinous exudate and fibrous contraction lead to additional lung parenchymal distortion
schneider et al. (expanded on by dernevik and colleagues)
a local pleuritis caused by irritants such as asbestos
in the event of a benign asbestos-related pleural effusion, the pleura contracts and thickens with shrinkage of the underlying lung, and atelectasis develops in a round configuration
aetiology
exposure to mineral dust: asbestosis, pneumoconiosis 13
exudative pleuritis: tuberculosis, haemothorax 13
less commonly seen in histoplasmosis, legionella, end-stage renal disease 13
sarcoidosis 13
locationthere may be a predilection towards the lower lobes 4.radiographic featuresct
round or oval in shape
almost always seen adjacent to a pleural surface
there is associated adjacent pleural abnormality, e.g. pleural thickening or pleural effusion
comet tail sign 2: produced by the pulling of bronchovascular bundles giving the shape of a comet tail
crow feet sign
as it represents collapsed lung, it commonly demonstrates a typical parenchymal enhancement
posterior lower lobes are most commonly involved and, sometimes, bilateral or symmetrical 14
rounded atelectasis can occasionally increase in size on serial scans 6,7.nuclear medicinefdg-pet
not metabolically active
may play a role in differentiating from malignancy when there are few or atypical features on chest radiographs and ct 9
diagnosisall five of the following findings must be present to diagnose round atelectasis:1) adjacent pleura must be abnormal.2) opacity must be peripheral and in contact with the pleura.3) opacity must be round or elliptical.4) volume loss must be present in the affected lobe.5) pulmonary vessels and bronchi leading into the opacity must be curved -- this is the comet tail sign15.history and etymologyit was first described by loeschke in 1928 6.see also
pulmonary pseudotumour
pulmonary inflammatory pseudotumour

entities.name: "ROUND ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Round Atelectasis, also known as Rounded Atelectasis, Folded Lung, or Blesovsky Syndrome, is an unusual type of lung atelectasis where there is infolding of a redundant pleura. It may be associated with asbestos lung exposure, therapeutic pneumothorax, congestive heart failure, pulmonary infarction, or parapneumonic effusion. The pathology involves two theories with underlying pleural effusion and pleuritis being key factors."

entities.name: "HANKE AND KRETZSCHMAR"
entities.description: "Hanke and Kretzschmar proposed a theory for the pathology of round atelectasis where underlying pleural effusion causes local atelectasis in the adjacent lung, leading to a cleft or infolding of the visceral pleura and subsequent lung collapse."

entities.name: "SCHNEIDER ET AL."
entities.description: "Schneider et al. proposed another theory involving a local pleuritis caused by irritants such as asbestos, leading to contraction and thickening of the pleura, and consequent development of atelectasis in a round configuration."

entities.name: "THERAPEUTIC PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Therapeutic pneumothorax is a procedure where air or gas is introduced into the pleural space to collapse a lung, which may lead to the development of round atelectasis as a complication."

entities.name: "CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE"
entities.description: "Congestive heart failure can result in pulmonary congestion and the accumulation of fluid in the lungs, which can contribute to the development of round atelectasis."

entities.name: "PULMONARY INFARCTION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary infarction, also known as lung infarction, can lead to localized lung tissue death and collapse, potentially contributing to the development of round atelectasis."

entities.name: "PARAPNEUMONIC EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Parapneumonic effusion is a type of pleural effusion that occurs as a complication of pneumonia, which can lead to the development of round atelectasis."

atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d2">fae622347ce1b4c90c0c114e21391e1a</data>    </node>    <node id=""DIFFUSE PLEURAL THICKENING"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Diffuse pleural thickening is a common manifestation of asbestos-related pleural disease, often associated with round atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d2">fae622347ce1b4c90c0c114e21391e1a</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL PLAQUES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural plaques are localized areas of thickening in the pleura that can develop as a result of asbestos exposure, sometimes leading to round atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d2">fae622347ce1b4c90c0c114e21391e1a</data>    </node>    <node id=""ASBESTOS FIBERS"">      <data key="d0">"SUBSTANCE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Asbestos fibers are mineral fibers that, when inhaled, can lead to various respiratory conditions including round atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d2">fae622347ce1b4c90c0c114e21391e1a</data>    </node>    <edge source=""ROUND ATELECTASIS"" target=""ASBESTOS-RELATED PLEURAL DISEASE"">      <data <edge source=""ASBESTOS-RELATED PLEURAL DISEASE"" target=""PLEURAL THICKENING"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Pleural thickening is a symptom observed in asbestos-related entities.name: "PULMONARY WINDOW"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Window is a medical condition affecting the lungs, potentially leading to respiratory issues."

entities.name: "AZYGO-OESOPHAGEAL RECESS"
entities.description: "Azygo-Oesophageal Recess is a condition characterized by a deviation in the recess between the azygous vein and the esophagus."

entities.name: "SPACES"
entities.description: "Spaces in the lungs, such as the retrosternal airspace and retrotracheal airspace, play a crucial role in the diagnosis and treatment of pulmonary diseases."

entities.name: "AIR BRONCHOGRAM"
entities.description: "Air Bronchogram is a radiological sign indicating air-filled bronchi surrounded by collapsed lung tissue, commonly seen in certain pulmonary conditions."

entities.name: "THE DEVICE"
entities.description: "The Device is central to the story, with potential game-changing implications, and is revered by Taylor."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs, which can lead to respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a collapsed lung condition that occurs when air leaks into the space between the lungs and chest wall, causing lung collapse and potential breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Bronchitis is an inflammation of the bronchial tubes in the lungs, often resulting in coughing, difficulty breathing, and chest discomfort."

entities.name: "CHEST X-RAY"
entities.description: "Chest X-ray is a diagnostic imaging technique used to visualize the structures inside the chest, including the heart, lungs, and bones, to aid in the diagnosis of various respiratory conditions."

entities.name: "MINIMALLY INVASIVE TUMOURS"
entities.description: "Minimally Invasive Tumours are a type of disease in the lung, characterized by certain invasive patterns and growth characteristics."

entities.name: "ADENOCARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Adenocarcinoma is a common type of lung cancer, with various subtypes such as lepidic predominant, acinar predominant, papillary predominant, micropapillary predominant, and others."

entities.name: "ADENOSQUAMOUS CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Adenosquamous Carcinoma is a type of lung cancer with features of both adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a disease involving abnormal cell growth in the lungs, with various subtypes and staging criteria."

entities.name: "SMALL-CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Small-Cell Lung Cancer is a type of aggressive lung cancer arising from neuroendocrine cells."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL CARCINOID TUMOURS"
entities.description: "Bronchial Carcinoid Tumours are a type of lung cancer arising from neuroendocrine cells in the bronchi."

entities.name: "PULMONARY BLASTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Blastoma is a rare malignant tumor that can arise in the lung."

entities.name: "CANCER"
entities.description: "Cancer is a broad term for diseases characterized by uncontrolled cell growth and the potential to invade or spread to other parts of the body."

entities.name: "MUCINOUS ADENOCARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Mucinous Adenocarcinoma is a subtype of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of mucin-producing cells."

entities.name: "CALCIFYING FIBROUS PSEUDOTUMOUR"
entities.description: "Calcifying Fibrous Pseudotumour is a benign lesion of the lung characterized by calcification and fibrous tissue proliferation."

entities.name: "LUNG METASTASES"
entities.description: "Lung Metastases refer to cancers that have spread to the lungs from other primary sites in the body."

entities.name: "PULMONARY CHONDROMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Chondroma is a benign tumor composed of cartilage tissue in the lung."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HAMARTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hamartoma is a benign tumor composed of normal lung tissue in an abnormal arrangement."

entities.name: "PLEURAL INVASION"
entities.description: "Pleural Invasion is a symptom indicating the spread of cancer cells from the lungs to the pleura, the lining of the chest cavity."

entities.name: "VASCULAR INVASION"
entities.description: "Vascular Invasion is a symptom indicating the spread of cancer cells from the lungs to blood vessels."

entities.name: "PANCOAST TUMOUR"
entities.description: "Pancoast Tumour is a type of lung cancer located at the top of the lung, often involving the brachial plexus and causing symptoms in the shoulder and arm."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER SCREENING"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer Screening refers to the process of detecting lung cancer in its early stages through various imaging and testing methods."

entities.name: "LARGE CELL CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Large Cell Carcinoma is a type of non-small cell lung cancer that does not fit into the categories of squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, or small-cell lung cancer."

entities.name: "MESOTHELIOMA"
entities.description: "Mesothelioma is a type of cancer that affects the mesothelial cells lining the chest and abdomen, often associated with asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a symptom of excess fluid accumulation in the pleural space around the lungs, commonly seen in lung cancer patients."

entities.name: "LUNG NODULE"
entities.description: "Lung Nodule is a small abnormal mass or lesion in the lung, which can be benign or malignant."

entities.name: "BRONCHIOLOALVEOLAR CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Bronchioloalveolar Carcinoma is a subtype of lung adenocarcinoma that arises from the alveolar sacs in the lungs."

entities.name: "CARCINOID TUMOUR"
entities.description: "Carcinoid Tumour is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in the lungs and other organs."

entities.name: "PLEURAL MESOTHELIOMA"
entities.description: "Pleural Mesothelioma is a type of mesothelioma that specifically affects the lining of the lungs."

entities.name: "MEDIASTINAL TUMOUR"
entities.description: "Mediastinal Tumour is a type of tumor that develops in the mediastinum, the area in the middle of the chest containing the heart, esophagus, and other structures."

entities.name: "LUNG ABSCESS"
entities.description: "Lung Abscess is a condition characterized by the formation of a pus-filled cavity within the lung tissue, often caused by bacterial infections."

entities.name: "PLEURAL THICKENING"
entities.description: "Pleural Thickening is a symptom of the pleura becoming thickened, which can occur due to various lung diseases including cancer."

entities.name: "GROUND-GLASS OPACITY"
entities.description: "Ground-Glass Opacity is a radiological finding in lung imaging that appears as hazy increased opacity without obscuring the underlying vessels."

entities.name: "LUNG BIOPSY"
entities.description: "Lung Biopsy is a procedure to remove a small piece of lung tissue for examination under a microscope to diagnose lung conditions, including cancer."

entities.name: "SPUTUM CYTOLOGY"
entities.description: "Sputum Cytology is a diagnostic test that examines mucus coughed up from the lungs to detect cancer cells or other abnormalities."

key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG METASTASES"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Metastases refer to cancers that have spread to the lungs from other primary sites in the body."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY CHONDROMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Chondroma is a benign tumor composed of cartilage tissue in the lung."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY HAMARTOMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Hamartoma is a benign tumor composed of normal lung tissue in an abnormal arrangement."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL INVASION"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Invasion is a symptom indicating the spread of cancer cells from the lungs to the pleura, the lining of the chest cavity."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""VASCULAR INVASION"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Vascular Invasion is a symptom indicating the spread of cancer cells from the lungs to blood vessels."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""PANCOAST TUMOUR"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pancoast Tumour is a type of lung cancer located at the top of the lung, often involving the brachial plexus and causing symptoms in the shoulder and arm."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG CANCER SCREENING"">      <data key="d0">"ACTION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Cancer Screening refers to the process of detecting lung cancer in its early stages through various imaging and testing methods."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""LARGE CELL CARCINOMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Large Cell Carcinoma is a type of non-small cell lung cancer that does not fit into the categories of squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, or small-cell lung cancer."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""MESOTHELIOMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Mesothelioma is a type of cancer that affects the mesothelial cells lining the chest and abdomen, often associated with asbestos exposure."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL EFFUSION"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Effusion is a symptom of excess fluid accumulation in the pleural space around the lungs, commonly seen in lung cancer patients."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG NODULE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Nodule is a small abnormal mass or lesion in the lung, which can be benign or malignant."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIOLOALVEOLAR CARCINOMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchioloalveolar Carcinoma is a subtype of lung adenocarcinoma that arises from the alveolar sacs in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""CARCINOID TUMOUR"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Carcinoid Tumour is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in the lungs and other organs."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL MESOTHELIOMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Mesothelioma is a type of mesothelioma that specifically affects the lining of the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""MEDIASTINAL TUMOUR"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Mediastinal Tumour is a type of tumor that develops in the mediastinum, the area in the middle of the chest containing the heart, esophagus, and other structures."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG ABSCESS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Abscess is a condition characterized by the formation of a pus-filled cavity within the lung tissue, often caused by bacterial infections."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL THICKENING"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Thickening is a symptom of the pleura becoming thickened, which can occur due to various lung diseases including cancer."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""GROUND-GLASS OPACITY"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ground-Glass Opacity is a radiological finding in lung imaging that appears as hazy increased opacity without obscuring the underlying vessels."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG BIOPSY"">      <data key="d0">"ACTION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Biopsy is a procedure to remove a small piece of lung tissue for examination under a microscope to diagnose lung conditions, including cancer."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <node id=""SPUTUM CYTOLOGY"">      <data key="d0">"ACTION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Sputum Cytology is a diagnostic test that examines mucus coughed up from the lungs to detect cancer cells or other abnormalities."</data>      <data key="d2">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </node>    <edge source=""LUNG CANCER"" target=""PANCOAST TUMOUR"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Pancoast Tumour is a source=""SMALL-CELL LUNG CANCER"" target=""LUNG METASTASES"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Small-Cell Lung Cancer is known for its aggressive nature and high propensity for metastases, including to the lungs."</data>      <data key="d5">38c75aed6147f8e51e03bf0fd9f5af66</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""MUCINOUS ADENOCARCINOMA"" target=""CALCIFYING FIBROUS PSEUDOTUMOUR"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Both Calcifying Fibrous Pseudotumour and Mucinous Adenocarcinoma are distinct types of lung lesions with specific histological chunk:
crackles are the clicking, rattling, or crackling noises that may be made by one or both lungs of a human with a respiratory disease during inhalation, and occasionally during exhalation. they are usually heard only with a stethoscope ("on auscultation"). pulmonary crackles are abnormal breath sounds that were formerly referred to as rales.
bilateral crackles refers to the presence of crackles in both lungs. basal crackles are crackles apparently originating in or near the base of the lung. bibasal crackles, also called bilateral basal crackles, are crackles heard at the bases of both the left and right lungs.
crackles are caused by the "popping open" of small airways and alveoli collapsed by fluid, exudate, or lack of aeration during expiration.
crackles can be heard in patients with pneumonia, atelectasis, pulmonary fibrosis, acute bronchitis, bronchiectasis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ards), interstitial lung disease or post thoracotomy or metastasis ablation. pulmonary edema secondary to left-sided congestive heart failure can also cause crackles.
== terminology ==
rene laennec adopted the existing word rales (which has been translated as "rattles", 'groans" and otherwise) to describe the added breath sounds that are now referred to as "crackles". he described them using unusual daily examples, such as "whistling of little birds", "crackling of salt on a heated dish", "cooing of the woodpidgeon", etc., but he soon realized that he was unable to use the term in front of his patients because it conjured the association of le rale de la mort, which translates to "the death rattle", the noise that people who are about to die make when they can no longer clear secretions. therefore, at the bedside, he used the latin word rhonchus, which originally meant a 'snore'. that was not clearly understood by his translator, john forbes, and the terminology became very confusing after the publication in the 1830s of forbes's english translation of laennec's de l'auscultation mediate. the difficulty of translating rale itself had been remarked upon in a british review of laennec's work in 1820.
the terminology of rales and rhonchi in english remained variable until 1977, when a standardization was established by the american thoracic society and american college of chest physicians. as a result, the term rales was abandoned, and crackles became its recommended substitute. the term rales is still common in english-language medical literature, but cognizance of the ats/chest guidelines calls for crackles.
== sound ==
crackles are caused by explosive opening of small airways and are discontinuous, nonmusical, and brief. crackles are more common during the inspiratory than the expiratory phase of breathing, but they may be heard during the expiratory phase.
crackles are often described as fine, medium, and coarse. they can also be characterized as to their timing: fine crackles are usually late-inspiratory, whereas coarse crackles are early inspiratory.
fine crackles are soft, high-pitched, and very brief. this sound can be simulated by rolling a strand of hair between one's fingers near the ears or by moistening one's thumb and index finger and separating them near the ears. their presence usually indicates an interstitial process, such as pulmonary fibrosis or congestive heart failure. the sounds from interstitial pulmonary fibrosis have been described as sounding like opening a velcro fastener.
coarse crackles are somewhat louder, lower in pitch, and last longer than fine crackles. their presence usually indicates an airway disease, such as bronchiectasis.
they can also be described as unilateral or bilateral, as well as dry or moist/wet.
== associated diagnoses ==
crackles are often associated with inflammation or infection of the small bronchi, bronchioles, and alveoli.
crackles that do not clear after a cough may indicate pulmonary edema or fluid in the alveoli due to heart failure, pulmonary fibrosis, or acute resp

entities.name: "CRACKLES"
entities.description: "Crackles are abnormal breath sounds heard in the lungs of individuals with respiratory diseases, caused by the opening of small airways and alveoli collapsed by fluid or lack of aeration."

entities.name: "PULMONARY CRACKLES"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Crackles are abnormal breath sounds heard in the lungs during inhalation or exhalation, previously referred to as rales."

entities.name: "BILATERAL CRACKLES"
entities.description: "Bilateral Crackles are crackles present in both lungs of an individual."

entities.name: "BASAL CRACKLES"
entities.description: "Basal Crackles are crackles originating near the base of the lung."

entities.name: "BIBASAL CRACKLES"
entities.description: "Bibasal Crackles are crackles heard at the bases of both the left and right lungs."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is a lung infection that can cause crackles to be heard in patients."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is the collapse of a part or all of a lung, which can cause crackles."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease characterized by scarring of lung tissue, which can be associated with crackles."

entities.name: "ACUTE BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Acute Bronchitis is an inflammation of the bronchial tubes, which can lead to the presence of crackles."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a condition where the bronchial tubes are widened, leading to possible crackles in the lungs."

entities.name: "ARDS"
entities.description: "ARDS stands for Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome, which can be associated with crackles in the lungs."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Interstitial Lung Disease is a group of lung disorders that can cause crackles to be heard."

entities.name: "POST THORACOTOMY OR METASTASIS ABLATION"
entities.description: "Post Thoracotomy or Metastasis Ablation procedures can lead to crackles in the lungs as secondary effects."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is fluid accumulation in the lungs, often caused by heart failure and can lead to crackles being heard."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that can present with crackles in the lungs."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, which can cause crackles to be heard."

entities.name: "ASTHMA"
entities.description: "Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, sometimes leading to crackles in the lungs."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Interstitial Pneumonia is inflammation of the interstitium of the lung tissue, which can present with crackles on auscultation."

entities.name: "HEART FAILURE"
entities.description: "Heart Failure is a condition where the heart is unable to pump blood effectively, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs and crackles on auscultation."

key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchiectasis is a condition where the bronchial tubes are widened, leading to possible crackles in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""ARDS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"ARDS stands for Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome, which can be associated with crackles in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Interstitial Lung Disease is a group of lung disorders that can cause crackles to be heard."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""POST THORACOTOMY OR METASTASIS ABLATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Post Thoracotomy or Metastasis Ablation procedures can lead to crackles in the lungs as secondary effects."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Edema is fluid accumulation in the lungs, often caused by heart failure and can lead to crackles being heard."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that can present with crackles in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EMBOLISM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, which can cause crackles to be heard."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""ASTHMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, sometimes leading to crackles in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Interstitial Pneumonia is inflammation of the interstitium of the lung tissue, which can present with crackles on auscultation."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>    <node id=""HEART FAILURE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Heart Failure is a condition where the heart is unable to pump blood effectively, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs and crackles on auscultation."</data>      <data key="d2">fb5cec6cc929f57189052530de2ccf54</data>    </node>  </graph></graphml>

entities.name: "ANECTASIS"
entities.description: "Anectasis refers to primary atelectasis, the failure of the lung to fully expand at birth."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is related to Anectasis, representing the collapse of lung tissue."

entities.name: "LUNG"
entities.description: "The Lung is involved in Anectasis, where it fails to fully expand at birth."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY SYSTEM"
entities.description: "Anectasis involves the respiratory system, specifically the lungs."

entities.name: "NEONATES"
entities.description: "Anectasis is commonly seen in neonates, affecting their lung expansion at birth."

entities.name: "THORACIC CAVITY"
entities.description: "The thoracic cavity plays a role in Anectasis, as it encompasses the lungs."

entities.name: "PULMONARY SURFACTANT"
entities.description: "Deficiency in pulmonary surfactant can contribute to Anectasis, affecting lung expansion."

synonyms:
crows feet bands
crow foot sign
crow's feet sign
crow feet sign is a characteristic, but uncommon, feature seen in round atelectasis.on ct, this is seen as linear bands radiating from a mass into adjacent lung tissue resembling the feet of a crow. this sign should not be confused with fibrotic changes occurring in the lung.
references
1.lynch j, shelmerdine s, mahadevan v. mcqs in clinical radiology. jp medical publishers. isbn:1907816348. read it at google books - find it at amazon
2.andrey yudin. rounded atelectasis, comet-tail sign, and crow's foot sign. 45-45. doi:10.1007/978-3-319-04013-4_23
3.gevenois pa, de maertelaer v, madani a et-al. asbestosis, pleural plaques and diffuse pleural thickening: three distinct benign responses to asbestos exposure. eur. respir. j. 1998;11 (5): 1021-7. eur. respir. j. (abstract) - pubmed citation

entities.name: "CROW FEET SIGN"
entities.description: "Crow Feet Sign, also known as round atelectasis, is a characteristic feature seen on CT scans as linear bands radiating from a mass into adjacent lung tissue resembling the feet of a crow."

entities.name: "ROUND ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Round Atelectasis is a condition where the lung collapses in a rounded shape, often associated with the Crow Feet Sign."

entities.name: "CT SCAN"
entities.description: "CT Scan is a diagnostic imaging technique used to visualize internal structures of the body, such as in the case of round atelectasis."

entities.name: "RADIOLOGY REFERENCE ARTICLE"
entities.description: "Radiology Reference Articles provide information and insights on various radiological findings, including the Crow Feet Sign and round atelectasis."

entities.name: "CRAIG HACKING"
entities.description: "Craig Hacking is a contributor who last revised the article on the Crow Feet Sign, indicating his involvement in updating medical information."

entities.name: "DIAGNOSIS"
entities.description: "Diagnosis is the process of identifying a disease or condition, often aided by radiological findings like the Crow Feet Sign and round atelectasis."

entities.name: "TREATMENT"
entities.description: "Treatment of round atelectasis may involve interventions based on CT scan results and radiological findings like the Crow Feet Sign."

entities.name: "PLEURAL PLAQUE"
entities.description: "Pleural Plaques are discrete fibrous or partially calcified thickened areas of the pleura, potentially visible on CT scans in relation to round atelectasis."

entities.name: "DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS"
entities.description: "Differential Diagnosis involves distinguishing between conditions with similar symptoms, aided by radiological findings like the Crow Feet Sign and round atelectasis."

entities.name: "CORKSCREW SIGN"
entities.description: "Corkscrew Sign refers to a term used in medical imaging to describe specific patterns in various conditions, including diffuse esophageal spasm and inner ear conditions."

entities.name: "CRAZY PAVING SIGN"
entities.description: "Crazy Paving Sign is a radiologic finding seen in conditions like pulmonary edema and interstitial lung diseases, characterized by an interstitial and alveolar pattern."

entities.name: "GROUND GLASS OPACITY"
entities.description: "Ground Glass Opacity is a radiographic finding in the lungs associated with various conditions like infections, inflammation, and malignancies, showing a hazy or frosted appearance."

entities.name: "HORSESHOE KIDNEY"
entities.description: "Horseshoe Kidney is a congenital anomaly where the two kidneys are fused at the lower poles and form a U-shaped structure."

entities.name: "HORSESHOE LUNG"
entities.description: "Horseshoe Lung is a rare radiologic finding in the lungs that resembles a horseshoe shape, possibly associated with certain lung diseases or congenital abnormalities."

entities.name: "MISTY MESENTERY SIGN"
entities.description: "Misty Mesentery Sign is a radiographic finding indicating abnormality of the mesentery, potentially seen in conditions like mesenteric ischemia or inflammation."

entities.name: "ONION PEEL SIGN"
entities.description: "Onion Peel Sign is a radiologic appearance seen in conditions such as pulmonary hydatid cyst, where concentric layers resemble the skin of an onion."

entities.name: "STRING OF PEARLS SIGN"
entities.description: "String of Pearls Sign is a radiographic appearance seen in conditions such as chilaiditi syndrome or gastric volvulus, showing a row of small, spherical gas bubbles resembling a string of pearls."

entities.name: "BIRD'S BEAK SIGN"
entities.description: "Bird's Beak Sign is a radiologic finding in conditions like achalasia and volvulus, characterized by a beak-like appearance typically seen on barium swallow studies."

entities.name: "CHAIR-SHAPED KIDNEY"
entities.description: "Chair-shaped Kidney is a rare morphological variant of the kidney where the renal pelvis is located anteriorly, giving a chair-like appearance to the kidney."

entities.name: "DOUBLE BUBBLE SIGN"
entities.description: "Double Bubble Sign is a radiologic finding associated with conditions like duodenal atresia or annular pancreas, showing two air-filled bubbles in the abdomen resembling a double bubble."

entities.description: "Caput Medusae Sign is a term that refers to a developmental venous anomaly, highlighting a unique visualization resembling the appearance of Medusa's head."

entities.name: "CAPUT MEDUSAE SIGN (PORTAL HYPERTENSION)"
entities.description: "Caput Medusae Sign specifically in the context of portal hypertension, indicating a distinctive clinical sign associated with liver disease."

entities.name: "CHEERIO SIGN (DISAMBIGUATION)"
entities.description: "Cheerio Sign can refer to various medical contexts, each having a different meaning or significance."

entities.name: "CHEERIO SIGN (PULMONARY NODULE)"
entities.description: "Cheerio Sign in the presence of pulmonary nodules, suggesting a unique visual characteristic detected in radiological imaging."

entities.name: "CHEERIO SIGN (SHOULDER)"
entities.description: "Cheerio Sign related to the shoulder, indicating a particular sign or observation seen in medical examinations."

entities.name: "CHOCOLATE CYST"
entities.description: "Chocolate Cyst is a type of ovarian cyst containing old blood that resembles chocolate in appearance, indicative of a specific pathological condition."

entities.name: "COTTAGE LOAF SIGN"
entities.description: "Cottage Loaf Sign is a term used in radiology to describe a distinct appearance resembling a loaf of bread, seen in a certain medical context."

entities.name: "DOUBLE OREO COOKIE (GLENOID LABRUM)"
entities.description: "Double Oreo Cookie appearance specifically related to the glenoid labrum, indicating a radiological finding with a unique visual similarity to a popular cookie."

entities.name: "PANDA SIGN"
entities.description: "Panda Sign is a unique radiological finding characterized by a black-and-white appearance resembling a panda, typically seen in a particular medical condition."

entities.name: "INTERVENTIONAL RADIOLOGY"
entities.description: "Interventional Radiology is a branch of radiology that involves minimally invasive procedures for diagnosis and treatment."

entities.name: "PATHOLOGY"
entities.description: "Pathology is the study of diseases and their effects on the body, often involving the examination of tissues and organs."

entities.name: "RADIOGRAPHY"
entities.description: "Radiography is a diagnostic technique using X-rays to produce images of the internal structures of the body."

entities.name: "SIGNS"
entities.description: "Signs refer to objective measurements or observations that indicate the presence of a disease or condition."

entities.name: "STAGING"
entities.description: "Staging is the process of determining the extent and spread of a disease, often used to guide treatment decisions."

entities.name: "SYNDROMES"
entities.description: "Syndromes are a collection of symptoms that characterize a particular disease or condition."

entities.name: "BREAST"
entities.description: "The Breast is a specific area of the body that can be affected by various diseases and conditions."

entities.name: "CARDIAC"
entities.description: "The Cardiac refers to the heart and related structures, involving diseases and conditions affecting the cardiovascular system."

entities.name: "CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM"
entities.description: "The Central Nervous System includes the brain and spinal cord, susceptible to various neurological diseases."

entities.name: "CHEST"
entities.description: "The Chest area is associated with diseases of the respiratory system, heart, and chest wall."

entities.name: "GASTROINTESTINAL"
entities.description: "The Gastrointestinal system involves the digestive tract and associated organs, affected by a range of diseases."

entities.name: "GYNECOLOGY"
entities.description: "Gynecology focuses on the female reproductive system, dealing with diseases and conditions specific to women."

entities.name: "HAEMATOLOGY"
entities.description: "Haematology refers to blood-related diseases and conditions, including disorders of the blood and bone marrow."

entities.name: "HEAD & NECK"
entities.description: "The Head & Neck region encompasses diseases affecting the structures in the head and neck area."

entities.name: "HEPATOBILIARY"
entities.description: "Hepatobiliary involves diseases of the liver, gallbladder, and bile ducts, impacting digestive and metabolic processes."

entities.name: "MUSCULOSKELETAL"
entities.description: "Musculoskeletal conditions affect the muscles, bones, and joints, leading to a range of orthopedic problems."

entities.name: "OBSTETRICS"
entities.description: "Obstetrics deals with pregnancy and childbirth, addressing maternal and fetal health during the reproductive process."

entities.name: "ONCOLOGY"
entities.description: "Oncology focuses on the study and treatment of cancerous diseases, involving the diagnosis and management of tumors."

entities.name: "PAEDIATRICS"
entities.description: "Paediatrics concerns medical care for children, dealing with various diseases and developmental issues in pediatric patients."

entities.name: "SPINE"
entities.description: "The Spine refers to the vertebral column, prone to conditions such as back pain, herniated discs, and spinal cord injuries."

entities.name: "TRAUMA"
entities.description: "Trauma represents injuries or wounds caused by external forces, affecting different parts of the body."

entities.name: "UROGENITAL"
entities.description: "Urogenital pertains to diseases of the urinary and reproductive systems, including conditions in the kidneys, bladder, and genitals."

entities.name: "VASCULAR"
entities.description: "Vascular conditions involve diseases of the blood vessels, arteries, and veins, impacting circulation and cardiovascular health."

entities.name: "DERMATOLOGY"
entities.description: "Dermatology deals with skin diseases and conditions, encompassing dermatologic evaluations and treatments."

entities.name: "ENDOCRINOLOGY"
entities.description: "Endocrinology focuses on hormonal disorders and glands, involving endocrine evaluations and medical management."

entities.name: "HEMATOLOGY"
entities.description: "Hematology is the study of blood-related diseases, including hematologic evaluations and treatments."

entities.name: "NEUROLOGY"
entities.description: "Neurology deals with disorders of the nervous system, encompassing neurological evaluations and treatments."

entities.name: "NEPHROLOGY"
entities.description: "Nephrology focuses on kidney diseases and conditions, involving nephrologic evaluations and treatments."

entities.name: "OPHTHALMOLOGY"
entities.description: "Ophthalmology specializes in eye diseases and conditions, including ophthalmologic evaluations and treatments."

entities.name: "OTOLARYNGOLOGY"
entities.description: "Otolaryngology deals with ear, nose, and throat diseases, encompassing ENT evaluations and interventions."

entities.name: "PEDIATRICS"
entities.description: "Pediatrics involves medical care for infants, children, and adolescents, addressing pediatric diseases and developmental issues."

entities.name: "PULMONOLOGY"
entities.description: "Pulmonology focuses on diseases of the respiratory system, involving pulmonary evaluations and treatments."

entities.name: "RHEUMATOLOGY"
entities.description: "Rheumatology deals with musculoskeletal and autoimmune diseases, encompassing rheumatologic evaluations and treatments."

tags:
cases, case2
synonyms:
relaxation atelectasis
passive atelectasis, also known as relaxation atelectasis, is a form of lung atelectasis due to the loss of the negative pressure state in the pleural space.
on this page:
article:
clinical presentation
pathology
radiographic features
related articles
references
images:cases and figures
clinical presentationthe clinical presentation would depend on the extent of atelectasis and how quickly it develops. small and gradually developing areas of atelectasis may be asymptomatic or present as a non-productive cough. larger areas that develop more quickly can present with hypoxia, respiratory failure, cough, and/or pleuritic chest pain 6.physical examination of the lungs may reveal diminished movement of the affected area, dullness on percussion, decreased or absent breath sounds, and ipsilateral tracheal deviation 6.pathologywith a loss of the negative intrapleural pressure (e.g. in pneumothorax) there is equalisation of intrapleural and intra-alveolar pressures and the lung is said to "relax" due to its normal elastic recoil, resulting in lung volume loss 5. in diaphragmatic abnormalities, there is a reduction in downward force to fully expand the lungs, resulting in passive atelectasis 5.aetiologycauses of passive atelectasis may be grouped into three main categories 5:
simple pneumothorax
diaphragmatic abnormalities
diaphragmatic hernia
diaphragmatic paralysis
diaphragmatic eventration
conditions of hypoventilation
pleural effusion
haemothorax
pleural tumour
chest wall mass
radiographic featuresplain radiographthere may not be a significant increase in density from the atelectasis, as perfusion of the affected lung also decreases ref.

entities.name: "PASSIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Passive Atelectasis, also known as Relaxation Atelectasis, is a form of lung atelectasis due to the loss of negative pressure in the pleural space."

entities.name: "LUNG ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Lung Atelectasis refers to the collapse or closure of a part of the lung, affecting lung function and gas exchange."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition characterized by the presence of air in the pleural cavity, leading to lung collapse and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "DIAPHRAGMATIC ABNORMALITIES"
entities.description: "Diaphragmatic Abnormalities are conditions that affect the function of the diaphragm, potentially leading to respiratory issues and lung collapse."

entities.name: "PLEURITIC CHEST PAIN"
entities.description: "Pleuritic Chest Pain is a sharp chest discomfort that worsens with breathing, often caused by inflammation of the pleura."

entities.name: "OBESITY"
entities.description: "Obesity is a risk factor for atelectasis due to decreased lung volume and compromised respiratory function."

entities.name: "THORACIC SURGERY"
entities.description: "Thoracic Surgery can lead to atelectasis as a postoperative complication."

entities.name: "CHRONIC RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS"
entities.description: "Chronic Respiratory Infections can contribute to the development of atelectasis due to airway blockages and inflammation."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a medical condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, leading to symptoms such as chest pain and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "LUNG ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Lung Atelectasis refers to the collapse or closure of lung tissue resulting in impaired gas exchange and respiratory function."

entities.name: "COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Compressive Atelectasis occurs when an external force compresses the lung tissue, causing it to collapse and leading to respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition characterized by the presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse and potentially life-threatening complications."

entities.name: "HEPATIC ABSCESSES AND LARGE SPLENIC ABSCESS"
entities.description: "Hepatic Abscesses and Large Splenic Abscess are serious infections involving the liver and spleen, typically requiring medical intervention for treatment."

entities.name: "CATAMENIAL PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Catamenial Pneumothorax is a rare condition where lung collapse occurs in relation to menstruation, often requiring specialized management."

entities.name: "KIDNEY INJURY DUE TO FALL"
entities.description: "Kidney Injury due to Fall refers to trauma or damage to the kidney as a result of a fall, requiring medical assessment and treatment."

entities.name: "SMALL BOWEL OBSTRUCTION DUE TO WANDERING GASTROSTOMY TUBE"
entities.description: "Small Bowel Obstruction due to Wandering Gastrostomy Tube is a complication involving blockage in the small intestine caused by a movable feeding tube, necessitating urgent medical attention."

entities.name: "CLOSTRIDIOIDES DIFFICILE COLITIS"
entities.description: "Clostridioides Difficile Colitis is a bacterial infection of the colon leading to diarrhea and abdominal pain, often associated with antibiotic use."

entities.name: "IVOR LEWIS ESOPHAGECTOMY COMPLICATION"
entities.description: "Ivor Lewis Esophagectomy Complication refers to potential surgical complications following an esophagectomy procedure, requiring post-operative monitoring and care."

entities.name: "PLEURAL SARCOMATOID MESOTHELIOMA"
entities.description: "Pleural Sarcomatoid Mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive form of cancer affecting the lining of the lungs, necessitating specialized treatment."

entities.name: "DELAYED TRAUMATIC SPLENIC RUPTURE"
entities.description: "Delayed Traumatic Splenic Rupture is a serious injury to the spleen that occurs after a period of time following trauma, requiring urgent medical attention."

entities.name: "MASSIVE AORTIC ANEURYSM, DISSECTION, AND PERICARDIAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Massive Aortic Aneurysm, Dissection, and Pericardial Effusion involve serious vascular conditions affecting the aorta and heart, necessitating urgent intervention for prevention of complications."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, typically caused by blood clots traveling from other parts of the body."

entities.name: "ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS)"
entities.description: "Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a severe lung condition that causes fluid to leak into the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and low oxygen levels in the blood."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease that causes scarring of the lung tissue, leading to breathing difficulties and decreased oxygen levels in the blood."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the lungs and can spread to other parts of the body, often leading to respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, leading to cough, fever, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "PLEURISY"
entities.description: "Pleurisy is inflammation of the pleura, the membrane that covers the lungs and lines the chest cavity, causing sharp chest pain and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Bronchitis is the inflammation of the bronchial tubes in the lungs, leading to cough, mucus production, and difficulty breathing."

key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""SMALL BOWEL OBSTRUCTION DUE TO WANDERING GASTROSTOMY TUBE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Small Bowel Obstruction due to Wandering Gastrostomy Tube is a complication involving blockage in the small intestine caused by a movable feeding tube, necessitating urgent medical attention."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""CLOSTRIDIOIDES DIFFICILE COLITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Clostridioides Difficile Colitis is a bacterial infection of the colon leading to diarrhea and abdominal pain, often associated with antibiotic use."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""IVOR LEWIS ESOPHAGECTOMY COMPLICATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ivor Lewis Esophagectomy Complication refers to potential surgical complications following an esophagectomy procedure, requiring post-operative monitoring and care."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL SARCOMATOID MESOTHELIOMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Sarcomatoid Mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive form of cancer affecting the lining of the lungs, necessitating specialized treatment."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""DELAYED TRAUMATIC SPLENIC RUPTURE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Delayed Traumatic Splenic Rupture is a serious injury to the spleen that occurs after a period of time following trauma, requiring urgent medical attention."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""MASSIVE AORTIC ANEURYSM, DISSECTION, AND PERICARDIAL EFFUSION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Massive Aortic Aneurysm, Dissection, and Pericardial Effusion involve serious vascular conditions affecting the aorta and heart, necessitating urgent intervention for prevention of complications."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EMBOLISM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, typically caused by blood clots traveling from other parts of the body."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a severe lung condition that causes fluid to leak into the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and low oxygen levels in the blood."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY FIBROSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease that causes scarring of the lung tissue, leading to breathing difficulties and decreased oxygen levels in the blood."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the lungs and can spread to other parts of the body, often leading to respiratory symptoms."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""PNEUMONIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, leading to cough, fever, and difficulty breathing."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURISY"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleurisy is inflammation of the pleura, the membrane that covers the lungs and lines the chest cavity, causing sharp chest pain and difficulty breathing."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchitis is the inflammation of the bronchial tubes in the lungs, leading to cough, mucus production, and difficulty breathing."</data>      <data key="d2">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </node>    <edge source=""PLEURAL EFFUSION"" target=""PNEUMOTHORAX"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Pleural Effusion and Pneumothorax are both conditions affecting the pleural space and may share risk factors and diagnostic considerations."</data>      <data key="d5">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PLEURAL EFFUSION"" target=""MASSIVE AORTIC ANEURYSM, DISSECTION, AND PERICARDIAL EFFUSION"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Massive Aortic Aneurysm, Dissection, and Pericardial Effusion have implications on cardiovascular health, potentially impacting conditions such as Pleural Effusion."</data>      <data key="d5">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""LUNG ATELECTASIS"" target=""COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Lung Atelectasis and Compressive Atelectasis both involve the collapse of lung tissue, with the latter specifying the cause as external compression."</data>      <data key="d5">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""HEPATIC ABSCESSES AND LARGE SPLENIC ABSCESS"" target=""KIDNEY INJURY DUE TO FALL"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Hepatic Abscesses, Large Splenic Abscess, and Kidney Injury due to Fall are all medical cases involving organ damage and complications following trauma."</data>      <data key="d5">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""CATAMENIAL PNEUMOTHORAX"" target=""SMALL BOWEL OBSTRUCTION DUE TO WANDERING GASTROSTOMY TUBE"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Catamenial Pneumothorax and Small Bowel Obstruction due to Wandering Gastrostomy Tube are specific medical cases requiring tailored management due to unique triggers."</data>      <data key="d5">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""CLOSTRIDIOIDES DIFFICILE COLITIS"" target=""IVOR LEWIS ESOPHAGECTOMY COMPLICATION"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Clostridioides Difficile Colitis and Ivor Lewis Esophagectomy Complication are medical conditions that may occur as complications following specific procedures or treatments."</data>      <data key="d5">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PLEURAL SARCOMATOID MESOTHELIOMA"" target=""DELAYED TRAUMATIC SPLENIC RUPTURE"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Pleural Sarcomatoid Mesothelioma and Delayed Traumatic Splenic Rupture are serious medical conditions requiring prompt diagnosis and intervention for optimal outcomes."</data>      <data key="d5">abcffe2d14ee9a93e2d04f74acd21c40</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>
