entities.name: "BRONCHUS INTERMEDIUS"
entities.description: "Bronchus Intermedius is a condition affecting the intermediate bronchus."

entities.name: "RIGHT PARASPINAL LINE"
entities.description: "Right Paraspinal Line is a symptom related to a specific area of the chest or back."

entities.name: "LEFT PARASPINAL LINE"
entities.description: "Left Paraspinal Line is a symptom related to a specific area of the chest or back."

entities.name: "AORTIC-PULMONARY STRIPE"
entities.description: "Aortic-pulmonary Stripe is a symptom related to a specific area of the chest or back."

entities.name: "AORTOPULMONARY WINDOW"
entities.description: "Aortopulmonary Window is a symptom related to a specific area of the chest or back."

entities.name: "AZYGO-OESOPHAGEAL RECESS"
entities.description: "Azygo-oesophageal Recess is a symptom affecting the interaction between the azygous vein and the esophagus."

entities.name: "AIR BRONCHOGRAM"
entities.description: "Air Bronchogram is a radiologic sign of air-filled bronchi within a consolidated lung."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Tracheal Stenosis is a condition characterized by the narrowing of the trachea, leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE TRACHEAL NARROWING"
entities.description: "Diffuse Tracheal Narrowing refers to a condition where the trachea is uniformly narrowed, impacting airflow."

entities.name: "LUCENCY"
entities.description: "Lucency is a radiographic feature indicating an area of increased radiolucency in an image."

entities.name: "COBRA HEAD SIGN"
entities.description: "Cobra Head Sign is a radiologic sign characterized by a curved tube-like appearance."

entities.name: "THORACIC DUCT"
entities.description: "The Thoracic Duct is a major lymphatic vessel in the chest that drains lymph from the lower body and left side of the upper body."

entities.name: "PANCOAST TUMOR"
entities.description: "Pancoast Tumor is a type of lung tumor that typically occurs in the upper part of the lungs."

entities.name: "MEDIASTINAL WIDENING"
entities.description: "Mediastinal Widening refers to an abnormal widening of the mediastinum seen on imaging studies."

entities.name: "HAMPTON'S HUMP"
entities.description: "Hampton's Hump is a radiologic sign of a wedge-shaped opacity in the lung parenchyma."

entities.name: "AZYGOS LOBE"
entities.description: "The Azygos Lobe is a rare anatomical variant of the right lung that is formed by an accessory lobe."

entities.description: "Adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that can manifest in different subtypes and patterns of invasion in the lung."

entities.description: "Pleural invasion is a characteristic feature of invasive lung cancer, indicating spread of the tumor to the pleura."

entities.name: "CANNONBALL METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cannonball metastases are a pattern of metastatic lung cancer presentation characterized by round, well-circumscribed nodules."

entities.name: "LUNG-RADS"
entities.description: "Lung-RADS is a lung cancer screening and reporting system used to categorize and manage lung nodules found on screening CT scans."

entities.name: "IASLC 8TH EDITION"
entities.description: "IASLC 8th Edition refers to the latest international guideline for lung cancer staging, providing standardized criteria for disease classification."

entities.name: "LUNG NODULE"
entities.description: "A lung nodule is a small, round or oval-shaped growth in the lung, often detected incidentally on imaging studies like chest x-rays or CT scans."

entities.name: "EGFR MUTATION"
entities.description: "EGFR mutation is a genetic alteration commonly found in non-small cell lung cancer that can influence treatment decisions and outcomes."

entities.name: "PD-L1 EXPRESSION"
entities.description: "PD-L1 expression refers to the presence of a protein on cancer cells that can help predict response to immunotherapy in lung cancer patients."

entities.name: "BRONCHOSCOPY"
entities.description: "Bronchoscopy is a diagnostic test that allows visualization of the airways and collection of tissue samples for analysis in lung cancer evaluation."

chunk:
asbestos-related diseases are disorders of the lung and pleura caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibres. asbestos-related diseases include non-malignant disorders such as asbestosis (pulmonary fibrosis due to asbestos), diffuse pleural thickening, pleural plaques, pleural effusion, rounded atelectasis and malignancies such as lung cancer and malignant mesothelioma.
people who worked in jobs with high asbestos dust exposure are at the highest risk of developing asbestos-related disease. however, exposure to asbestos may also occur in the worker's home due to dust that has accumulated on the worker's clothing (para-occupational exposure). asbestos-related diseases can also occur as a result of non-occupational, environmental exposure. asbestos was extensively used in many building materials, therefore large quantities of asbestos still remain in buildings that were built prior to the restriction of asbestos use that applies in many countries. the weathering and aging of such buildings may cause asbestos fragments to be released in the air and create a potential hazard. anyone who disturbs the asbestos-containing material during home maintenance and renovation can be affected, although the exact risks are difficult to quantify.
== pathophysiology ==
inhaled asbestos fibres enter the upper and lower respiratory tracts when asbestos is released into the air. some of the inhaled fibers are cleared by the mucociliary clearance mechanism but long thin asbestos fibers may reach the lower airways and alveoli, and can be retained in the lungs for many years. amphibole fibers are not cleared as effectively as serpentines and therefore accumulate more readily in the distal lung parenchyma. asbestos fibres are recognised by the lungs as foreign bodies and cause the activation of the lung's local immune system leading to inflammation, cell and tissue damage. in the long term, this can lead to fibrosis, or rarely to malignancy. from the lungs, some asbestos fibres (mainly short fibres) can also migrate to pleural and peritoneal (abdominal) spaces.
== non-malignant asbestos-related pleural diseases ==
benign asbestos-related pleural abnormalities encompass four types of pleural changes:
pleural plaques
diffuse pleural thickening
benign asbestos pleural effusions
rounded atelectasis (folded lung)
the pleura appears to be more sensitive than the lung parenchyma to the effects of asbestos fibres. thus asbestos-related pleural diseases can result from much lower doses than the fibrotic changes in the lung.
=== pleural plaques ===
pleural plaques are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure, affecting up to 58% of asbestos-exposed workers. the prevalence among the general population exposed environmentally ranges from 0.53 to 8%. pleural plaques are discrete circumscribed areas of hyaline fibrosis (patches of thickening) of the parietal pleura and rarely the visceral pleura that develop 20 to 40 years after first exposure. over time, usually more than 30 years, they often become partly calcified. they consist of mature collagen fibers arranged in an open basket-weave pattern and are covered by flattened or cuboidal mesothelial cells. they have a white or pale yellow shaggy appearance and are typically distributed on the posterolateral chest wall, diaphragm, and mediastinal pleura. the number and size varies. pleural plaques are typically asymptomatic, however, there is still some controversy on this topic. an association between pleural plaques and chest pain has been reported, but this has not been confirmed in more recent studies. similarly, an association between pleural plaques and a restrictive impairment with diminished diffusing capacity on pulmonary function testing has been described. this has not been a consistent finding and it has been postulated that this might be related to undetected early fibrosis. the pathogenesis of pleural plaques remains uncertain. the most likely explanation is that asbestos fibres reach the

entities.name: "ASBESTOS-RELATED DISEASES"
entities.description: "Asbestos-related Diseases are disorders of the lung and pleura caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibres."

entities.name: "ASBESTOSIS"
entities.description: "Asbestosis is pulmonary fibrosis due to asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE PLEURAL THICKENING"
entities.description: "Diffuse Pleural Thickening is a non-malignant disorder associated with asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "PLEURAL PLAQUES"
entities.description: "Pleural Plaques are discrete areas of thickening on the pleura caused by asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a non-malignant condition related to asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "ROUNDED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Rounded Atelectasis is a lung condition associated with asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a malignancy linked to asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA"
entities.description: "Malignant Mesothelioma is a cancer caused by asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "PEOPLE WITH HIGH ASBESTOS DUST EXPOSURE"
entities.description: "People with High Asbestos Dust Exposure are at the highest risk of developing asbestos-related diseases."

entities.name: "PARA-OCCUPATIONAL EXPOSURE"
entities.description: "Para-occupational Exposure occurs when individuals are exposed to asbestos due to dust accumulated on clothing."

entities.name: "NON-OCCUPATIONAL, ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURE"
entities.description: "Non-occupational, Environmental Exposure to asbestos can lead to asbestos-related diseases."

entities.name: "ASBESTOS"
entities.description: "Asbestos was extensively used in building materials and remains a hazard in older buildings."

entities.name: "ASBESTOS FIBRES"
entities.description: "Asbestos Fibres are microscopic particles that can be inhaled and cause Asbestos-related Diseases."

entities.name: "ASBESTOS CONTAMINATION"
entities.description: "Asbestos Contamination in the environment can lead to Asbestos-related Diseases."

entities.name: "WORK-RELATED ASBESTOS EXPOSURE"
entities.description: "Work-related Asbestos Exposure is a common cause of Asbestos-related Diseases among industrial workers."

entities.name: "OCCUPATIONAL ASBESTOS EXPOSURE"
entities.description: "Occupational Asbestos Exposure occurs in various industries and can result in Asbestos-related Diseases."

entities.name: "SECONDARY ASBESTOS EXPOSURE"
entities.description: "Secondary Asbestos Exposure happens when individuals come into contact with asbestos through contaminated clothing or materials."

entities.name: "ASBESTOS FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Asbestos Fibrosis is a condition characterized by the scarring of lung tissue due to asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "ASBESTOS-RELATED PLEURAL DISEASE"
entities.description: "Asbestos-Related Pleural Disease encompasses various pleural conditions caused by asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "BENIGN ASBESTOS-RELATED DISEASES"
entities.description: "Benign Asbestos-Related Diseases include non-cancerous conditions resulting from asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "ASBESTOS-RELATED PARENCHYMAL DISEASE"
entities.description: "Asbestos-Related Parenchymal Disease affects the lung tissue due to asbestos exposure."

entities.name: "ASBESTOS-RELATED MALIGNANCIES"
entities.description: "Asbestos-Related Malignancies are cancers triggered by asbestos exposure, such as lung cancer and mesothelioma."

entities.name: "ASBESTOS MINING"
entities.description: "Asbestos Mining involves extracting asbestos from the earth and poses a high risk of exposure to asbestos fibres."

chunk:
flat-chested kitten syndrome (fcks) is a disorder in cats wherein kittens develop a compression of the thorax (chest/ribcage) caused by lung collapse. this is a soft-tissue problem and is not caused by vertebral or bony malformation. however, lung collapse can be a secondary symptom caused by bony deformity affecting the thorax such as pectus excavatum. in mild cases, the underside of the chest becomes flattened (hence the name of the condition); in extreme cases the entire thorax is flattened, looking as if the kitten has been stepped on. the kitten will appear to go from normal to flat in the space of about two to three hours, and will usually then stabilise. fcks is frequently misdiagnosed as pectus excavatum due to inadequate veterinary literature or lack of experience with the condition on the part of the clinician.
fcks is most frequently caused by collapsed lungs (and not as formerly believed, by a muscle spasm in the intercostal muscles). there are numerous causes for lung collapse, and therefore numerous causes for fcks. one possible cause for flat chestedness that develops soon after birth is atelectasis.
causes of atelectasis include insufficient attempts at respiration by the newborn, bronchial obstruction, or absence of surfactant (a substance secreted by alveoli that coats the lungs and prevents the surfaces from sticking together). lack of surfactant reduces the surface area available for effective gas exchange causing lung collapse if severe. there can be many reasons for atelectasis in kittens, but probably the most common cause is prematurity. newborn atelectasis would not be unusual in a very large litter of kittens (such as 10), where the size of the litter may lead all the kittens to be small and mildly underdeveloped.
unlike human babies, kittens are born very immature: blind, deaf, the intestinal tract not fully developed etc., so even slight prematurity may tip them over the edge from being viable to non viable. many fcks kittens may have fallen just the wrong side of this boundary in their development at the time of birth. further, if a kitten does not scream or open its lungs well enough at birth, even if it is fully mature and has sufficient surfactant, it may end up with atelectasis. patches of atelectasis in the lungs mean that part of a lung is not operating properly. if the kitten goes to sleep and its respiratory rate drops, the patches of atelectasis can slowly expand until large areas of the lung collapse and cannot be reinflated. good advice to any breeder therefore would be to ensure that kittens cry loudly when they are born, to make sure that the airways are clear, but also that the lungs expand as fully as possible. (this was the reason newborn babies were always held upside down immediately after birth (so that any residual fluid drains downwards) and smacked to make them cry strongly.)
some kittens suffer from congenital 'secondary' atelectasis, which presents shortly after birth. there have been no reports of kittens born flat (primary atelectasis). hyaline membrane disease is a type of respiratory distress syndrome of the newborn in which there is formation of a hyaline-like membrane lining the terminal respiratory passages, and this may also be a (rarer) cause of fcks. pressure from outside the lung from fluid or air can cause atelectasis as well as obstruction of lung air passages by mucus resulting from various infections and lung diseases - which may explain the development of fcks in older kittens (e.g. 10 days old) who are not strong enough to breathe through even a light mucus, or who may have inhaled milk during suckling.
tumors and inhaled objects (possible if bedding contains loose fluff) can also cause obstruction or irritation of the airway, leading to lung collapse and secondary atelectasis. in an older cat the intercostal muscles are so well developed, and the ribs rigid enough that the ribcage will not flatten if the lung collapses: in kittens the bones are much more fl

entities.name: "FLAT-CHESTED KITTEN SYNDROME (FCKS)"
entities.description: "FCKS is a disorder in cats where kittens develop a compression of the thorax caused by lung collapse, often mistaken for pectus excavatum, with potential causes including collapsed lungs, atelectasis, bony deformities, and environmental factors."

entities.name: "THORAX"
entities.description: "The thorax in FCKS refers to the chest area where compression occurs due to lung collapse, leading to visible flattening."

entities.name: "LUNG COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Lung collapse is a key symptom in FCKS, contributing to the thoracic compression and potential respiratory issues in affected kittens."

entities.name: "PECTUS EXCAVATUM"
entities.description: "Pectus Excavatum is mentioned as a potential factor that can lead to lung collapse and contribute to the manifestation of FCKS in kittens."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is described as a potential cause of lung collapse in FCKS, associated with insufficient respiration, surfactant deficiency, and other factors."

entities.name: "BONY DEFORMITIES"
entities.description: "Bony deformities are cited as a potential factor contributing to FCKS, potentially leading to thoracic compression and respiratory issues in affected kittens."

entities.name: "ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS"
entities.description: "Environmental factors are mentioned as possible triggers for FCKS, affecting the development of thoracic compression and associated respiratory problems in kittens."

chunk:
coronavirus disease 2019 (covid-19) is a contagious disease caused by the coronavirus sars-cov-2. the first known case was identified in wuhan, china, in december 2019. most scientists believe the sars-cov-2 virus entered into human populations through natural zoonosis, similar to the sars-cov-1 and mers-cov outbreaks, and consistent with other pandemics in human history. social and environmental factors including climate change, natural ecosystem destruction and wildlife trade increased the likelihood of such zoonotic spillover. the disease quickly spread worldwide, resulting in the covid-19 pandemic.
the symptoms of covid-19 are variable but often include fever, fatigue, cough, breathing difficulties, loss of smell, and loss of taste. symptoms may begin one to fourteen days after exposure to the virus. at least a third of people who are infected do not develop noticeable symptoms. of those who develop symptoms noticeable enough to be classified as patients, most (81%) develop mild to moderate symptoms (up to mild pneumonia), while 14% develop severe symptoms (dyspnea, hypoxia, or more than 50% lung involvement on imaging), and 5% develop critical symptoms (respiratory failure, shock, or multiorgan dysfunction). older people are at a higher risk of developing severe symptoms. some complications result in death. some people continue to experience a range of effects (long covid) for months or years after infection, and damage to organs has been observed. multi-year studies are underway to further investigate the long-term effects of the disease.
covid-19 transmission occurs when infectious particles are breathed in or come into contact with the eyes, nose, or mouth. the risk is highest when people are in close proximity, but small airborne particles containing the virus can remain suspended in the air and travel over longer distances, particularly indoors. transmission can also occur when people touch their eyes, nose or mouth after touching surfaces or objects that have been contaminated by the virus. people remain contagious for up to 20 days and can spread the virus even if they do not develop symptoms.
testing methods for covid-19 to detect the virus's nucleic acid include real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rt-pcr), transcription-mediated amplification, and reverse transcription loop-mediated isothermal amplification (rt-lamp) from a nasopharyngeal swab.
several covid-19 vaccines have been approved and distributed in various countries, many of which have initiated mass vaccination campaigns. other preventive measures include physical or social distancing, quarantining, ventilation of indoor spaces, use of face masks or coverings in public, covering coughs and sneezes, hand washing, and keeping unwashed hands away from the face. while drugs have been developed to inhibit the virus, the primary treatment is still symptomatic, managing the disease through supportive care, isolation, and experimental measures.
== nomenclature ==
during the initial outbreak in wuhan, the virus and disease were commonly referred to as "coronavirus" and "wuhan coronavirus", with the disease sometimes called "wuhan pneumonia". in the past, many diseases have been named after geographical locations, such as the spanish flu, middle east respiratory syndrome, and zika virus. in january 2020, the world health organization (who) recommended 2019-ncov and 2019-ncov acute respiratory disease as interim names for the virus and disease per 2015 guidance and international guidelines against using geographical locations or groups of people in disease and virus names to prevent social stigma. the official names covid-19 and sars-cov-2 were issued by the who on 11 february 2020 with covid-19 being shorthand for "coronavirus disease 2019". the who additionally uses "the covid-19 virus" and "the virus responsible for covid-19" in public communications.
== symptoms and signs ==
=== complications ===
complications may include pneumon

entities.description: "COVID-19 is a contagious disease caused by the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, with symptoms ranging from fever, fatigue, cough, breathing difficulties, loss of smell, to more severe cases leading to respiratory failure and multiorgan dysfunction. entities.name: "SOCIAL DISTANCING"

entities.description: "Vaccines are substances that stimulate the immune system to produce immunity to specific diseases, with COVID-19 vaccines being developed to prevent infection and spread of the virus."

chunk:
dornase alfa, sold under the brand name pulmozyme, is used for the treatment of cystic fibrosis. it is a recombinant human deoxyribonuclease i (rhdnase), an enzyme which selectively cleaves dna. dornase alfa hydrolyzes the dna present in sputum/mucus and reduces viscosity in the lungs, promoting improved clearance of secretions. it is produced in chinese hamster ovary cells.
== medical uses ==
dornase alfa is indicated for the management of people with cystic fibrosis to improve pulmonary function.
== society and culture ==
=== legal status ===
dornase alfa is an orphan drug.
== research ==
dornase alfa has been shown to improve lung function in non-cystic fibrosis pre-term infants atelectasis.
== references ==

band atelectases
fleischner line
plate atelectases
linear atelectasis (plural: atelectases), and also known as discoid, plate or band atelectasis, refers to a focal area of subsegmental atelectasis that has a linear shape. linear atelectasis may appear to be horizontal, oblique or perpendicular and is very common. it usually occurs as a consequence of subsegmental bronchial obstruction and can resolve as quickly as it occurs.
on this page:
article:
terminology
pathology
history and etymology
see also
related articles
references
terminologydepending on its shape, linear atelectasis is also known as plate, discoid or band atelectasis (and historically as fleischner lines on chest radiographs, but not on ct). subsegmental vs linear atelectasisthere is confusion about the use of the terms "subsegmental atelectasis" and "linear atelectasis" (and their synonyms). from an academic point of view, the term linear atelectasis is reserved for atelectasis which appears primarily in the lung bases and is secondary to hypoventilation. conversely, subsegmental atelectasis includes both linear atelectases and all other forms of atelectasis that do not involve a whole bronchopulmonary segment. in other words, every linear atelectasis is a subsegmental atelectasis, but not every subsegmental atelectasis is a linear atelectasis.
advertisement: supporters see fewer/no ads
pathologyaetiology
hypoventilatory change in patients who are not taking deep breaths ("splinting")
postoperative status
chest wall trauma such as rib fracture
pleuritic chest disease
pulmonary embolism
pneumonia
aspiration
bronchogenic carcinoma
history and etymologyfleischner lines were named after felix fleischner (1893-1969), an austrian-american radiologist, who first described them in 1938.see alsoatelectasis
references
1. woodring jh, reed jc. types and mechanisms of pulmonary atelectasis. (1996) journal of thoracic imaging. 11 (2): 92-108. pubmed
2. baron mg. fleischner lines and pulmonary emboli. (1972) circulation. 45 (1): 171-8. doi:10.1161/01.cir.45.1.171 - pubmed
3. ozturk k, soylu e, topal u. linear atelectasis around the hilum on chest radiography: a novel sign of early lung cancer. (2018) journal of clinical imaging science. 8: 27. doi:10.4103/jcis.jcis_35_18 - pubmed

entities.name: "BILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Bilateral Airspace Opacification is a differential diagnosis related to the opacification of both lung fields."

entities.name: "LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Lobar Consolidation is a symptom where a region of the lung becomes solid instead of filled with air."

entities.name: "RIGHT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Upper Lobe Consolidation is a symptom where the upper lobe of the right lung becomes solid instead of filled with air."

entities.name: "RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Middle Lobe Consolidation is a symptom where the middle lobe of the right lung becomes solid instead of filled with air."

entities.name: "RIGHT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Lower Lobe Consolidation is a symptom where the lower lobe of the right lung becomes solid instead of filled with air."

entities.name: "LEFT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Left Upper Lobe Consolidation is a symptom where the upper lobe of the left lung becomes solid instead of filled with air."

entities.name: "LEFT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Left Lower Lobe Consolidation is a symptom where the lower lobe of the left lung becomes solid instead of filled with air."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is a condition where the lung or part of it collapses, leading to incomplete expansion of air spaces."

entities.name: "MECHANISM-BASED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Mechanism-based Atelectasis is a type of lung collapse due to various factors such as obstruction, relaxation, compression, or scarring."

entities.name: "MORPHOLOGY-BASED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Morphology-based Atelectasis is a categorization of lung collapse based on its appearance, such as linear, segmental, subsegmental, or round."

entities.name: "ROUND ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Round Atelectasis is a specific form of lung collapse that can be induced by adjacent pulmonary abnormalities like osteophytes."

entities.name: "SUBSEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Subsegmental Atelectasis is a type of lung collapse that occurs in a subsegment of the lung, leading to incomplete expansion of air spaces."

entities.name: "MULTILOBAR CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Multilobar Consolidation is a symptom where multiple lobes of the lung become solid instead of filled with air."

entities.name: "ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS)"
entities.description: "Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a severe lung condition characterized by widespread inflammation in the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and low oxygen levels."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is a condition characterized by the accumulation of excess fluid in the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and reduced oxygen levels in the blood."

SYNDROME (ARDS)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a severe lung condition characterized by widespread inflammation in the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and low oxygen levels."</data>      <data key="d2">3e8d87c864ffd039559f39405b1a4ded</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Edema is a condition characterized by the accumulation of excess fluid in the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and reduced oxygen levels in the blood."</data>      <data key="d2">3e8d87c864ffd039559f39405b1a4ded</data>    </node>    <edge source=""BILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"" target=""LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">"Lobar Consolidation can be a presentation in cases of Bilateral Airspace Opacification."</data>      <data key="d6">3e8d87c864ffd039559f39405b1a4ded</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"" target=""ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">"Atelectasis can lead to the development of Lobar Consolidation if not addressed timely."</data>      <data key="d6">3e8d87c864ffd039559f39405b1a4ded</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

entities.name: "ERIO V SIGN"
entities.description: "Erio V Sign is a potential indication of a specific medical condition, manifesting as a sign in imaging studies."

entities.name: "PALLA SIGN"
entities.description: "Palla Sign is a specific marker observed in medical imaging, potentially linked to certain diseases or conditions."

entities.name: "PERICARDIAL FAT TAG SIGN"
entities.description: "Pericardial Fat Tag Sign is a discernible sign in medical imaging likely related to cardiac or pericardial abnormalities."

entities.name: "SHMOO SIGN"
entities.description: "Shmoo Sign, when present in medical imaging, may suggest a particular pathological process or anatomical feature."

entities.name: "SILHOUETTE SIGN"
entities.description: "Silhouette Sign is a radiological finding that can assist in diagnosing specific medical conditions or issues."

entities.name: "CERVICOTHORACIC SIGN"
entities.description: "Cervicothoracic Sign refers to a radiological clue indicating abnormalities or structures in the neck or chest regions."

entities.name: "THORACOABDOMINAL SIGN"
entities.description: "Thoracoabdominal Sign is a radiological marker that may point towards thoracic and abdominal pathologies or anomalies."

entities.name: "SNOWMAN SIGN"
entities.description: "Snowman Sign is a visual finding in medical imaging that could imply certain medical conditions or anatomical variations."

entities.name: "SPINNAKER SIGN"
entities.description: "Spinnaker Sign is a recognizable sign in imaging studies that might be associated with specific syndromes or diseases."

entities.name: "STEEPLE SIGN"
entities.description: "Steeple Sign, observed in radiological images, may be suggestive of certain clinical conditions or anatomical variations."

entities.name: "STRAIGHT LEFT HEART BORDER SIGN"
entities.description: "Straight Left Heart Border Sign is a radiological observation that could be linked to cardiac or vascular abnormalities."

entities.name: "THIRD MOGUL SIGN"
entities.description: "Third Mogul Sign is a distinctive feature seen in medical imaging that may have diagnostic implications for certain diseases."

entities.name: "TRAM-TRACK SIGN"
entities.description: "Tram-Track Sign is a radiological finding that could indicate specific pathological processes or anatomical structures."

entities.name: "WALKING MAN SIGN"
entities.description: "Walking Man Sign is a recognizable feature in medical imaging that may be indicative of particular medical conditions."

entities.name: "WATER BOTTLE SIGN"
entities.description: "Water Bottle Sign is a radiological sign that might suggest specific anatomical variations or pathological processes."

entities.name: "WAVE SIGN"
entities.description: "Wave Sign is a visual finding in medical imaging that could indicate certain clinical conditions or physiological changes."

entities.name: "WESTERMARK SIGN"
entities.description: "Westermark Sign is a radiological observation that may have diagnostic value in specific medical contexts."

entities.name: "HRCT"
entities.description: "HRCT, High-Resolution Computed Tomography, is an advanced imaging tool used for detailed evaluation of anatomical structures and pathologies."

entities.name: "HRCT TERMINOLOGY"
entities.description: "HRCT Terminology refers to the specific language and terms used in interpreting High-Resolution Computed Tomography scans in clinical practice."

entities.name: "SECONDARY PULMONARY LOBULE"
entities.description: "Secondary Pulmonary Lobule is a unit of lung anatomy important in understanding pulmonary structure and function."

entities.name: "LUNG NODULES"
entities.description: "Lung Nodules are abnormal growths in the lung tissue that can be benign or malignant, requiring proper evaluation."

entities.name: "GROUND-GLASS NODULES"
entities.description: "Ground-Glass Nodules are radiological findings in the lungs that may indicate various conditions, including malignancy or inflammation."

entities.name: "CALCIFIED LUNG NODULES"
entities.description: "Calcified Lung Nodules are nodules in the lung tissue that have undergone calcification, requiring assessment for potential underlying diseases."

entities.name: "CENTRILOBULAR LUNG NODULES"
entities.description: "Centrilobular Lung Nodules are nodules localized centrally in the lung lobule and may be associated with different pulmonary pathologies."

entities.name: "RANDOM PULMONARY NODULES"
entities.description: "Random Pulmonary Nodules are nodules found incidentally in the lung tissue and necessitate evaluation for possible underlying diseases."

entities.name: "PERILYMPHATIC NODULES PERIFISSURAL PULMONARY NODULES"
entities.description: "Perilymphatic Nodules Perifissural Pulmonary Nodules are nodules around the lymphatics in the lung and fissures, requiring diagnostic scrutiny."

entities.name: "AIRWAYS"
entities.description: "Airways refer to the passages through which air travels in and out of the lungs, vital for respiratory function and gas exchange."

entities.name: "BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Bronchitis is an inflammation of the bronchial tubes, leading to cough, phlegm production, and respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "ACUTE BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Acute Bronchitis is a sudden onset of bronchial inflammation, usually caused by viral infections and characterized by cough and chest discomfort."

entities.name: "CHRONIC BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Chronic Bronchitis is a long-term inflammation of the bronchial tubes, often associated with smoking and leading to persistent cough and sputum production."

entities.name: "SMALL AIRWAYS DISEASE"
entities.description: "Small Airways Disease refers to the conditions affecting the small air passages in the lungs, potentially causing breathing difficulties and airflow obstruction."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by permanent widening of the bronchial tubes, leading to mucus accumulation and recurrent infections."

entities.name: "BRONCHO-ARTERIAL RATIO"
entities.description: "Broncho-Arterial Ratio is a parameter used in diagnosing pulmonary diseases by comparing the sizes of bronchi and pulmonary arteries on imaging studies."

entities.name: "CYSTIC FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Cystic Fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the lungs and other organs, leading to mucus buildup, infections, and respiratory complications."

entities.name: "ALLERGIC BRONCHOPULMONARY ASPERGILLOSIS"
entities.description: "Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus fungi in the airways, causing inflammation and respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "WILLIAMS CAMPBELL SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Williams Campbell Syndrome is a rare congenital condition characterized by cartilage defects in the trachea, leading to airway malformations and breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "CONGENITAL TRACHEOBRONCHOMEGALY (A.K.A. MOUNIER KUHN SYNDROME)"
entities.description: "Congenital Tracheobronchomegaly, also known as Mounier Kuhn Syndrome, is a rare disorder involving abnormal dilation of the trachea and bronchi, affecting breathing function."

entities.name: "PRIMARY CILIARY DYSKINESIA"
entities.description: "Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia is a genetic disorder affecting the cilia of respiratory cells, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance and recurrent respiratory infections."

entities.name: "CENTRAL BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Central Bronchiectasis is a form of bronchiectasis affecting the central airways, potentially due to various underlying conditions, necessitating treatment."

entities.name: "UPPER LOBE BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Upper Lobe Bronchiectasis is bronchiectasis localized to the upper lung regions and may be associated with specific etiologies, requiring management."

entities.name: "MIDDLE LOBE BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Middle Lobe Bronchiectasis is bronchiectasis involving the middle lung lobe, often presenting distinctively and warranting diagnostic investigation."

entities.name: "LOWER LOBE BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Lower Lobe Bronchiectasis is bronchiectasis affecting the lower parts of the lungs, leading to respiratory symptoms and complications, requiring intervention."

entities.name: "TRACHEOBRONCHOMALACIA"
entities.description: "Tracheobronchomalacia is a condition involving weakness and collapse of the trachea and bronchi, causing airway obstruction and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Tracheal Stenosis is a narrowing of the trachea, often due to scarring or inflammation, leading to breathing difficulties and potentially requiring intervention."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE TRACHEAL NARROWING (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Diffuse Tracheal Narrowing, a diagnostic consideration, may indicate various underlying causes of tracheal constriction, mandating further evaluation."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Bronchial Stenosis refers to the narrowing of bronchial tubes, which can impede airflow and lead to respiratory symptoms requiring clinical attention."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE AIRWAY NARROWING (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Diffuse Airway Narrowing, a differential diagnosis, suggests various conditions causing widespread constriction of the air passages, necessitating thorough assessment."

entities.name: "DIVERTICULA"
entities.description: "Diverticula are pouch-like protrusions that can develop in the tracheal or bronchial walls, potentially causing respiratory complications and requiring medical management."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL DIVERTICULUM"
entities.description: "Tracheal Diverticulum is a pouch-like outgrowth in the tracheal wall, which may be congenital or acquired, necessitating evaluation for potential complications."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL DIVERTICULUM"
entities.description: "Bronchial Diverticulum is a pouch-like bulge in the bronchial walls, possibly leading to respiratory issues and necessitating clinical assessment."

entities.name: "PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Oedema is the accumulation of fluid in the lungs, leading to respiratory distress and impaired gas exchange, requiring prompt medical intervention."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Interstitial Oedema specifically refers to fluid accumulation in the interstitial spaces of the lungs, often seen in certain conditions and necessitating clinical management."

entities.name: "ALVEOLAR OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Alveolar Oedema denotes fluid buildup inside the alveoli of the lungs, impairing gas exchange and potentially indicating various cardiorespiratory issues."

entities.name: "CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Cardiogenic Pulmonary Oedema is pulmonary oedema resulting from heart-related causes, such as heart failure, leading to respiratory symptoms and requiring cardiovascular management."

entities.name: "NON-CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Oedema is lung fluid accumulation not primarily due to heart dysfunction, often associated with other conditions like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). "

entities.name: "GRADING"
entities.description: "Grading in the context of pulmonary oedema refers to assessing the severity or extent of lung fluid accumulation, aiding in treatment decisions and prognostication."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE (ILD)"
entities.description: "Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) encompasses a group of disorders affecting the interstitium of the lungs, leading to fibrosis, inflammation, and impaired respiratory function."

entities.name: "ANTI-JO-1 ANTIBODY-POSITIVE INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Anti-Jo-1 Antibody-Positive Interstitial Lung Disease refers to ILD associated with specific autoantibodies, potentially leading to distinctive clinical manifestations and requiring targeted therapy."

entities.name: "DRUG-INDUCED INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Drug-Induced Interstitial Lung Disease is ILD caused by medications or substances, necessitating recognition and cessation of the offending agent to manage the condition."

entities.name: "AMIODARONE LUNG"
entities.description: "Amiodarone Lung refers to a type of drug-induced ILD linked to amiodarone therapy, requiring close monitoring and potentially cessation of the medication."

entities.name: "BLEOMYCIN LUNG TOXICITY"
entities.description: "Bleomycin Lung Toxicity denotes lung damage caused by bleomycin chemotherapy, manifesting as interstitial lung disease, necessitating treatment modifications."

entities.name: "LEFLUNOMIDE-INDUCED ACUTE INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Leflunomide-Induced Acute Interstitial Pneumonia is a specific form of drug-induced lung injury associated with leflunomide therapy, necessitating prompt recognition and management."

entities.name: "METHOTREXATE LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Methotrexate Lung Disease encompasses pulmonary complications arising from methotrexate use, potentially manifesting as interstitial pneumonitis or fibrosis, requiring clinical attention."

entities.name: "HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis is an immunologically mediated lung condition triggered by exposure to allergens, leading to inflammation and respiratory symptoms, necessitating allergen avoidance and treatment."

entities.name: "ACUTE HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Acute Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis is a rapid-onset form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, necessitating prompt recognition and management to prevent progression to chronic disease."

entities.name: "SUBACUTE HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Subacute Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis is an intermediate form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, distinguished by a subacute course and specific radiological and clinical features, requiring appropriate interventions."

entities.name: "CHRONIC HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Chronic Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis is a prolonged form of hypersensitivity lung disease, necessitating ongoing identification of and protection from inciting antigens to prevent exacerbations."

entities.name: "BIRD FANCIER'S LUNG: PIGEON FANCIER'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Bird Fancier's Lung, also known as Pigeon Fancier's Lung, is a variant of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by exposure to bird antigens, requiring avoidance and treatment to prevent lung damage."

entities.name: "FARMER'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Farmer's Lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis triggered by moldy hay or other organic dust in agricultural settings, necessitating allergen avoidance and therapeutic measures."

entities.name: "CHEESE WORKERS' LUNG"
entities.description: "Cheese Workers' Lung is a form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis associated with exposure to cheese mold or whey proteins, requiring identification and avoidance of triggering allergens."

entities.name: "BAGASSOSIS"
entities.description: "Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling dust from sugarcane bagasse, manifesting as hypersensitivity pneumonitis and necessitating workplace modifications."

entities.name: "MUSHROOM WORKER'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Mushroom Worker's Lung is an allergic response to mushroom spores leading to hypersensitivity pneumonitis in individuals working with fungi, necessitating protective measures and treatment."

entities.name: "MALT WORKER'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Malt Worker's Lung is hypersensitivity pneumonitis triggered by exposure to malt dust in brewing and malting industries, requiring allergen avoidance and respiratory support."

entities.name: "MAPLE BARK DISEASE"
entities.description: "Maple Bark Disease is a variant of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by exposure to maple tree bark or dust, necessitating recognition of the condition and removal of the inciting agent."

entities.name: "HOT TUB LUNG"
entities.description: "Hot Tub Lung, also known as Hot Tub Lung Disease, is a form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis linked to inhaling Mycobacterium avium from contaminated hot tubs, necessitating avoidance of exposure and appropriate treatment."

entities.name: "WINE MAKER'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Wine Maker's Lung is an occupational lung disease associated with hypersensitivity pneumonitis from exposure to wine yeast or grape mold, necessitating protective measures and respiratory support."

entities.name: "WOODSMAN'S DISEASE"
entities.description: "Woodsman's Disease is a variant of hypersensitivity pneumonitis occurring in individuals exposed to certain wood dust or mold, necessitating identification and avoidance of hazardous materials."

entities.name: "THATCHED ROOF LUNG"
entities.description: "Thatched Roof Lung is a rare form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis related to exposure to thatched roofing materials or mold, requiring assessment and environmental modifications."

entities.name: "TOBACCO GROWER'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Tobacco Grower's Lung is hypersensitivity pneumonitis arising from exposure to tobacco dust or mold, requiring cessation of exposure and management of respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "POTATO RIDDLER'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Potato Riddler's Lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis linked to potato moth infestation, necessitating insect control and allergen avoidance to prevent respiratory complications."

entities.name: "SUMMER-TYPE PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Summer-Type Pneumonitis is an allergic lung condition triggered by specific summer-time allergens, requiring symptom management and avoidance of inciting factors."

entities.name: "DRY ROT LUNG"
entities.description: "Dry Rot Lung is a form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by exposure to fungi found in decayed wood, necessitating environmental remediation and respiratory support."

entities.name: "MACHINE OPERATOR'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Accelerated Silicosis"

entities.name: "ACUTE SILICOSIS"
entities.description: "Acute Silicosis is a rapidly progressing form of silicosis caused by intense silica inhalation, characterized by severe inflammation in the lungs and necessitating immediate treatment."

entities.name: "CHRONIC SILICOSIS"
entities.description: "Chronic Silicosis is a long-term lung condition caused by prolonged silica exposure, leading to progressive scarring and fibrosis in the lungs, requiring ongoing management."

entities.name: "SILICA DUST EXPOSURE"
entities.description: "Silica Dust Exposure refers to inhalation or contact with fine particles of crystalline silica, commonly found in mining, construction, or manufacturing industries, posing a risk of respiratory diseases like silicosis."

entities.name: "ANTHRACOSIS"
entities.description: "Anthracosis, also known as Black Lung Disease, is a condition caused by prolonged inhalation of coal dust or carbon particles, leading to lung discoloration and respiratory symptoms requiring assessment."

entities.name: "ASBESTOSIS"
entities.description: "Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease resulting from asbestos fiber inhalation, causing lung fibrosis, breathing difficulties, and an increased risk of mesothelioma or lung cancer, necessitating medical monitoring and management."

entities.name: "PLEURAL PLAQUES"
entities.description: "Pleural Plaques are localized areas of fibrous thickening on the pleural membranes of the lungs, often caused by asbestos exposure, requiring monitoring for potential complications."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE PLEURAL THICKENING"
entities.description: "Diffuse Pleural Thickening is a condition involving extensive fibrosis and scarring of the pleura, frequently associated with asbestos exposure, necessitating evaluation and follow-up."

entities.name: "PNEUMOCONIOSIS"
entities.description: "Pneumoconiosis is a group of lung diseases caused by inhalation of mineral dust particles, such as silicosis, asbestosis, or coal worker's pneumoconiosis, leading to lung damage and respiratory impairment."

entities.name: "BYSSINOSIS"
entities.description: "Byssinosis, known as Brown Lung Disease, is a respiratory condition caused by inhaling cotton dust or related plant fibers in textile or yarn manufacturing, resulting in airway constriction and breathing difficulties, necessitating workplace precautions."

entities.name: "BERYLLIOSIS"
entities.description: "Berylliosis is a lung disease arising from beryllium exposure, leading to granuloma formation in the lungs, respiratory symptoms, and potential long-term complications, requiring specialized care and monitoring."

entities.name: "COAL WORKER'S PNEUMOCONIOSIS"
entities.description: "Coal Worker's Pneumoconiosis, also known as Black Lung Disease, is caused by inhalation of coal dust, resulting in lung damage, scarring, and respiratory symptoms, necessitating monitoring and supportive care."

entities.name: "OXYGEN THERAPY"
entities.description: "Oxygen Therapy involves the administration of supplemental oxygen to alleviate symptoms of hypoxemia, support respiratory function, and improve oxygen levels in patients with various medical conditions, such as lung diseases or cardiovascular issues."

entities.name: "MECHANICAL VENTILATION"
entities.description: "Mechanical Ventilation is a medical intervention using a ventilator to assist or replace spontaneous breathing in patients with respiratory failure, critical illness, or surgery, providing controlled oxygen supply and respiratory support."

entities.name: "BRONCHOSCOPY"
entities.description: "Bronchoscopy is a diagnostic procedure that allows visualization of the airways using a thin, flexible tube with a camera, assisting in the evaluation of respiratory conditions, collection of samples, or removal of obstructions in the lungs."

key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""TOBACCO GROWER'S LUNG"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tobacco Grower's Lung is hypersensitivity pneumonitis arising from exposure to tobacco dust or mold, requiring cessation of exposure and management of respiratory symptoms."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""POTATO RIDDLER'S LUNG"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Potato Riddler's Lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis linked to potato moth infestation, necessitating insect control and allergen avoidance to prevent respiratory complications."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""SUMMER-TYPE PNEUMONITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Summer-Type Pneumonitis is an allergic lung condition triggered by specific summer-time allergens, requiring symptom management and avoidance of inciting factors."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""DRY ROT LUNG"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Dry Rot Lung is a form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by exposure to fungi found in decayed wood, necessitating environmental remediation and respiratory support."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""MACHINE OPERATOR'S LUNG"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"<"ENTITY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Accelerated Silicosis"</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""ACUTE SILICOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Acute Silicosis is a rapidly progressing form of silicosis caused by intense silica inhalation, characterized by severe inflammation in the lungs and necessitating immediate treatment."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHRONIC SILICOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chronic Silicosis is a long-term lung condition caused by prolonged silica exposure, leading to progressive scarring and fibrosis in the lungs, requiring ongoing management."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""SILICA DUST EXPOSURE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Silica Dust Exposure refers to inhalation or contact with fine particles of crystalline silica, commonly found in mining, construction, or manufacturing industries, posing a risk of respiratory diseases like silicosis."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""ANTHRACOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Anthracosis, also known as Black Lung Disease, is a condition caused by prolonged inhalation of coal dust or carbon particles, leading to lung discoloration and respiratory symptoms requiring assessment."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""ASBESTOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease resulting from asbestos fiber inhalation, causing lung fibrosis, breathing difficulties, and an increased risk of mesothelioma or lung cancer, necessitating medical monitoring and management."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL PLAQUES"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Plaques are localized areas of fibrous thickening on the pleural membranes of the lungs, often caused by asbestos exposure, requiring monitoring for potential complications."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""DIFFUSE PLEURAL THICKENING"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Diffuse Pleural Thickening is a condition involving extensive fibrosis and scarring of the pleura, frequently associated with asbestos exposure, necessitating evaluation and follow-up."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""PNEUMOCONIOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pneumoconiosis is a group of lung diseases caused by inhalation of mineral dust particles, such as silicosis, asbestosis, or coal worker's pneumoconiosis, leading to lung damage and respiratory impairment."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""BYSSINOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Byssinosis, known as Brown Lung Disease, is a respiratory condition caused by inhaling cotton dust or related plant fibers in textile or yarn manufacturing, resulting in airway constriction and breathing difficulties, necessitating workplace precautions."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""BERYLLIOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Berylliosis is a lung disease arising from beryllium exposure, leading to granuloma formation in the lungs, respiratory symptoms, and potential long-term complications, requiring specialized care and monitoring."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""COAL WORKER'S PNEUMOCONIOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Coal Worker's Pneumoconiosis, also known as Black Lung Disease, is caused by inhalation of coal dust, resulting in lung damage, scarring, and respiratory symptoms, necessitating monitoring and supportive care."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""OXYGEN THERAPY"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Oxygen Therapy involves the administration of supplemental oxygen to alleviate symptoms of hypoxemia, support respiratory function, and improve oxygen levels in patients with various medical conditions, such as lung diseases or cardiovascular issues."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""MECHANICAL VENTILATION"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Mechanical Ventilation is a medical intervention using a ventilator to assist or replace spontaneous breathing in patients with respiratory failure, critical illness, or surgery, providing controlled oxygen supply and respiratory support."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHOSCOPY"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchoscopy is a diagnostic procedure that allows visualization of the airways using a thin, flexible tube with a camera, assisting in the evaluation of respiratory conditions, collection of samples, or removal of obstructions in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">8f224bdf8daad37aaea99a2a9f22a648</data>    </node>  </graph></graphml>

entities.name: "SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of cancer originating in the squamous cells of the epithelium."

entities.name: "MUCOEPIDERMOID CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a rare salivary gland tumor that can be benign or malignant."

entities.name: "ADENOID CYSTIC CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a type of cancer that commonly affects the salivary glands."

entities.name: "ACINIC CELL CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Acinic cell carcinoma is a rare type of cancer that usually occurs in the salivary glands."

entities.name: "PULMONARY NEUROENDOCRINE TUMOURS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary neuroendocrine tumors are a group of lung tumors that arise from neuroendocrine cells."

entities.name: "SMALL-CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Small-cell lung cancer is a type of lung cancer that often spreads rapidly."

entities.name: "CARCINOID TUMOURS OF THE LUNG"
entities.description: "Carcinoid tumors of the lung are a type of neuroendocrine tumor that can be benign or malignant."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL CARCINOID TUMOURS"
entities.description: "Bronchial carcinoid tumors are a type of lung tumor that arises from the bronchial epithelium."

entities.name: "PERIPHERAL PULMONARY CARCINOID TUMOURS"
entities.description: "Peripheral pulmonary carcinoid tumors are a type of lung tumor that originates in the peripheral lung tissue."

entities.name: "LARGE CELL NEUROENDOCRINE CELL CARCINOMA OF THE LUNG"
entities.description: "Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung is a subtype of lung cancer with neuroendocrine features."

entities.name: "PREINVASIVE LESIONS"
entities.description: "Preinvasive lesions refer to abnormal cell growth that has not invaded surrounding tissues."

entities.description: "disease"

entities.name: "PLEOMORPHIC CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Pleomorphic carcinoma is a rare and aggressive type of lung cancer that often has poorly defined features."

entities.name: "PULMONARY BLASTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary blastoma is a rare type of lung cancer that contains both epithelial and mesenchymal components."

entities.name: "LYMPHOEPITHELIOMA-LIKE CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma is a type of lung cancer that resembles undifferentiated nasopharyngeal carcinoma."

entities.name: "SARCOMATOID CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Sarcomatoid carcinoma is a rare type of lung cancer that has both carcinomatous and sarcomatous components."

entities.name: "BASALOID SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Basaloid squamous cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that presents histological features of both basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma."

entities.name: "KERATOACANTHOMA"
entities.description: "Keratoacanthoma is a rapidly-growing skin tumor that is considered a type of squamous cell carcinoma."

entities.name: "MELANOMA"
entities.description: "Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes."

entities.name: "BASAL CELL CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Basal cell carcinoma is a common type of skin cancer that arises from basal cells in the epidermis."

entities.name: "SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA OF THE SKIN"
entities.description: "Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is a type of skin cancer that originates from squamous cells."

synonyms:
lobar atelectasis
lobar lung atelectasis
lobar collapse
lobal volume loss
lobar volume loss
lobar collapse refers to the collapse of an entire lobe of the lung. as such it is a subtype of atelectasis (collapse is not entirely synonymous with atelectasis, which is a more generic term for 'incomplete expansion'). individual lobes of the lung may collapse due to obstruction of the supplying bronchus. pathologymost often collapse of most or all of a lobe is secondary to bronchial obstruction causing resorptive atelectasis.aetiology
luminal
aspirated foreign material
mucus plugging
endobronchial mass
misplaced endotracheal tube
murallung cancer
extrinsiccompression by adjacent mass
radiographic featuresthere are several classical rules that a lobar collapse follows 9:
bowing or displacement of a fissure/s occurs towards the collapsing lobe
a significant amount of volume loss is required to cause air space opacification
the collapsed lobe is triangular or pyramidal in shape, with the apex pointing to the hilum
the collapsed lung peripherally maintains contact with the costal parietal pleura, except:
in rml collapse where the lobe collapses adjacent to the mediastinum
in the presence of pleural effusion
in the presence of pneumothorax
several factors may influence the typical appearance of lobar collapse, including pre-existing lung disease, amount of volume loss, concomitant consolidation, pleural effusion or the presence of pneumothorax.plain radiographgenerally, there is pulmonary air space opacification but the appearance on chest x-ray varies according to the lobe involved and are discussed separately:
right upper lobe collapse
right middle lobe collapse
right lower lobe collapse
left upper lobe collapse
left lower lobe collapse
some features, however, are generic markers of volume loss and are helpful in directing one's attention to the collapse, as well as enabling distinction from opacification of the lobe without collapse (i.e. consolidation e.g. lobar pneumonia). these features include 5,9:
direct signs
displacement of fissures
crowding of pulmonary vessels
indirect signs
elevation of the ipsilateral hemidiaphragm
crowding of the ipsilateral ribs
shift of the mediastinum towards the side of atelectasis
compensatory hyperinflation of normal lobes
hilar displacement towards the collapse
shifting granuloma sign
ctlobar collapse is usually trivially easy to identify on ct, but identification of the cause is not always easy, as the collapsed lung can make identification of an obstructing lesion difficult. the density of the collapsed lobe is high post contrast administration.
references
1. proto av, tocino i. radiographic manifestations of lobar collapse. semin roentgenol. 1980;15 (2): 117-73. - pubmed citation
2. robbins ll, clayton hh. the roentgen appearance of lobar and segmental collapse of the lung. vi. collapse of the upper lobes. radiology 1945; 45:347-355.
3. lubert m, krause gr. further observations on lobar collapse. radiol clin north am 1963; 1:331-346.
4. lee sk, ahn jm, im j, muller nl. lobar atelectasis: typical and atypical radiographic and ct findings. postgrad radiol 1995; 15:203-217.
5. collins j, stern ej. chest radiology, the essentials. lippincott williams & wilkins. (2007) isbn:0781763142. read it at google books - find it at amazon
6. woodring jh, reed jc. radiographic manifestations of lobar atelectasis. j thorac

entities.name: "LOBAR LUNG COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Lobar Lung Collapse refers to the collapse of an entire lobe of the lung, often caused by bronchial obstruction leading to resorptive atelectasis."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is a generic term for incomplete lung expansion, with lobar collapse being a specific subtype."

entities.name: "BRONCHUS"
entities.description: "Bronchus is a component of the respiratory system and can be obstructed, leading to lobar collapse."

entities.name: "ASPIRATED FOREIGN MATERIAL"
entities.description: "Aspirated Foreign Material is a possible cause of bronchial obstruction and subsequent lobar collapse."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a condition where fluid accumulates in the pleural space, potentially affecting the appearance of lobar collapse on imaging."

entities.name: "COLLAPSE RULES"
entities.description: "Collapse Rules refer to characteristic features seen in lobar collapse, aiding in its radiographic identification."

entities.name: "SYMPTOMS OF LOBAR COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Symptoms of Lobar Collapse may include difficulty breathing, chest pain, and decreased lung function."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia can lead to lobar collapse if it causes obstructive atelectasis in a bronchus."

entities.name: "TUMOR COMPRESSION"
entities.description: "Tumor Compression can block a bronchus and result in lobar collapse."

entities.name: "LUNG ABSCESS"
entities.description: "Lung Abscess, a localized collection of pus within the lung, can contribute to lobar collapse if it leads to bronchial obstruction."

entities.name: "CHEST TUBE PLACEMENT"
entities.description: "Chest Tube Placement may be necessary in cases of lobar collapse associated with conditions such as pleural effusion."

entities.name: "POSTOPERATIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Postoperative Atelectasis, a type of lung collapse that can occur after surgery, may involve lobar collapse."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY THERAPY"
entities.description: "Respiratory Therapy techniques, such as incentive spirometry, can help prevent lobar collapse in at-risk individuals."

entities.name: "COUGHING"
entities.description: "Frequent or severe coughing can sometimes trigger lobar collapse in individuals with underlying lung conditions."

entities.name: "OBESITY HYPOVENTILATION SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome, a condition characterized by decreased breathing during sleep, can potentially lead to lobar collapse."

attr.type="string" />  <key id="d0" for="node" attr.name="type" attr.type="string" />  <graph edgedefault="undirected">    <node id=""LOBAR LUNG COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lobar Lung Collapse refers to the collapse of an entire lobe of the lung, often caused by bronchial obstruction leading to resorptive atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Atelectasis is a generic term for incomplete lung expansion, with lobar collapse being a specific subtype."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHUS"">      <data key="d0">"ANATOMY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchus is a component of the respiratory system and can be obstructed, leading to lobar collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""ASPIRATED FOREIGN MATERIAL"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Aspirated Foreign Material is a possible cause of bronchial obstruction and subsequent lobar collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL EFFUSION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Effusion is a condition where fluid accumulates in the pleural space, potentially affecting the appearance of lobar collapse on imaging."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""COLLAPSE RULES"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Collapse Rules refer to characteristic features seen in lobar collapse, aiding in its radiographic identification."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""SYMPTOMS OF LOBAR COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Symptoms of Lobar Collapse may include difficulty breathing, chest pain, and decreased lung function."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""PNEUMONIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pneumonia can lead to lobar collapse if it causes obstructive atelectasis in a bronchus."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""TUMOR COMPRESSION"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tumor Compression can block a bronchus and result in lobar collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG ABSCESS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Abscess, a localized collection of pus within the lung, can contribute to lobar collapse if it leads to bronchial obstruction."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHEST TUBE PLACEMENT"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chest Tube Placement may be necessary in cases of lobar collapse associated with conditions such as pleural effusion."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""POSTOPERATIVE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Postoperative Atelectasis, a type of lung collapse that can occur after surgery, may involve lobar collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""RESPIRATORY THERAPY"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Respiratory Therapy techniques, such as incentive spirometry, can help prevent lobar collapse in at-risk individuals."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""COUGHING"">      <data key="d0">"ACTIVITY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Frequent or severe coughing can sometimes trigger lobar collapse in individuals with underlying lung conditions."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <node id=""OBESITY HYPOVENTILATION SYNDROME"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome, a condition characterized by decreased breathing during sleep, can potentially lead to lobar collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </node>    <edge source=""LOBAR LUNG COLLAPSE"" target=""ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Lobar Lung Collapse is a specific type of Atelectasis, with bronchial obstruction being a common underlying cause."</data>      <data key="d5">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""LOBAR LUNG COLLAPSE"" target=""PLEURAL EFFUSION"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Pleural Effusion can affect the appearance of lobar collapse on imaging studies."</data>      <data key="d5">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""BRONCHUS"" target=""ASPIRATED FOREIGN MATERIAL"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Aspirated Foreign Material can obstruct the bronchus, leading to lobar collapse."</data>      <data key="d5">805e1098ca71225105394b23625b0656</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis refers to the partial or complete collapse of the lung, with various mechanisms and types described."

entities.name: "LOBAR PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Lobar Pneumonia is a type of pneumonia that affects a specific lobe of the lung, causing consolidation and atelectasis."

entities.name: "CHEST RADIOGRAPHY"
entities.description: "Chest Radiography involves imaging the chest area to diagnose conditions like atelectasis and pneumonia."

entities.name: "CICATRISATION ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Cicatrisation Atelectasis occurs due to fibrosis or scarring in the lung, leading to collapse."

entities.name: "PULMONARY MYCOBACTERIUM ABSCESSUS INFECTION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Mycobacterium Abscessus Infection is a lung infection caused by a specific bacteria, potentially leading to atelectasis."

entities.name: "SAM RIVERA"
entities.description: "Sam Rivera is not present in the given text, so not identified."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a serious respiratory condition that can lead to atelectasis and other complications in the lungs."

entities.name: "TRACHEOSTOMY TUBE"
entities.description: "A Tracheostomy Tube is a medical device used for airway management and breathing support."

entities.name: "CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema is a type of pulmonary edema caused by heart-related issues."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a lung condition where the bronchial tubes are permanently damaged and widened."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Bronchial Stenosis refers to the narrowing of the bronchial tubes, leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "DIVERTICULA"
entities.description: "Diverticula are abnormal pouches that can form in the trachea or bronchial tubes."

entities.name: "MEDIAL STRIPE"
entities.description: "Medial Stripe Sign is a radiological sign seen in chest x-rays indicating a specific appearance near the heart's mediastinum."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a buildup of excess fluid between the layers of the pleura outside the lungs, often causing difficulty breathing or chest pain."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Fibrosis is a progressive lung disease characterized by scarring of the lung tissue, leading to difficulty breathing and decreased lung function."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a severe lung condition that primarily affects premature infants and causes breathing difficulties due to underdeveloped lungs."

key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a severe lung condition that primarily affects premature infants and causes breathing difficulties due to underdeveloped lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">342502818793fc08cd7bd607519362dc</data>    </node>    <edge source=""TRACHEOSTOMY TUBE"" target=""CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"A Tracheostomy Tube may be used in patients with Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema to assist with breathing support."</data>      <data key="d5">342502818793fc08cd7bd607519362dc</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""TRACHEOSTOMY TUBE"" target=""MEDIAL STRIPE"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"The observation of the Medial Stripe Sign may influence the decision to place a Tracheostomy Tube."</data>      <data key="d5">342502818793fc08cd7bd607519362dc</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY EDEMA"" target=""BRONCHIAL STENOSIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"In cases of severe Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema, Bronchial Stenosis may contribute to respiratory distress."</data>      <data key="d5">342502818793fc08cd7bd607519362dc</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""BRONCHIAL STENOSIS"" target=""DIVERTICULA"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Bronchial Stenosis can lead to the formation of Diverticula in the airways, complicating respiratory functions."</data>      <data key="d5">342502818793fc08cd7bd607519362dc</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>
