entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Interstitial Oedema is a medical condition characterized by fluid accumulation in the interstitial spaces of tissues."

entities.name: "ALVEOLAR OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Alveolar Oedema is a type of pulmonary edema involving the alveoli of the lungs, often caused by heart conditions or lung injuries."

entities.name: "CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Cardiogenic Pulmonary Oedema is a condition where the lungs fill with fluid due to heart-related issues."

entities.name: "NON-CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Oedema is a type of lung edema not caused by heart problems, potentially related to lung injuries or infections."

entities.name: "ILD"
entities.description: "ILD stands for Interstitial Lung Disease, a group of lung disorders affecting the interstitium, with various causes and symptoms."

entities.name: "ANTI-JO-1 ANTIBODY-POSITIVE INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Anti-Jo-1 Antibody-Positive Interstitial Lung Disease is an ILD associated with the presence of specific antibodies, affecting lung function."

entities.name: "AMIODARONE LUNG"
entities.description: "Amiodarone Lung refers to lung damage caused by the medication amiodarone, leading to pulmonary symptoms."

entities.name: "BLEOMYCIN LUNG TOXICITY"
entities.description: "Bleomycin Lung Toxicity is a condition where the drug bleomycin causes lung damage and respiratory issues."

entities.name: "HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis is a lung condition triggered by inhaling certain allergens or irritants, leading to inflammation."

entities.name: "AIP"
entities.description: "AIP stands for Acute Interstitial Pneumonia, a severe lung condition causing inflammation and impaired respiratory function."

entities.name: "SARCOIDOSIS"
entities.description: "Sarcoidosis is a disease characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, commonly the lungs."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Fibrosis is a progressive lung disease that results in scarring of lung tissue, leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "LYMPHANGIOLEIOMYOMATOSIS"
entities.description: "Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare lung disease that affects the lungs' air sacs and lymphatic system, leading to symptoms like shortness of breath."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid or pus, causing cough with phlegm or pus, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description: "Pulmonary metastases refer to the spread of cancer to the lungs, often originating from another part of the body."

entities.name: "CYSTIC PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cystic pulmonary metastases are characterized by the presence of cysts in the lungs associated with metastatic cancer."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER SCREENING"
entities.description: "Lung cancer screening involves methods to detect potential lung cancer in individuals at risk."

entities.name: "LUNG-RADS"
entities.description: "Lung-RADS is a system used for categorizing and managing lung nodules detected on imaging studies."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER STAGING"
entities.description: "Lung cancer staging determines the extent of lung cancer spread in order to guide treatment decisions."

entities.name: "IASLC (INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LUNG CANCER) 8TH EDITION (CURRENT)"
entities.description: "The current 8th edition of the International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer provides guidelines and standards for lung cancer management."

entities.name: "IASLC (INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LUNG CANCER) 7TH EDITION (SUPERSEEDED)"
entities.description: "The superseded 7th edition of the International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer had guidelines for lung cancer management."

entities.name: "1996 AJCC-UICC REGIONAL LYMPH NODE CLASSIFICATION FOR LUNG CANCER STAGING"
entities.description: "The 1996 AJCC-UICC regional lymph node classification system plays a role in staging lung cancer based on lymph node involvement."

entities.name: "PRIMARY LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Primary lung cancer originates in the lungs and can spread to other parts of the body."

entities.name: "LUNG NODULES"
entities.description: "Lung nodules are small round or oval-shaped growths in the lungs that can be detected on imaging studies."

entities.name: "ADJUVANT THERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Adjuvant therapy for lung cancer is additional treatment given after primary treatment to lower the risk of cancer recurrence."

entities.name: "TARGETED THERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Targeted therapy for lung cancer uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells."

entities.name: "CHEMOTHERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Chemotherapy for lung cancer involves the use of drugs to kill cancer cells or stop them from growing and spreading."

entities.name: "RADIATION THERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Radiation therapy for lung cancer uses high-energy radiation to shrink tumors and kill cancer cells."

entities.name: "SURGERY FOR LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Surgery for lung cancer involves the removal of the tumor and surrounding tissue to treat the disease."

entities.name: "IMMUNOTHERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Immunotherapy for lung cancer boosts the body's immune system to help fight cancer cells."

entities.name: "POSTOPERATIVE CARE FOR LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Postoperative care for lung cancer involves monitoring and support after surgical treatment."

STAGING"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"The 1996 AJCC-UICC regional lymph node classification system plays a role in staging lung cancer based on lymph node involvement."</data>      <data key="d2">31f72f9b1ce29ae36c1d771f05549fd3</data>    </node>    <node id=""PRIMARY LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Primary lung cancer originates in the lungs and can spread to other parts of the body."</data>      <data key="d2">31f72f9b1ce29ae36c1d771f05549fd3</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG NODULES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung nodules are small round or oval-shaped growths in the lungs that can be detected on imaging studies."</data>      <data key="d2">31f72f9b1ce29ae36c1d771f05549fd3</data>    </node>    <node id=""ADJUVANT THERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Adjuvant therapy for lung cancer is additional treatment given after primary treatment to lower the risk of cancer recurrence."</data>      <data key="d2">31f72f9b1ce29ae36c1d771f05549fd3</data>    </node>    <node id=""TARGETED THERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Targeted therapy for lung cancer uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells."</data>      <data key="d2">31f72f9b1ce29ae36c1d771f05549fd3</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHEMOTHERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chemotherapy for lung cancer involves the use of drugs to kill cancer cells or stop them from growing and spreading."</data>      <data key="d2">31f72f9b1ce29ae36c1d771f05549fd3</data>    </node>    <node id=""RADIATION THERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Radiation therapy for lung cancer uses high-energy radiation to shrink tumors and kill cancer cells."</data>      <data key="d2">31f72f9b1ce29ae36c1d771f05549fd3</data>    </node>    <node id=""SURGERY FOR LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Surgery for lung cancer involves the removal of the tumor and surrounding tissue to treat the disease."</data>      <data key="d2">31f72f9b1ce29ae36c1d771f05549fd3</data>    </node>    <node id=""IMMUNOTHERAPY FOR LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Immunotherapy for lung cancer boosts the body's immune system to help fight cancer cells."</data>      <data key="d2">31f72f9b1ce29ae36c1d771f05549fd3</data>    </node>    <node id=""POSTOPERATIVE CARE FOR LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Postoperative care for synonyms:
subsegmental atelectatic changes
subsegmental atelectases
subsegmental atelectasis (plural: atelectases) is a descriptive term for the mildest form of lung atelectasis, involving less than one bronchopulmonary segment.
on this page:
article:
terminology
pathology
radiographic features
differential diagnosis
related articles
references
terminologythe term subsegmental atelectasis includes any loss of lung volume so small that it does not cause indirect signs of volume loss (as might be seen with larger atelectases). a subtype of subsegmental atelectasis is linear atelectasis (also known as discoid or plate-like atelectasis, and historically as fleischner lines on chest radiographs).subsegmental vs linear atelectasisthere is confusion about the use of the terms "subsegmental atelectasis" and "linear atelectasis" (and their synonyms). from an academic point of view, the term linear atelectasis is reserved for atelectasis which appears primarily in the lung bases and is secondary to hypoventilation. conversely, subsegmental atelectasis includes both linear atelectases and all other forms of atelectasis that do not involve a whole bronchopulmonary segment. in other words, every linear atelectasis is subsegmental atelectasis, but not every subsegmental atelectasis is linear atelectasis.pathologyaetiologymany subsegmental atelectases are secondary to airway obstruction of a small segment of the lung, either from benign (mucus plug, airway inflammation) or malignant causes (endobronchial tumour).linear atelectasis is usually due to a lack of adequate inspiration, and not due to any underlying airway obstruction. they are most commonly seen in post-surgical patients or those with abdominal pain, and may also be observed in the morbidly obese or immobile patients.radiographic featuresplain radiograph/ctby definition, subsegmental atelectasis (regardless of its aetiology) does not produce volume loss and subsequent shifting of mobile thoracic structures, and in most cases lacks clinical relevance and does not need to be reported.linear atelectases may result in minor linear densities of varying thickness usually parallel to the diaphragm, most commonly at the lung bases or less mobile regions of the lungs (e.g. lingula).other subsegmental atelectases present as linear or wedge-shaped densities and can affect any lung lobe. unlike linear atelectases, subsegmental atelectases due to obstructive causes usually adopt a radial distribution rather than a horizontal one, as they are secondary to airway obstruction rather than parenchymal compression (as occurs in hypoventilation). therefore, they follow the distribution of the bronchial and bronchiolar tree.differential diagnosis
small linear scars: can mimic this pattern and tends not to resolve on serial imaging
subpleural lines: commonly in asbestosis

entities.name: "SUBSEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Subsegmental Atelectasis is the mildest form of lung atelectasis involving less than one bronchopulmonary segment, characterized by a loss of lung volume without significant clinical relevance."

entities.name: "LINEAR ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Linear Atelectasis is a subtype of subsegmental atelectasis characterized by minor linear densities often seen in post-surgical patients or those with abdominal pain."

entities.name: "AETIOLOGY"
entities.description: "Aetiology refers to the causes or origins of subsegmental atelectasis, including airway obstruction from benign or malignant sources."

entities.name: "RADIAL DISTRIBUTION"
entities.description: "Radial Distribution is a pattern seen in subsegmental atelectasis due to obstructive causes, following the distribution of the bronchial and bronchiolar tree."

entities.name: "SUBPLEURAL LINES"
entities.description: "Subpleural Lines are commonly seen in asbestosis and can mimic the appearance of subsegmental atelectasis on imaging."

entities.name: "ALVEOLAR COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Alveolar Collapse is a histological feature of atelectasis where the air-filled alveoli in the lung collapse due to various factors."

entities.name: "PLATELIKE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Platelike Atelectasis is a form of atelectasis characterized by linear opacities parallel to the pleura, resembling a plate-like appearance on imaging studies."

entities.name: "COMPRESSION ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Compression Atelectasis is a type of atelectasis caused by external compression of the lung tissue, leading to its collapse."

entities.name: "CICATRIZATION ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Cicatrization Atelectasis is a rare form of atelectasis where scarring in the lung tissue causes it to collapse."

entities.name: "LINEAR ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Linear Atelectasis is a novel sign of early lung cancer, visible on chest radiography and may be associated with atelectasis."

entities.name: "SMALL AIRWAYS DISEASE"
entities.description: "Small Airways Disease is a condition affecting the small airways in the lungs, potentially linked to chest radiography findings."

entities.name: "SICKLE CELL DISEASE (ACUTE CHEST SYNDROME)"
entities.description: "Sickle Cell Disease can lead to acute chest syndrome, a serious complication that may be identified through chest imaging techniques."

entities.name: "LUNG ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Lung Atelectasis refers to the collapse or closure of a lung lobe, potentially detectable on chest radiography."

entities.name: "VIRAL BRONCHIOLITIS"
entities.description: "Viral Bronchiolitis is a viral inflammation of the bronchioles, with potential associations to chest imaging findings."

entities.name: "COCAINE-INDUCED PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Cocaine-Induced Pneumonitis is a condition caused by cocaine abuse, possibly identifiable through chest radiography."

entities.name: "NEUROENDOCRINE CARCINOMA OF GALLBLADDER - METASTATIC"
entities.description: "Metastatic Neuroendocrine Carcinoma originating from the gallbladder may present with chest radiography abnormalities."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE LARGE B-CELL LYMPHOMA"
entities.description: "Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma is a type of cancer that might manifest with abnormalities on chest imaging studies."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis involves the collapse of lung tissue, leading to potentially identifiable changes on chest radiography."

entities.name: "AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Airspace Opacification refers to the filling of lung airspaces with fluid or other substances, visible on chest imaging techniques."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is the accumulation of fluid in the lungs, detectable through chest imaging techniques."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism occurs when a blood clot travels to the lungs, potentially visible on chest radiography."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is the buildup of excess fluid in the pleural space, often detectable on chest imaging studies."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Interstitial Lung Disease involves scarring of the lungs' interstitium, which can be identified on chest radiography."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a condition characterized by the abnormal dilation of the bronchi, visible on chest imaging techniques."

   <node id=""VIRAL BRONCHIOLITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Viral Bronchiolitis is a viral inflammation of the bronchioles, with potential associations to chest </node>    <node id=""NEUROENDOCRINE CARCINOMA OF GALLBLADDER - METASTATIC"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Metastatic Neuroendocrine Carcinoma originating from the entities.name: "FISSURE"
entities.description: "Fissure refers to a vertical line seen on a chest X-ray, potentially indicative of a medical condition."

entities.name: "DIAPHRAGM"
entities.description: "Diaphragm shows normal appearance and flattening on a chest X-ray, which may suggest abnormalities in breathing or lung function."

entities.name: "GASTRIC BUBBLE"
entities.description: "Gastric Bubble is a noticeable structure on a chest X-ray, possibly related to gastrointestinal issues or conditions."

entities.name: "NIPPLE SHADOW"
entities.description: "Nipple Shadow is a notable shadow observed on a chest X-ray, possibly indicating breast-related concerns."

entities.name: "POSTERIOR TRACHEAL STRIPE"
entities.description: "Posterior Tracheal Stripe is a visible line on a chest X-ray, related to structures in the trachea or airway."

entities.name: "BRONCHUS INTERMEDIUS"
entities.description: "Posterior Wall of Bronchus Intermedius is a feature on a chest X-ray, associated with the midsection of the bronchial tubes."

entities.name: "RIGHT PARASPINAL LINE"
entities.description: "Right Paraspinal Line is a line visible on a chest X-ray, possibly indicative of spinal or musculoskeletal concerns."

entities.name: "AORTOPULMONARY WINDOW"
entities.description: "Aortopulmonary Window is a structure shown on a chest X-ray, connected to the heart and blood vessels."

entities.name: "AIR BRONCHOGRAM"
entities.description: "Air Bronchogram is a specific pattern seen on chest X-rays, indicating air-filled bronchial tubes surrounded by fluid or tissue."

entities.name: "COIN LESION"
entities.description: "Coin Lesion refers to a round or coin-shaped spot seen on chest X-rays, which may represent a tumor or mass in the lungs."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a lung condition characterized by abnormal widening of the airways, potentially leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "CYSTIC FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Cystic Fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system, causing mucus buildup and respiratory problems."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is a condition where fluid accumulates in the lungs, often due to heart failure or lung infections."

entities.name: "ASBESTOS-RELATED DISEASES"
entities.description: "Asbestos-related Diseases are medical conditions caused by exposure to asbestos fibers, including lung cancer and mesothelioma."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a condition where excess fluid collects in the pleural space around the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, causing cough, fever, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition where air leaks into the space between the lungs and chest wall, leading to lung collapse and chest pain."

entities.name: "FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Fibrosis refers to a condition characterized by the thickening and scarring of tissue, often affecting the lungs."

entities.name: "HUT LUNG"
entities.description: "Hut Lung is a domestically acquired particulate lung disease with specific characteristics and implications."

entities.name: "GIANT CELL INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Giant Cell Interstitial Pneumonia is a specific form of lung disease characterized by the presence of giant cells in the interstitium."

entities.name: "SILICOSIS"
entities.description: "Silicosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica dust, leading to lung tissue scarring."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a malignant disease affecting the lungs, with various subtypes and manifestations."

entities.name: "ADENOCARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that starts in the cells that line certain internal organs and glands."

entities.name: "PULMONARY SIDEROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Siderosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of iron particles, resulting in lung tissue damage."

entities.name: "PANCOAST TUMOUR"
entities.description: "Pancoast Tumour is a type of lung tumor located at the apex of the lung and associated with specific symptoms."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a lung condition where the bronchial tubes become widened, damaged, and scarred, leading to recurrent respiratory infections."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that specifically affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart."

entities.name: "EMPHYSEMA"
entities.description: "Emphysema is a lung condition characterized by damage to the air sacs in the lungs, leading to shortness of breath and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "COPD is a chronic lung disease that includes conditions such as emphysema and chronic bronchitis, leading to airflow obstruction and breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, leading to symptoms such as cough, fever, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "ASTHMA"
entities.description: "Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath."

synonyms:
focal pulmonary atelectasis adjacent to thoracic spinal osteophytes
focal pulmonary interstitial opacities adjacent to thoracic spinal osteophytosis
osteophyte related fibrosis
pulmonary atelectasis and fibrosis due to regional thoracic osteophytosis
osteophyte induced lung fibrosis
osteophyte induced lung fibrosis (oif)
osteophyte-induced adjacent pulmonary atelectasis and fibrosis are typically seen as focal pulmonary interstitial opacities adjacent to thoracic spinal osteophytes. they are a relatively common finding in thoracic ct imaging.
on this page:
article:
epidemiology
pathology
treatment and prognosis
related articles
references
images:cases and figures
epidemiologythey are more common in older individuals.pathologythey are thought to represent a variable combination of compressive atelectasis +- fibrosis (focal pulmonary fibrosis).locationthey are typically seen involving the medial basal segment of the right lower lobe and posterior segment of the left lower lobe where osteophytes are more commonly located. some studies have suggested that the likelihood of lung fibrosis is commensurate with the size of the osteophyte 3. subpleural fat is considered a protective measure against osteophyte-induced lung fibrosis.treatment and prognosismost are not thought to be of clinical significance, generally do not appear to progress, and are not considered a pre-clinical form of more extensive fibrosing lung disease 2.
references
1. otake s, takahashi m, ishigaki t. focal pulmonary interstitial opacities adjacent to thoracic spine osteophytes. ajr am j roentgenol. 2002;179 (4): 893-6. doi:10.2214/ajr.179.4.1790893 - pubmed citation
2. hansell dm. thin-section ct of the lungs: the hinterland of normal. radiology. 2010;256 (3): 695-711. doi:10.1148/radiol.10092307 - pubmed citation
3. salvatore m, henschke c, yip r et al. osteophyte induced lung fibrosis prevalence and osteophyte qualities predicting disease. clin imaging. 2017;44:1-4. doi:10.1016/j.clinimag.2017.02.008 - pubmed

entities.name: "OSTEOPHYTE-INDUCED ADJACENT PULMONARY ATELECTASIS AND FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Osteophyte-induced adjacent pulmonary atelectasis and fibrosis are focal interstitial opacities adjacent to thoracic spinal osteophytes, commonly seen in thoracic CT imaging, more prevalent in older individuals."

entities.name: "THORACIC SPINAL OSTEOPHYTES"
entities.description: "Thoracic spinal osteophytes are bony outgrowths from the vertebral bodies, commonly located in the right lower lobe's medial basal segment and the left lower lobe's posterior segment, associated with potential lung fibrosis."

entities.name: "SUBPLEURAL FAT"
entities.description: "Subpleural fat is a protective measure against osteophyte-induced lung fibrosis, believed to mitigate the likelihood of severe fibrotic lung disease."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY COMPLICATIONS"
entities.description: "Respiratory complications, such as shortness of breath and decreased lung function, can arise from osteophyte-induced adjacent pulmonary atelectasis and fibrosis."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is the collapse or closure of a lung resulting in reduced or absent gas exchange."

entities.name: "RESORPTIVE (OBSTRUCTIVE) ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Resorptive Atelectasis occurs due to the obstruction of bronchi preventing lung inflation."

entities.name: "PASSIVE (RELAXATION) ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Passive Atelectasis happens when the lung cannot expand fully due to a lack of air entering the alveoli."

entities.name: "COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Compressive Atelectasis occurs when pressure from other structures collapses the lung tissue."

entities.name: "CICATRISATION ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Cicatrisation Atelectasis results from scarring that obstructs the expansion of the lung tissue."

entities.name: "ADHESIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Adhesive Atelectasis happens when the alveoli collapse due to the attraction of their inner surfaces."

entities.name: "GRAVITY DEPENDANT ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Gravity Dependent Atelectasis is influenced by changes in body position leading to lung collapse."

entities.name: "MORPHOLOGY-BASED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Morphology-based Atelectasis involves the collapse of lung tissue based on its structure and form."

entities.name: "LINEAR ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Linear Atelectasis is characterized by the collapse of lung tissue in a linear pattern."

entities.name: "SEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Segmental Atelectasis refers to the collapse of a segment of the lung, affecting a specific region."

entities.name: "SUBSEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Subsegmental Atelectasis involves the collapse of a smaller portion of a lung segment."

entities.name: "ROUND ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Round Atelectasis forms a rounded or disc-shaped area of collapsed lung tissue."

entities.name: "OSTEOPHYTE INDUCED ADJACENT PULMONARY ATELECTASIS AND FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Osteophyte Induced Atelectasis occurs when bone spurs cause the collapse of nearby lung tissue with scarring."

entities.name: "LOBAR LUNG COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Lobar Lung Collapse results in the collapse of an entire lobe of the lung due to various factors."

entities.name: "RIGHT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right Upper Lobe Collapse specifically affects the upper lobe of the right lung, leading to collapse."

entities.name: "RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right Middle Lobe Collapse targets the middle lobe of the right lung, causing collapse."

entities.name: "RIGHT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right Lower Lobe Collapse involves the collapse of the lower lobe of the right lung."

entities.name: "LEFT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Left Upper Lobe Collapse results in collapse of the upper lobe of the left lung."

entities.name: "LEFT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Left Lower Lobe Collapse leads to collapse of the lower lobe of the left lung."

entities.name: "MULTIFOCAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Multifocal Atelectasis refers to the collapse of multiple areas within the lungs simultaneously."

entities.name: "PULMONARY ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Atelectasis is a term commonly used to describe the collapse of lung tissue."

entities.name: "NEONATAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Neonatal Atelectasis occurs in newborns and is characterized by the collapse of lung tissue."

entities.name: "ACUTE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Acute Atelectasis refers to the rapid onset of lung collapse."

entities.name: "CHRONIC ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Chronic Atelectasis describes long-term or persistent lung collapse."

entities.name: "RECURRENT ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Recurrent Atelectasis involves multiple episodes of lung collapse."

entities.name: "SECONDARY ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Secondary Atelectasis occurs as a result of another underlying condition or disease."

entities.name: "POSTOPERATIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Postoperative Atelectasis develops after surgery due to various factors."

entities.name: "TRAUMATIC ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Traumatic Atelectasis is caused by physical injury to the chest or lungs."

entities.name: "RADIATION-INDUCED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Radiation-induced Atelectasis results from radiation therapy affecting lung tissue."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION-INDUCED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion-induced Atelectasis occurs due to fluid accumulation compressing the lungs."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX-INDUCED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax-induced Atelectasis is caused by the collapse of lung tissue due to a pneumothorax."

entities.name: "ASPIRATION-INDUCED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Aspiration-induced Atelectasis results from inhaling foreign material into the lungs."

entities.name: "DRUG-INDUCED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Drug-induced Atelectasis is caused by certain medications affecting lung function."

<key id="d3" for="edge" attr.name="weight" attr.type="double" />  <key id="d2" for="node" attr.name="source_id" attr.type="string" />  <key id="d1" for="node" attr.name="description" attr.type="string" />  <key id="d0" for="node" attr.name="type" attr.type="string" />  <graph edgedefault="undirected">    <node id=""ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Atelectasis is the collapse or closure of a lung resulting in reduced or absent gas exchange."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""RESORPTIVE (OBSTRUCTIVE) ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Resorptive Atelectasis occurs due to the obstruction of bronchi preventing lung inflation."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""PASSIVE (RELAXATION) ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Passive Atelectasis happens when the lung cannot expand fully due to a lack of air entering the alveoli."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Compressive Atelectasis occurs when pressure from other structures collapses the lung tissue."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""CICATRISATION ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cicatrisation Atelectasis results from scarring that obstructs the expansion of the lung tissue."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""ADHESIVE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Adhesive Atelectasis happens when the alveoli collapse due to the attraction of their inner surfaces."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""GRAVITY DEPENDANT ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Gravity Dependent Atelectasis is influenced by changes in body position leading to lung collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""MORPHOLOGY-BASED ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Morphology-based Atelectasis involves the collapse of lung tissue based on its structure and form."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""LINEAR ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Linear Atelectasis is characterized by the collapse of lung tissue in a linear pattern."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""SEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Segmental Atelectasis refers to the collapse of a segment of the lung, affecting a specific region."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""SUBSEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Subsegmental Atelectasis involves the collapse of a smaller portion of a lung segment."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""ROUND ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Round Atelectasis forms a rounded or disc-shaped area of collapsed lung tissue."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""OSTEOPHYTE INDUCED ADJACENT PULMONARY ATELECTASIS AND FIBROSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Osteophyte Induced Atelectasis occurs when bone spurs cause the collapse of nearby lung tissue with scarring."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""LOBAR LUNG COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lobar Lung Collapse results in the collapse of an entire lobe of the lung due to various factors."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Upper Lobe Collapse specifically affects the upper lobe of the right lung, leading to collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Middle Lobe Collapse targets the middle lobe of the right lung, causing collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Lower Lobe Collapse involves the collapse of the lower lobe of the right lung."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Upper Lobe Collapse results in collapse of the upper lobe of the left lung."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Lower Lobe Collapse leads to collapse of the lower lobe of the left lung."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""MULTIFOCAL ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Multifocal Atelectasis refers to the collapse of multiple areas within the lungs simultaneously."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Atelectasis is a term commonly used to describe the collapse of lung tissue."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""NEONATAL ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Neonatal Atelectasis occurs in newborns and is characterized by the collapse of lung tissue."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""ACUTE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Acute Atelectasis refers to the rapid onset of lung collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHRONIC ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chronic Atelectasis describes long-term or persistent lung collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""RECURRENT ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Recurrent Atelectasis involves multiple episodes of lung collapse."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""SECONDARY ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Secondary Atelectasis occurs as a result of another underlying condition or disease."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""POSTOPERATIVE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Postoperative Atelectasis develops <data key="d1">"Traumatic Atelectasis is caused by physical injury to the chest or lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""RADIATION-INDUCED  <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pneumothorax-induced Atelectasis is caused by the collapse of lung tissue due to a pneumothorax."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""ASPIRATION-INDUCED ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Aspiration-induced Atelectasis results from inhaling foreign material into the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <node id=""DRUG-INDUCED ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Drug-induced Atelectasis is caused by certain medications affecting lung function."</data>      <data key="d2">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </node>    <edge source=""ATELECTASIS"" target=""RESORPTIVE (OBSTRUCTIVE) ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Resorptive Atelectasis can lead to a general collapse of lung tissue."</data>      <data key="d5">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""RESORPTIVE (OBSTRUCTIVE) ATELECTASIS"" target=""PASSIVE (RELAXATION) ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"The obstruction causing Resorptive Atelectasis may contribute to Passive Atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d5">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"" target=""CICATRISATION ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Scarring can result in Compressive Atelectasis due to <edge source=""ROUND ATELECTASIS"" target=""OSTEOPHYTE INDUCED ADJACENT PULMONARY ATELECTASIS AND FIBROSIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Osteophyte-induced lung damage can key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Right Upper Lobe Collapse can be part of a broader Lobar Lung Collapse scenario."</data>      <data key="d5">76618b9d5bda6f4686db2102603098cc</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE COLLAPSE"" target=""RIGHT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Collapse in the Right Middle Lobe can affect anatomically COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Symmetrical lung damage may occur between the Left Upper and Lower Lobes."</data>      <data entities.name: "HRCT"
entities.description: "HRCT refers to High-Resolution Computed Tomography, a medical imaging technique used to visualize the lungs in detail."

entities.name: "SECONDARY PULMONARY LOBULE"
entities.description: "The secondary pulmonary lobule is a structural unit within the lung, important for understanding lung anatomy."

entities.name: "LUNG NODULES"
entities.description: "Lung nodules are small masses or lesions in the lung, which can be benign or malignant."

entities.name: "GROUND-GLASS NODULES"
entities.description: "Ground-glass nodules are a type of lung nodule with hazy appearance on imaging, commonly seen in certain lung conditions."

entities.name: "CALCIFIED LUNG NODULES"
entities.description: "Calcified lung nodules are lung nodules that have become calcified, often a result of previous infections or scarring."

entities.name: "BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Bronchitis is an inflammation of the bronchial tubes, leading to cough and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by abnormal widening of the bronchi, leading to mucus buildup and recurrent infections."

entities.name: "CYSTIC FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to breathing difficulties and other complications."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, often caused by a blood clot."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, causing cough, fever, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "ASTHMA"
entities.description: "Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition that leads to inflammation and narrowing of the airways, causing breathing difficulties and wheezing."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "COPD is a progressive lung disease that causes breathing-related problems, such as chronic bronchitis and emphysema."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is a condition in which all or part of a lung becomes airless and collapses, leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural effusion is a buildup of excess fluid between the layers of the pleura outside the lungs, causing chest pain and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS)"
entities.description: "ARDS is a severe lung condition that causes fluid to accumulate in the lungs, leading to low oxygen levels in the blood."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary edema is a condition caused by excess fluid buildup in the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and reduced oxygen levels in the blood."

chunk:
atelectasis is the partial collapse or closure of a lung resulting in reduced or absent gas exchange. it is usually unilateral, affecting part or all of one lung. it is a condition where the alveoli are deflated down to little or no volume, as distinct from pulmonary consolidation, in which they are filled with liquid. it is often referred to informally as a collapsed lung, although more accurately it usually involves only a partial collapse, and that ambiguous term is also informally used for a fully collapsed lung caused by a pneumothorax.
it is a very common finding in chest x-rays and other radiological studies, and may be caused by normal exhalation or by various medical conditions. although frequently described as a collapse of lung tissue, atelectasis is not synonymous with a pneumothorax, which is a more specific condition that can cause atelectasis. acute atelectasis may occur as a post-operative complication or as a result of surfactant deficiency. in premature babies, this leads to infant respiratory distress syndrome.
the term uses combining forms of atel- + ectasis, from greek: ateles, "incomplete" + ektasis, "extension".
== signs and symptoms ==
may have no signs and symptoms or they may include:
cough, but not prominent;
chest pain (not common);
breathing difficulty (fast and shallow);
low oxygen saturation;
pleural effusion (transudate type);
cyanosis (late sign);
increased heart rate.
it is a common misconception and pure speculation that atelectasis causes fever. a study of 100 post-op patients followed with serial chest x-rays and temperature measurements showed that the incidence of fever decreased as the incidence of atelectasis increased. a recent review article summarizing the available published evidence on the association between atelectasis and post-op fever concluded that there is no clinical evidence supporting this speculation.
== causes ==
the most common cause is post-surgical atelectasis, characterized by splinting, i.e. restricted breathing after abdominal surgery. atelectasis develops in 75-90% of people undergoing general anesthesia for a surgical procedure.
another common cause is pulmonary tuberculosis. smokers and the elderly are also at an increased risk. outside of this context, atelectasis implies some blockage of a bronchiole or bronchus, which can be within the airway (foreign body, mucus plug), from the wall (tumor, usually squamous cell carcinoma) or compressing from the outside (tumor, lymph node, tubercle). another cause is poor surfactant spreading during inspiration, causing the surface tension to be at its highest which tends to collapse smaller alveoli. atelectasis may also occur during suction, as along with sputum, air is withdrawn from the lungs. there are several types of atelectasis according to their underlying mechanisms or the distribution of alveolar collapse; resorption, compression, microatelectasis and contraction atelectasis. relaxation atelectasis (also called passive atelectasis) is when a pleural effusion or a pneumothorax disrupts the contact between the parietal and visceral pleurae.
risk factors associated with increased likelihood of the development of atelectasis include: type of surgery (thoracic, cardiopulmonary surgeries), use of muscle relaxation, obesity, high oxygen, the lower lung segments.
factors also associated with the development of atelectasis include: age, presence of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or asthma, and type of anesthetic.
in the early 1950s, in uk aviation medicine, the condition acceleration atelectasis was given the name "hunter lung" due to its prevalence in pilots of the transonic fighter jet, the hawker hunter, which used a 100% oxygen supply.
== diagnosis ==
clinically significant atelectasis is generally visible on chest x-ray; findings can include lung opacification and/or loss of lung volume. post-surgical atelectasis will be bibasal in pattern. chest ct or bronchoscopy may be necessary if the cause of

chunk:
prune belly syndrome is a rare, genetic birth defect affecting about 1 in 40,000 births. about 97% of those affected are male. prune belly syndrome is a congenital disorder of the urinary system, characterized by a triad of symptoms. the syndrome is named for the mass of wrinkled skin that is often (but not always) present on the abdomen of those with the disorder.
== signs and symptoms ==
prune-belly triad consists of signs such as:
a partial or complete lack of abdominal wall muscles. there may be wrinkly folds of skin covering the abdomen.
cryptorchidism (undescended testicles) in males
urinary tract abnormality such as unusually large ureters, distended bladder, accumulation and backflow of urine from the bladder to the ureters and the kidneys (vesicoureteral reflux)
other signs include:
frequent urinary tract infections due to the inability to properly expel urine.
ventricular septal defect
malrotation of the gut
club foot
later in life, a common symptom is post-ejaculatory discomfort. most likely a bladder spasm, it lasts about two hours.
musculoskeletal abnormalities include pectus excavatum, scoliosis, and congenital joint dislocations including the hip. diagnosis of prune belly syndrome necessitates a thorough orthopaedic evaluation because of the high prevalence of associated musculoskeletal abnormalities.
pulmonary hypoplasia, pneumonia, and atelectasis involving lung lobes
=== complications ===
prune belly syndrome can result in distention and enlargement of internal organs such as the bladder and intestines. surgery is often required but will not return the organs to a normal size. bladder reductions have shown that the bladder will again stretch to its previous size due to lack of muscle. complications may also arise from enlarged/malformed kidneys, which may result in kidney failure and the child's going on dialysis or requiring a kidney transplant. many individuals with prune belly syndrome have good physical and mental health, despite all the concerns. with proper treatment, however, a longer, healthier life is possible.
== diagnosis ==
prune belly syndrome can be diagnosed via ultrasound while a child is still in-utero. urinary tract dilation, bladder outlet obstruction, distended bladder wall and an abnormally large abdominal cavity with deficient abdominal wall musculature are key indicators, as the abdomen swells with the pressure of accumulated urine.
in young children, frequent urinary tract infections often herald prune belly syndrome, as they are normally uncommon. if a problem is suspected, doctors can perform blood tests to check renal function. another study that may suggest the syndrome is a voiding cystourethrogram.
pbs is far more common in males. autosomal recessive inheritance has been suggested in some cases. a homozygous mutation in the muscarinic cholinergic receptor-3 gene (chrm3) on chromosome 1q43 was reported in one family.
== treatment ==
the type of treatment, like that of most disorders, depends on the severity of the symptoms. one option is to perform a vesicostomy, which allows the bladder to drain through a small hole in the abdomen, thus helping to prevent urinary tract infections. similarly, consistent self-catheterization, often several times per day, can be an effective approach to preventing infections. a more drastic procedure is a surgical "remodeling" of the abdominal wall and urinary tract. boys often need to undergo an orchiopexy to move the testes to their proper place in the scrotum.
== references ==
== external links ==

entities.name: "PRUNE BELLY SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Prune Belly Syndrome is a rare genetic birth defect affecting the urinary system, characterized by a triad of symptoms and musculoskeletal abnormalities."

entities.name: "ABDOMINAL WALL MUSCLES"
entities.description: "Partial or complete lack of abdominal wall muscles is a key symptom of Prune Belly Syndrome."

entities.name: "CRYPTORCHIDISM"
entities.description: "Cryptorchidism, or undescended testicles, is a common symptom in males with Prune Belly Syndrome."

entities.name: "URINARY TRACT ABNORMALITY"
entities.description: "Urinary tract abnormality, such as distended bladder and vesicoureteral reflux, is a symptom of Prune Belly Syndrome."

entities.name: "FREUQENT URINARY TRACT INFECTIONS"
entities.description: "Frequent urinary tract infections are common due to the inability to properly expel urine in individuals with Prune Belly Syndrome."

entities.name: "MUSCULOSKELETAL ABNORMALITIES"
entities.description: "Musculoskeletal abnormalities, including pectus excavatum and scoliosis, are associated symptoms of Prune Belly Syndrome."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPOPLASIA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary hypoplasia is a complication involving the lungs in individuals with Prune Belly Syndrome."

entities.name: "VENTRICULAR SEPTAL DEFECT"
entities.description: "Ventricular septal defect is a potential symptom in individuals with Prune Belly Syndrome."

entities.name: "KIDNEY FAILURE"
entities.description: "Kidney failure is a potential complication due to enlarged/malformed kidneys in individuals with Prune Belly Syndrome."

entities.name: "DIALYSIS"
entities.description: "Dialysis may be required for individuals with Prune Belly Syndrome who experience kidney failure."

entities.name: "DIAGNOSIS METHODS"
entities.description: "Diagnosis of Prune Belly Syndrome can be done via ultrasound, blood tests, and voiding cystourethrogram to check for key indicators like urinary tract dilation and abdominal wall musculature."

entities.name: "TREATMENT OPTIONS"
entities.description: "Treatment options for Prune Belly Syndrome include vesicostomy, self-catheterization, surgical abdominal wall remodeling, and orchiopexy for boys with the disorder."

entities.name: "TRIAD OF SYMPTOMS"
entities.description: "Prune Belly Syndrome is characterized by a triad of symptoms, including partial or complete lack of abdominal wall muscles, urinary tract abnormality, and cryptorchidism."

entities.name: "ENLARGED KIDNEYS"
entities.description: "Enlarged kidneys are a common feature in individuals with Prune Belly Syndrome and can lead to complications like kidney failure."

entities.name: "GENITOURINARY ANOMALIES"
entities.description: "Prune Belly Syndrome is associated with genitourinary anomalies such as undescended testicles, dilated ureters, and abnormal bladder function."

entities.name: "MULTIPLE ORGAN SYSTEMS"
entities.description: "Prune Belly Syndrome affects multiple organ systems, including the urinary, musculoskeletal, and respiratory systems."

entities.name: "MALE INFERTILITY"
entities.description: "Male infertility can be a result of complications related to Prune Belly Syndrome, such as cryptorchidism and genitourinary abnormalities."

entities.name: "CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE"
entities.description: "Chronic renal failure is a potential long-term complication in individuals with Prune Belly Syndrome due to the impact on kidney function."

entities.name: "GASTROINTESTINAL ISSUES"
entities.description: "Gastrointestinal issues, such as malrotation of the intestines, can occur in individuals with Prune Belly Syndrome due to the abdominal wall muscle deficiency."

entities.name: "BLADDER FUNCTION PROBLEMS"
entities.description: "Bladder function problems, like urinary retention and incontinence, are common in individuals with Prune Belly Syndrome."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY COMPLICATIONS"
entities.description: "Respiratory complications, such as respiratory distress syndrome, can occur in newborns with Prune Belly Syndrome due to underdeveloped lungs."

chunk:
william pasteur (1855-1943) was a british physician and pioneer of pulmonology.
== biography ==
after education at the cram school philberds, maidenhead, and at university college, london, william pasteur qualified mrcs in 1880 from university college hospital and became a house physician there. he graduated m.b. (lond.) in 1882. after postgraduate study at vienna clinics, he graduated md in 1884.
he then accepted a registrar's post at the middlesex hospital, which he continued to serve throughout his career as assistant physician, full physician and consulting physician, lecturer on forensic medicine, hygiene and medicine, and dean of the medical school. another lifelong association was with the queen's hospital for children, hackney, which elected him as its physician and consulting physician. a fluent speaker of french and german, he was also physician to the french hospital for some years.
he was elected frcp in 1891. he gave the bradshaw lecture in 1908. on 15 may 1911 he delivered his presidential address to the medical society of london on post-operative lung complications. during wwi he served from 1914 to 1918, at the rouen base with the temporary rank of colonel, army medical services, as consultant physician to the british armies in france. his predecessor in that post was james kingston fowler. for his military service, pasteur was mentioned in dispatches and was appointed cb in 1918 and cmg in 1919. wwi gave him many opportunities for studying gunshot wounds to the chest.
thoracic disease was the main -- although not the only -- field of his private researches. his bradshaw lecture of 1908 discussed massive collapse of the lung after operation, a condition to which he referred again in an article in 1914 and one which, indeed, owed its discovery and description to pasteur.
he was a member of the athenaeum club and the alpine club.
== family ==
william pasteur's parents emigrated from switzerland to england. in 1890 william pasteur married violet mabel seddon. they had two daughters and a son. their son, william raymond pasteur, was born in 1896. he became a captain in the british army, was killed in action on 10 july 1917 in west flanders, and was awarded the military cross.
== atelectasis ==
atelectasis (at-uh-lek-tuh-sis) is a complete or partial collapse of the entire lung or area (lobe) of the lung. it occurs when the tiny air sacs (alveoli) within the lung become deflated or possibly filled with alveolar fluid. atelectasis is one of the most common breathing (respiratory) complications after surgery. it's also a possible complication of other respiratory problems, including cystic fibrosis, lung tumors, chest injuries, fluid in the lung and respiratory weakness. you may develop atelectasis if you breathe in a foreign object.
the term atelectasis pulmonum was introduced in 1832 by the physician eduard jorg (1808-1878), whose father was johann christian gottfried jorg (1779-1856), leipzig professor of medicine, specializing in obstetrics, gynecology, and pediatrics. clinical interest in atelectasis was stimulated by william pasteur's presentation in 1890.
== selected publications ==
with solomon solis-cohen: "spontaneous pneumothorax and pneumo-pericardium". the american journal of the medical sciences. 103 (2). philadelphia: 193-194. february 1892.
"a case of myxoedema supervening on graves' disease". transact. of the clin. soc. of london. 33: 189-192. 1900.
pasteur, w. (1908). "acute anterior poliomyelitis with permanent paralysis of the diaphragm and abdominal muscles". proc r soc med. 1(clin sect (clin sect): 51-53. pmc 2046132. pmid 19972761.
pasteur, w. (1910). "discussion on pericarditis with effusion, as determined by operation or post-mortem examination". proc r soc med. 3(med sect) (med sect): 82-83. pmc 1961194. pmid 19974488.
"active lobar collapse of the lung after abdominal operation". the lancet. 176 (4545): 1080-1083. 8 october 1910. doi:10.1016/s0140-6736(01)33673-5.

chunk:
streptococcal pharyngitis, also known as streptococcal sore throat (strep throat), is pharyngitis (an infection of the pharynx, the back of the throat) caused by streptococcus pyogenes, a gram-positive, group a streptococcus. common symptoms include fever, sore throat, red tonsils, and enlarged lymph nodes in the front of the neck. a headache and nausea or vomiting may also occur. some develop a sandpaper-like rash which is known as scarlet fever. symptoms typically begin one to three days after exposure and last seven to ten days.
strep throat is spread by respiratory droplets from an infected person, spread by talking, coughing or sneezing, or by touching something that has droplets on it and then touching the mouth, nose, or eyes. as with all respiratory pathogens once presumed to transmit via respiratory droplets, it is highly likely to be carried by the aerosols generated during routine breathing, talking, and even singing. it may be spread directly through touching infected sores. it may also be spread by contact with skin infected with group a strep. the diagnosis is made based on the results of a rapid antigen detection test or throat culture. some people may carry the bacteria without symptoms.
prevention is with airborne precautions, frequent hand washing, and not sharing eating utensils. there is no vaccine for the disease. treatment with antibiotics is only recommended in those with a confirmed diagnosis. those infected should stay away from other people until fever is gone and for at least 12 hours after starting treatment. pain can be treated with paracetamol (acetaminophen) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen.
strep throat is a common bacterial infection in children. it is the cause of 15-40% of sore throats among children and 5-15% among adults. cases are more common in late winter and early spring. potential complications include rheumatic fever and peritonsillar abscess.
== signs and symptoms ==
the typical signs and symptoms of streptococcal pharyngitis are a sore throat, fever of greater than 38 degc (100 degf), tonsillar exudates (pus on the tonsils), and large cervical lymph nodes.
other symptoms include: headache, nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain, muscle pain, or a scarlatiniform rash or palatal petechiae, the latter being an uncommon but highly specific finding.
symptoms typically begin one to three days after exposure and last seven to ten days.
strep throat is unlikely when any of the symptoms of red eyes, hoarseness, runny nose, or mouth ulcers are present. it is also unlikely when there is no fever.
== cause ==
strep throat is caused by group a b-hemolytic streptococcus (gas or s. pyogenes). humans are the primary natural reservoir for group a streptococcus. other bacteria such as non-group a b-hemolytic streptococci and fusobacterium may also cause pharyngitis. it is spread by direct, close contact with an infected person; thus crowding, as may be found in the military and schools, increases the rate of transmission. dried bacteria in dust are not infectious, although moist bacteria on toothbrushes or similar items can persist for up to fifteen days. contaminated food can result in outbreaks, but this is rare. of children with no signs or symptoms, 12% carry gas in their pharynx, and, after treatment, approximately 15% of those remain positive, and are true "carriers".
== diagnosis ==
a number of scoring systems exist to help with diagnosis; however, their use is controversial due to insufficient accuracy. the modified centor criteria are a set of five criteria; the total score indicates the probability of a streptococcal infection.
one point is given for each of the criteria:
absence of a cough
swollen and tender cervical lymph nodes
temperature >38.0 degc (100.4 degf)
tonsillar exudate or swelling
age less than 15 (a point is subtracted if age >44)
a score of one may indicate no treatment or culture is needed or i

chunk:
pneumothorax ex vacuo is a rare type of pneumothorax which forms adjacent to an atelectatic lobe. it is seen preferentially with atelectasis of the right upper lobe and is the result of rapid atelectasis producing an abrupt decrease in the intrapleural pressure with subsequent release of nitrogen from pleural capillaries.
treatment consists of bronchoscopy rather than chest tube drainage. radiographically, pneumothorax ex vacuo is suggested when an atelectatic lobe or lung, particularly right upper lobe atelectasis, is surrounded by a focal pneumothorax.
== related illness ==
"trapped lung" presents in the same way as pneumothorax ex vacuo and can occur in patients with visceral pleural thickening and following drainage of an effusion.
== references ==

entities.name: "TRAPPED LUNG"
entities.description: "Trapped Lung presents similar to pneumothorax ex vacuo and can occur in patients with visceral pleural thickening and following drainage of an effusion."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "A pleural effusion is an abnormal collection of fluid between the thin layers of tissue that line the lungs and chest cavity, which can lead to complications such as trapped lung."

chunk:
the thorax (pl.: thoraces or thoraxes) or chest is a part of the anatomy of mammals and other tetrapod animals located between the neck and the abdomen. in insects, crustaceans, and the extinct trilobites, the thorax is one of the three main divisions of the creature's body, each of which is in turn composed of multiple segments.
the human thorax includes the thoracic cavity and the thoracic wall. it contains organs including the heart, lungs, and thymus gland, as well as muscles and various other internal structures. many diseases may affect the chest, and one of the most common symptoms is chest pain.
== etymology ==
the word thorax comes from the greek thorax thorax "breastplate, cuirass, corslet" via latin: thorax.
== human thorax ==
=== structure ===
in humans and other hominids, the thorax is the chest region of the body between the neck and the abdomen, along with its internal organs and other contents. it is mostly protected and supported by the rib cage, spine, and shoulder girdle.
==== contents ====
the contents of the thorax include the heart and lungs (and the thymus gland); the major and minor pectoral muscles, trapezius muscles, and neck muscle; and internal structures such as the diaphragm, the esophagus, the trachea, and a part of the sternum known as the xiphoid process. arteries and veins are also contained - (aorta, superior vena cava, inferior vena cava and the pulmonary artery); bones (the shoulder socket containing the upper part of the humerus, the scapula, sternum, thoracic portion of the spine, collarbone, and the rib cage and floating ribs).
external structures are the skin and nipples.
==== the chest ====
in the human body, the region of the thorax between the neck and diaphragm in the front of the body is called the chest. the corresponding area in an animal can also be referred to as the chest.
the shape of the chest does not correspond to that part of the thoracic skeleton that encloses the heart and lungs. all the breadth of the shoulders is due to the shoulder girdle, and contains the axillae and the heads of the humeri. in the middle line the suprasternal notch is seen above, while about three fingers' breadth below it a transverse ridge can be felt, which is known as the sternal angle and this marks the junction between the manubrium and body of the sternum. level with this line the second ribs join the sternum, and when these are found the lower ribs can often be counted. at the lower part of the sternum, where the seventh or last true ribs join it, the ensiform cartilage begins, and above this there is often a depression known as the pit of the stomach.
==== bones ====
the bones of the thorax, called the "thoracic skeleton" is a component of the axial skeleton.
it consists of the ribs and sternum. the ribs of the thorax are numbered in ascending order from 1-12. 11 and 12 are known as floating ribs because they have no anterior attachment point in particular the cartilage attached to the sternum, as 1 through 7 are, and therefore are termed "floating". whereas ribs 8 through 10 are termed false ribs as their costal cartilage articulates with the costal cartilage of the rib above. the thorax bones also have the main function of protecting the heart, lungs, and major blood vessels in the thorax area, such as the aorta.
==== anatomical landmarks ====
the anatomy of the chest can also be described through the use of anatomical landmarks. the nipple in the male is situated in front of the fourth rib or a little below; vertically it lies a little external to a line drawn down from the middle of the clavicle; in the female it is not so constant. a little below it the lower limit of the great pectoral muscle is seen running upward and outward to the axilla; in the female this is obscured by the breast, which extends from the second to the sixth rib vertically and from the edge of the sternum to the mid-axillary line laterally. the female nipple is surrounded for half an inch by a more

chunk:
postpartum infections, also known as childbed fever and puerperal fever, are any bacterial infections of the female reproductive tract following childbirth or miscarriage. signs and symptoms usually include a fever greater than 38.0 degc (100.4 degf), chills, lower abdominal pain, and possibly bad-smelling vaginal discharge. it usually occurs after the first 24 hours and within the first ten days following delivery.
the most common infection is that of the uterus and surrounding tissues known as puerperal sepsis, postpartum metritis, or postpartum endometritis. risk factors include caesarean section (c-section), the presence of certain bacteria such as group b streptococcus in the vagina, premature rupture of membranes, multiple vaginal exams, manual removal of the placenta, and prolonged labour among others. most infections involve a number of types of bacteria. diagnosis is rarely helped by culturing of the vagina or blood. in those who do not improve, medical imaging may be required. other causes of fever following delivery include breast engorgement, urinary tract infections, infections of an abdominal incision or an episiotomy, and atelectasis.
due to the risks following caesarean section, it is recommended that all women receive a preventive dose of antibiotics such as ampicillin around the time of surgery. treatment of established infections is with antibiotics, with most people improving in two to three days. in those with mild disease, oral antibiotics may be used; otherwise intravenous antibiotics are recommended. common antibiotics include a combination of ampicillin and gentamicin following vaginal delivery or clindamycin and gentamicin in those who have had a c-section. in those who are not improving with appropriate treatment, other complications such as an abscess should be considered.
in 2015, about 11.8 million maternal infections occurred. in the developed world about 1% to 2% develop uterine infections following vaginal delivery. this increases to 5% to 13% among those who have more difficult deliveries and 50% with c-sections before the use of preventive antibiotics. in 2015, these infections resulted in 17,900 deaths down from 34,000 deaths in 1990. they are the cause of about 10% of deaths around the time of pregnancy. the first known descriptions of the condition date back to at least the 5th century bce in the writings of hippocrates. these infections were a very common cause of death around the time of childbirth starting in at least the 18th century until the 1930s when antibiotics were introduced. in 1847, hungarian physician ignaz semmelweiss decreased death from the disease in the first obstetrical clinic of vienna from nearly 20% to 2% through the use of handwashing with calcium hypochlorite.
== signs and symptoms ==
signs and symptoms usually include a fever greater than 38.0 degc (100.4 degf), chills, low abdominal pain, and possibly bad-smelling vaginal discharge. it usually occurs after the first 24 hours and within the first ten days following delivery.
== causes ==
after childbirth, a woman's genital tract has a large bare surface, which is prone to infection. infection may be limited to the cavity and wall of her uterus, or it may spread beyond to cause septicaemia (blood poisoning) or other illnesses, especially when her resistance has been lowered by long labour or severe bleeding. puerperal infection is most common on the raw surface of the interior of the uterus after separation of the placenta (afterbirth), but pathogenic organisms may also affect lacerations of any part of the genital tract. by whatever portal, they can invade the bloodstream and lymph system to cause sepsis, cellulitis (inflammation of connective tissue), and pelvic or generalized peritonitis (inflammation of the abdominal lining). the severity of the illness depends on the virulence of the infecting organism, the resistance of the invaded tissues, and the general health of the woman. organisms commonly producing this in

entities.name: "POSTPARTUM INFECTIONS"
entities.description: "Postpartum Infections, also known as childbed fever and puerperal fever, are bacterial infections of the female reproductive tract following childbirth or miscarriage. Common signs and symptoms include fever, chills, abdominal pain, and bad-smelling discharge. It often occurs within the first ten days post-delivery."

entities.name: "PUERPERAL SEPSIS"
entities.description: "Puerperal Sepsis is the most common infection involving the uterus and surrounding tissues following childbirth. It is also known as postpartum metritis or postpartum endometritis."

entities.name: "GROUP B STREPTOCOCCUS"
entities.description: "Group B Streptococcus is a bacteria that can increase the risk of postpartum infections, especially after a caesarean section."

entities.name: "ANTIBIOTICS"
entities.description: "Antibiotics are used in the treatment and prevention of postpartum infections, with common options including ampicillin and gentamicin."

entities.name: "CHILDBIRTH"
entities.description: "Childbirth, also known as labor and delivery, is the process by which a baby is born from the mother's uterus. It can be a natural or assisted process, including vaginal delivery or caesarean section."

entities.name: "MISCARRIAGE"
entities.description: "Miscarriage, also known as spontaneous abortion, is the loss of a pregnancy before the 20th week. It can occur due to various factors, such as genetic abnormalities or maternal health conditions."

entities.name: "UTERUS"
entities.description: "The uterus, or womb, is a hollow, pear-shaped organ where fetal development occurs during pregnancy. It plays a crucial role in menstruation, conception, and childbirth."

entities.name: "ABDOMINAL PAIN"
entities.description: "Abdominal pain is a common symptom of postpartum infections, often indicating inflammation or infection in the reproductive tract. It can range from mild discomfort to severe cramping."

synonyms:
atelectasis of the middle ear
middle ear atelectasis refers to reduction in volume of the middle ear cavity and is sometimes considered a stage of tympanic membrane retraction (stage iii).

entities.name: "MIDDLE EAR ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Middle Ear Atelectasis refers to reduction in volume of the middle ear cavity and is sometimes considered a stage of tympanic membrane retraction (stage iii)."

entities.name: "TYMPANIC MEMBRANE RETRACTION"
entities.description: "Tympanic Membrane Retraction is associated with Middle Ear Atelectasis as a potential stage of the condition."

entities.name: "OTITIS MEDIA"
entities.description: "Middle Ear Atelectasis is commonly associated with Otitis Media, an infection of the middle ear."

entities.name: "HEARING LOSS"
entities.description: "Middle Ear Atelectasis can result in Hearing Loss due to decreased sound conduction through the middle ear cavity."

the silent sinus syndrome represents maxillary sinus atelectasis that results in painless enophthalmos, hypoglobus and facial asymmetry 1-3. some authors restrict the term to patients with no history of sinusitis, trauma or surgery 2. some authors suggest that is part of the spectrum of chronic maxillary atelectasis 6.

clinical presentation
pathology
radiographic features
treatment and prognosis

related articles
