images:cases and figures
epidemiologysilent sinus syndrome usually presents in the 3rd to 5th decade, without a gender predilection. in general, the condition is idiopathic. however, in a small number of patients, trauma to the lateral nasal wall and ostiomeatal complex may be the cause, e.g. endonasal intubation 1,2.clinical presentationthe presentation is typically with painless and usually relatively long-standing (months to years) facial asymmetry, enophthalmos of 2-5 mm, and hypoglobus 1-3. symptoms of sinusitis are not always present 1. when there is significant deformity of the orbital floor, patients may develop diplopia. however, extraocular movements are usually normal 2.pathologychronic occlusion of the maxillary sinus ostium/ostia results in gradual resorption of the air. subsequently, negative pressure is generated within the sinus 3. this, in turn, results in gradual inward bowing of all four of the maxillary walls: roof (orbital floor), medial, posterolateral and anterior walls. orbital volume increases with resultant enophthalmos and variable flattening of the malar eminence 1.a number of other hypotheses have been advanced, including inflammatory erosion and softening of walls due to chronic sinusitis; or sinusitis in a hypoplastic sinus 4. however, manometric measurement in a number of cases have confirmed the presence of negative pressures, as well as proof of normal-sized sinuses on previous imaging 3 - these make the latter two hypotheses unlikely.radiographic featuresalthough the diagnosis is usually made clinically, usually by otolaryngologists and ophthalmologists, imaging of the sinuses confirms the findings. additionally, the diagnosis may be made incidentally on imaging of the region for other reasons.plain radiographplain radiographs are no longer considered sufficiently sensitive or specific for the assessment of paranasal sinus disease. however, they are still not infrequently performed. the findings are the same as those seen on ct (see below).ctct, preferably performed as a volumetric acquisition with three-plane orthogonal reformats, is able to elegantly demonstrate changes in the sinus and the adjacent structures.the sinus is fully formed but fully opacified and reduced in volume with inward bowing of all four walls. this manifests as 1:
inferior bowing of the roof (orbital floor): increased orbital volume and enophthalmos
lateral bowing of the medial wall: lateral displacement of the middle and inferior turbinate
posterior bowing of the anterior wall: flattening of the malar eminence
anteromedial bowing of the posterolateral wall
the uncinate process is usually superiorly and laterally displaced, in direct contact with the inferomedial wall of the orbit, and the ostiomeatal complex is occluded 1.mrimri is not required for the diagnosis. if it is performed, it will demonstrate (in addition to the anatomical changes above) a fully opacified sinus with thickening and enhancement of the mucosa. the secretions are of variable intensity.treatment and prognosisthe condition is benign

entities.name: "SILENT SINUS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Silent Sinus Syndrome represents maxillary sinus atelectasis that results in painless enophthalmos, hypoglobus, and facial asymmetry. It usually presents in the 3rd to 5th decade without a gender predilection. The condition is typically idiopathic, but trauma to the lateral nasal wall and ostiomeatal complex can be a cause in some cases."

entities.name: "MAXILLARY SINUS"
entities.description: "Maxillary Sinus is fully formed but fully opacified and reduced in volume with inward bowing of all four walls. The condition manifests as features like increased orbital volume, enophthalmos, lateral displacement of the middle and inferior turbinate, flattening of the malar eminence."

entities.name: "TRAUMA"
entities.description: "Trauma to the lateral nasal wall and ostiomeatal complex can be a cause of Silent Sinus Syndrome in some cases."

entities.name: "ENDONASAL INTUBATION"
entities.description: "Endonasal Intubation is mentioned as a potential cause of trauma leading to Silent Sinus Syndrome."

entities.name: "HYPOGLOBUS"
entities.description: "Hypoglobus is a symptom of Silent Sinus Syndrome, defined as the downward displacement of the eyeball within the orbit without any pain or discomfort."

entities.name: "FACIAL ASYMMETRY"
entities.description: "Facial Asymmetry is a symptom of Silent Sinus Syndrome, presenting as an imbalance or lack of harmony in the facial features due to the condition affecting the maxillary sinus."

entities.name: "IDIOPATHIC"
entities.description: "Silent Sinus Syndrome is typically considered idiopathic, meaning that its exact cause is unknown or unclear in most cases."

entities.name: "OSTIOMEATAL COMPLEX"
entities.description: "The ostiomeatal complex is a critical anatomical region in the nose and sinuses, responsible for the drainage and ventilation of the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoid sinuses. Trauma to this complex can contribute to the development of Silent Sinus Syndrome."

entities.name: "LATERAL NASAL WALL"
entities.description: "The lateral nasal wall is an important structure that plays a role in the airflow and drainage within the nasal cavity. Trauma to this area can result in changes that lead to Silent Sinus Syndrome symptoms."

chunk:
the uncinate process is usually superiorly and laterally displaced, in direct contact with the inferomedial wall of the orbit, and the ostiomeatal complex is occluded 1.mrimri is not required for the diagnosis. if it is performed, it will demonstrate (in addition to the anatomical changes above) a fully opacified sinus with thickening and enhancement of the mucosa. the secretions are of variable intensity.treatment and prognosisthe condition is benign but may result in diplopia. treatment involves the creation of a drainage route for the sinus. this can be with a nasal antral window or maxillary antrostomy.once drainage is established, no further volume loss will develop. however, any deformity at the time of surgery will be permanent and may require surgical correction, especially if diplopia is present.differential diagnosisthe differential is usually small. however, conditions to be considered include:
congenital maxillary sinus hypoplasiamore common and does not present with a developing facial deformity
post-traumatic maxillary sinus deformity
inferior orbital decompression
mucocele: similar process but the expansion of sinus due to build-up of secretions
chronic sinusitis with mucoperiosteal thickening
references
1. illner a, davidson h, harnsberger h, hoffman j. the silent sinus syndrome: clinical and radiographic findings. ajr am j roentgenol. 2002;178(2):503-6. doi:10.2214/ajr.178.2.1780503 - pubmed
2. hobbs c, saunders m, potts m. "imploding antrum" or silent sinus syndrome following naso-tracheal intubation. br j ophthalmol. 2004;88(7):974-5. doi:10.1136/bjo.2003.035386 - pubmed
3. davidson j, soparkar c, williams j, patrinely j. negative sinus pressure and normal predisease imaging in silent sinus syndrome. arch ophthalmol. 1999;117(12):1653-4. - pubmed
4. eto r & house j. enophthalmos, a sequela of maxillary sinusitis. ajnr am j neuroradiol. 1995;16(4 suppl):939-41. pmc8332249 - pubmed
5. kilty s. maxillary sinus atelectasis (silent sinus syndrome): treatment with balloon sinuplasty. j laryngol otol. 2014;128(2):189-91. doi:10.1017/s0022215113003538 - pubmed
6. mangussi-gomes j, nakanishi m, chalita m, damasco f, de oliveira c. stage ii chronic maxillary atelectasis associated with subclinical visual field defect. int arch otorhinolaryngol. 2013;17(4):409-12. doi:10.1055/s-0033-1351679 - pubmed

{"current_user":null,"inclusions":[{"imageid":428046,"studyid":10126,"caseslug":"normal-ostiomeatal-complex-illustration","caption":"figure 1: normal ostiomeatal complex","isstack":false,"diagnosticcertainty":"not_applicable","thumbnail":"https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/428046/d69c

entities.name: "UNCINATE PROCESS"
entities.description: "The Uncinate Process is usually displaced in direct contact with the orbit wall and may result in diplopia, a symptom of the condition."

entities.name: "MRI"
entities.description: "MRI is a diagnostic tool that can show anatomical changes and opacification of the sinus in relation to the condition."

entities.name: "SINUS"
entities.description: "The Sinus exhibits thickening, enhancement of mucosa, and variable secretions, which are key features of the condition."

entities.name: "DIPLOPIA"
entities.description: "Diplopia is a symptom associated with the condition and may require surgical correction."

entities.name: "MAXILLARY ANTROSTOMY"
entities.description: "Maxillary Antrostomy is a treatment procedure to create a drainage route for the sinus in the condition."

entities.name: "CONGENITAL MAXILLARY SINUS HYPOPLASIA"
entities.description: "Congenital Maxillary Sinus Hypoplasia is a differential diagnosis with different presentation and implications compared to the condition."

entities.name: "OPHTHALMOLOGIC EXAMINATION"
entities.description: "Ophthalmologic Examination is often recommended to assess any visual disturbances caused by the condition."

entities.name: "ENDOSCOPIC SINUS SURGERY"
entities.description: "Endoscopic Sinus Surgery is a treatment option for severe cases of the condition that do not respond to other interventions."

entities.name: "NASAL ENDOSCOPY"
entities.description: "Nasal Endoscopy is used to visualize the nasal passages and sinus cavities to assess the extent of the condition and guide treatment."

entities.name: "FACIAL PAIN"
entities.description: "Facial Pain can be a symptom of the condition, often due to pressure and inflammation in the sinus cavities."

entities.name: "NASAL CONGESTION"
entities.description: "Nasal Congestion is a common symptom of the condition, caused by inflammation and blockage of the sinus passages."

entities.name: "COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY (CT) SCAN"
entities.description: "A Computed Tomography (CT) Scan is another imaging modality that can provide detailed information about the sinus anatomy and any abnormalities present in the condition."

entities.name: "SILENT SINUS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Silent Sinus Syndrome is a condition characterized by negative pressure within the maxillary sinus, leading to maxillary atelectasis."

entities.name: "NEGATIVE PRESSURE"
entities.description: "Negative Pressure refers to a symptom experienced in Silent Sinus Syndrome, indicating an abnormal condition within the maxillary sinus."

entities.name: "MAXILLARY ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Maxillary Atelectasis is a condition in which the maxillary sinus collapses or becomes airless, commonly associated with Silent Sinus Syndrome."

chunk:
oxygen therapy, also referred to as supplemental oxygen, is the use of oxygen as medical treatment. supplemental oxygen can also refer to the use of oxygen enriched air at altitude. acute indications for therapy include hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels), carbon monoxide toxicity and cluster headache. it may also be prophylactically given to maintain blood oxygen levels during the induction of anesthesia. oxygen therapy is often useful in chronic hypoxemia caused by conditions such as severe copd or cystic fibrosis. oxygen can be delivered via nasal cannula, face mask, or endotracheal intubation at normal atmospheric pressure, or in a hyperbaric chamber. it can also be given through bypassing the airway, such as in ecmo therapy.
oxygen is required for normal cellular metabolism. however, excessively high concentrations can result in oxygen toxicity, leading to lung damage and respiratory failure. higher oxygen concentrations can also increase the risk of airway fires, particularly while smoking. oxygen therapy can also dry out the nasal mucosa without humidification. in most conditions, an oxygen saturation of 94-96% is adequate, while in those at risk of carbon dioxide retention, saturations of 88-92% are preferred. in cases of carbon monoxide toxicity or cardiac arrest, saturations should be as high as possible. while air is typically 21% oxygen by volume, oxygen therapy can increase o2 content of air up to 100%.
the medical use of oxygen first became common around 1917, and is the most common hospital treatment in the developed world. it is currently on the world health organization's list of essential medicines. home oxygen can be provided either by oxygen tanks or oxygen concentrator.
== medical uses ==
oxygen is widely used by hospitals, ems, and first-aid providers in a variety of conditions and settings. a few indications frequently requiring high-flow oxygen include resuscitation, major trauma, anaphylaxis, major bleeding, shock, active convulsions, and hypothermia.
=== acute conditions ===
in context of acute hypoxemia, oxygen therapy should be titrated to a target level based on pulse oximetry (94-96% in most patients, or 88-92% in people with copd). this can be performed by increasing oxygen delivery, described as fio2(fraction of inspired oxygen). in 2018, the british medical journal recommended that oxygen therapy be stopped for saturations greater than 96% and not started for saturations above 90 to 93%. this may be due to an association between excessive oxygenation in the acutely ill and increased mortality. exceptions to these recommendations include carbon monoxide poisoning, cluster headaches, sickle cell crisis, and pneumothorax.
oxygen therapy has also been used as emergency treatment for decompression sickness for years. recompression in a hyperbaric chamber with 100% oxygen is the standard treatment for decompression illness. the success of recompression therapy is greatest if given within four hours after resurfacing, with earlier treatment associated with a decreased number of recompression treatments required for resolution. it has been suggested in literature that heliox may be a better alternative to oxygen therapy.
in the context of stroke, oxygen therapy may be beneficial as long as hyperoxic environments are avoided.
people receiving outpatient oxygen therapy for hypoxemia following acute illness or hospitalization should be re-assessed by a physician prior to prescription renewal to gauge the necessity of ongoing oxygen therapy. if the initial hypoxemia has resolved, additional treatment may be an unnecessary use of resources.
=== chronic conditions ===
common conditions which may require a baseline of supplementary oxygen include chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), chronic bronchitis, and emphysema. patients may also require additional oxygen during acute exacerbations. oxygen may also be prescribed for breathlessness, end-stage cardiac failure, respiratory failure, advance

entities.name: "OXYGEN THERAPY"
entities.description: "Oxygen Therapy is the medical treatment involving the use of oxygen. It is used in various acute and chronic conditions to maintain blood oxygen levels."

entities.name: "HYPOXEMIA"
entities.description: "Hypoxemia is a condition characterized by low blood oxygen levels, often requiring oxygen therapy for treatment."

entities.name: "CARBON MONOXIDE TOXICITY"
entities.description: "Carbon Monoxide Toxicity is a condition that may require oxygen therapy for treatment, as high concentrations of oxygen can help in such cases."

entities.name: "CLUSTER HEADACHE"
entities.description: "Cluster Headache is a condition where oxygen therapy can be used as a treatment option."

entities.name: "LUNG DAMAGE"
entities.description: "Lung Damage can result from oxygen toxicity caused by excessively high concentrations of oxygen during therapy."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY FAILURE"
entities.description: "Respiratory Failure can occur as a complication of oxygen toxicity, leading to the need for additional medical intervention."

entities.name: "AIRWAY FIRES"
entities.description: "Airway Fires are a risk associated with high concentrations of oxygen, especially in the presence of smoking."

entities.name: "NASAL MUCOSA"
entities.description: "Nasal Mucosa may dry out as a side effect of oxygen therapy, highlighting the need for humidification."

entities.name: "OXYGEN SATURATION LEVELS"
entities.description: "Oxygen Saturation Levels are monitored during oxygen therapy, with specific target ranges based on different clinical conditions."

entities.name: "WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION"
entities.description: "The World Health Organization lists oxygen therapy as an essential medicine, recognizing its importance in healthcare."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Oxygen Therapy is commonly used in the management of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) to improve oxygen levels."

entities.name: "ASTHMA"
entities.description: "During severe asthma attacks, Oxygen Therapy can be administered to help alleviate breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "EMPHYSEMA"
entities.description: "Emphysema, a type of COPD, may require Oxygen Therapy to assist in breathing and increase oxygen levels."

entities.name: "HEART FAILURE"
entities.description: "In cases of Heart Failure, Oxygen Therapy may be used to improve oxygenation of the body and alleviate symptoms."

entities.name: "OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNEA"
entities.description: "Oxygen Therapy is a treatment option for Obstructive Sleep Apnea to help maintain proper oxygen levels during sleep."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Patients with Pulmonary Fibrosis may benefit from Oxygen Therapy to improve breathing and oxygen saturation."

entities.name: "HIGH ALTITUDE SICKNESS"
entities.description: "High Altitude Sickness can be treated with Oxygen Therapy to alleviate symptoms and improve oxygen levels in the body."

entities.name: "ANEMIA"
entities.description: "Oxygen Therapy may be used in cases of severe Anemia to ensure the body receives an adequate supply of oxygen."

entities.name: "CYSTIC FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Patients with Cystic Fibrosis may require Oxygen Therapy to help with breathing and improve oxygen saturation levels."

entities.name: "POSTOPERATIVE CARE"
entities.description: "In postoperative care, Oxygen Therapy is often utilized to support patients during the recovery process."

key="d0">"DISEASE/SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Patients with Cystic Fibrosis may require Oxygen Therapy to help with breathing and improve oxygen saturation levels."</data>      <data key="d2">2591ff20a9b26d87698e858a66fa6192</data>    </node>    <node id=""POSTOPERATIVE CARE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE/SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"In postoperative care, Oxygen Therapy is often utilized to support patients during the recovery process."</data>      <data key="d2">2591ff20a9b26d87698e858a66fa6192</data>    </node>    <edge source=""OXYGEN THERAPY"" target=""HYPOXEMIA"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Oxygen Therapy is utilized to treat Hypoxemia by increasing blood oxygen levels."</data>      <data key="d5">2591ff20a9b26d87698e858a66fa6192</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""OXYGEN THERAPY"" target=""CARBON MONOXIDE TOXICITY"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Oxygen Therapy is used to address Carbon Monoxide Toxicity by providing additional oxygen."</data>      <data key="d5">2591ff20a9b26d87698e858a66fa6192</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""OXYGEN THERAPY"" target=""CLUSTER HEADACHE"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Oxygen Therapy can be a treatment option for Cluster Headaches, potentially alleviating symptoms."</data>      <data concentrations during therapy can lead to Lung Damage, highlighting a potential risk."</data>      <data key="d5">2591ff20a9b26d87698e858a66fa6192</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""OXYGEN THERAPY"" target=""RESPIRATORY FAILURE"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Respiratory Failure may necessitate additional oxygen therapy as part of the treatment plan."</data>      <data chunk:
ventilator-associated lung injury (vali) is an acute lung injury that develops during mechanical ventilation and is termed ventilator-induced lung injury (vili) if it can be proven that the mechanical ventilation caused the acute lung injury. in contrast, ventilator-associated lung injury (vali) exists if the cause cannot be proven. vali is the appropriate term in most situations because it is virtually impossible to prove what actually caused the lung injury in the hospital.
== cause ==
it is generally regarded, based on animal models and human studies, that volutrauma is the most harmful aspect of mechanical ventilation. this may be regarded as the over-stretching of the airways and alveoli.
during mechanical ventilation, the flow of gas into the lung will take the path of least resistance. areas of the lung that are collapsed (atelectasis) or filled with secretions will be underinflated, while those areas that are relatively normal will be overinflated. these areas will become overdistended and injured. this may be reduced by using smaller tidal volumes.
during positive pressure ventilation, atelectatic regions will inflate, however, the alveoli will be unstable and will collapse during the expiratory phase of the breath (atelectotrauma). this repeated alveolar collapse and expansion (race) is thought to cause vali. by opening the lung and keeping the lung open race (and vali) is reduced.
another possible ventilator-associated lung injury is known as biotrauma. biotrauma involves the lung suffering injury from any mediators of the inflammatory response or from bacteremia.
finally oxygen toxicity contributes to ventilator-associated lung injury through several mechanisms including oxidative stress.
possible reasons for predisposition to vali include:
an injured lung may be at risk for further injury
cyclic atelectasis is particularly common in an injured lung
== pathogenesis ==
overdistension of alveoli and cyclic atelectasis (atelectotrauma) are the primary causes for alveolar injury during positive pressure mechanical ventilation. severe injury to alveoli causes swelling of the tissues (edema) in the lungs, bleeding of the alveoli, loss of surfactant (decrease in lung compliance) and complete alveoli collapse (biotrauma). high flow rates are associated with rheotrauma, high volumes with volutrauma and pressures with barotrauma. collectively these may be converted into a single unit of mechanical power.
== diagnosis ==
vali does not need to be distinguished from progressive ali/ards because management is the same in both. additionally, definitive diagnosis of vali may not be possible because of lack of sign or symptoms.
== prevention ==
=== preventing alveolar overdistension ===
alveolar overdistension is mitigated by using small tidal volumes, maintaining a low plateau pressure, and most effectively by using volume-limited ventilation. a 2018 systematic review by the cochrane collaboration provided evidence that low tidal volume ventilation reduced post operative pneumonia and reduced the requirement for both invasive and non invasive ventilation after surgery
=== preventing cyclic atelectasis (atelectotrauma) ===
applied positive end-expiratory pressure (peep) is the principal method used to keep the alveoli open and lessen cyclic atelectasis.
=== open lung ventilation ===
open lung ventilation is a ventilatory strategy that combines small tidal volumes (to lessen alveolar overdistension) and an applied peep above the low inflection point on the pressure-volume curve (to lessen cyclic atelectasis).
high frequency ventilation is thought to reduce ventilator-associated lung injury, especially in the context of ards and acute lung injury.
permissive hypercapnia and hypoxaemia allow the patient to be ventilated at less aggressive settings and can, therefore, mitigate all forms of ventilator-associated lung injury
== epidemiology ==
vali is most common in people receiving mechanical ventilation for acute lun

entities.name: "VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED LUNG INJURY (VALI)"
entities.description: "VALI is an acute lung injury that develops during mechanical ventilation, with variations such as VILI and VALI depending on the cause of the injury and difficulty in proving the cause."

entities.name: "MECHANICAL VENTILATION"
entities.description: "Mechanical ventilation involves the flow of gas into the lung, with harmful aspects like volutrauma and atelectasis leading to lung injury."

entities.name: "VOLUTRAUMA"
entities.description: "Volutrauma is the over-stretching of the airways and alveoli, considered a harmful aspect of mechanical ventilation."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis refers to areas of the lung that are collapsed or filled with secretions, contributing to underinflation during mechanical ventilation."

entities.name: "BIOTRAUMA"
entities.description: "Biotrauma is a ventilator-associated lung injury caused by inflammatory mediators or bacteremia affecting the lung tissue."

entities.name: "INFLAMMATORY MEDIATORS"
entities.description: "Inflammatory mediators are signaling molecules that trigger an immune response, playing a role in lung injury like Biotrauma."

entities.name: "BACTEREMIA"
entities.description: "Bacteremia refers to the presence of bacteria in the bloodstream, a factor in causing lung injury such as Biotrauma."

entities.name: "AIRWAY TRAUMA"
entities.description: "Airway trauma involves damage to the air passages, which can occur during mechanical ventilation and contribute to lung injury."

entities.name: "ALVEOLAR DAMAGE"
entities.description: "Alveolar damage refers to harm or injury to the tiny air sacs in the lungs, which can result from mechanical ventilation and lead to lung issues like Volutrauma."

entities.name: "CHEMOTAXIS"
entities.description: "Chemotaxis is the movement of cells in response to chemical signals, a process that can contribute to lung injury and inflammation during mechanical ventilation."

entities.name: "BAROTRAUMA"
entities.description: "Barotrauma is physical damage to tissues caused by pressure changes, including damage that can occur in the lungs during mechanical ventilation."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a potentially serious complication that can arise during mechanical ventilation, involving the accumulation of air in the pleural space around the lungs."

entities.name: "HYPOXEMIA"
entities.description: "Hypoxemia is a condition of abnormally low levels of oxygen in the blood, a common issue that may occur during mechanical ventilation and contribute to patient complications."

entities.name: "HYPERCAPNIA"
entities.description: "Hypercapnia is a condition of elevated levels of carbon dioxide in the blood, which can occur during mechanical ventilation and impact patient respiratory function."

entities.name: "LUNG COMPLIANCE"
entities.description: "Lung compliance refers to the ability of the lung to expand and contract, with changes in compliance playing a role in lung issues associated with mechanical ventilation."

entities.name: "ARDS"
entities.description: "Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a severe lung condition that can be exacerbated by mechanical ventilation, leading to complications such as VALI and VILI."

entities.name: "POSITIVE END-EXPIRATORY PRESSURE (PEEP)"
entities.description: "PEEP is a setting on mechanical ventilators that applies pressure to the airways at the end of exhalation, helping to keep the lungs open and improve oxygenation."

entities.name: "TIDAL VOLUME"
entities.description: "Tidal volume refers to the amount of air moved in and out of the lungs during normal breathing or mechanical ventilation, with tidal volume settings impacting lung health."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY RATE"
entities.description: "Respiratory rate is the number of breaths taken per minute, a parameter that can be adjusted on mechanical ventilators to support patient respiratory function."

entities.name: "FIO2"
entities.description: "FiO2, or Fraction of Inspired Oxygen, is the percentage of oxygen in the gases delivered by a ventilator, a setting that influences patient oxygen levels."

entities.name: "PEEP VALVE"
entities.description:
"The PEEP valve is a component of mechanical ventilators that controls the positive end-expiratory pressure, crucial for maintaining lung inflation and oxygenation."
"The Peep Valve is a device used in mechanical ventilation to provide positive end-expiratory pressure, improving oxygenation and lung expansion."

entities.name: "LUNG INJURY SCORE"
entities.description: "The Lung Injury Score is a method used to assess the severity of lung damage in patients on mechanical ventilation, aiding in treatment decisions."

entities.name: "PEEP TITRATION"
entities.description: "PEEP titration is the process of adjusting the positive end-expiratory pressure settings on a mechanical ventilator to optimize lung recruitment and oxygen delivery."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED PNEUMONIA (VAP)"
entities.description: "Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia is a type of lung infection that can occur in patients on mechanical ventilation, contributing to respiratory complications."

entities.name: "AUTO-PEEP"
entities.description: "Auto-PEEP, or Intrinsic PEEP, is a phenomenon where air remains trapped in the lungs at the end of exhalation, potentially causing lung overdistension."

entities.name: "SEPSIS"
entities.description: "Sepsis is a severe condition resulting from the body's overwhelming response to infection, which can complicate the management of patients on mechanical ventilation."

entities.name: "HYPOTENSION"
entities.description: "Hypotension is low blood pressure, a condition that may occur in patients on mechanical ventilation due to various factors such as fluid shifts and medication effects."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR BUNDLE"
entities.description: "A Ventilator Bundle is a set of evidence-based practices aimed at preventing complications in patients on mechanical ventilation, including measures to reduce the risk of VALI."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR MANAGEMENT"
entities.description: "Ventilator management encompasses the strategies and interventions used to optimize the care of patients on mechanical ventilation, reducing the risk of complications like VALI."

entities.name: "PEAK INSPIRATORY PRESSURE (PIP)"
entities.description: "Peak Inspiratory Pressure is the maximum pressure applied to the airways during inhalation on a mechanical ventilator, a parameter that can impact lung mechanics and the risk of injury."

entities.name: "MICROASPIRATION"
entities.description: "Microaspiration is the entry of small amounts of secretions or fluids into the lower airways, a factor that can lead to lung infection and complications in ventilated patients."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR-INDUCED DIAPHRAGMATIC DYSFUNCTION (VIDD)"
entities.description: "Ventilator-Induced Diaphragmatic Dysfunction is a condition where prolonged mechanical ventilation causes weakness and atrophy in the diaphragm muscle, affecting respiratory function."

entities.name: "PLATEAU PRESSURE"
entities.description: "Plateau pressure is the pressure in the airways at the end of an inspiratory breath hold, a parameter monitored in mechanical ventilation to prevent lung overdistension."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR WITHDRAWAL"
entities.description: "Ventilator withdrawal is the process of gradually reducing and removing mechanical ventilation support once a patient's respiratory function improves, aiming to prevent complications and wean off the ventilator safely."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED EVENTS (VAE)"
entities.description: "Ventilator-Associated Events are adverse occurrences in ventilated patients, including conditions like pneumonia, requiring close monitoring and preventative measures."

entities.name: "POSITIVE PRESSURE VENTILATION"
entities.description: "Positive Pressure Ventilation is a ventilation technique that delivers air under positive pressure to keep the airways open, commonly used in mechanical ventilation for respiratory support."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR-INDUCED LUNG INJURY (VILI)"
entities.description: "Ventilator-Induced Lung Injury (VILI) is a form of lung injury caused by mechanical ventilation, with similarities and variations compared to VALI."

entities.name: "PRESSURE-VOLUME CURVE"
entities.description: "The Pressure-Volume Curve represents the relationship between lung volume and pressure, aiding in understanding lung mechanics and potential injury during mechanical ventilation."

entities.name: "FENTANYL"
entities.description: "Fentanyl is a potent opioid medication sometimes used in sedation during mechanical ventilation, with considerations for dosing and side effects."

entities.name: "INTUBATION"
entities.description: "Intubation is the insertion of a tube into the airway, a step often necessary for mechanical ventilation to support breathing and oxygenation."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR DYSSYNCHRONY"
entities.description: "Ventilator dyssynchrony refers to a lack of coordination between the patient's respiratory efforts and the mechanical ventilator, potentially leading to discomfort or increased risk of lung injury."

entities.name: "NEUROMUSCULAR BLOCKADE"
entities.description: "Neuromuscular blockade involves the use of medications to temporarily paralyze specific muscles, a strategy sometimes employed in patients on mechanical ventilation to improve synchrony and reduce oxygen consumption."

entities.name: "TRACHEOSTOMY"
entities.description: "Tracheostomy is a surgical procedure to create a stoma in the neck and trachea, often performed in patients requiring long-term mechanical ventilation for airway access and management."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR DISCONNECTION"
entities.description: "Ventilator disconnection is a critical event where the patient becomes disconnected from the mechanical ventilator, requiring immediate intervention to restore ventilation and prevent hypoxia."

entities.name: "SEDATION VACATION"
entities.description: "A sedation vacation involves temporarily reducing or stopping sedative medications in mechanically ventilated patients to assess neurological status and facilitate weaning from ventilation."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR CHECK"
entities.description: "A ventilator check is a routine assessment of the mechanical ventilator settings, alarms, and patient-ventilator interaction, crucial for ensuring proper ventilation and patient safety."

entities.name: "HIGH-FREQUENCY OSCILLATORY VENTILATION (HFOV)"
entities.description: "High-Frequency Oscillatory Ventilation is a type of mechanical ventilation that delivers very rapid breaths at low tidal volumes, used in certain cases of respiratory failure."

entities.name: "PRONE POSITIONING"
entities.description: "Prone positioning involves turning the patient onto their stomach, a strategy used in mechanically ventilated patients to improve oxygenation and reduce complications like ventilator-associated lung injury."

entities.name: "EXTRACORPOREAL MEMBRANE OXYGENATION (ECMO)"
entities.description: "Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation is a life support technique that provides cardiac and respiratory support by temporarily oxygenating the blood outside the body, sometimes used in severe cases of respiratory failure."

entities.name: "WEANING PROTOCOL"
entities.description: "A weaning protocol is a structured approach to gradually reduce and discontinue mechanical ventilation in patients as their respiratory function improves, aiming to prevent complications and facilitate successful extubation."

entities.name: "VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED COMPLICATIONS"
entities.description: "Ventilator-Associated Complications encompass a range of issues that can arise in mechanically ventilated patients, including infections, lung injury, and other adverse events."

<data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR BUNDLE"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"A Ventilator Bundle is a set of evidence-based practices aimed at preventing complications in patients on mechanical ventilation, including measures to reduce the risk of VALI."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR MANAGEMENT"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ventilator management encompasses the strategies and interventions used to optimize the care of patients on mechanical ventilation, reducing the risk of complications like VALI."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""PEAK INSPIRATORY PRESSURE (PIP)"">      <data key="d0">"PARAMETER"</data>      <data key="d1">"Peak Inspiratory Pressure is the maximum pressure applied to the airways during inhalation on a mechanical ventilator, a parameter that can impact lung mechanics and the risk of injury."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""MICROASPIRATION"">      <data key="d0">"COMPLICATION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Microaspiration is the entry of small amounts of secretions or fluids into the lower airways, a factor that can lead to lung infection and complications in ventilated patients."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR-INDUCED DIAPHRAGMATIC DYSFUNCTION (VIDD)"">      <data key="d0">"CONDITION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ventilator-Induced Diaphragmatic Dysfunction is a condition where prolonged mechanical ventilation causes weakness and atrophy in the diaphragm muscle, affecting respiratory function."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLATEAU PRESSURE"">      <data key="d0">"PARAMETER"</data>      <data key="d1">"Plateau pressure is the pressure in the airways at the end of an inspiratory breath hold, a parameter monitored in mechanical ventilation to prevent lung overdistension."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR WITHDRAWAL"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ventilator withdrawal is the process of gradually reducing and removing mechanical ventilation support once a patient's respiratory function improves, aiming to prevent complications and wean off the ventilator safely."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED EVENTS (VAE)"">      <data key="d0">"COMPLICATION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ventilator-Associated Events are adverse occurrences in ventilated patients, including conditions like pneumonia, requiring close monitoring and preventative measures."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""POSITIVE PRESSURE VENTILATION"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Positive Pressure Ventilation is a ventilation technique that delivers air under positive pressure to keep the airways open, commonly used in mechanical ventilation for respiratory support."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR-INDUCED LUNG INJURY (VILI)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ventilator-Induced Lung Injury (VILI) is a form of lung injury caused by mechanical ventilation, with similarities and variations compared to VALI."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""PRESSURE-VOLUME CURVE"">      <data key="d0">"PHYSIOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"The Pressure-Volume Curve represents the relationship between lung volume and pressure, aiding in understanding lung mechanics and potential injury during mechanical ventilation."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""FENTANYL"">      <data key="d0">"MEDICATION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Fentanyl is a potent opioid medication sometimes used in sedation during mechanical ventilation, with considerations for dosing and side effects."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""INTUBATION"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Intubation is the insertion of a tube into the airway, a step often necessary for mechanical ventilation to support breathing and oxygenation."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR DYSSYNCHRONY"">      <data key="d0">"CONDITION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ventilator dyssynchrony refers to a lack of coordination between the patient's respiratory efforts and the mechanical ventilator, potentially leading to discomfort or increased risk of lung injury."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""NEUROMUSCULAR BLOCKADE"">      <data key="d0">"INTERVENTION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Neuromuscular blockade involves the use of medications to temporarily paralyze specific muscles, a strategy sometimes employed in patients on mechanical ventilation to improve synchrony and reduce oxygen consumption."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEOSTOMY"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheostomy is a surgical procedure to create a stoma in the neck and trachea, often performed in patients requiring long-term mechanical ventilation for airway access and management."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR DISCONNECTION"">      <data key="d0">"COMPLICATION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ventilator disconnection is a critical event where the patient becomes disconnected from the mechanical ventilator, requiring immediate intervention to restore ventilation and prevent hypoxia."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""SEDATION VACATION"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"A sedation vacation involves temporarily reducing or stopping sedative medications in mechanically ventilated patients to assess neurological status and facilitate weaning from ventilation."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR CHECK"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"A ventilator check is a routine assessment of the mechanical ventilator settings, alarms, and patient-ventilator interaction, crucial for ensuring proper ventilation and patient safety."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""HIGH-FREQUENCY OSCILLATORY VENTILATION (HFOV)"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"High-Frequency Oscillatory Ventilation is a type of mechanical ventilation that delivers very rapid breaths at low tidal volumes, used in certain cases of respiratory failure."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""PRONE POSITIONING"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Prone positioning involves turning the patient onto their stomach, a strategy used in mechanically ventilated patients to improve oxygenation and reduce complications like ventilator-associated lung injury."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""EXTRACORPOREAL MEMBRANE OXYGENATION (ECMO)"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation is a life support technique that provides cardiac and respiratory support by temporarily oxygenating the blood outside the body, sometimes used in severe cases of respiratory failure."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""WEANING PROTOCOL"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"A weaning protocol is a structured approach to gradually reduce and discontinue mechanical ventilation in patients as their respiratory function improves, aiming to prevent complications and facilitate successful extubation."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <node id=""VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED COMPLICATIONS"">      <data key="d0">"COMPLICATION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ventilator-Associated Complications encompass a range of issues that can arise in mechanically ventilated patients, including infections, lung injury, and other adverse events."</data>      <data key="d2">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </node>    <edge source=""VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED LUNG INJURY (VALI)"" target=""VOLUTRAUMA"">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">"Volutrauma is considered the most harmful aspect of mechanical ventilation that causes VALI."</data>      <data key="d6">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""VENTILATOR-ASSOCIATED LUNG INJURY (VALI)"" target=""BIOTRAUMA"">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">"Biotrauma can lead to VALI through inflammatory mediators or bacteremia."</data>      <data key="d6">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""MECHANICAL VENTILATION"" target=""ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">"Atelectasis causes underinflation areas in the lung during mechanical ventilation, contributing to volutrauma."</data>      <data key="d6">5a08ca2f0af19fb355e030719cf7894e</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

synonyms:
segmental lung atelectasis
segmental lung collapse
segmental collapse
segmental lung atelectases
segmental atelectases
segmental collapses
segmental atelectasis (plural: atelectases) refers to collapse of one or several segments of a lung lobe. it is a morphological subtype of lung atelectasis. it is better appreciated on ct and its radiographic appearance can range from being a thin linear to a wedge-shaped opacity that does not abut an interlobar fissure.

entities.name: "AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Airspace Opacification refers to the abnormal filling of airspaces in the lungs, potentially indicating various underlying conditions."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is the collapse of part or all of a lung, commonly categorized into different types based on mechanisms or morphology."

entities.name: "LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Lobar Consolidation refers to the solidification of lung tissue in a specific lobe, often associated with pneumonia or inflammatory processes."

entities.name: "CHEST X-RAY"
entities.description: "Chest X-Ray is a diagnostic imaging technique used to visualize structures within the chest cavity, commonly employed in clinical settings."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is a condition caused by excess fluid in the lungs, often leading to symptoms such as shortness of breath and coughing."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, typically caused by a blood clot."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a condition characterized by permanent enlargement of the airways in the lungs, leading to recurrent infections and airway obstruction."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Interstitial Lung Disease encompasses various types of lung diseases affecting the interstitium, potentially caused by drugs, environmental factors, or idiopathic reasons."

entities.name: "AMIODARONE LUNG"
entities.description: "Amiodarone Lung refers to lung damage caused by the medication Amiodarone, with potential toxic effects."

entities.name: "BLEOMYCIN LUNG TOXICITY"
entities.description: "Bleomycin Lung Toxicity is a lung condition associated with the toxic effects of the drug Bleomycin."

entities.name: "LEFLUNOMIDE-INDUCED ACUTE INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Leflunomide-induced Acute Interstitial Pneumonia refers to a specific type of acute lung disease induced by the drug Leflunomide."

entities.name: "METHOTREXATE LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Methotrexate Lung Disease is a condition involving lung damage caused by the medication Methotrexate."

entities.name: "HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description:
"Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis is an immune-mediated lung condition triggered by exposure to allergens, leading to inflammation and lung damage."
"Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis is an immune-mediated lung condition triggered by exposure to allergens."

entities.name: "AETIOLOGY"
entities.description: "Aetiology refers to the causative factors or origins of diseases, relevant in understanding the development of various lung conditions."

entities.name: "PNEUMOCONIOSES"
entities.description: "Pneumoconioses are a group of lung diseases caused by the inhalation of mineral dust particles, leading to fibrotic or non-fibrotic lung conditions."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a malignant tumor that originates in the lungs, with various subtypes and invasive patterns."

entities.name: "DIAGNOSTIC HRCT CRITERIA FOR UIP PATTERN - ATS/ERS/JRS/ALAT (2011)"
entities.description: "Diagnostic HRCT Criteria for UIP Pattern - ATS/ERS/JRS/ALAT (2011) are guidelines used to diagnose the Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) pattern on high-resolution CT scans."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HAMARTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hamartoma is a benign lung tumor made up of disorganized but mature tissue elements."

entities.name: "IDIOPATHIC PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis is a chronic progressive lung disease characterized by scarring of the lung tissue."

entities.name: "SARCOIDOSIS"
entities.description: "Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease that commonly affects the lungs, causing granulomas and organ damage."

entities.name: "ASBESTOSIS"
entities.description: "Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers, leading to lung scarring and impairment."

entities.name: "COAL WORKER'S PNEUMOCONIOSIS"
entities.description: "Coal Worker's Pneumoconiosis, also known as Black Lung Disease, is a lung condition caused by long-term inhalation of coal dust."

entities.name: "SILICOSIS"
entities.description: "Silicosis is a form of pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of crystalline silica dust, resulting in fibrotic lung disease."

entities.name: "DESQUAMATIVE INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia is a rare type of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia characterized by smoking-related lung damage."

entities.description: "Regional Lymph Node Classification is a system used for staging lung cancer based on the involvement of lymph nodes in the region."

entities.description: "Segmental Atelectasis is a condition of partial lung collapse, confirmed in a radiological case with diagnostic certainty."

entities.name: "STAGING"
entities.description: "Staging is the process of determining the extent and spread of a cancer, which helps in planning treatment and predicting prognosis."

entities.description: "Involvement of lymph nodes refers to the presence of cancer cells in the lymph nodes, which plays a crucial role in determining the stage of cancer and treatment options."

chunk:
respiratory failure results from inadequate gas exchange by the respiratory system, meaning that the arterial oxygen, carbon dioxide, or both cannot be kept at normal levels. a drop in the oxygen carried in the blood is known as hypoxemia; a rise in arterial carbon dioxide levels is called hypercapnia. respiratory failure is classified as either type 1 or type 2, based on whether there is a high carbon dioxide level, and can be acute or chronic. in clinical trials, the definition of respiratory failure usually includes increased respiratory rate, abnormal blood gases (hypoxemia, hypercapnia, or both), and evidence of increased work of breathing. respiratory failure causes an altered state of consciousness due to ischemia in the brain.
the typical partial pressure reference values are oxygen pa o2 more than 80 mmhg (11 kpa) and carbon dioxide pa co2 less than 45 mmhg (6.0 kpa).
== cause ==
a variety of conditions that can potentially result in respiratory failure. the etiologies of each type of respiratory failure (see below) may differ, as well. different types of conditions may cause respiratory failure:
conditions that reduce the flow of air into and out of the lungs, including physical obstruction by foreign bodies or masses and reduced breathing due to drugs or changes to the chest.
conditions that impair the lungs' blood supply. these include thromboembolic conditions and conditions that reduce the output of the right heart, such as right heart failure and some myocardial infarctions.
conditions that limit the ability of the lung tissue to exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide between the blood and the air within the lungs. any disease which can damage the lung tissue can fit into this category. the most common causes are (in no particular order) infections, interstitial lung disease, and pulmonary edema.
== types ==
respiratory failure is generally organized into 4 types. below is a diagram that provides a general overview of the 4 types of respiratory failure, their distinguishing characteristics, and major causes of each.
=== type 1 ===
type 1 respiratory failure is characterized by a low level of oxygen in the blood (hypoxemia) (pao2) < 60 mmhg with a normal (normocapnia) or low (hypocapnia) level of carbon dioxide (paco2) in the blood.
the fundamental defect in type 1 respiratory failure is a failure of oxygenation characterized by:
type i respiratory failure is caused by conditions that affect oxygenation and therefore lead to lower-than-normal oxygen in the blood. these include:
low ambient oxygen (e.g. at high altitude).
ventilation-perfusion mismatch (parts of the lung receive oxygen but not enough blood to absorb it, e.g. pulmonary embolism, acute respiratory distress syndrome, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, congestive heart failure.
alveolar hypoventilation (decreased minute volume due to reduced respiratory muscle activity, e.g. in acute neuromuscular disease); this form can also cause type 2 respiratory failure if severe.
diffusion problem (oxygen cannot enter the capillaries due to parenchymal disease, e.g. in pneumonia or ards).
right-to-left shunt (oxygenated blood mixes with non-oxygenated blood from the venous system, e.g. arteriovenous malformation, complete atelectasis, severe pneumonia, severe pulmonary edema).
=== type 2 ===
hypoxemia (pao2 <8kpa or normal) with hypercapnia (paco2 >6.0kpa).
the basic defect in type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by:
type 2 respiratory failure is caused by inadequate alveolar ventilation; both oxygen and carbon dioxide are affected. defined as the buildup of carbon dioxide levels (paco2) that has been generated by the body but cannot be eliminated. the underlying causes include:
increased airways resistance (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, suffocation)
reduced breathing effort (drug effects, brain stem lesion, extreme obesity)
a decrease in the area of the lung available for gas exchange (such as in chronic bronchitis)
neuromu

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY FAILURE"
entities.description: "Respiratory Failure results from inadequate gas exchange by the respiratory system, leading to abnormal levels of arterial oxygen and carbon dioxide. It can be classified as type 1 or type 2, acute or chronic, and causes altered consciousness due to brain ischemia."

entities.name: "HYPOXEMIA"
entities.description: "Hypoxemia refers to low oxygen levels in the blood, typically below 80 mmHg (11 kPa), and is a key characteristic of respiratory failure."

entities.name: "HYPERCAPNIA"
entities.description: "Hypercapnia indicates high levels of carbon dioxide in the blood, usually above 45 mmHg (6.0 kPa), and is associated with respiratory failure."

entities.name: "WASHINGTON"
entities.description: "Washington is a location where communications are being received, indicating its importance in the decision-making process."

entities.name: "BRAIN ISCHEMIA"
entities.description: "Brain ischemia refers to inadequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain, often leading to tissue damage and altered neurological function in cases of respiratory failure."

entities.name: "ACUTE RESPIRATORY FAILURE"
entities.description: "Acute respiratory failure is a sudden inability of the respiratory system to maintain adequate gas exchange, resulting in hypoxemia and hypercapnia."

entities.name: "CHRONIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE"
entities.description: "Chronic respiratory failure refers to an ongoing inability of the respiratory system to maintain sufficient gas exchange over an extended period, leading to hypoxemia and hypercapnia."

chunk:
mediastinal shift is an abnormal movement of the mediastinal structures toward one side of the chest cavity. a shift indicates a severe imbalance of pressures inside the chest. mediastinal shifts are generally caused by increased lung volume, decreased lung volume, or abnormalities in the pleural space. additionally, masses inside the mediastinum or musculoskeletal abnormalities can also lead to abnormal mediastinal arrangement. typically, these shifts are observed on x-ray but also on computed tomography (ct) or magnetic resonance imaging (mri). on chest x-ray, tracheal deviation, or movement of the trachea away from its midline position can be used as a sign of a shift. other structures, like the heart, can also be used as reference points. below are examples of pathologies that can cause a mediastinal shift and their appearance.
== pleural space abnormalities ==
=== tension pneumothorax ===
tension pneumothorax is an emergent condition in which air gets trapped in the space between the chest wall and the lung. this space is referred to as the pleural space. because air can't escape from this space, the air pocket grows larger and larger, resulting in the lung collapse closest to the pneumothorax. forces are transmitted to the mediastinum and effectively "push" the mediastinal structures to the opposite side of the chest.
=== pleural effusion ===
a pleural effusion is an accumulation of fluid inside the pleural space. if this collection of fluid gets large enough, it can also push structures in the chest away from it and cause a mediastinal shift. however, a pleural effusion can also pull the mediastinal structure towards itself. if this is the case, then there is an underlying condition causing the collapse of the lung on that side. an example is a tumor obstructing a bronchus and causing lung collapse and pleural effusion.
=== hemothorax ===
hemothorax, or accumulation of blood in the pleural space, can result from trauma or surgical procedures in the chest. this accumulation of blood can grow large enough to compress the lung and push away other structures in the chest, thus causing a mediastinal shift. on a chest x-ray, a hemothorax can appear similarly to a pleural effusion with blunting of the pleural recess and white out of normal lung zones. in the setting of traumatic chest injury, rib fractures are also commonly observed on x-ray.
=== empyema ===
an empyema is a collection of pus inside the pleural cavity. it is a complication of pneumonia or thoracic injury or surgery and also requires urgent diagnosis and treatment. radiographic appearance is similar to that of a pleural effusion with costophrenic angle blunting and white out of lung zones. ct imaging is necessary to evaluate the structure of the empyema and evaluate for loculation or separation of the pus into different compartments. finally, ultrasound is becoming a more commonly used imaging technique to evaluate an empyema. ultrasound is more readily available at the bedside, is better at detecting pleural effusion, and can be used to guide thoracentesis to remove the empyema.
=== masses ===
masses such as tumors can also cause compression and displacement of mediastinal structures. there are various mediastinal tumors, and they are classified by their location in the chest. notable examples include germ cell tumors and lymphomas. teratomas are a class of germ cell tumors that arise in the chest due to failure of germ cell migration during development. they can expand to large sizes and cause hemoptysis and pleural effusion. radiographic features of teratomas typically include fluid and fat but also muscle, teeth, and bones inside the mass.
== decreased lung volume ==
=== atelectasis ===
atelectasis is the partial collapse of a lung that is reversible. there are numerous etiologies, including post-operative atelectasis, surfactant deficiency, mucus plugging, and foreign body aspiration. notably, post-operative atelectasis is thought t

entities.name: "MEDIASTINAL SHIFT"
entities.description: "Mediastinal Shift is an abnormal movement of mediastinal structures in the chest caused by various factors such as lung volume abnormalities or pleural space issues."

entities.name: "TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Tension Pneumothorax is a condition where air gets trapped in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse and a mediastinal shift."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, which can push or pull structures in the chest causing a mediastinal shift."

entities.name: "HEMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Hemothorax is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space, compressing the lung and causing a mediastinal shift."

entities.name: "EMPYEMA"
entities.description: "Empyema is the collection of pus in the pleural cavity, leading to lung compression and a mediastinal shift."

entities.name: "MASSES"
entities.description: "Masses such as tumors can cause compression and displacement of mediastinal structures in the chest."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is the partial collapse of a lung that is reversible, caused by various factors like post-operative complications or mucus plugging."

entities.name: "PLEURAL SPACE"
entities.description: "Pleural Space refers to the space between the chest wall and lung where air or fluid can accumulate, affecting lung function and causing mediastinal shifts."

entities.name: "PNEUMOMEDIASTINUM"
entities.description: "Pneumomediastinum is the presence of air in the mediastinum, often caused by trauma or medical procedures, resulting in a mediastinal shift."

entities.name: "MEDIASTINUM"
entities.description: "Mediastinum is the central compartment of the thoracic cavity containing vital structures such as the heart, esophagus, and major blood vessels."

entities.name: "PERICARDIAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pericardial Effusion is the accumulation of fluid around the heart in the pericardial sac, which can lead to compression of adjacent structures and a mediastinal shift."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that causes inflammation in the air sacs of the lungs, leading to consolidation and potential mediastinal shift due to increased lung density."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is the presence of air in the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse and potentially resulting in a mediastinal shift."

entities.name: "CHEST TRAUMA"
entities.description: "Chest Trauma refers to any injury to the chest area, which can result in mediastinal shifts if it affects the structures within the mediastinum."

synonyms:
obstructive atelectasis
resorptive atelectasis
resorptive obstructive atelectasis
resorptive or obstructive atelectasis is a form of lung collapse that is due to obstruction of the airways supplying a lung segment or lobe. it is a term used to distinguish atelectasis identified on imaging based on the underlying pathophysiology to guide diagnosis.
on this page:
article:
clinical presentation
pathology
radiographic features
related articles
references
images:cases and figures
clinical presentationthe presentation of patients with atelectasis depends on the underlying cause. however, breathlessness is common if there is significant lung collapse and infective symptoms can be present if there is co-existing sepsis.pathologyas the name implies, in this form of atelectasis there is partial or complete bronchial obstruction which leads to poor ventilation of the airways supplied. as ventilation between the distal airspaces and the trachea is disrupted the residual air in the affected lung is resorbed by the circulating blood at a rate greater than it is replaced by fresh ventilated air. this causes volume loss in the affected lung. volume loss may be minimal in distal airways obstruction due to the presence of collateral ventilation via the pores of kohn.the rate at which atelectasis progresses depends on whether there is obstruction of a lobar or segmental bronchus. lobar obstruction manifests as lobar atelectasis. in segmental atelectasis, there is often a degree of collateral ventilation from adjacent lung segments which causes a slightly distinct radiographic presentation. the speed of collapse is quicker if the patient is being given 100% oxygen 3.collapse occurs quickly if the obstruction is due to a luminal lesion that can act as a one-way valve.eventually, there can be sequestration of local lung secretions over time and areas of significant atelectasis are prone to become infected. hence, this type of collapse is frequently seen with co-existing consolidation.aetiologythe causes of resorption (obstructive) atelectasis can be thought of in terms of where the obstructing lesion is arising from with respect to the bronchial lumen:
extraluminal
neoplasm
lymphadenopathy
bronchial
fibrotic stricture
neoplasm
spontaneous rupture 4
luminal
mucus plugging
asthma
pneumonia
postoperative
post anaesthetic
pusbacterial pneumonia
bloodpost-traumatic lung injury
foreign body
endobronchial intubation
advertisement: supporters see fewer/no ads
radiographic featuresplain radiograph / ctthe imaging features of atelectasis are similar on plain radiographs and ct with more detail being available on the ct:
increased density at the site of atelectasis
loss of normal thoracic silhouettes (silhouette sign)
displacement of the fissures toward the area of atelectasis
upward displacement of ipsilateral hemidiaphragm
crowding of pulmonary vessels and bronchi affected area
compensatory hyperinflation of the unaffected lung
mediastinal shift
ipsilateral tracheal deviation
ipsilateral shift of the heart
if volume loss is minimal and there is consolidation present, then the term drowned lung can be used to indicate transudate replacing the air in the collapsing lung. the transudate is rapidly cleared when the obstruction is removed, as is commonly seen in postoperative patients with mucus plugging.ultrasoundas a consequence of the cessation of ventilation, lung sliding is immediately abolished. in contrast to a pneumothorax, another cause of absent lung sliding, the presence of a lung pulse implies that the visceral and parietal pleura are still in apposition. as alveolar gas is absorbed, the lung parenchyma may assume a tissue-like echogenicity, with the following internal features 9:
air bronchograms
unlike

entities.name: "RESORPTIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Resorptive Atelectasis is a form of lung collapse caused by obstruction of airways supplying a lung segment or lobe, leading to poor ventilation and volume loss in the affected lung."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL OBSTRUCTION"
entities.description: "Bronchial Obstruction is the partial or complete blockage of bronchial airways, resulting in poor ventilation and potential collapse of lung segments."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is the partial or complete collapse of a lung or lobe, typically due to obstruction or other underlying causes."

entities.name: "LUNG COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Lung Collapse is the reduction in lung volume or loss of lung function, often leading to respiratory difficulties and potential complications."

entities.name: "VENTILATION"
entities.description: "Ventilation refers to the process of moving air in and out of the lungs, allowing for gas exchange and oxygen uptake."

entities.name: "LUNG SEGMENTS"
entities.description: "Lung Segments are the anatomical divisions of the lungs that can be individually affected by conditions such as atelectasis or obstruction."

entities.name: "LUNG LOBES"
entities.description: "Lung Lobes are the major divisions of the lungs, with the right lung consisting of three lobes and the left lung consisting of two lobes."

air bronchograms
unlike dynamic air bronchograms (present in e.g. pneumonia) these lentiform, branching echogenicities do not move with respiration 8
referred to as static air bronchograms
fluid bronchograms 7tubular hypoechoic structures lacking vascular flow on colour doppler

entities.name: "OPERATIVE PATIENTS"
entities.description: "Operative patients are individuals with mucus plugging, indicating a medical condition that affects their lungs."

entities.name: "LUNG"
entities.description: "The lung is a vital organ that is affected by conditions such as atelectasis, leading to changes in its appearance on imaging techniques like ultrasound."

entities.name: "PLEURA"
entities.description: "The pleura refers to the membrane enclosing the lungs, which can be affected by conditions like atelectasis."

entities.name: "AIR BRONCHOGRAMS"
entities.description: "Air bronchograms are abnormal signs on imaging related to lung conditions like atelectasis."

entities.name: "FLUID BRONCHOGRAMS"
entities.description: "Fluid bronchograms are another abnormal sign on imaging related to lung conditions like atelectasis."

entities.name: "ULTRASOUND"
entities.description: "Ultrasound is a medical imaging technique used to visualize internal structures such as the lung and pleura in conditions like atelectasis."

entities.name: "RESORPTIVE-OBSTRUCTIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Resorptive-obstructive atelectasis is a type of lung collapse caused by blockage of airways, leading to breathing difficulties and changes in lung appearance on imaging."

entities.name: "BLOCKAGE"
entities.description: "Blockage of airways in the lungs can lead to conditions like resorptive-obstructive atelectasis, affecting the respiratory function of the individual."

entities.name: "BREATHING DIFFICULTIES"
entities.description: "Individuals with resorptive-obstructive atelectasis may experience breathing difficulties due to the collapse of lung tissue and obstruction of airways."

entities.name: "ABSENT LUNG SLIDING"
entities.description: "Absent lung sliding is a characteristic feature seen in conditions like resorptive-obstructive atelectasis on imaging studies like ultrasound."
