entities.name: "ENDOBRONCHIAL INTUBATION"
entities.description: "Endobronchial Intubation is a medical procedure involving the insertion of a tube into the trachea and bronchi to provide ventilation or administer medication."

entities.name: "OESOPHAGEAL INTUBATION"
entities.description: "Oesophageal Intubation is a medical condition where a tube intended for the trachea is mistakenly inserted into the esophagus, leading to potential complications."

entities.name: "CENTRAL VENOUS CATHETERS"
entities.description: "Central Venous Catheters are medical devices inserted into a large vein that provide access for drawing blood or administering fluids and medication."

entities.name: "JUGULAR VENOUS CATHETER"
entities.description: "Jugular Venous Catheter is a specific type of central venous catheter inserted into the jugular vein, commonly used for hemodialysis or administering medication."

entities.name: "GROSHONG CATHETER"
entities.description: "Groshong Catheter is a type of central venous catheter designed to prevent backflow of blood, widely used for long-term venous access."

entities.name: "HICKMAN CATHETER"
entities.description: "Hickman Catheter is a long-term central venous catheter with multiple lumens for chemotherapy or other medical treatments."

entities.name: "PULMONARY ARTERY (SWAN-GANZ) CATHETER"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Artery (Swan-Ganz) Catheter is a specialized catheter used to measure pressures in the heart and lungs, aiding in the management of critically ill patients."

entities.name: "DIFFERENTIAL OF LEFT PARAMEDIASTINAL CATHETER POSITIONS"
entities.description: "Differential of Left Paramediastinal Catheter Positions refers to the different possible locations and orientations of catheters near the mediastinum, affecting diagnosis and treatment."

entities.name: "OESOPHAGEAL TEMPERATURE PROBE"
entities.description: "Oesophageal Temperature Probe is a medical device used to monitor core body temperature through the esophagus, providing accurate readings for clinical assessment."

entities.name: "TRACHEOSTOMY TUBE"
entities.description: "Tracheostomy Tube is a breathing tube inserted into a surgically created opening in the trachea to assist with breathing, commonly used in patients with airway issues."

entities.name: "PLEURAL CATHETERS"
entities.description: "Pleural Catheters are tubes inserted into the pleural space to drain fluid or air, relieving pressure and treating conditions like pleural effusion or pneumothorax."

entities.name: "CARDIAC CONDUCTION DEVICES"
entities.description: "Cardiac Conduction Devices are medical implants that regulate the heart's electrical activity, including pacemakers and defibrillators, crucial for managing cardiac arrhythmias."

entities.name: "PROSTHETIC HEART VALVE"
entities.description: "Prosthetic Heart Valve is an artificial device surgically implanted to replace a diseased heart valve, restoring proper blood flow and cardiac function."

entities.name: "AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Airspace Opacification refers to an abnormal finding on imaging where lung airspaces appear filled or blocked, indicating conditions like pneumonia or pulmonary edema."

entities.name: "ACUTE UNILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Acute Unilateral Airspace Opacification (Differential) is a specific radiological finding that suggests various differential diagnoses for unilateral lung opacity, requiring further evaluation."

entities.name: "ACUTE BILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Acute Bilateral Airspace Opacification (Differential) is a radiological pattern indicating different potential causes of bilateral lung opacity, necessitating careful assessment and diagnosis."

entities.name: "CHRONIC UNILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Chronic Unilateral Airspace Opacification (Differential) involves persistent lung opacity on imaging with multiple differential possibilities for unilateral lung involvement, warranting thorough investigation."

entities.name: "CHRONIC BILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Chronic Bilateral Airspace Opacification (Differential) indicates long-standing bilateral lung opacity with diverse differential diagnoses to consider based on clinical context and imaging features."

entities.name: "LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Lobar Consolidation is a radiological term describing lung tissue becoming solid in a specific lobe, commonly seen in conditions like pneumonia or lung cancer."

entities.name: "RIGHT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Upper Lobe Consolidation refers to the solidification of lung tissue in the upper lobe of the right lung, often associated with pneumonia or other inflammatory processes."

entities.name: "RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Middle Lobe Consolidation describes the solidification of lung tissue in the middle lobe of the right lung, typically indicating infection, atelectasis, or other pathological conditions."

entities.name: "RIGHT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Lower Lobe Consolidation signifies the solidification of lung tissue in the lower lobe of the right lung, frequently linked to pneumonia, bronchiectasis, or other pulmonary diseases."

entities.name: "LEFT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Left Upper Lobe Consolidation signifies the solidification of lung tissue in the upper lobe of the left lung, a common feature of diseases like pneumonia, tuberculosis, or lung abscess."

entities.name: "LEFT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Left Lower Lobe Consolidation is the solidification of lung tissue in the lower lobe of the left lung, often indicating inflammatory conditions, bronchial obstruction, or parenchymal abnormalities."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis refers to the partial or complete collapse of the lung due to airway blockage, lung compression, or lung scarring, leading to reduced gas exchange and lung function."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL AIR COLUMN"
entities.description: "Tracheal Air Column represents the normal passage of air through the trachea, visible on imaging studies like chest X-rays or CT scans to assess airway patency and tracheal abnormalities."

entities.name: "HORIZON...  ("RELATIONSHIP"
entities.description: "Oesophageal Intubation"

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties, chest pain, and other respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition characterized by the presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse, chest pain, and shortness of breath."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage of the pulmonary artery or its branches by a blood clot, causing sudden onset of chest pain, difficulty breathing, and potentially life-threatening consequences."

entities.name: "EMPHYSEMA"
entities.description: "Emphysema is a chronic lung condition characterized by the destruction of alveoli, leading to difficulties in breathing, coughing, and wheezing, often associated with smoking."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a progressive lung disease that includes conditions such as emphysema and chronic bronchitis, resulting in airflow limitation, coughing, and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease characterized by progressive scarring of lung tissue, leading to shortness of breath, dry cough, and diminished exercise tolerance."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a malignant tumor that starts in the cells of the lung, often associated with smoking and leading to symptoms such as persistent cough, chest pain, and unexplained weight loss."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by widening and thickening of the bronchial tubes, leading to recurrent lung infections, coughing up of mucus, and breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "PLEURAL THICKENING"
entities.description: "Pleural Thickening is a condition where the pleura, the membrane surrounding the lungs, becomes thickened and scarred, often due to inflammation, asbestos exposure, or infection."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart, leading to symptoms like shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a life-threatening lung condition that most often affects premature infants, characterized by breathing difficulties, low oxygen levels, and lung inflammation."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is a condition characterized by fluid accumulation in the air sacs of the lungs, leading to symptoms like shortness of breath, coughing, and wheezing, often caused by heart failure or lung injury."

entities.name: "PULMONARY NODULES"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Nodules are small, round or oval growths in the lungs, often detected incidentally on imaging studies and requiring evaluation to determine whether they are benign or malignant."

entities.name: "PLEURAL PLAQUES"
entities.description: "Pleural Plaques are areas of thickened, fibrous tissue that develop on the pleura, commonly associated with asbestos exposure and detected through imaging studies."

<data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""HICKMAN CATHETER"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Hickman Catheter is a long-term central venous catheter with multiple lumens for chemotherapy or other medical treatments."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY ARTERY (SWAN-GANZ) CATHETER"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Artery (Swan-Ganz) Catheter is a specialized catheter used to measure pressures in the heart and lungs, aiding in the management of critically ill patients."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""DIFFERENTIAL OF LEFT PARAMEDIASTINAL CATHETER POSITIONS"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Differential of Left Paramediastinal Catheter Positions refers to the different possible locations and orientations of catheters near the mediastinum, affecting diagnosis and treatment."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""OESOPHAGEAL TEMPERATURE PROBE"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Oesophageal Temperature Probe is a medical device used to monitor core body temperature through the esophagus, providing accurate readings for clinical assessment."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEOSTOMY TUBE"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheostomy Tube is a breathing tube inserted into a surgically created opening in the trachea to assist with breathing, commonly used in patients with airway issues."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL CATHETERS"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Catheters are tubes inserted into the pleural space to drain fluid or air, relieving pressure and treating conditions like pleural effusion or pneumothorax."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""CARDIAC CONDUCTION DEVICES"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cardiac Conduction Devices are medical implants that regulate the heart's electrical activity, including pacemakers and defibrillators, crucial for managing cardiac arrhythmias."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PROSTHETIC HEART VALVE"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Prosthetic Heart Valve is an artificial device surgically implanted to replace a diseased heart valve, restoring proper blood flow and cardiac function."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Airspace Opacification refers to an abnormal finding on imaging where lung airspaces appear filled or blocked, indicating conditions like pneumonia or pulmonary edema."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""ACUTE UNILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Acute Unilateral Airspace Opacification (Differential) is a specific radiological finding that suggests various differential diagnoses for unilateral lung opacity, requiring further evaluation."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""ACUTE BILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Acute Bilateral Airspace Opacification (Differential) is a radiological pattern indicating different potential causes of bilateral lung opacity, necessitating careful assessment and diagnosis."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHRONIC UNILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chronic Unilateral Airspace Opacification (Differential) involves persistent lung opacity on imaging with multiple differential possibilities for unilateral lung involvement, warranting thorough investigation."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHRONIC BILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chronic Bilateral Airspace Opacification (Differential) indicates long-standing bilateral lung opacity with diverse differential diagnoses to consider based on clinical context and imaging features."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lobar Consolidation is a radiological term describing lung tissue becoming solid in a specific lobe, commonly seen in conditions like pneumonia or lung cancer."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Upper Lobe Consolidation refers to the solidification of lung tissue in the upper lobe of the right lung, often associated with pneumonia or other inflammatory processes."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE CONSOLIDATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Middle Lobe Consolidation describes the solidification of lung tissue in the middle lobe of the right lung, typically indicating infection, atelectasis, or other pathological conditions."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Lower Lobe Consolidation signifies the solidification of lung tissue in the lower lobe of the right lung, frequently linked to pneumonia, bronchiectasis, or other pulmonary diseases."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Upper Lobe Consolidation signifies the solidification of lung tissue in the upper lobe of the left lung, a common feature of diseases like pneumonia, tuberculosis, or lung abscess."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Lower Lobe Consolidation is the solidification of lung tissue in the lower lobe of the left lung, often indicating inflammatory conditions, bronchial obstruction, or parenchymal abnormalities."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Atelectasis refers to the partial or complete collapse of the lung due to airway blockage, lung compression, or lung scarring, leading to reduced gas exchange and lung function."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEAL AIR COLUMN"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheal Air Column represents the normal passage of air through the trachea, visible on imaging studies like chest X-rays or CT scans to assess airway patency and tracheal abnormalities."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""HORIZON...  ("RELATIONSHIP"">      <data key="d0">"ENDOBRONCHIAL INTUBATION"</data>      <data key="d1">"Oesophageal Intubation"</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PERIPHERALLY INSERTED CENTRAL CATHETERS"">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHITIS"">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL EFFUSION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Effusion is an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties, chest pain, and other respiratory symptoms."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PNEUMOTHORAX"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pneumothorax is a condition characterized by the presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse, chest pain, and shortness of breath."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EMBOLISM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage of the pulmonary artery or its branches by a blood clot, causing sudden onset of chest pain, difficulty breathing, and potentially life-threatening consequences."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""EMPHYSEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Emphysema is a chronic lung condition characterized by the destruction of alveoli, leading to difficulties in breathing, coughing, and wheezing, often associated with smoking."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a progressive lung disease that includes conditions such as emphysema and chronic bronchitis, resulting in airflow limitation, coughing, and respiratory distress."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY FIBROSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease characterized by progressive scarring of lung tissue, leading to shortness of breath, dry cough, and diminished exercise tolerance."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Cancer is a malignant tumor that starts in the cells of the lung, often associated with smoking and leading to symptoms such as persistent cough, chest pain, and unexplained weight loss."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by widening and thickening of the bronchial tubes, leading to recurrent lung infections, coughing up of mucus, and breathing difficulties."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL THICKENING"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Thickening is a condition where the pleura, the membrane surrounding the lungs, becomes thickened and scarred, often due to inflammation, asbestos exposure, or infection."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart, leading to symptoms like shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a life-threatening lung condition that most often affects premature infants, characterized by breathing difficulties, low oxygen levels, and lung inflammation."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Edema is a condition characterized by fluid accumulation in the air sacs of the lungs, leading to symptoms like shortness of breath, coughing, and wheezing, often caused by heart failure or lung injury."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY NODULES"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Nodules are small, round or oval growths in the lungs, often detected incidentally on imaging studies and requiring evaluation to determine whether they are benign or malignant."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL PLAQUES"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Plaques are areas of thickened, fibrous tissue that develop on the pleura, commonly associated with asbestos exposure and detected through imaging studies."</data>      <data key="d2">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </node>    <edge source=""CENTRAL VENOUS CATHETERS"" target=""JUGULAR VENOUS CATHETER"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Both are medical devices for venous access, with the latter specifically inserted into the jugular vein."</data>      <data key="d5">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""GROSHONG CATHETER"" target=""HICKMAN CATHETER"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Both are types of central venous catheters designed for long-term use, differing in specific features like lumens."</data>      <data key="d5">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PULMONARY ARTERY (SWAN-GANZ) CATHETER"" target=""PERIPHERALLY INSERTED CENTRAL CATHETERS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Both are specialized catheters for medical monitoring and treatment, with one focused on the heart and lungs while the other used for central venous access."</data>      <data key="d5">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"" target=""ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Both are lung conditions affecting airspaces and lung tissue, with atelectasis involving collapse and lobar consolidation leading to solidification."</data>      <data key="d5">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PULMONARY OEDEMA"" target=""BRONCHITIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Both are respiratory conditions involving fluid accumulation, with pulmonary edema affecting alveoli and bronchitis affecting airways."</data>      <data key="d5">685cc777648a29471fd7d6538215c1ea</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

entities.name: "ECTASIS"
entities.description: "Ectasis is a medical condition characterized by abnormal dilation or enlargement of a tubular structure, such as the trachea or bronchi."

entities.name: "TRACHEOBRONCHOMALACIA"
entities.description: "Tracheobronchomalacia is a medical condition involving the softening of the cartilage in the trachea and bronchi, leading to collapse during breathing."

entities.name: "NARROWING"
entities.description: "Narrowing refers to the constriction or reduction in the diameter of the airways, such as tracheal stenosis or bronchial stenosis."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Tracheal stenosis is a medical condition characterized by the narrowing of the trachea, leading to breathing difficulties and potential complications."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Bronchial stenosis is a medical condition involving the narrowing of the bronchial tubes, leading to breathing difficulties and obstruction."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE TRACHEAL NARROWING (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Diffuse tracheal narrowing (differential) is a medical condition characterized by widespread constriction in the trachea, with potential differential diagnoses to consider."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL DIVERTICULUM"
entities.description:
"Bronchial diverticulum is a medical condition characterized by an abnormal bulge or pocket in the bronchial tubes, potentially causing breathing difficulties and problems."
"Bronchial diverticulum is a medical condition involving an outpouching or abnormality in the bronchial tubes, which can lead to complications."

entities.name: "PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary edema is a medical condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the lungs, leading to respiratory distress and potential complications."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Interstitial edema is a medical condition involving the accumulation of fluid in the interstitial spaces of the lungs, which can impair gas exchange and lung function."

entities.name: "ALVEOLAR OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Alveolar edema is a medical condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the alveoli of the lungs, leading to impaired oxygenation and respiratory function."

entities.name: "CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Cardiogenic pulmonary edema is a type of pulmonary edema caused by heart-related issues, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs due to heart failure or dysfunction."

entities.name: "NON-CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema is a type of pulmonary edema not caused by heart issues, often triggered by conditions like pneumonia, sepsis, or ARDS."

entities.name: "DIVERTICULA"
entities.description: "Diverticula are abnormal pouches or protrusions that can occur in various organs or structures, such as the trachea or bronchi."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL DIVERTICULUM"
entities.description: "Tracheal diverticulum is a medical condition involving an abnormal outpouching in the trachea, which may lead to respiratory issues and complications."

entities.name: "HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a type of lung inflammation triggered by exposure to allergens or irritants, leading to respiratory symptoms and immune reactions."

entities.name: "MACHINE OPERATOR'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Machine operator's lung is a type of lung condition associated with occupational exposure to harmful substances or particles, resulting in respiratory issues and lung damage."

entities.name: "FIBROTIC NON-SPECIFIC INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Fibrotic non-specific interstitial pneumonia is a form of interstitial lung disease characterized by scarring and fibrosis in the lung tissue, leading to impaired respiratory function and symptoms."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary fibrosis is a chronic lung disease involving the thickening and scarring of lung tissue, leading to breathing difficulties and reduced lung function over time."

entities.name: "MESOTHELIOMA"
entities.description: "Mesothelioma is a rare form of cancer that develops from the protective lining covering the internal organs, often linked to asbestos exposure and leading to respiratory issues and tumors."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL OBSTRUCTION"
entities.description: "Bronchial obstruction is a medical condition involving blockage or narrowing in the bronchial tubes, which can impair airflow and respiratory function."

entities.name: "TRACHEOMALACIA"
entities.description: "Tracheomalacia is a medical condition characterized by weakness or softening of the tracheal walls, leading to collapse or airway obstruction during breathing."

entities.name: "BRONCHOMALACIA"
entities.description: "Bronchomalacia is a medical condition involving weakness or softening of the bronchial walls, which can result in collapse or narrowing of the airways."

entities.name: "TRACHEOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA"
entities.description: "Tracheoesophageal fistula is a medical condition characterized by an abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus, leading to respiratory and swallowing difficulties."

entities.name: "BRONCHOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA"
entities.description: "Bronchoesophageal fistula is a medical condition involving an abnormal passage between the bronchial tubes and esophagus, which can lead to respiratory issues and digestive complications."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL STRICTURE"
entities.description: "Tracheal stricture is a medical condition characterized by the narrowing or tightening of the trachea, often leading to breathing problems and reduced airflow."

entities.name: "BRONCHIAL STRICTURE"
entities.description: "Bronchial stricture is a medical condition involving the narrowing or constriction of the bronchial tubes, which can result in breathing difficulties and airflow obstruction."

entities.name: "TRACHEOSTOMY"
entities.description: "Tracheostomy is a surgical procedure that involves creating a hole in the trachea to bypass upper airway obstructions and assist with breathing."

entities.name: "BRONCHOSCOPY"
entities.description: "Bronchoscopy is a medical procedure that allows visualization of the bronchial tubes using a flexible scope, often used for diagnosis and treatment of respiratory conditions."

entities.name: "TRACHEOSTOMY TUBE"
entities.description: "A tracheostomy tube is a medical device inserted into the trachea through a surgical opening to maintain airflow, assist with breathing, or remove secretions."

entities.name: "BRONCHODILATOR"
entities.description: "A bronchodilator is a type of medication that helps relax the muscles in the airways and improve breathing in conditions like asthma or COPD."

id=""ECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Ectasis is a medical condition characterized by abnormal dilation or enlargement of a tubular structure, such as the trachea or bronchi."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEOBRONCHOMALACIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheobronchomalacia is a medical condition involving the softening of the cartilage in the trachea and bronchi, leading to collapse during breathing."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""NARROWING"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Narrowing refers to the constriction or reduction in the diameter of the airways, such as tracheal stenosis or bronchial stenosis."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEAL STENOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheal stenosis is a medical condition characterized by the narrowing of the trachea, leading to breathing difficulties and potential complications."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIAL STENOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchial stenosis is a medical condition involving the narrowing of the bronchial tubes, leading to breathing difficulties and obstruction."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""DIFFUSE TRACHEAL NARROWING (DIFFERENTIAL)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Diffuse tracheal narrowing (differential) is a medical condition characterized by widespread constriction in the trachea, with potential differential diagnoses to consider."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIAL DIVERTICULUM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchial diverticulum is a medical condition characterized by an abnormal bulge or pocket in the bronchial tubes, potentially causing breathing difficulties and problems.""Bronchial diverticulum is a medical condition involving an outpouching or abnormality in the bronchial tubes, which can lead to complications."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>      <data key="d3">"DISEASE"</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary edema is a medical condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the lungs, leading to respiratory distress and potential complications."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""INTERSTITIAL OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Interstitial edema is a medical condition involving the accumulation of fluid in the interstitial spaces of the lungs, which can impair gas exchange and lung function."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""ALVEOLAR OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Alveolar edema is a medical condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the alveoli of the lungs, leading to impaired oxygenation and respiratory function."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cardiogenic pulmonary edema is a type of pulmonary edema caused by heart-related issues, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs due to heart failure or dysfunction."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""NON-CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema is a type of pulmonary edema not caused by heart issues, often triggered by conditions like pneumonia, sepsis, or ARDS."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""DIVERTICULA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Diverticula are abnormal pouches or protrusions that can occur in various organs or structures, such as the trachea or bronchi."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEAL DIVERTICULUM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheal diverticulum is a medical condition involving an abnormal outpouching in the trachea, which may lead to respiratory issues and complications."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a type of lung inflammation triggered by exposure to allergens or irritants, leading to respiratory symptoms and immune reactions."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""MACHINE OPERATOR'S LUNG"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Machine operator's lung is a type of lung condition associated with occupational exposure to harmful substances or particles, resulting in respiratory issues and lung damage."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""FIBROTIC NON-SPECIFIC INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Fibrotic non-specific interstitial pneumonia is a form of interstitial lung disease characterized by scarring and fibrosis in the lung tissue, leading to impaired respiratory function and symptoms."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY FIBROSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary fibrosis is a chronic lung disease involving the thickening and scarring of lung tissue, leading to breathing difficulties and reduced lung function over time."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""MESOTHELIOMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Mesothelioma is a rare form of cancer that develops from the protective lining covering the internal organs, often linked to asbestos exposure and leading to respiratory issues and tumors."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIAL OBSTRUCTION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchial obstruction is a medical condition involving blockage or narrowing in the bronchial tubes, which can impair airflow and respiratory function."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEOMALACIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheomalacia is a medical condition characterized by weakness or softening of the tracheal walls, leading to collapse or airway obstruction during breathing."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHOMALACIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchomalacia is a medical condition involving weakness or softening of the bronchial walls, which can result in collapse or narrowing of the airways."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheoesophageal fistula is a medical key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchoesophageal fistula is a medical key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEAL STRICTURE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheal stricture is a medical condition <node id=""BRONCHIAL STRICTURE"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchial stricture is a medical condition involving the narrowing or constriction of the bronchial tubes, key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheostomy is a surgical procedure that involves creating a hole in the trachea to bypass upper airway obstructions and assist with breathing."</data>      <data key="d2">0a4cbb818d2e09502ee67767c7807f8a</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHOSCOPY"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchoscopy is a medical procedure that allows visualization of the bronchial tubes using a flexible scope, often used for diagnosis and treatment of respiratory conditions."</data>      <data id=""BRONCHODILATOR"">      <data key="d0">"MEDICATION"</data>      <data key="d1">"A bronchodilator is a type of medication that helps relax the muscles in the airways and improve breathing in entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung cancer refers to a type of cancer that originates in the lungs, with various subtypes and staging methods for diagnosis and treatment."

entities.name: "CANNONBALL METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cannonball metastases are a visual mnemonic for describing metastatic lesions in the lungs, indicating advanced disease."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER SCREENING"
entities.description: "Lung cancer screening involves the use of imaging technology to detect early signs of lung cancer in at-risk individuals."

entities.name: "SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Small cell lung cancer is a less common but aggressive type of lung cancer that is highly responsive to chemotherapy."

entities.name: "TNM STAGING SYSTEM"
entities.description: "The TNM staging system is used to classify the extent of spread of lung cancer based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and metastasis."

entities.name: "CHEMOTHERAPY"
entities.description: "Chemotherapy is a systemic treatment approach used in lung cancer to kill cancer cells and shrink tumors."

synonyms:
adhesive atelectases
adhesive atelectasis refers to the specific form of lung atelectasis that occurs due to the decrease or absence of pulmonary surfactant produced by type ii pneumocytes. without sufficient surfactant the alveoli collapse due to increased surface tension. it is most commonly seen in neonates with respiratory distress syndrome.aetiologydiffuse surfactant deficiency
respiratory distress syndrome (rds) of the newborn (surfactant deficiency disorder)

entities.name: "ADHESIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Adhesive Atelectasis refers to a specific form of lung atelectasis caused by the decrease or absence of pulmonary surfactant, leading to alveolar collapse due to increased surface tension."

entities.name: "PULMONARY SURFACTANT"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Surfactant is a substance produced by type II pneumocytes that reduces surface tension in the alveoli, preventing collapse and aiding in lung function."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (RDS)"
entities.description: "Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a disorder characterized by surfactant deficiency in newborns, leading to breathing difficulties and potential lung collapse."

entities.name: "ALVEOLI"
entities.description: "Alveoli are tiny air sacs in the lungs where the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide takes place."

entities.name: "TYPE II PNEUMOCYTES"
entities.description: "Type II Pneumocytes are specialized cells in the alveoli that produce pulmonary surfactant."

entities.name: "NEWBORNS"
entities.description: "Newborns refer to infants within the first 28 days of life."

entities.name: "BREATHING DIFFICULTIES"
entities.description: "Breathing difficulties include shortness of breath, labored breathing, and wheezing, indicating an underlying respiratory issue."

entities.name: "SURFACE TENSION"
entities.description: "Surface tension is the property of a liquid that allows it to resist an external force, such as the collapse of alveoli in the lungs without sufficient surfactant."

entities.name: "LUNG COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Lung collapse, also known as atelectasis, can result from various factors such as surfactant deficiency or airway blockage, leading to impaired lung function."

entities.name: "LUNG FUNCTION"
entities.description: "Lung function refers to the ability of the respiratory system to take in oxygen and remove carbon dioxide, essential for sustaining life."

entities.name: "EXCHANGE OF GASES"
entities.description: "The exchange of gases, specifically oxygen and carbon dioxide, occurs in the alveoli of the lungs during respiration."

entities.name: "OXYGENATION"
entities.description: "Oxygenation is the process of supplying oxygen to the body's tissues, vital for cellular function and energy production."

entities.name: "CARBON DIOXIDE"
entities.description: "Carbon Dioxide is a waste product of cellular metabolism that must be removed from the body through exhalation."

entities.name: "SURFACTANT DEFICIENCY"
entities.description: "Surfactant deficiency occurs when there is an inadequate amount of pulmonary surfactant in the alveoli, leading to respiratory complications."

entities.name: "AIRWAY BLOCKAGE"
entities.description: "Airway blockage refers to the obstruction of the respiratory passage, which can impede airflow and lead to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "INFANTS"
entities.description: "Infants are children in their early years of life, typically ranging from birth to one year old."

entities.name: "SHORTNESS OF BREATH"
entities.description: "Shortness of breath, also known as dyspnea, is a sensation of difficulty or discomfort in breathing, commonly associated with respiratory or cardiac conditions."

entities.name: "LABORED BREATHING"
entities.description: "Labored breathing is characterized by visible effort or difficulty in breathing, often indicating an underlying medical issue affecting the respiratory system."

entities.name: "WHEEZING"
entities.description: "Wheezing is a high-pitched whistling sound produced during breathing, typically due to narrowed airways or inflammation in the respiratory tract."

entities.name: "EXTERNAL FORCE"
entities.description: "An external force is a physical influence or factor that acts on an object or system from the outside, such as the surface tension affecting alveoli stability."

entities.name: "CELLULAR METABOLISM"
entities.description: "Cellular metabolism refers to the biochemical processes within cells that convert nutrients into energy and produce waste products like carbon dioxide."

entities.name: "TISSUES"
entities.description: "Tissues are groups of cells that work together to perform a specific function in the body, such as oxygen exchange in the alveoli."

entities.name: "ENERGY PRODUCTION"
entities.description: "Energy production is the generation of usable energy from nutrients to sustain cellular activities and overall bodily functions."

entities.name: "HEART"
entities.description: "The heart is a muscular organ that pumps blood throughout the body, providing oxygen and nutrients to tissues and removing waste products like carbon dioxide."

entities.name: "RESPIRATION"
entities.description: "Respiration is the process of inhaling oxygen and exhaling carbon dioxide, essential for the exchange of gases in the lungs and cellular function."

entities.name: "NARROWED AIRWAYS"
entities.description: "Narrowed airways result from inflammation or constriction, restricting airflow and causing symptoms like wheezing and shortness of breath."

entities.name: "INFLAMMATION"
entities.description: "Inflammation is the body's natural response to injury or infection, characterized by redness, swelling, pain, and heat, often affecting the respiratory tract in conditions like asthma."

entities.name: "BODY"
entities.description: "The body refers to the physical structure of a living organism, comprising various systems such as the respiratory system involved in oxygenation and carbon dioxide removal."

entities.name: "USABLE ENERGY"
entities.description: "Usable energy is the energy derived from nutrients that cells can utilize for various biological processes, including growth, repair, and movement."

entities.name: "NUTRIENTS"
entities.description: "Nutrients are substances essential for growth, development, and maintenance of the body, obtained from food and used in metabolic processes like energy production."

entities.name: "BLOOD"
entities.description: "Blood is a connective tissue that transports oxygen, nutrients, hormones, and waste products throughout the body, vital for cellular function and homeostasis."

entities.name: "HOMEOSTASIS"
entities.description: "Homeostasis is the body's ability to maintain internal stability and balance despite external changes, crucial for optimal physiological function and overall health."

entities.name: "PATHOLOGY"
entities.description: "Pathology is the study of disease processes, including their causes, mechanisms, and effects on the body's structure and function."

entities.name: "LUNG TISSUE"
entities.description: "Lung tissue is the specialized structure in the respiratory system responsible for gas exchange, comprising bronchioles, alveoli, and blood vessels."

entities.name: "BLOOD VESSELS"
entities.description: "Blood vessels are the tubular structures that transport blood throughout the body, delivering nutrients and oxygen to tissues and removing waste products."

entities.name: "SECRETION"
entities.description: "Secretion is the release of substances, such as pulmonary surfactant, by cells or glands into the body for various physiological functions like reducing surface tension in the lungs."

entities.name: "GROWTH"
entities.description: "Growth is the process of increasing in physical size or developing and maturing biologically, supported by nutrient intake, cellular metabolism, and genetic factors."

entities.name: "REPAIR"
entities.description: "Repair is the physiological process of restoring damaged tissues or organs to maintain structure and function, essential for recovery from injuries or diseases."

entities.name: "MOVEMENT"
entities.description: "Movement refers to the ability to change position or location through muscle contraction and coordinated actions of the musculoskeletal system, vital for mobility and daily activities."

entities.name: "GENETIC FACTORS"
entities.description: "Genetic factors are inherited traits encoded in an individual's DNA that influence various aspects of health, development, and susceptibility to certain conditions."

entities.name: "STRUCTURE"
entities.description: "Structure refers to the arrangement of tissues, organs, and cells in the body that form functional units responsible for specific physiological processes."

entities.name: "FUNCTION"
entities.description: "Function denotes the action or purpose of a biological structure or system, such as the respiratory system's function in gas exchange and oxygenation."

entities.name: "CAUSES"
entities.description: "Causes are factors or events that contribute to the development or occurrence of a disease, injury, or abnormal condition in the body."

entities.name: "MECHANISMS"
entities.description: "Mechanisms are the processes or pathways by which biological functions, diseases, or responses occur in the body, involving intricate cellular and molecular interactions."

entities.name: "EFFECTS"
entities.description: "Effects are the outcomes or consequences of a disease, treatment, or intervention on the body's structure, function, and overall well-being."

entities.name: "AIR"
entities.description: "Air is the mixture of gases in Earth's atmosphere, essential for respiration and providing oxygen for metabolic processes in living organisms."

entities.name: "METABOLISM"
entities.description: "Metabolism refers to the chemical reactions that occur within cells to sustain life, including energy production, growth, and waste elimination."

entities.name: "BRAIN"
entities.description: "The brain is the central organ of the nervous system responsible for processing information, controlling bodily functions, and coordinating responses to stimuli."

entities.name: "NERVOUS SYSTEM"
entities.description: "The nervous system is a complex network of nerves and cells that transmit signals between different parts of the body, regulating sensory perception, movements, and organ functions."

entities.name: "SENSORY PERCEPTION"
entities.description: "Sensory perception is the ability to detect and interpret sensory stimuli, such as sight, sound, touch, taste, and smell, allowing organisms to interact with their environment."

entities.name: "STIMULI"
entities.description: "Stimuli are changes or events in the environment that evoke a response in an organism, influencing behavior, physiology, and survival."

entities.name: "PERCEPTION"
entities.description: "Perception is the process of recognizing and interpreting sensory information to understand the environment and make appropriate behavioral or physiological responses."

entities.name: "BEHAVIOR"
entities.description: "Behavior is the actions, reactions, and conduct of an organism in response to internal or external stimuli, influenced by genetics, environment, and individual experiences."

entities.name: "PHYSIOLOGY"
entities.description: "Physiology is the branch of biology that focuses on the normal functions and mechanisms of living organisms, including processes like respiration, circulation, and digestion."

entities.name: "CIRCULATION"
entities.description: "Circulation is the movement of blood through the heart and blood vessels, distributing oxygen, nutrients, and hormones to tissues and removing waste products for elimination."

entities.name: "DIGESTION"
entities.description: "Digestion is the process of breaking down food into nutrients that can be absorbed and utilized by the body for energy, growth, and maintenance of bodily functions."

entities.name: "HEART RATE"
entities.description: "Heart rate is the number of times the heart beats per minute, reflecting the cardiovascular system's ability to pump blood and deliver oxygen to tissues."

entities.name: "BLOOD PRESSURE"
entities.description: "Blood pressure is the force exerted by circulating blood against the walls of blood vessels, essential for maintaining adequate blood flow and organ perfusion."

entities.name: "ORGANISM"
entities.description: "An organism is an individual living being that exhibits characteristics of life, including metabolism, growth, response to stimuli, and reproduction."

entities.name: "REPRODUCTION"
entities.description: "Reproduction is the biological process of producing offspring, ensuring the perpetuation of genetic material and species survival."

entities.name: "SURVIVAL"
entities.description: "Survival is the continued existence or living through challenging circumstances, requiring adaptive behaviors, physiological responses, and resource acquisition."

entities.name: "RESOURCE ACQUISITION"
entities.description: "Resource acquisition refers to the procurement of essential materials like food, water, shelter, and mates for survival, growth, and reproduction."

entities.name: "ADAPTIVE BEHAVIORS"
entities.description: "Adaptive behaviors are actions or responses that increase an organism's chances of survival and reproduction in changing or challenging environments."

entities.name: "RECEPTOR"
entities.description: "A receptor is a specialized cell or protein that detects external signals, such as hormones, neurotransmitters, or sensory stimuli, triggering a cellular response."

entities.name: "HORMONES"
entities.description: "Hormones are chemical messengers produced by endocrine glands that regulate various physiological functions, including growth, metabolism, and reproductive processes."

entities.name: "NEUROTRANSMITTERS"
entities.description: "Neurotransmitters are chemical substances that transmit signals between nerve cells, regulating neuronal communication and functions like muscle contractions, cognition, and emotions."

entities.name: "PROTEIN"
entities.description: "Proteins are large biomolecules composed of amino acids that perform diverse functions in the body, such as enzymatic reactions, structural support, and immune response."

entities.name: "ENZYMATIC REACTIONS"
entities.description: "Enzymatic reactions are biochemical processes catalyzed by enzymes, speeding up chemical reactions in the body essential for metabolism, digestion, and other functions."

entities.name: "SUPPORT"
entities.description: "Support refers to providing structural reinforcement or assistance to maintain the integrity and function of tissues, organs, or systems in the body."

entities.name: "IMMUNE RESPONSE"
entities.description: "The immune response is the body's defense mechanism against pathogens, foreign substances, and abnormal cells, involving the activation of immune cells and production of antibodies."

entities.name: "ANTIBODIES"
entities.description: "Antibodies, also known as immunoglobulins, are specialized proteins produced by the immune system to identify and neutralize foreign invaders like viruses and bacteria."

entities.name: "NEURONAL COMMUNICATION"
entities.description: "Neuronal communication involves the transmission of information between nerve cells through electrical and chemical signals, enabling sensory perception, motor functions, and cognitive processes."

entities.name: "MUSCLE CONTRACTIONS"
entities.description: "Muscle contractions are the activation of muscle fibers to generate force and movement, allowing for physical activities like walking, running, and grasping objects."

entities.name: "COGNITION"
entities.description: "Cognition refers to mental processes like thinking, learning, memory, and problem-solving, essential for decision-making, perception, and understanding of the world."

entities.name: "EMOTIONS"
entities.description: "Emotions are complex psychological responses to stimuli or situations that involve subjective feelings, physiological changes, and behavioral expressions, influencing mood and behavior."

entities.name: "MOOD"
entities.description: "Mood is a prolonged emotional state or disposition that influences one's subjective experience, behavior, and overall well-being, reflecting feelings like joy, sadness, or anxiety."

entities.name: "BEHAVIORAL EXPRESSIONS"
entities.description: "Behavioral expressions are outward manifestations of internal thoughts, feelings, or states, including gestures, facial expressions, and verbal communication, conveying emotions and intentions."

entities.name: "VERBAL COMMUNICATION"
entities.description: "Verbal communication involves the use of spoken language to convey information, ideas, emotions, or intentions, facilitating social interactions, learning, and expression."

entities.name: "SOCIAL INTERACTIONS"
entities.description: "Social interactions are the behaviors and communications between individuals or groups, essential for forming relationships, sharing knowledge, and developing social norms and structures."

entities.name: "KNOWLEDGE"
entities.description: "Knowledge is the understanding or awareness of information, facts, principles, or skills acquired through education

entities.name: "CENTRAL VENOUS CATHETERS"
entities.description: "Central Venous Catheters are medical devices used for venous access and central venous pressure monitoring."

entities.name: "JUGULAR VENOUS CATHETER"
entities.description: "Jugular Venous Catheter is a type of central venous catheter placed in the jugular vein for venous access."

entities.name: "GROSHONG CATHETER"
entities.description: "Groshong Catheter is a type of central venous catheter with a valve mechanism to prevent blood reflux."

entities.name: "HICKMAN CATHETER"
entities.description: "Hickman Catheter is a type of central venous catheter inserted into a large vein for chemotherapy and IV medications."

entities.name: "PULMONARY ARTERY (SWAN-GANZ) CATHETER"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Artery (Swan-Ganz) Catheter is used for hemodynamic monitoring and measuring pressure in the pulmonary artery."

entities.name: "PERIPHERALLY INSERTED CENTRAL CATHETERS"
entities.description: "Peripherally Inserted Central Catheters are long catheters placed in a peripheral vein with the tip near the heart."

entities.name: "DIFFERENTIAL OF LEFT PARAMEDIASTINAL CATHETER POSITIONS"
entities.description: "Differential of Left Paramediastinal Catheter Positions refers to variations in the placement of catheters near the mediastinum."

entities.name: "OESOPHAGEAL TEMPERATURE PROBE"
entities.description: "Oesophageal Temperature Probe is a device used for monitoring body temperature via the esophagus."

entities.name: "TRACHEOSTOMY TUBE"
entities.description: "Tracheostomy Tube is a tube inserted into the trachea to assist breathing in patients with airway issues."

entities.name: "PLEURAL CATHETERS"
entities.description: "Pleural Catheters are tubes placed in the pleural cavity to drain fluid or air."

entities.name: "CARDIAC CONDUCTION DEVICES"
entities.description: "Cardiac Conduction Devices are implants used to regulate heart rhythms in patients with arrhythmias."

entities.name: "PROSTHETIC HEART VALVE"
entities.description: "Prosthetic Heart Valve is an artificial device used to replace a damaged or malfunctioning heart valve."

entities.name: "REVIEW AREAS"
entities.description: "Review Areas are sections of study material focused on specific topics or subject areas."

entities.name: "AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Airspace Opacification refers to areas of the lung that appear opaque on imaging, suggesting fluid, blood, or other substances."

entities.name: "DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES OF AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Differential Diagnoses of Airspace Opacification are potential conditions that could manifest as lung opacities on imaging studies."

entities.name: "ACUTE UNILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Acute Unilateral Airspace Opacification is a differential diagnosis characterized by sudden opacity in one lung region."

entities.name: "ACUTE BILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Acute Bilateral Airspace Opacification is a differential diagnosis involving sudden opacities in both lung fields."

entities.name: "ACUTE AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION WITH LYMPHADENOPATHY (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Acute Airspace Opacification with Lymphadenopathy is a differential diagnosis with lung opacity and lymph node enlargement."

entities.name: "CHRONIC UNILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Chronic Unilateral Airspace Opacification is a differential diagnosis with persistent lung opacity in one side."

entities.name: "CHRONIC BILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION (DIFFERENTIAL)"
entities.description: "Chronic Bilateral Airspace Opacification is a differential diagnosis involving long-term lung opacities in both lungs."

entities.name: "LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Lobar Consolidation refers to the condensation of lung tissue in a specific lobe, often due to infection or inflammation."

entities.name: "RIGHT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Upper Lobe Consolidation is the consolidation of the upper right lung lobe observed on imaging studies."

entities.name: "RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Middle Lobe Consolidation is the consolidation of the middle right lung lobe seen on imaging."

entities.name: "RIGHT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Lower Lobe Consolidation is the consolidation of the lower right lung lobe visible on imaging scans."

entities.name: "LEFT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Left Upper Lobe Consolidation is the consolidation of the upper left lung lobe detected on imaging tests."

entities.name: "LEFT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Left Lower Lobe Consolidation is the consolidation of the lower left lung lobe observed on imaging exams."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is the collapse or closure of a part of the lung, leading to airless areas and impaired gas exchange."

entities.name: "MECHANISM-BASED"
entities.description: "Mechanism-Based Atelectasis refers to types of lung collapse based on different causes such as obstruction or relaxation."

entities.name: "RESORPTIVE (OBSTRUCTIVE) ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Resorptive Atelectasis occurs when a bronchus is obstructed, leading to the collapse of lung tissue."

entities.name: "PASSIVE (RELAXATION) ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Passive Atelectasis results from poor lung expansion due to conditions like pleural effusion or diaphragmatic weakness."

entities.name: "COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Compressive Atelectasis is caused by external pressure on the lung, leading to collapse of the alveoli."

entities.name: "CICATRISATION ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Cicatrisation Atelectasis results from scar tissue formation in the lung, causing a collapse of that area."

entities.name: "ADHESIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Adhesive Atelectasis is due to the failure of surfactant production, leading to collapse of lung segments."

entities.name: "GRAVITY DEPENDENT ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Gravity Dependent Atelectasis occurs when lung collapse is influenced by body position, with dependent areas collapsing first."

entities.name: "MORPHOLOGY-BASED"
entities.description: "Morphology-Based Atelectasis refers to types of lung collapse based on the appearance of affected areas on imaging scans."

entities.name: "LINEAR ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Linear Atelectasis presents as linear opacities due to passive collapse of lung segments."

entities.name: "SEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Segmental Atelectasis involves the collapse of specific lung segments, leading to localized opacities."

entities.name: "SUBSEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Subsegmental Atelectasis refers to the collapse of smaller lung units, causing discrete opacities on imaging."

entities.name: "ROUND ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Round Atelectasis forms a round opacity in the lung, often due to fibrosis or adjacent lesions like osteophytes."

entities.name: "OSTEOPHYTE INDUCED ADJACENT PULMONARY ATELECTASIS AND FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Osteophyte Induced Atelectasis is caused by bony growths that compress and collapse nearby lung tissue, leading to fibrosis."

entities.name: "LOBAR LUNG COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Lobar Lung Collapse involves the complete collapse of a lung lobe, often due to obstructing lesions or foreign bodies."

entities.name: "RIGHT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right Upper Lobe Collapse is the total or partial collapse of the upper right lung lobe, affecting that region's ventilation."

entities.name: "RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right Middle Lobe Collapse refers to the complete or partial collapse of the middle right lung lobe, impacting its function."

entities.name: "RIGHT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right Lower Lobe Collapse involves the collapse of the lower right lung lobe, leading to decreased air exchange in that area."

entities.name: "LEFT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Left Upper Lobe Collapse is the total or partial collapse of the upper left lung lobe, affecting respiratory function."

entities.name: "LEFT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Left Lower Lobe Collapse results in the complete or partial collapse of the lower left lung lobe, impeding gas exchange."

entities.name: "CHEST X-RAY IN THE EXAM SETTING"
entities.description: "Chest X-Ray in the Exam Setting involves imaging the chest for diagnostic purposes as part of an examination."

entities.name: "ADULT CHEST X-RAY IN THE EXAM SETTING"
entities.description: "Adult Chest X-Ray in the Exam Setting refers to imaging the chest of adult patients in a clinical or exam setting."

entities.name: "PAEDIATRIC CHEST X-RAY IN THE EXAM SETTING"
entities.description: "Paediatric Chest X-Ray in the Exam Setting involves imaging the chest of pediatric patients during clinical evaluations or exams."

entities.name: "NEONATAL CHEST X-RAY IN THE EXAM SETTING"
entities.description: "Neonatal Chest X-Ray in the Exam Setting refers to imaging the chest of newborns or neonates for diagnostic purposes."

entities.name: "CARDIOMEDIASTINAL CONTOUR"
entities.description: "Cardiomediastinal Contour refers to the silhouette of the heart and mediastinum observed on imaging studies like x-rays."

entities.name: "AORTIC KNOB/AORTIC NIPPLE"
entities.description: "Aortic Knob, also known as Aortic Nipple, is the prominent aortic arch seen on chest x-rays."

entities.name: "CARDIAC SILHOUETTE"
entities.description: "Cardiac Silhouette describes the outline of the heart visible on imaging, indicative of heart size and contour."

entities.name: "ENLARGEMENT OF THE CARDIAC SILHOUETTE"
entities.description: "Enlargement of the Cardiac Silhouette refers to abnormal heart size observed on imaging studies, indicating potential cardiac conditions."

entities.name: "RIGHT ATRIAL ENLARGEMENT"
entities.description: "Right Atrial Enlargement is the enlargement of the right atrium of the heart, often visible on imaging studies."

entities.name: "LEFT ATRIAL ENLARGEMENT"
entities.description: "Left Atrial Enlargement refers to the enlargement of the left atrium of the heart, detectable on imaging exams."

entities.name: "RIGHT VENTRICULAR ENLARGEMENT"
entities.description: "Right Ventricular Enlargement is the enlargement of the right ventricle of the heart, seen on imaging studies."

entities.name: "LEFT VENTRICULAR ENLARGEMENT"
entities.description: "Left Ventricular Enlargement involves the enlargement of the left ventricle of the heart, visible on imaging scans."

entities.name: "CARDIOTHORACIC RATIO"
entities.description: "Cardiothoracic Ratio is a measurement comparing the size of the heart to the thoracic cavity, often used in heart assessments."

entities.name: "CAVOATRIAL JUNCTION"
entities.description: "Cavoatrial Junction refers to the area where the superior vena cava meets the right atrium of the heart in cardiac anatomy."

entities.name: "MOGULS OF THE HEART"
entities.description: "Moguls of the Heart are protrusions on the cardiac silhouette that represent normal variations in heart anatomy."

entities.name: "VASCULAR PEDICLE"
entities.description: "Vascular Pedicle denotes the structures forming the blood vessels of the lungs, vital for oxygenation and circulation."

entities.name: "CHEST RADIOGRAPH ZONES"
entities.description: "Chest Radiograph Zones are defined regions used to describe findings on chest x-rays, divided into apical, upper, mid, and lower zones."

entities.name: "APICAL ZONE"
entities.description: "Apical Zone refers to the uppermost part of the lung fields visible on chest radiographs, often including the apices."

entities.name: "UPPER ZONE"
entities.description: "Upper Zone is the region of lung fields in chest x-rays above the hila, often relating to the middle and upper lung lobes."

entities.name: "MID ZONE"
entities.description: "Mid Zone is the central part of the lung fields on chest x-rays, lying between the upper and lower zones."

entities.name: "LOWER ZONE"
entities.description: "Lower Zone is the lowermost part of the lung fields visible on chest x-rays, often including the bases of the lungs."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL AIR COLUMN/TRACHEAL BIFURCATION ANGLE"
entities.description: "Tracheal Air Column relates to the central airway on chest x-rays, with the Tracheal Bifurcation Angle indicating tracheal branching."

entities.name: "FISSURES"
entities.description: "Fissures are natural divisions in the lungs visible on imaging studies, separating lobes or lung segments."

entities.name: "HORIZONTAL FISSURE"
entities.description: "Horizontal Fissure is a division between lobes of the lung in a horizontal plane, visible on chest x-rays."

entities.name: "OBLIQUE FISSURE"
entities.description: "Oblique Fissure is a slanting division between lobes of the lung observable on chest radiographs."

entities.name: "ACCESSORY FISSURES"
entities.description: "Accessory Fissures are additional lung fissures beyond the standard lobes divisions seen on imaging studies."

entities.name: "AZYGOS FISSURE"
entities.description: "Azygos Fissure is a rare separation seen between lobes of the lung, often associated with anatomical variations."

entities.name: "SUPERIOR ACCESSORY FISSURE"
entities.description: "Superior Accessory Fissure refers to an extra division in the lungs, distinct from the predominant lobes, visible on imaging."

entities.name: "INFERIOR ACCESSORY FISSURE"
entities.description: "Inferior Accessory Fissure is an additional fissure in the lung lobes, separate from standard division lines."

entities.name: "LEFT HORIZONTAL FISSURE"
entities.description: "Left Horizontal Fissure denotes a specific horizontal division between lung lobes on imaging studies."

entities.name: "VERTICAL FISSURE LINE"
entities.description: "Vertical Fissure Line signifies a vertical division between lung lobes on imaging exams, aiding in lobe identification."

entities.name: "NORMAL CHEST X-RAY APPEARANCE OF THE DIAPHRAGM"
entities.description: "Normal Chest X-Ray Appearance of the Diaphragm describes the expected diaphragmatic silhouette on chest radiographs."

entities.name: "FLATTENING OF THE DIAPHRAGM"
entities.description: "Flattening of the Diaphragm refers to an altered diaphragmatic contour on chest x-rays, indicative of pulmonary hyperinflation or pathology."

entities.name: "GASTRIC BUBBLE"
entities.description: "Gastric Bubble is the gas-filled area of the stomach seen on chest x-ray imaging."

entities.name: "NIPPLE SHADOW/NIPPLE MARKER"
entities.description: "Nipple Shadow, also known as Nipple Marker, is an artifact on chest x-rays representing nipple tissue."

entities.name: "LINES AND STRIPES"
entities.description: "Lines and Stripes are patterns seen on chest radiographs that may represent normal anatomical structures or artifacts."

entities.name: "ANTERIOR JUNCTION LINE"
entities.description: "Anterior Junction Line is a radiographic line at the junction of the lung and chest wall on imaging studies."

entities.name: "POSTERIOR JUNCTION LINE"
entities.description: "Posterior Junction Line is a line visible at the posterior lung-chest interface on chest x-rays or radiographs."

entities.name: "RIGHT PARATRACHEAL STRIPE"
entities.description: "Right Paratracheal Stripe refers to a radiopaque line alongside the trachea visible on chest x-rays."

entities.name: "LEFT PARATRACHEAL STRIPE"
entities.description: "Left Paratracheal Stripe indicates a radiopaque line adjacent to the trachea observed on chest radiographs."

entities.name: "POSTERIOR TRACHEAL STRIPE/TRACHEO-OESOPHAGEAL STRIPE"
entities.description: "Posterior Tracheal Stripe or Tracheo-Oesophageal Stripe denotes a radiopaque band along the trachea visible on imaging studies."

entities.name: "POSTERIOR WALL OF BRONCHUS INTERMEDIUS"
entities.description: "Posterior Wall of Bronchus Intermedius describes the radiographic appearance of the bronchus segment between the bronchi."

entities.name: "RIGHT PARASPINAL LINE"
entities.description: "Right Paraspinal Line indicates the radiopaque line adjacent to the spine seen on chest x-rays, aiding in anatomical localization."

entities.name: "LEFT PARASPINAL LINE"
entities.description: "Left Paraspinal Line denotes the radiopaque line beside the spine visible on chest radiographs, assisting in clinical interpretations."

entities.name: "AORTIC-PULMONARY STRIPE"
entities.description: "Aortic-Pulmonary Stripe is a radiopaque band near the aorta and pulmonary artery visualized on chest imaging."

entities.name: "AORTOPULMONARY WINDOW"
entities.description: "Aortopulmonary Window refers to the space between the aorta and pulmonary artery visible on chest radiography."

entities.name: "AZYGOS-OESOPHAGEAL RECESS/DEVIATION OF THE AZYGOS-OESOPHAGEAL RECESS"
entities.description: "Azygos-Oesophageal Recess or Deviation refers to anatomical structures near the azygos vein and esophagus observed on radiographic("entity"

entities.name: "SUPERIOR VENA CAVA"
entities.description: "Superior Vena Cava is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the right atrium of the heart."

entities.name: "INFERIOR VENA CAVA"
entities.description: "Inferior Vena Cava is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower body to the right atrium of the heart."

entities.name: "PULMONARY ARTERY"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Artery is a blood vessel that carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs for oxygenation."

entities.name: "PULMONARY VEIN"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Vein is a blood vessel that returns oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart, specifically the left atrium."

entities.name: "BRONCHUS"
entities.description: "Bronchus is a passage of the respiratory tract that conducts air into the lungs, with the right and left main bronchi branching into smaller airways."

entities.name: "SURFACTANT"
entities.description: "Surfactant is a substance produced in the lungs that helps reduce surface tension, preventing alveolar collapse and promoting gas exchange."

entities.name: "LUNG LOBES"
entities.description: "Lung Lobes are divisions of the lung separated by fissures, including the right lung with three lobes and the left lung with two lobes."

entities.name: "MEDIASTINUM"
entities.description: "Mediastinum is the central compartment of the thoracic cavity containing the heart, great vessels, esophagus, trachea, and other structures."

entities.name: "COSTOPHRENIC ANGLE"
entities.description: "Costophrenic Angle is the sharp interface between the diaphragm and the chest wall, often evaluated for signs of pathology on chest imaging."

entities.name: "SILHOUETTE SIGN"
entities.description: "Silhouette Sign is the loss of the normal border of a cardiac silhouette or diaphragm due to an adjacent opacity, aiding in localizing pathology."

entities.name: "HILA"
entities.description: "Hila are the regions where major bronchi, blood vessels, and lymphatics enter and exit the lungs, observed as radiodense markings on chest x-rays."

entities.name: "HYDROPNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Hydropneumothorax is a condition characterized by the presence of both air and fluid in the pleural space, often requiring drainage for management."

entities.name: "PNEUMOMEDIASTINUM"
entities.description: "Pneumomediastinum is the presence of air in the mediastinum, often seen in conditions like trauma, esophageal rupture, or spontaneous pneumomediastinum."

entities.name: "APICAL CAP"
entities.description: "Apical Cap refers to the normal fluoroscopic appearance of the apex of the lung, which can mimic pathology when rotated on chest x-rays."

key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""PASSIVE (RELAXATION) ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Passive Atelectasis results from ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Compressive Atelectasis is caused by external pressure on the lung, leading to collapse of the alveoli."</data>      <data
