key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LOBAR LUNG COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lobar Lung Collapse involves the complete collapse of a lung lobe, often due to obstructing lesions or foreign bodies."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Upper Lobe Collapse is the total or partial collapse of the upper right lung lobe, affecting that region's ventilation."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Middle Lobe Collapse refers to the complete or partial collapse of the middle right lung lobe, impacting its function."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Lower Lobe Collapse involves the collapse of the lower right lung lobe, leading to decreased air exchange in that area."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Upper Lobe Collapse is the total or partial collapse of the upper left lung lobe, affecting respiratory function."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Lower Lobe Collapse results in the complete or partial collapse of the lower left lung lobe, impeding gas exchange."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHEST X-RAY IN THE EXAM SETTING"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chest X-Ray in the Exam Setting involves imaging the chest for diagnostic purposes as part of an examination."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""ADULT CHEST X-RAY IN THE EXAM SETTING"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Adult Chest X-Ray in the Exam Setting refers to imaging the chest of adult patients in a clinical or exam setting."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""PAEDIATRIC CHEST X-RAY IN THE EXAM SETTING"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Paediatric Chest X-Ray in the Exam Setting involves imaging the chest of pediatric patients during clinical evaluations or exams."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""NEONATAL CHEST X-RAY IN THE EXAM SETTING"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Neonatal Chest X-Ray in the Exam Setting refers to imaging the chest of newborns or neonates for diagnostic purposes."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""CARDIOMEDIASTINAL CONTOUR"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cardiomediastinal Contour refers to the silhouette of the heart and mediastinum observed on imaging studies like x-rays."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""AORTIC KNOB/AORTIC NIPPLE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Aortic Knob, also known as Aortic Nipple, is the prominent aortic arch seen on chest x-rays."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""CARDIAC SILHOUETTE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cardiac Silhouette describes the outline of the heart visible on imaging, indicative of heart size and contour."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""ENLARGEMENT OF THE CARDIAC SILHOUETTE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Enlargement of the Cardiac Silhouette refers to abnormal heart size observed on imaging studies, indicating potential cardiac conditions."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT ATRIAL ENLARGEMENT"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Atrial Enlargement is the enlargement of the right atrium of the heart, often visible on imaging studies."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT ATRIAL ENLARGEMENT"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Atrial Enlargement refers to the enlargement of the left atrium of the heart, detectable on imaging exams."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT VENTRICULAR ENLARGEMENT"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Ventricular Enlargement is the enlargement of the right ventricle of the heart, seen on imaging studies."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT VENTRICULAR ENLARGEMENT"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Ventricular Enlargement involves the enlargement of the left ventricle of the heart, visible on imaging scans."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""CARDIOTHORACIC RATIO"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cardiothoracic Ratio is a measurement comparing the size of the heart to the thoracic cavity, often used in heart assessments."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""CAVOATRIAL JUNCTION"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cavoatrial Junction refers to the area where the superior vena cava meets the right atrium of the heart in cardiac anatomy."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""MOGULS OF THE HEART"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Moguls of the Heart are protrusions on the cardiac silhouette that represent normal variations in heart anatomy."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""VASCULAR PEDICLE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Vascular Pedicle denotes the structures forming the blood vessels of the lungs, vital for oxygenation and circulation."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""CHEST RADIOGRAPH ZONES"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chest Radiograph Zones are defined regions used to describe findings on chest x-rays, divided into apical, upper, mid, and lower zones."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""APICAL ZONE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Apical Zone refers to the uppermost part of the lung fields visible on chest radiographs, often including the apices."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""UPPER ZONE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Upper Zone is the region of lung fields in chest x-rays above the hila, often relating to the middle and upper lung lobes."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""MID ZONE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Mid Zone is the central part of the lung fields on chest x-rays, lying between the upper and lower zones."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LOWER ZONE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lower Zone is the lowermost part of the lung fields visible on chest x-rays, often including the bases of the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""TRACHEAL AIR COLUMN/TRACHEAL BIFURCATION ANGLE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tracheal Air Column relates to the central airway on chest x-rays, with the Tracheal Bifurcation Angle indicating tracheal branching."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""FISSURES"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Fissures are natural divisions in the lungs visible on imaging studies, separating lobes or lung segments."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""HORIZONTAL FISSURE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Horizontal Fissure is a division between lobes of the lung in a horizontal plane, visible on chest x-rays."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""OBLIQUE FISSURE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Oblique Fissure is a slanting division between lobes of the lung observable on chest radiographs."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""ACCESSORY FISSURES"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Accessory Fissures are additional lung fissures beyond the standard lobes divisions seen on imaging studies."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""AZYGOS FISSURE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Azygos Fissure is a rare separation seen between lobes of the lung, often associated with anatomical variations."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""SUPERIOR ACCESSORY FISSURE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Superior Accessory Fissure refers to an extra division in the lungs, distinct from the predominant lobes, visible on imaging."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""INFERIOR ACCESSORY FISSURE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Inferior Accessory Fissure is an additional fissure in the lung lobes, separate from standard division lines."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT HORIZONTAL FISSURE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Horizontal Fissure denotes a specific horizontal division between lung lobes on imaging studies."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""VERTICAL FISSURE LINE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Vertical Fissure Line signifies a vertical division between lung lobes on imaging exams, aiding in lobe identification."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""NORMAL CHEST X-RAY APPEARANCE OF THE DIAPHRAGM"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Normal Chest X-Ray Appearance of the Diaphragm describes the expected diaphragmatic silhouette on chest radiographs."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""FLATTENING OF THE DIAPHRAGM"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Flattening of the Diaphragm refers to an altered diaphragmatic contour on chest x-rays, indicative of pulmonary hyperinflation or pathology."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""GASTRIC BUBBLE"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Gastric Bubble is the gas-filled area of the stomach seen on chest x-ray imaging."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""NIPPLE SHADOW/NIPPLE MARKER"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Nipple Shadow, also known as Nipple Marker, is an artifact on chest x-rays representing nipple tissue."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LINES AND STRIPES"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lines and Stripes are patterns seen on chest radiographs that may represent normal anatomical structures or artifacts."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""ANTERIOR JUNCTION LINE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Anterior Junction Line is a radiographic line at the junction of the lung and chest wall on imaging studies."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""POSTERIOR JUNCTION LINE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Posterior Junction Line is a line visible at the posterior lung-chest interface on chest x-rays or radiographs."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT PARATRACHEAL STRIPE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Paratracheal Stripe refers to a radiopaque line alongside the trachea visible on chest x-rays."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT PARATRACHEAL STRIPE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Paratracheal Stripe indicates a radiopaque line adjacent to the trachea observed on chest radiographs."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""POSTERIOR TRACHEAL STRIPE/TRACHEO-OESOPHAGEAL STRIPE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Posterior Tracheal Stripe or Tracheo-Oesophageal Stripe denotes a radiopaque band along the trachea visible on imaging studies."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""POSTERIOR WALL OF BRONCHUS INTERMEDIUS"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Posterior Wall of Bronchus Intermedius describes the radiographic appearance of the bronchus segment between the bronchi."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""RIGHT PARASPINAL LINE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Right Paraspinal Line indicates the radiopaque line adjacent to the spine seen on chest x-rays, aiding in anatomical localization."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LEFT PARASPINAL LINE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Left Paraspinal Line denotes the radiopaque line beside the spine visible on chest radiographs, assisting in clinical interpretations."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""AORTIC-PULMONARY STRIPE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Aortic-Pulmonary Stripe is a radiopaque band near the aorta and pulmonary artery visualized on chest imaging."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""AORTOPULMONARY WINDOW"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Aortopulmonary Window refers to the space between the aorta and pulmonary artery visible on chest radiography."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""AZYGOS-OESOPHAGEAL RECESS/DEVIATION OF THE AZYGOS-OESOPHAGEAL RECESS"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Azygos-Oesophageal Recess or Deviation refers to anatomical structures near the azygos vein and esophagus observed on radiographic("entity"</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""SUPERIOR VENA CAVA"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Superior Vena Cava is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the right atrium of the heart."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""INFERIOR VENA CAVA"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Inferior Vena Cava is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower body to the right atrium of the heart."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY ARTERY"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Artery is a blood vessel that carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs for oxygenation."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY VEIN"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Vein is a blood vessel that returns oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart, specifically the left atrium."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHUS"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchus is a passage of the respiratory tract that conducts air into the lungs, with the right and left main bronchi branching into smaller airways."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""SURFACTANT"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Surfactant is a substance produced in the lungs that helps reduce surface tension, preventing alveolar collapse and promoting gas exchange."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG LOBES"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Lobes are divisions of the lung separated by fissures, including the right lung with three lobes and the left lung with two lobes."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""MEDIASTINUM"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Mediastinum is the central compartment of the thoracic cavity containing the heart, great vessels, esophagus, trachea, and other structures."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""COSTOPHRENIC ANGLE"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Costophrenic Angle is the sharp interface between the diaphragm and the chest wall, often evaluated for signs of pathology on chest imaging."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""SILHOUETTE SIGN"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Silhouette Sign is the loss of the normal border of a cardiac silhouette or diaphragm due to an adjacent opacity, aiding in localizing pathology."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""HILA"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Hila are the regions where major bronchi, blood vessels, and lymphatics enter and exit the lungs, observed as radiodense markings on chest x-rays."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""HYDROPNEUMOTHORAX"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Hydropneumothorax is a condition characterized by the presence of both air and fluid in the pleural space, often requiring drainage for management."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""PNEUMOMEDIASTINUM"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pneumomediastinum is the presence of air in the mediastinum, often seen in conditions like trauma, esophageal rupture, or spontaneous pneumomediastinum."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>    <node id=""APICAL CAP"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Apical Cap refers to the normal fluoroscopic appearance of the apex of the lung, which can mimic pathology when rotated on chest x-rays."</data>      <data key="d2">1b29a67660676d3e5ab486b22b4ff18b</data>    </node>  </graph></graphml>

entities.name: "STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Stenosis is a condition characterized by various types of narrowing in the airways or trachea, including bronchial stenosis and tracheal stenosis."

entities.name: "DIVERTICULA"
entities.description: "Diverticula are abnormal pouches that can form in the trachea or bronchi."

entities.name: "PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Oedema refers to the abnormal accumulation of fluid in the lungs, with classifications like interstitial oedema and alveolar oedema and causes such as cardiogenic and non-cardiogenic factors."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE (ILD)"
entities.description: "Interstitial Lung Disease is a group of lung disorders, including subtypes like anti-jo-1 antibody-positive interstitial lung disease, drug-induced ILD, and others."

entities.name: "HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis is an inflammatory lung condition caused by exposure to various organic particles, presenting as acute, subacute, or chronic forms."

entities.name: "IDIOPATHIC INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA (MNEMONIC)"
entities.description: "Idiopathic Interstitial Pneumonia is a type of lung disease with subtypes like Acute Interstitial Pneumonia (AIP), Cryptogenic Organising Pneumonia (COP), and more."

entities.name: "PNEUMOCONIOSES"
entities.description: "Pneumoconioses are a group of lung diseases caused by inhalation of mineral or metal dust, including fibrotic and non-fibrotic types like silicosis, asbestosis, and others."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a malignant tumor that develops in the lungs, with subtypes like Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer, Small-Cell Lung Cancer, and various histological variants."

entities.name: "TUMOURS BY LOCATION"
entities.description: "An overview of different types of lung tumors categorized based on their anatomical location and characteristics, including Pancoast tumor and benign neoplasms."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition in which air leaks into the space between the lungs and chest wall, leading to lung collapse."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a condition where the airways in the lungs become damaged, widened, and scarred, leading to recurrent infections."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by blood clots that travel to the lungs from the legs or other parts of the body."

entities.name: "ASTHMA"
entities.description: "Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to symptoms like wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease is a progressive lung disease that makes it hard to breathe, including conditions like emphysema and chronic bronchitis."

entities.name: "LUNG ABSCESS"
entities.description: "Lung Abscess is a localized collection of pus within the lung tissue, often caused by bacterial infections."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS)"
entities.description: "Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a severe lung condition causing difficulty in breathing, usually occurring in critically ill individuals."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a buildup of excess fluid between the layers of the pleura outside the lungs, leading to chest pain and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "PULMONARY CHONDROMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary chondroma is a type of tumor that originates in the lung tissue."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HAMARTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary hamartoma is a benign tumor-like growth that occurs in the lung tissue."

entities.name: "PULMONARY MESENCHYMAL CYSTIC HAMARTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary mesenchymal cystic hamartoma is a type of benign growth in the lung tissue with cystic components."

entities.name: "PULMONARY SCLEROSING PNEUMOCYTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary sclerosing pneumocytoma is a rare tumor of the lung, often benign in nature."

entities.name: "PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description: "Pulmonary metastases refer to the spread of cancer from other parts of the body to the lungs."

entities.name: "CANNONBALL METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cannonball metastases is a term used to describe multiple round lesions in the lung caused by cancer spread."

entities.name: "CAVITARY PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cavitary pulmonary metastases are cancerous lung lesions with cavities or hollow spaces."

entities.name: "CYSTIC PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cystic pulmonary metastases refer to cancerous lung lesions that contain cysts or fluid-filled pockets."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER SCREENING"
entities.description: "Lung cancer screening involves tests and procedures to detect lung cancer at an early stage when treatment is more effective."

entities.name: "LUNG-RADS"
entities.description: "Lung-RADS is a classification system used to categorize lung nodules detected on imaging studies."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER STAGING"
entities.description: "Lung cancer staging is the process of determining the extent and spread of lung cancer in the body."

entities.name: "IASLC (INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LUNG CANCER) 8TH EDITION"
entities.description: "IASLC's 8th edition provides guidelines for the study and management of lung cancer."

entities.name: "IASLC (INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LUNG CANCER) 7TH EDITION"
entities.description: "IASLC's 7th edition was previously used for the study of lung cancer but has been superseded by the 8th edition."

entities.name: "1996 AJCC-UICC REGIONAL LYMPH NODE CLASSIFICATION FOR LUNG CANCER STAGING"
entities.description: "The 1996 AJCC-UICC classification system helps stage lung cancer based on involvement of regional lymph nodes."

entities.name: "SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Small cell lung cancer is a type of aggressive lung cancer that typically originates in the bronchi."

entities.name: "NON-SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Non-small cell lung cancer is a common type of lung cancer that includes several subtypes like adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma."

entities.name: "PULMONARY CARCINOID TUMOR"
entities.description: "Pulmonary carcinoid tumor is a rare type of lung tumor that arises from neuroendocrine cells."

entities.name: "PULMONARY BLASTOMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary blastoma is a rare and aggressive type of lung cancer that can occur in both adults and children."

entities.name: "ADENO-SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Adeno-squamous cell carcinoma is a type of lung cancer that contains both adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma components."

entities.name: "LARGE CELL CARCINOMA OF THE LUNG"
entities.description: "Large cell carcinoma of the lung is a type of non-small cell lung cancer that grows and spreads quickly."

entities.name: "PANCOAST TUMOR"
entities.description: "Pancoast tumor is a type of lung cancer that occurs in the upper part of the lungs and can affect nearby tissues and nerves."

entities.name: "CARCINOMA IN SITU OF LUNG"
entities.description: "Carcinoma in situ of the lung refers to early-stage lung cancer that has not invaded surrounding tissues."

entities.name: "LUNG ADENOCARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Lung adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer and is often found in the outer areas of the lungs."

entities.name: "SQUAMOUS CELL LUNG CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Squamous cell lung carcinoma is a type of non-small cell lung cancer that typically arises in the bronchi."

entities.name: "PLEOMORPHIC CARCINOMA OF LUNG"
entities.description: "Pleomorphic carcinoma of the lung is a rare and aggressive type of non-small cell lung cancer with diverse cell characteristics."

entities.name: "LUNG NEUROENDOCRINE TUMORS"
entities.description: "Lung neuroendocrine tumors are a group of rare lung cancers that originate from neuroendocrine cells in the lungs."

entities.name: "THYMOMA"
entities.description: "Thymoma is a tumor that originates in the thymus gland, which can sometimes extend into the lungs."

entities.name: "THYMIC CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Thymic carcinoma is a rare type of cancer that arises from the epithelial cells of the thymus gland and can spread to the lungs."

entities.name: "MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA"
entities.description: "Malignant mesothelioma is a cancer that affects the mesothelial cells lining the lungs and other organs."

entities.name: "CARCINOID SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Carcinoid syndrome is a group of symptoms that occur due to the release of certain substances by lung carcinoid tumors."

entities.name: "GRANULAR CELL TUMOR OF THE TRACHEA"
entities.description: "Granular cell tumor of the trachea is a rare tumor that can affect the windpipe and adjacent structures."

entities.name: "TRACHEOBRONCHOPATHIA OSTEOCHONDROPLASTICA"
entities.description: "Tracheobronchopathia osteochondroplastica is a rare condition characterized by cartilage and bone formation in the trachea and bronchi."

entities.name: "BRONCHOPULMONARY SEQUESTRATION"
entities.description: "Bronchopulmonary sequestration is a congenital condition where lung tissue is not connected to the airway and receives blood supply from systemic arteries."

entities.name: "PULMONARY ALVEOLAR MICROLITHIASIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis is a rare lung disorder characterized by the accumulation of microliths within the alveoli."

entities.name: "BRONCHOPULMONARY DYSPLASIA"
entities.description: "Bronchopulmonary dysplasia is a lung condition that primarily affects premature infants who have received mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy."

chunk:
a pulmonary alveolus (pl.: alveoli, from latin alveolus, "little cavity"), also known as an air sac or air space, is one of millions of hollow, distensible cup-shaped cavities in the lungs where pulmonary gas exchange takes place. oxygen is exchanged for carbon dioxide at the blood-air barrier between the alveolar air and the pulmonary capillary. alveoli make up the functional tissue of the mammalian lungs known as the lung parenchyma, which takes up 90 percent of the total lung volume.
alveoli are first located in the respiratory bronchioles that mark the beginning of the respiratory zone. they are located sparsely in these bronchioles, line the walls of the alveolar ducts, and are more numerous in the blind-ended alveolar sacs. the acini are the basic units of respiration, with gas exchange taking place in all the alveoli present. the alveolar membrane is the gas exchange surface, surrounded by a network of capillaries. oxygen is diffused across the membrane into the capillaries and carbon dioxide is released from the capillaries into the alveoli to be breathed out.
alveoli are particular to mammalian lungs. different structures are involved in gas exchange in other vertebrates.
== structure ==
the alveoli are first located in the respiratory bronchioles as scattered outpockets, extending from their lumens. the respiratory bronchioles run for considerable lengths and become increasingly alveolated with side branches of alveolar ducts that become deeply lined with alveoli. the ducts number between two and eleven from each bronchiole. each duct opens into five or six alveolar sacs into which clusters of alveoli open.
each terminal respiratory unit is called an acinus and consists of the respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, alveolar sacs, and alveoli. new alveoli continue to form until the age of eight years.
a typical pair of human lungs contains about 480 million alveoli, providing a total surface area for gas exchange of between 70 and 80 square metres. each alveolus is wrapped in a fine mesh of capillaries covering about 70% of its area. the diameter of an alveolus is between 200 and 500 mm.
=== microanatomy ===
an alveolus consists of an epithelial layer of simple squamous epithelium (very thin, flattened cells), and an extracellular matrix surrounded by capillaries. the epithelial lining is part of the alveolar membrane, also known as the respiratory membrane, that allows the exchange of gases. the membrane has several layers - a layer of alveolar lining fluid that contains surfactant, the epithelial layer and its basement membrane; a thin interstitial space between the epithelial lining and the capillary membrane; a capillary basement membrane that often fuses with the alveolar basement membrane, and the capillary endothelial membrane. the whole membrane however is only between 0.2 mm at its thinnest part and 0.6 mm at its thickest.
in the alveolar walls there are interconnecting air passages between the alveoli known as the pores of kohn. the alveolar septum that separates the alveoli in the alveolar sac contains some collagen fibers and elastic fibers. the septa also house the enmeshed capillary network that surrounds each alveolus. the elastic fibres allow the alveoli to stretch when they fill with air during inhalation. they then spring back during exhalation in order to expel the carbon dioxide-rich air.
there are three major types of alveolar cell. two types are pneumocytes or pneumonocytes known as type i and type ii cells found in the alveolar wall, and a large phagocytic cell known as an alveolar macrophage that moves about in the lumens of the alveoli, and in the connective tissue between them. type i cells, also called type i pneumocytes, or type i alveolar cells, are squamous, thin and flat and form the structure of the alveoli. type ii cells, also called type ii pneumocytes or type ii alveolar cells, release pulmonary surfactant to lower surface tension, and can also differentiate to replace damag

entities.description: "The Pulmonary Alveolus is a hollow, distensible cavity in the lungs where gas exchange takes place, crucial for oxygen-carbon dioxide exchange."

entities.name: "ALVEOLI"
entities.description: "Alveoli are small, cup-shaped cavities in the lungs that make up the lung parenchyma and are essential for gas exchange."

entities.name: "OXYGEN"
entities.description: "Oxygen is exchanged for carbon dioxide at the blood-air barrier within the alveoli, aiding in the respiratory process."

entities.name: "CARBON DIOXIDE"
entities.description: "Carbon Dioxide is released from the blood into the alveoli, to be exhaled out of the body."

entities.name: "BLOOD-AIR BARRIER"
entities.description: "The Blood-Air Barrier is a thin membrane in the alveoli where gas exchange occurs between the air in the alveoli and the blood in the capillaries."

entities.name: "CAPILLARIES"
entities.description: "Capillaries are tiny blood vessels that surround the alveoli and facilitate the exchange of gases between the bloodstream and the alveolar air."

synonyms:
right middle lobe atelectasis
atelectasis of the right middle lobe
collapse of the right middle lobe
middle lobe collapse
rml collapse
right middle lobe collapse (or simply termed middle lobe collapse) has distinctive features, but can be subtle on frontal chest radiographs. for a general discussion please refer to the article on lobar collapse. it is important to note that of all the lobes, the right middle lobe is the most likely to be chronically collapsed. when this is the case it is referred to as right middle lobe syndrome 1-3.

differential diagnosis

images:
cases and figures
imaging differential diagnosis
radiographic featuresplain radiographon frontal radiographs the findings are subtle compared to the lateral projection and include 1,2:
right mid to lower zone air space opacification (which can be subtle)
the normal horizontal fissure is no longer visible (as it rotates inferiorly rendering it non-tangental to the x-ray beam
a lordotic view may help identify the displaced fissure 2
obscuration of the right heart border
increased opacity adjacent to the right heart border requires a degree of consolidation as well as atelectasis
non-specific signs indicating right-sided atelectasis may also be present although due to the small size of the right middle lobe they may well be subtle or absent 2:
elevation of the hemidiaphragm
crowding of the right-sided ribs
a shift of the mediastinum to the right
displacement of the right hilum
on lateral projection, right middle lobe collapse is usually relatively easy to identify, appearing as a triangular opacity in the anterior aspect of the chest overlying the cardiac shadow, with its apex at the right hilum. the horizontal fissure is displaced inferiorly and the inferior part of the oblique fissure is displaced and bowed anterosuperiorly.the presence of tubular lucencies in the collapsed right middle lobe should suggest that the collapse is chronic (right middle lobe syndrome), with associated bronchiectasis 3.if there is an obstructing lesion in the bronchus intermedius, there will be signs of both rml and rll collapse.ct
triangular opacification in axial images abutting the right heart border, thinner at the hilum, and the apex pointing laterally 2
horizontal fissure rotates anteromedially 2
oblique fissure bows anteriorly 2
rul rotates anterolaterally and rll rotates posterolaterally and meets lateral to the collapsed rml 2
advertisement: supporters see fewer/no ads
differential diagnosisfrontal projectionon frontal (pa or ap) projection, right middle lobe collapse should be distinguished from:
right middle lobe consolidation: absence of signs of volume loss
pectus excavatum: downward sloping ribs and shift of the heart away from the right are clues; lateral projections make the distinction easy
lateral projectionon the lateral projection, right middle lobe collapse should be distinguished from:
fluid within the oblique fissure (pseudotumour): horizontal fissure should be visible as separate to the opacity 2
fat within the oblique fissure
consolidation of the right middle lobe

entities.description: "Right Middle Lobe refers to a collapse of the middle lobe of the right lung, which can be subtle on radiographs and may result in specific radiographic features."

entities.name: "RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Right Middle Lobe Syndrome occurs when the right middle lobe is chronically collapsed, with distinctive features that may include bronchiectasis."

entities.name: "RIGHT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right upper lobe collapse is a medical condition affecting the upper lobe of the right lung, causing an collapse of that particular area."

entities.name: "RIGHT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right lower lobe collapse is a medical condition affecting the lower lobe of the right lung, causing a collapse of that particular area."

entities.name: "LEFT UPPER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Left upper lobe collapse is a medical condition affecting the upper lobe of the left lung, causing a collapse of that particular area."

entities.name: "LEFT LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Left lower lobe collapse is a medical condition affecting the lower lobe of the left lung, causing a collapse of that particular area."

entities.name: "AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Airspace opacification is a radiological finding that indicates the presence of fluid, cells, or other substances in the air spaces of the lung, leading to an opaque appearance on imaging scans."

entities.name: "DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES OF AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Differential diagnoses of airspace opacification refer to the various possible conditions or diseases that can present with similar radiographic findings of airspace opacification, requiring a thorough evaluation to determine the specific cause."

entities.name: "BILATERAL LOWER LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Bilateral lower lobe collapse is a medical condition affecting both lower lobes of the lungs, resulting in a collapse in those specific areas."

entities.name: "MULTILOBAR COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Multilobar collapse is a medical condition characterized by the collapse of multiple lobes in one or both lungs, leading to significant respiratory impairment."

entities.name: "LOBAR PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Lobar pneumonia is a type of pneumonia that affects a specific lobe of the lung, leading to consolidation and inflammation within that area."

entities.name: "ROUND PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Round pneumonia is a term used to describe a rounded area of consolidation in the lung, often mimicking a tumor but caused by an infectious process such as pneumonia."

entities.name: "PULMONARY CONTUSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary contusion is a bruise or injury to the lung tissue, usually caused by blunt force trauma to the chest, resulting in impaired gas exchange and respiratory function."

entities.name: "CHRONIC UNILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Chronic Unilateral Airspace Opacification is a condition characterized by persistent opacity in one lung airspace."

entities.name: "CHRONIC BILATERAL AIRSPACE OPACIFICATION"
entities.description: "Chronic Bilateral Airspace Opacification is a condition characterized by persistent opacity in both lung airspaces."

entities.name: "LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Lobar Consolidation is the solidification of lung tissue in a specific lobe."

entities.name: "RIGHT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Upper Lobe Consolidation is the solidification of lung tissue in the upper right lobe."

entities.name: "RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Middle Lobe Consolidation is the solidification of lung tissue in the middle right lobe."

entities.name: "RIGHT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right Lower Lobe Consolidation is the solidification of lung tissue in the lower right lobe."

entities.name: "LEFT UPPER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Left Upper Lobe Consolidation is the solidification of lung tissue in the upper left lobe."

entities.name: "LEFT LOWER LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Left Lower Lobe Consolidation is the solidification of lung tissue in the lower left lobe."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is the collapse of lung tissue resulting in incomplete expansion of the affected area."

entities.name: "RESORPTIVE (OBSTRUCTIVE) ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Resorptive Atelectasis, also known as Obstructive Atelectasis, occurs due to airway obstruction leading to lung collapse."

entities.name: "PASSIVE (RELAXATION) ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Passive Atelectasis, also known as Relaxation Atelectasis, happens when lungs cannot expand fully due to external forces."

entities.name: "COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Compressive Atelectasis occurs when external pressure compresses the lung, causing collapse."

entities.name: "CICATRISATION ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Cicatrisation Atelectasis is lung collapse due to scar tissue formation."

entities.name: "ADHESIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Adhesive Atelectasis results from alveolar collapse due to surfactant deficiency."

entities.name: "GRAVITY DEPENDANT ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Gravity Dependent Atelectasis occurs when lung collapse due to specific positioning."

entities.name: "MORPHOLOGY-BASED ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Morphology-Based Atelectasis is a categorization based on the appearance and location of the collapsed lung."

entities.name: "LINEAR ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Linear Atelectasis is a thin band of collapsed lung tissue."

entities.name: "SEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Segmental Atelectasis is the collapse of lung segments."

entities.name: "SUBSEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Subsegmental Atelectasis is the collapse of smaller lung segments."

entities.name: "ROUND ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Round Atelectasis is a rounded shape of collapsed lung."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in your lungs."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is a condition caused by excess fluid in the lungs."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease that occurs when lung tissue becomes damaged and scarred."

entities.name: "ASTHMA"
entities.description: "Asthma is a chronic condition that affects the airways in the lungs, making it difficult to breathe."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition where the airways in the lungs are permanently widened, leading to mucus buildup and recurrent infections."

entities.name: "SARCOIDOSIS"
entities.description: "Sarcoidosis is a disease that leads to inflammation in different organs of the body, most commonly affecting the lungs."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the lungs."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a buildup of fluid between the tissues that line the lungs and the chest cavity."

entities.name: "EMPYEMA"
entities.description: "Empyema is a condition where pus accumulates in the pleural cavity, usually due to a bacterial infection."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart."

entities.name: "TUBERCULOSIS"
entities.description: "Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs."

entities.name: "ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS)"
entities.description: "Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a severe lung condition caused by fluid buildup in the lungs."

entities.name: "CYSTIC FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Cystic Fibrosis is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system."

entities.name: "PULMONARY NODULES"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Nodules are small, round growths in the lungs, often detected incidentally on imaging tests."

collapse due to surfactant deficiency."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""GRAVITY DEPENDANT ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Gravity Dependent Atelectasis occurs when lung collapse due to specific positioning."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""MORPHOLOGY-BASED ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Morphology-Based Atelectasis is a categorization based on the appearance and location of the collapsed lung."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""LINEAR ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Linear Atelectasis is a thin band of collapsed lung tissue."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""SEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Segmental Atelectasis is the collapse of lung segments."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""SUBSEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Subsegmental Atelectasis is the collapse of smaller lung segments."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""ROUND ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Round Atelectasis is a rounded shape of collapsed lung."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""INTERSTITIAL OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""ALVEOLAR OEDEMA"">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""PNEUMONIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EMBOLISM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in your lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Edema is a condition caused by excess fluid in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY FIBROSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease that occurs when lung tissue becomes damaged and scarred."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""ASTHMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Asthma is a chronic condition that affects the airways in the lungs, making it difficult to breathe."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHIECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition where the airways in the lungs are permanently widened, leading to mucus buildup and recurrent infections."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""SARCOIDOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Sarcoidosis is a disease that leads to inflammation in different organs of the body, most commonly affecting the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""LUNG CANCER"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lung Cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""PLEURAL EFFUSION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pleural Effusion is a buildup of fluid between the tissues that line the lungs and the chest cavity."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""EMPYEMA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Empyema is a condition where pus accumulates in the pleural cavity, usually due to a bacterial infection."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""TUBERCULOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a severe lung condition caused by fluid buildup in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""CYSTIC FIBROSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cystic Fibrosis is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY NODULES"">      <data key="d0">"SYMPTOM"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Nodules are small, round growths in the lungs, often detected incidentally on imaging tests."</data>      <data key="d2">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </node>    <edge source=""INTERSTITIAL OEDEMA"" target=""ALVEOLAR OEDEMA"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Interstitial Oedema and Alveolar Oedema are two types of pulmonary oedema with distinct locations and causes."</data>      <data key="d5">ab6ac68669eb883a358c1f280d09eaf7</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

{"current_user":null,"inclusions":[{"imageid":36881642,"studyid":66192,"caseslug":"normal-chest-x-ray-lobes-illustration","caption":"figure 1: position of rml","isstack":false,"diagnosticcertainty":"not_applicable","thumbnail":"https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/36881642/06badcc304026

entities.name: "METHOTREXATE LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Methotrexate lung disease is a condition associated with the use of methotrexate, potentially leading to lung-related symptoms."

entities.name: "HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS"
entities.description: "Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an inflammatory lung disease triggered by exposure to specific antigens, resulting in respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "BIRD FANCIER'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Bird fancier's lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by exposure to bird droppings, leading to respiratory issues."

entities.name: "FARMER'S LUNG"
entities.description: "Farmer's lung is a form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis resulting from exposure to moldy hay or straw, causing respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "CHEESE WORKERS' LUNG"
entities.description: "Cheese workers' lung is a subtype of hypersensitivity pneumonitis associated with exposure to mold spores in cheese-making environments, leading to respiratory complications."

entities.name: "IDIOPATHIC INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Idiopathic interstitial pneumonia refers to a group of lung diseases characterized by inflammation and scarring of lung tissue of unknown cause."

entities.name: "NON-SMALL-CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Non-small-cell lung cancer is a type of lung malignancy that includes various subtypes such as adenocarcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and large cell carcinoma."

entities.name: "CALCIFYING FIBROUS PSEUDOTUMOUR OF THE LUNG"
entities.description: "Calcifying fibrous pseudotumour of the lung is a benign lesion characterized by fibrous tissue with psammomatous or hyalinized calcifications."

entities.name: "LUNG-RADS"
entities.description: "Lung-RADS is a lung imaging reporting and data system used for standardized lung cancer screening and follow-up."

entities.name: "IASLC"
entities.description: "IASLC, the International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer, is a global organization dedicated to lung cancer research and education."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a chronic inflammatory lung condition that causes obstructed airflow."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by blood clots."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart."

entities.name: "LUNG ABSCESS"
entities.description: "A lung abscess is a localized collection of pus in the lung tissue, often caused by bacterial infections."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition in which air leaks into the space between the lung and the chest wall, causing the lung to collapse."

entities.name: "BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Bronchitis is the inflammation of the bronchial tubes in the lungs, leading to coughing and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary edema is a buildup of fluid in the lungs, usually due to heart problems."

entities.name: "LUNG NODULES"
entities.description: "Lung nodules are small masses or spots in the lungs that are often detected incidentally on imaging tests."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Respiratory distress syndrome is a breathing disorder characterized by severe breathing difficulty and low blood oxygen levels."

entities.name: "PULMONARY SARCOIDOSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary sarcoidosis is a type of sarcoidosis that affects the lungs, causing inflammation and scarring."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Calcineurin inhibitor-induced pulmonary fibrosis is a potential side effect of certain medications used after organ transplantation."

entities.name: "SMOKING-RELATED INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASES"
entities.description: "Smoking-related interstitial lung diseases are a group of lung conditions that can be triggered or exacerbated by smoking."

entities.name: "RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE COLLAPSE"
entities.description: "Right Middle Lobe Collapse is a condition where the right middle lobe of the lung collapses, as indicated by confirmed substantiated cases."

entities.name: "RML"
entities.description: "RML refers to the right middle lobe of the lung, which can be affected in cases of collapse."

entities.name: "CYSTIC FIBROSIS WITH MIDDLE LOBE COLLAPSE AND BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Cystic Fibrosis with Middle Lobe Collapse and Bronchiectasis is a condition involving cystic fibrosis, middle lobe collapse, and bronchiectasis, supported by confirmed substantiated cases."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a condition where the bronchial tubes in the lungs are abnormally widened."

entities.name: "RADIOGRAPHY"
entities.description: "Radiography is a type of imaging technology used in medical diagnostics, involving the use of X-rays to create images of the body."

entities.name: "CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Consolidation refers to a radiographic finding indicating a region of the lung where air spaces are filled with fluid or other substances."

entities.name: "RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Right middle lobe consolidation is a specific radiographic feature indicating consolidation in the right middle lobe of the lung."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is a common lung infection characterized by inflammation in the air sacs of the lungs, often leading to symptoms such as cough, fever, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "X-RAYS"
entities.description: "X-rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation used in medical imaging to create detailed images of the internal structures of the body, such as bones and organs."

entities.name: "BODY"
entities.description: "The body refers to the physical structure of a person or animal, including all internal organs, tissues, and systems."

entities.name: "AIR SPACES"
entities.description: "Air spaces in the lungs are the areas where oxygen is taken in and carbon dioxide is released during the breathing process, allowing for efficient gas exchange."

entities.name: "FLUID"
entities.description: "Fluid in the lungs refers to any liquid or material that is present within the lung tissue, which can indicate various health conditions when detected on imaging studies."

entities.name: "REGION"
entities.description: "In medical terms, a region refers to a specific area or part of the body that may be of interest for evaluation, diagnosis, or treatment purposes."

entities.name: "INFECTION"
entities.description: "Infection is a condition caused by the invasion and multiplication of harmful microorganisms, such as bacteria or viruses, in the body, leading to illness and symptoms."

entities.name: "INFLAMMATION"
entities.description: "Inflammation is the body's natural response to injury, infection, or irritation, characterized by redness, swelling, heat, and pain in the affected area."

entities.name: "SYMPTOMS"
entities.description: "Symptoms are the subjective experiences or manifestations of a health condition that are reported by the patient, such as pain, fatigue, or coughing."

chunk:
pulmonary hygiene, also referred to as pulmonary toilet, is a set of methods used to clear mucus and secretions from the airways. the word pulmonary refers to the lungs. the word toilet, related to the french toilette, refers to body care and hygiene; this root is used in words such as toiletry that also relate to cleansing.
respiratory health (pulmonary hygiene) depends on consistent clearance of airway secretions. normal airway clearance is accomplished by two important mechanisms: the mucociliary clearance system and the ability to cough. impaired mucociliary clearance is linked to poor lung function in a broad range of diseases and disabilities.
pulmonary hygiene prevents atelectasis (the collapse of the alveoli of the lungs) and rids the respiratory system of secretions, which could cause respiratory infections. it can also decrease pulmonary shunting, increase the functional reserve capacity of the lungs, and prevent respiratory infection after chest trauma. methods include using suction to remove fluids and placing the patient in a position that allows secretions to drain by gravity.
== methods ==
methods used for pulmonary hygiene include suctioning of the airways, chest physiotherapy, blow bottles, and nasotracheal suction. bronchoscopy, in which a tube is inserted into the airways so that an examiner can view them, can be used therapeutically as part of pulmonary hygiene. incentive spirometry and use of analgesics (pain medications) that do not inhibit breathing are also parts of pulmonary toilet. coughing is also important for ridding the airways of secretions, so healthcare providers are careful not to oversedate patients, because that could inhibit coughing. tracheotomy facilitates pulmonary toilet. percussion, another method, loosens secretions and allows the cilia of the airways to remove material. positioning is another method for promoting drainage of secretions; sometimes patients are placed in a prone position to aid in this purpose.
=== conventional chest physiotherapy ===
the most common treatment of atelectasis in the hospital setting is manual chest physiotherapy though there is limited evidence of its efficacy. chest percussion and postural drainage are used in bronchiectasis and lung abscess. the patient's body is positioned so that the trachea is inclined downward and below the affected chest area. postural drainage is essential in treating bronchiectasis. patients must receive physiotherapy to learn to tip themselves into a position in which the lobe to be drained is uppermost at least three times daily for up to 30 minutes during each session.
the treatment is often used in conjunction with a technique for loosening secretions in the chest cavity called chest percussion. chest percussion is performed by clapping the back or chest with a cupped hand. alternatively, a mechanical vibrator may be used in some cases to facilitate loosening of secretions. there are drainage positions for all segments of the lung. these positions are modified depending on the patient's condition and the location of the area in most need of therapy.
=== intermittent positive pressure breathing (physiotherapy) ===
intermittent positive pressure breathing (ippb) physiotherapy has long been used in the intensive care setting in non-intubated patients. although widely accepted, few studies have validated its efficacy. in a respiratory care clinical practice guideline, ippb is suggested for patients who have impaired airway clearance, and for delivery of aerosolized medications to patients with neuromuscular weakness who are incapable of inhaling deeply. ippb physiotherapy should be used with caution in patients with severe, uncontrolled bronchospasm or severe airway obstruction
=== mechanical insufflation-exsufflation physiotherapy ===
people with neuromuscular weakness and atelectasis benefit from mechanical insufflation-exsufflation. mechanically-assisted coughing greatly improves secretion clearance in t

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYGIENE"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hygiene is a method used to clear mucus and secretions from the airways to maintain respiratory health."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is the collapse of the alveoli of the lungs, which can be prevented by pulmonary hygiene methods."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY INFECTIONS"
entities.description: "Respiratory Infections are prevented by maintaining pulmonary hygiene to clear secretions from the respiratory system."

entities.name: "BRONCHOSCOPY"
entities.description: "Bronchoscopy is a therapeutic method used as part of pulmonary hygiene to view and clear the airways."

entities.name: "CHEST PHYSIOTHERAPY"
entities.description: "Chest Physiotherapy is a common method for treating atelectasis and other respiratory conditions, often used in conjunction with postural drainage."

entities.name: "IPPB PHYSIOTHERAPY"
entities.description: "IPPB Physiotherapy is used in patients with impaired airway clearance and neuromuscular weakness to aid in breathing and delivery of medications."

entities.name: "MUCUS"
entities.description: "Mucus is a secretion that needs to be cleared from the airways for effective pulmonary hygiene."

entities.name: "SECRETIONS"
entities.description: "Secretions in the respiratory system need to be cleared through pulmonary hygiene to prevent infections and improve lung function.")("relationship"

entities.name: "POSTURAL DRAINAGE"
entities.description: "Postural Drainage is a technique used in pulmonary hygiene to help mobilize and clear secretions from different areas of the lungs."

entities.name: "FLUTTER VALVE"
entities.description: "The Flutter Valve is a device used in pulmonary hygiene to help mobilize and clear mucus from the airways through positive expiratory pressure."

entities.name: "COUGHING"
entities.description: "Coughing is a natural mechanism that assists in clearing mucus and secretions from the lungs as part of pulmonary hygiene."

entities.name: "CYSTIC FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Patients with Cystic Fibrosis may benefit from pulmonary hygiene techniques to manage the build-up of mucus in the lungs."

entities.name: "TRACHEOSTOMY"
entities.description: "Tracheostomy is a surgical procedure that may be used in conjunction with pulmonary hygiene methods to assist with airway clearance and secretion management."

chunk:
postoperative fever refers to an elevated body temperature (>= 38.5 degc) occurring after a recent surgical procedure. diagnosing the cause of postoperative fever can sometimes be challenging; while fever in this context may be benign, self-limited, or unrelated to the surgical procedure, it can also be indicative of a surgical complication, such as infection.
== causes ==
the most common causes of postoperative fever are often summarized for medical students by a mnemonic beginning with the letter w. the classic list consists of five w's - wind, water, wound, walking, and wonder drugs, but two other causes should also be considered - wing/waterway and (w)abscess. there is a characteristic timeframe after surgery when many of these complications tend to develop (postoperative days or pod).
other important causes of early post-operative fever that are omitted from this list include malignant hyperthermia, a potentially life-threatening but treatable response to inhalational anesthetic and paralytic agents.
early postoperative fever (i.e., within the first 48 hours post-operatively) has often been ascribed to atelectasis, or splinting, but it is most likely part of a natural and non-infectious inflammatory response (with sympathetic nervous system involvement) to the tissue injury sustained during surgery; it generally requires no medical intervention except antipyretics and extra fluid intake.
== workup ==
the diagnostic workup of post-operative fever is guided by the potential etiologies on the differential diagnosis. the patient's surgical and post-operative course should be reviewed in detail, noting whether the patient has been regularly using an incentive spirometer or not, whether a foley catheter was/is in place, what medications s/he has received, etc. the patient should be asked if s/he is having any pain (and where?) or other symptoms such as coughing or dysuria, which may help to localize the source of the fever. a thorough physical exam should be conducted, auscultating the lungs, noting erythema or drainage from the surgical incision(s), evaluating iv sites, noting lower extremity edema, etc.
laboratory testing and imaging is generally deferred for evaluation of fever that occurs within the first 48 hours post-operatively, unless prompted by specific findings in the history and physical exam. beyond 48 hours, testing routinely includes urine and blood cultures as well as a chest x-ray.
== popular culture ==
in the pilot episode of the medical drama grey's anatomy, meredith grey refers to this mnemonic: "wind, water, wound, walking, wonder drugs. the 5 ws. most of the time it's wind; splinting or pneumonia. pneumonia is easy to assume. especially if you're too busy to do the tests."
== see also ==
patient safety
perioperative mortality
== references ==

entities.name: "POSTOPERATIVE FEVER"
entities.description: "Postoperative Fever refers to an elevated body temperature occurring after surgery, with various potential causes and implications."

entities.name: "MALIGNANT HYPERTHERMIA"
entities.description: "Malignant Hyperthermia is a life-threatening response to anesthetic agents, requiring prompt treatment."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is a condition often associated with early post-operative fever, involving incomplete lung expansion."

entities.name: "SPLINTING"
entities.description: "Splinting is a possible explanation for early post-operative fever, involving restricted movement of the chest."

entities.name: "INFLAMMATORY RESPONSE"
entities.description: "Inflammatory Response is a natural reaction to tissue injury, possibly contributing to post-operative fever."

entities.name: "INCENTIVE SPIROMETER"
entities.description: "Incentive Spirometer is a device used post-surgery to promote lung expansion and prevent atelectasis."

entities.name: "FOLEY CATHETER"
entities.description: "Foley Catheter is often utilized during surgery to drain urine and monitor fluid output."

entities.name: "MEREDITH GREY"
entities.description: "Meredith Grey is a character from Grey's Anatomy who references the mnemonic for postoperative fever causes."

entities.name: "URINARY TRACT INFECTION"
entities.description: "Urinary Tract Infection is a common cause of postoperative fever, especially in patients with indwelling catheters."

entities.name: "DEEP VEIN THROMBOSIS"
entities.description: "Deep Vein Thrombosis is a potential complication post-surgery that can manifest with symptoms like fever and swelling."

entities.name: "WOUND INFECTION"
entities.description: "Wound Infection can result in postoperative fever and typically presents with local signs of redness, warmth, and discharge."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY INFECTION"
entities.description: "Respiratory Infection can lead to fever after surgery, particularly if the patient is intubated or has a compromised immune system."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a serious condition characterized by a blockage in the pulmonary arteries, which can present with symptoms like fever and chest pain."

entities.name: "DRUG REACTION"
entities.description: "Drug Reaction to medications administered during surgery can sometimes manifest as postoperative fever."

entities.name: "HEMATOMA"
entities.description: "Hematoma formation at the surgical site can lead to localized inflammation and fever as part of the healing process."

entities.name: "HYPOVOLEMIA"
entities.description: "Hypovolemia, or low blood volume, can contribute to postoperative fever as the body works to compensate for inadequate circulating fluid."

chunk:
tympanic membrane retraction describes a condition in which a part of the eardrum lies deeper within the ear than its normal position.
the eardrum comprises two parts: the pars tensa, which is the main part of the eardrum, and the pars flaccida, which is a smaller part of the eardrum located above the pars tensa. either or both of these parts may become retracted. the retracted segment of eardrum is often known as a retraction pocket. the terms atelectasis or sometimes adhesive otitis media can be used to describe retraction of a large area of the pars tensa.
tympanic membrane retraction is fairly common and has been observed in one quarter of a population of british school children. retraction of both eardrums is less common than having a retraction in just one ear. it is more common in children with cleft palate. tympanic membrane retraction also occurs in adults.
attempts have been made to categorise the extent of tympanic membrane retraction though the validity of these classifications is limited.
== presentation ==
the majority of tympanic membrane retractions do not cause any symptoms. some cause hearing loss by restricting sound-induced vibrations of the eardrum. permanent conductive hearing loss can be caused by erosion of the ossicles (hearing bones). discharge from the ear often indicates that the retraction pocket has developed into a cholesteatoma.
== pathogenesis ==
three factors must occur for the tympanic membrane to become retracted:
=== negative middle ear pressure ===
when gas pressure within the middle ear is less than atmospheric pressure, the eardrum can become sucked into the middle ear space. this may be caused by disrupted gas exchange in the middle ear mucosa, inadequate opening of the eustachian tube or a combination of these factors. people with a patulous eustachian tube may also cause negative middle ear pressure by repeatedly sniffing to try to keep their eustachian tube closed.
=== weakness of the tympanic membrane ===
the middle layer of the pars tensa is strengthened by fibers of collagen protein. this layer may be weaker in the postero-superior quadrant (top rear quarter) or after the eardrum heals after perforation or tympanostomy tubes (grommets) so predispose to retraction in these areas. the pars flaccida is prone to retraction as it does not contain the same stiffening layer of collagen.
=== increase in surface area of the tympanic membrane ===
all over the body, new skin cells are continually produced to replace old skin cells which dry out and slough off. growth of new cells on the surface of the eardrum is unusual in that the new cells migrate over the surface and move out along the ear canal. even if migration along the ear canal is blocked, new cells continue to grow so the surface of the eardrum becomes larger. this process of proliferation and migration can result in enlargement of a retraction pocket so that the eardrum expands and grows deeper into the ear.
== natural history ==
the majority of tympanic membrane retractions remain stable for long periods of time, or may even resolve spontaneously so that the eardrum becomes normal again. not all retractions are able to resolve even if middle ear pressure normalizes, as the retracted segment may become adherent to other structures within the middle ear. some retractions continue to progress and grow more deeply into the ear. this can result in erosion of bone and cholesteatoma formation. asymptomatic deep pars tensa retractions tend to remain stable in adults. however, behaviour of symptomatic pars tensa retractions significantly differ between children and adults. there is a likelihood that such ears in children will recover spontaneously. there is no simple clinical means of identifying which ears will deteriorate to accumulate keratin debris in the pars tensa retraction, a phenomenon that is not influenced by age. in children, the pars tensa retraction may remain unchanged while the pars flaccida deteriorate

entities.name: "TYMPANIC MEMBRANE RETRACTION"
entities.description: "Tympanic Membrane Retraction is a condition where a part of the eardrum lies deeper within the ear than normal, leading to potential complications in hearing and ossicle erosion."

entities.name: "EARDRUM"
entities.description: "The Eardrum consists of the pars tensa and pars flaccida, with retraction potentially affecting both parts and leading to the formation of a retraction pocket."

entities.name: "CHOLESTEATOMA"
entities.description: "Cholesteatoma is indicated by discharge from the ear and can result from the development of a retraction pocket within the eardrum."

entities.name: "BRITISH SCHOOL CHILDREN"
entities.description: "British School Children have shown a prevalence of tympanic membrane retraction in one quarter of the population, with variations based on factors such as cleft palate."

entities.name: "POSTERO-SUPERIOR QUADRANT"
entities.description: "The Postero-Superior Quadrant refers to the top rear quarter of the tympanic membrane, where weakness in collagen fibers may predispose to retraction."

entities.name: "MIDDLE EAR"
entities.description: "The Middle Ear can experience negative pressure, leading to tympanic membrane retraction, which may be influenced by issues in the eustachian tube or middle ear mucosa."

entities.name: "EUSTACHIAN TUBE"
entities.description: "The Eustachian Tube connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx and is involved in regulating pressure in the middle ear, impacting the development of tympanic membrane retraction."

entities.name: "MIDDLE EAR MUCOSA"
entities.description: "The Middle Ear Mucosa lines the middle ear space and can be a factor in tympanic membrane retraction when inflammation or dysfunction occurs."

entities.name: "OSSICLES"
entities.description: "The Ossicles are three small bones in the middle ear that transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear, and can be at risk of erosion in cases of tympanic membrane retraction."

entities.name: "RETRACTION POCKET"
entities.description: "A Retraction Pocket is a pocket or pouch that forms in the eardrum due to tympanic membrane retraction, and can potentially lead to complications like cholesteatoma."

chunk:
the comet tail sign is a radiological finding seen in chest ct. it refers to a specific appearance resembling a comet's tail, characterised by a bright, streaky opacity due to the presence of a round atelectasis in chest ct.
== description ==
in case of a round atelectatic mass, the nearby bronchovascular bundle appears to be pulled into the mass, resembling the tail of a comet. the comet tail usually extends from a central point in the lung periphery towards the hilum. if intravenous contrast is injected, homogenous enhancement is seen.
== references ==
