chunk:
silent sinus syndrome is a spontaneous, asymptomatic collapse of an air sinus (usually the maxillary sinus and orbital floor) associated with negative sinus pressures. it can cause painless facial asymmetry, diplopia and enophthalmos. diagnosis is suspected based on symptoms, and can be confirmed using a ct scan. treatment is surgical involving making an outlet for mucous drainage from the obstructed sinus, and, in some cases, paired with reconstruction of the orbital floor. it is slightly more common in middle age.
== signs and symptoms ==
silent sinus syndrome can cause facial asymmetry (usually without pain), and vision problems (such as diplopia and enophthalmos). it may also cause headaches, and a feeling of fullness in the nose.
== mechanism ==
silent sinus syndrome most often affects the maxillary sinus, usually with a collapse of the orbital floor. it may also affect the frontal sinus or the ethmoid sinus. when the maxillary sinus is involved, the inferior oblique muscle may be damaged.
the cause of silent sinus syndrome is not well understood. bacteria in the maxillary sinus may be involved. the connection to the nose may be blocked. this can create negative pressure in the sinus, as secretions are reabsorbed.
risk factors for silent sinus syndrome include any anatomic condition causing obstruction of the maxillary ostium, such as ipsilateral nasal septum deviation,ipsilateral laterally deviated middle turbinate, and narrowed infundibulum.
== diagnosis ==
silent sinus syndrome is first suspected based on symptoms. a ct scan can be used to confirm a diagnosis. this can have characteristic features, including maxillary sinus outlet obstruction, sinus opacification, and sinus volume loss caused by inward retraction of the sinus walls.
=== differential diagnosis ===
silent sinus syndrome is a subtype of stage three chronic maxillary atelectasis. the distinguishing factor is that in silent sinus syndrome, there is an absence of sinusitis symptoms. to be clear, chronic maxillary sinusitis may be a primary causitive factor in a significant number of silent sinus syndrome cases, it just may be asymptomatic. silent sinus syndrome also must be distinguished from maxillary sinus hypoplasia, which is congenital.
== treatment ==
silent sinus syndrome is usually treated with surgery. the first stage involves restoring sinus function, most often by performing an endoscopic uncinectomy (removal of uncinate process) and maxillary antrostomy. the second stage, if needed, involves reconstruction of the orbital floor. while some clinics perform the two stages simultaneously, most authorities recommend waiting a minimum of 6 or as many as 18 months, as spontaneous remodeling of the orbital floor after the sinus repair will occur in many if not most cases. any prolapsed contents (such as those from the orbit) must be put back in place, though this is an rare occurrence in an already rare syndrome. if the inferior oblique muscle is damaged, it may be partially removed (known as myectomy). mucus and secretions must be drained from the sinus. earlier treatment has better outcomes.
== epidemiology ==
silent sinus syndrome is fairly rare. it can occur at any age, but is slightly more common in middle-aged people. it occurs equally in sinuses on each side of the face.
== history ==
silent sinus syndrome was first described in 1964.
== references ==
=== bibliography ===
illner a, davidson hc, harnsberger hr, hoffman j (2002). "the silent sinus syndrome: clinical and radiographic findings". ajr am j roentgenol. 178 (2): 503-6. doi:10.2214/ajr.178.2.1780503. pmid 11804926. full text
numa wa, desai u, gold dr, heher kl, annino dj (2005). "silent sinus syndrome: a case presentation and comprehensive review of all 84 reported cases". ann otol rhinol laryngol. 114 (9): 688-94. doi:10.1177/000348940511400906. pmid 16240931. s2cid 19348879.
habicht me, eppenberger pe, galassi fm, ruhli fj, henneberg m (2018). "queen meresankh iii - the

entities.name: "SILENT SINUS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Silent Sinus Syndrome is a condition characterized by a collapse of an air sinus, usually the maxillary sinus and orbital floor, leading to facial asymmetry, diplopia, and enophthalmos."

entities.name: "FACIAL ASYMMETRY"
entities.description: "Facial Asymmetry is a symptom of Silent Sinus Syndrome, often presenting without pain and causing a visual asymmetry in the face."

entities.name: "DIPLOPIA"
entities.description: "Diplopia is a symptom of Silent Sinus Syndrome, characterized by double vision."

entities.name: "ENOPHTHALMOS"
entities.description: "Enophthalmos is a symptom of Silent Sinus Syndrome, where the eye recedes into the socket."

entities.name: "CT SCAN"
entities.description: "A CT scan is used in the diagnosis of Silent Sinus Syndrome to confirm symptoms and identify specific features in the sinuses."

entities.name: "TREATMENT"
entities.description: "Treatment for Silent Sinus Syndrome involves surgical intervention to restore sinus function and, in some cases, reconstruct the orbital floor for better outcomes."

entities.name: "ORBITAL FLOOR"
entities.description: "The orbital floor is often affected in Silent Sinus Syndrome, leading to diplopia and enophthalmos due to its collapse."

entities.name: "SURGICAL INTERVENTION"
entities.description: "Surgical intervention is a key aspect of treating Silent Sinus Syndrome, aiming to restore sinus function and correct facial asymmetry."

lung atelectasis (plural: atelectases) refers to the collapse or incomplete expansion of pulmonary parenchyma.

images:cases and figures
terminologyatelectasis may be used synonymously with collapse, but some authors reserve the term "atelectasis" for partial collapse, not inclusive of total atelectasis of the affected part of the lung or whole lung collapse.pathologyatelectasis is a radiopathological sign that can be categorised in many ways. each approach aims to help identify possible underlying causes together with other accompanying radiological and clinical findings.atelectasis can be subcategorised based on the underlying mechanism, as follows:
resorptive (obstructive) atelectasis
occurs as a result of complete obstruction of an airway
no new air can enter the portion of the lung distal to the obstruction, and any air that is already there is eventually absorbed into the pulmonary capillary system, leaving a collapsed section of the affected lung
because the visceral and parietal pleura do not separate in resorptive atelectasis, traction is created, and if the loss of volume is considerable, mobile thoracic structures may be pulled toward the side of volume loss ("mediastinal shift")
potential causes of resorptive atelectasis include obstructing neoplasms, mucus plugging in asthmatics or critically ill patients and foreign body aspiration
resorptive atelectasis of an entire lung ("collapsed lung") can result from complete obstruction of the right or left main bronchus
passive (relaxation) atelectasis
occurs when contact between the parietal and visceral pleura is disrupted with loss of normal negative pressure and the lung relaxes due to natural elastic recoil
the three most common specific aetiologies of passive atelectasis are pleural effusion, pneumothorax and diaphragmatic abnormality
compressive atelectasis
occurs as a result of any thoracic space-occupying lesion (e.g. large pneumothorax) compressing the lung and forcing air out of the alveoli
cicatrisation atelectasis
occurs as a result of scarring or fibrosis that reduces lung expansion
common aetiologies include granulomatous disease, necrotising pneumonia and radiation fibrosis
adhesive atelectasis
occurs from surfactant deficiency 2
depending on aetiology, this deficiency may either be diffuse throughout the lungs or localised
gravity dependant atelectasis (dependent atelectasis)
in the most dependent portions of the lungs due to the weight of the lungs
osteophyte-induced adjacent pulmonary atelectasis and fibrosis
atelectasis can also be subcategorised by morphology:
linear (a.k.a. plate, band, discoid) atelectasis: a minimal degree of collapse as seen in patients who are not taking deep breaths ("splinting"), such as postoperative patients or patients with rib fracture or pleuritic chest pain; this is very common
round atelectasis: classically associated with asbestos exposure
lastly atelectasis can be described according to anatomical extent:
lung atelectasis: complete collapse of one lung
lobar atelectasis: collapse of one or more lobes of a lung.
segmental atelectasis: collapse of one or more individual pulmonary segments
subsegmental atelectasis: collapse of a portion of a pulmonary segment

entities.name: "LUNG ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Lung Atelectasis refers to the collapse or incomplete expansion of pulmonary parenchyma."

entities.name: "RESORPTIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Resorptive Atelectasis occurs due to complete obstruction of an airway, leading to collapse of a portion of the affected lung."

entities.name: "PASSIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Passive Atelectasis happens when contact between parietal and visceral pleura is disrupted, causing the lung to relax due to elastic recoil."

entities.name: "COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Compressive Atelectasis results from thoracic space-occupying lesions compressing the lung and forcing air out of the alveoli."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS MORPHOLOGY"
entities.description: "Atelectasis can be categorized based on morphology, including linear atelectasis and round atelectasis."

entities.name: "ANATOMICAL EXTENT OF ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis can be described based on anatomical extent, such as lung atelectasis, lobar atelectasis, and segmental atelectasis."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS SYMPTOMS"
entities.description: "Symptoms of atelectasis may include shortness of breath, chest pain, and decreased oxygen levels in the blood."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS DIAGNOSIS"
entities.description: "Diagnosis of atelectasis involves imaging studies such as chest X-rays and CT scans, as well as pulmonary function tests."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS TREATMENT"
entities.description: "Treatment for atelectasis may include chest physiotherapy, bronchodilators, and in severe cases, mechanical ventilation."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS PROGNOSIS"
entities.description: "The prognosis of atelectasis depends on the underlying cause and the extent of lung involvement, with most cases resolving with appropriate treatment."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS PREVENTION"
entities.description: "Prevention of atelectasis involves early mobilization after surgery, coughing and deep breathing exercises, and proper management of respiratory conditions."

Atelectasis happens when contact between parietal and visceral pleura is disrupted, causing the lung to relax due to elastic recoil."</data>      <data key="d2">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </node>    <node id=""COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Compressive Atelectasis results from thoracic space-occupying lesions compressing the lung and forcing air out of the alveoli."</data>      <data key="d2">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </node>    <node id=""ATELECTASIS MORPHOLOGY"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Atelectasis can be categorized based on morphology, including linear atelectasis and round atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d2">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </node>    <node id=""ANATOMICAL EXTENT OF ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Atelectasis can be described based on anatomical extent, such as lung atelectasis, lobar atelectasis, and segmental atelectasis."</data>      <data key="d2">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </node>    <node id=""ATELECTASIS SYMPTOMS"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Symptoms of atelectasis may include shortness of breath, chest pain, and decreased oxygen levels in the blood."</data>      <data key="d2">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </node>    <node id=""ATELECTASIS DIAGNOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Diagnosis of atelectasis involves imaging studies such as chest X-rays and CT scans, as well as pulmonary function tests."</data>      <data key="d2">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </node>    <node id=""ATELECTASIS TREATMENT"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Treatment for atelectasis may include chest physiotherapy, bronchodilators, and in severe cases, mechanical ventilation."</data>      <data key="d2">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </node>    <node id=""ATELECTASIS PROGNOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"The prognosis of atelectasis depends on the underlying cause and the extent of lung involvement, with most cases resolving with appropriate treatment."</data>      <data key="d2">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </node>    <node id=""ATELECTASIS PREVENTION"">      <data key="d0">"CONCEPT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Prevention of atelectasis involves early mobilization after surgery, coughing and deep breathing exercises, and proper management of respiratory conditions."</data>      <data key="d2">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </node>    <edge source=""LUNG ATELECTASIS"" target=""RESORPTIVE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Resorptive Atelectasis is a type of lung atelectasis that occurs due to airway obstruction."</data>      <data key="d5">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""LUNG ATELECTASIS"" target=""PASSIVE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Passive Atelectasis is another form of lung atelectasis that occurs due to disruption of parietal and visceral pleura."</data>      <data key="d5">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""LUNG ATELECTASIS"" target=""COMPRESSIVE ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Compressive Atelectasis is a type of lung atelectasis caused by thoracic lesions compressing the lung."</data>      <data key="d5">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""LUNG ATELECTASIS"" target=""ATELECTASIS MORPHOLOGY"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Different morphological types of atelectasis, such as linear and round, can affect the lung parenchyma."</data>      <data key="d5">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""LUNG ATELECTASIS"" target=""ANATOMICAL EXTENT OF ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Atelectasis can occur at different anatomical levels, including complete lung collapse and segmental collapse."</data>      <data key="d5">8fb01ff9af570ff63ae7bab33ccdac6c</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
chest pain; this is very common
round atelectasis: classically associated with asbestos exposure
lastly atelectasis can be described according to anatomical extent:
lung atelectasis: complete collapse of one lung
lobar atelectasis: collapse of one or more lobes of a lung.
segmental atelectasis: collapse of one or more individual pulmonary segments
subsegmental atelectasis: collapse of a portion of a pulmonary segment
advertisement: supporters see fewer/no ads
radiographic featuresvary depending on the underlying mechanism and type of atelectasisplain radiograph / ctdirect signs of atelectasis
displacement of interlobar fissures
crowding together of pulmonary vessels
crowded air bronchograms (does not apply to all types of atelectasis; can be seen in subsegmental atelectasis due to small peripheral bronchi obstruction, usually by secretions; if the cause of the atelectasis is central bronchial obstruction, there will usually be no air bronchograms)
indirect signs of atelectasis
pulmonary opacification
shifting granuloma (or any other previously documented lesion, used as a reference for comparison)
compensatory hyperexpansion of the surrounding or contralateral lung
displacement of the heart, mediastinum, trachea, hilum
elevation of the diaphragm
propinquity of the ribs
resorptive (obstructive) atelectasis
increased density (opacity) of the atelectatic portion of lung
displacement of the fissures toward the area of atelectasis
upward displacement of hemidiaphragm ipsilateral to the side of atelectasis
crowding of pulmonary vessels and bronchi in region of atelectasis
+/- compensatory overinflation of unaffected lung
+/- displacement of thoracic structures (if atelectasis is substantial)
linear (plate, discoid, subsegmental) atelectasisrelatively thin, linear densities in the lung bases orientated parallel to the diaphragm (known as fleischner lines) ultrasoundthe sonographic morphology of atelectatic lung may resemble hepatic parenchyma, often referred to as "tissue-like" or "hepatized" in appearance. distinguishing features of atelectasis by aetiology may appear as follows:
compressive atelectasis is most often visualised in the costophrenic recess bordered by a disproportionately large pleural effusion
low-level, homogenous echogenicity with few to no air bronchograms
margins are usually regular with a triangular shape 10
a shred sign may be present at the transition to aerated lung
obstructive atelectasis
early static air bronchograms due to distal air trapping
as the air is resorbed, bronchi may fill with fluid resulting in anechoic, tubular structures known as fluid bronchograms 11
may be differentiated from blood vessels with colour flow doppler
ctair bronchograms indicate patency of the proximal airways and the airways will be crowded indicating volume loss. if air bronchograms are absent suspect an obstructing lesion or mucoid impaction. in this latter case, bronchoscopy may be helpful.following iv contrast medium, atelectatic lung enhances more than skeletal muscle 12.these features of volume loss and marked enhancement together with the absence of fever help to distinguish atelectasis from pneumonic consolidation.
advertisement: supporters see fewer/no ads
history and etymologyatelectasis comes from the greek words 'ateles' and 'ektasis' translating to 'incomplete expansion' 6.

1. william kemp, dennis burns, travis brown. pathology: the big picture. (2007) isbn: 9780071477482 - google books
2. kumar. robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease, professional edition, 8th ed. saunders. 2009. purchase from amazon
3. woodring j & reed j. radiographic manifestations of lobar atelectasis. j thorac imaging. 1996;11(2):109-44. doi:10.1097/00005382-199621000-00003 - pubmed
4. woodring j. determining the cause of pulmonary atelectasis: a comparison of plain radiography and ct. ajr am j roentgenol. 1988;150(4):757-63. doi:10.2214/ajr.150.4.757 - pubmed
5. ashizawa k, hayashi k, aso n, minami k. lobar atelectasis: diagnostic pitfalls on chest radiography. br j radiol. 2001;74(877):89-97. doi:10.1259/bjr.74.877.740089 - pubmed
6. woodring j & reed j. types and mechanisms of pulmonary atelectasis. j thorac imaging. 1996;11(2):92-108. doi:10.1097/00005382-199621000-00002 - pubmed
7. richard b. gunderman. essential radiology. (2006) isbn: 9781588900821 - google books
8. e. robert heitzman. the lung, radiologic-pathologic correlations. (1984) isbn

entities.name: "CHEST PAIN"
entities.description: "Chest pain is a common symptom experienced by individuals."

entities.name: "ROUND ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Round atelectasis is classically associated with asbestos exposure, and can be described according to anatomical extent."

entities.name: "LUNG ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Lung atelectasis involves the complete collapse of one lung."

entities.name: "LOBAR ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Lobar atelectasis refers to the collapse of one or more lobes of a lung."

entities.name: "SEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Segmental atelectasis is characterized by the collapse of one or more individual pulmonary segments."

entities.name: "SUBSEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description:
"Subsegmental atelectasis is the collapse of a smaller portion within a pulmonary segment."
"Subsegmental atelectasis involves the collapse of a portion of a pulmonary segment."

entities.name: "RADIOGRAPHIC FEATURES"
entities.description: "Radiographic features vary based on the underlying mechanism and type of atelectasis."

entities.name: "OPACITY"
entities.description: "Opacity indicates increased density in the atelectatic portion of the lung."

entities.name: "AIR BRONCHOGRAMS"
entities.description: "Air bronchograms refer to crowded air-filled bronchi visible on imaging."

entities.name: "COMPENSATORY HYPEREXPANSION"
entities.description: "Compensatory hyperexpansion refers to increased lung volume in unaffected areas due to atelectasis."

entities.name: "HEART DISPLACEMENT"
entities.description: "Heart displacement is the movement of the heart from its normal position due to atelectasis."

entities.name: "DISPLACED DIAPHRAGM"
entities.description: "Elevation of the diaphragm is observed in atelectasis, causing displacement."

entities.name: "THORACIC STRUCTURES DISPLACEMENT"
entities.description: "Displacement of thoracic structures occurs with substantial atelectasis, impacting normal anatomy."

entities.name: "OBSTRUCTIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Obstructive atelectasis occurs due to blockage of the airways, preventing lung expansion."

entities.name: "ADHESIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Adhesive atelectasis is caused by surfactant deficiency, leading to lung collapse."

entities.name: "RESORPTIVE ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Resorptive atelectasis is associated with airway obstruction and absorption of trapped air."

entities.name: "COMPRESSION ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Compression atelectasis results from external pressure on the lung, causing collapse."

entities.name: "MICROATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Microatelectasis refers to small areas of collapsed lung tissue within the alveoli."

entities.name: "CENTRAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Central atelectasis involves collapse of the central portion of the lung, affecting the main bronchi."

entities.name: "CHRONIC ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Chronic atelectasis is a long-term condition of incomplete lung expansion or collapse."

entities.name: "EXPECTORATION"
entities.description: "Expectoration of sputum may occur in some cases of atelectasis."

entities.name: "CYANOSIS"
entities.description: "Cyanosis, a bluish discoloration of the skin, may be present in atelectasis due to poor oxygenation."

entities.name: "DIMINISHED BREATH SOUNDS"
entities.description: "Diminished breath sounds can be a clinical finding in patients with atelectasis."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS ON CT SCAN"
entities.description: "Atelectasis on CT scan may show areas of collapse or consolidation in the lung tissue."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS TREATMENT"
entities.description: "Atelectasis treatment aims to re-expand the collapsed lung tissue and improve ventilation."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS PREVENTION"
entities.description: "Prevention strategies for atelectasis include early mobility and pulmonary hygiene."

entities.name: "PULMONARY ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Atelectasis is a condition characterized by the collapse or closure of lung tissue, leading to symptoms such as difficulty breathing and chest pain."

entities.name: "RESORPTIVE (OBSTRUCTIVE) ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Resorptive Atelectasis is a type of lung collapse caused by blockage of the air passages, leading to impaired oxygen exchange and potential complications."

entities.name: "PULMONARY PARENCHYMAL BANDS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Parenchymal Bands refer to linear opacities seen on imaging studies, indicating underlying lung changes or diseases."

entities.name: "LINEAR ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Linear Atelectasis is a type of lung collapse characterized by linear shadowing on imaging, often associated with scarring or fibrosis."

entities.name: "SOLITARY PULMONARY NODULE"
entities.description: "Solitary Pulmonary Nodule is a single abnormal mass in the lung, which may be benign or malignant and requires further evaluation."

entities.name: "ROUND ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Round Atelectasis is a rare form of lung collapse marked by a rounded opacity on imaging, typically associated with pleural thickening or fibrosis."

entities.name: "SEGMENTAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Segmental Atelectasis is a partial collapse of a lung segment, usually due to blockage of a bronchus or other airway obstruction."

entities.name: "LOBAR ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Lobar Atelectasis is the collapse of an entire lobe of the lung, commonly caused by blockage of a bronchus or mass effect."

entities.name: "CONGENITAL ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Congenital Atelectasis is a type of lung collapse present at birth, often due to malformations or abnormalities in the airway development."

entities.name: "CHRONIC ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Chronic Atelectasis is a long-standing and persistent collapse of lung tissue, which can lead to complications such as infections or respiratory issues."

entities.name: "MEDIASTINAL CATHETER POSITIONS"
entities.description: "Mediastinal Catheter Positions are medical devices used for specific medical procedures in the chest area."

entities.name: "OESOPHAGEAL TEMPERATURE PROBE"
entities.description: "Oesophageal Temperature Probe is a medical device used to measure temperature in the esophagus."

entities.name: "TRACHEOSTOMY TUBE"
entities.description: "Tracheostomy Tube is a medical device inserted into the trachea to provide an airway."

entities.name: "PLEURAL CATHETERS"
entities.description: "Pleural Catheters are devices placed in the pleural space to drain fluid or air."

entities.name: "CARDIAC CONDUCTION DEVICES"
entities.description: "Cardiac Conduction Devices are devices used to manage heart rhythm disorders."

entities.name: "PROSTHETIC HEART VALVE"
entities.description: "Prosthetic Heart Valve is an artificial device used to replace a damaged heart valve."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is a condition where the lung or a portion of it collapses due to incomplete expansion of air sacs."

entities.name: "LOBAR CONSOLIDATION"
entities.description: "Lobar Consolidation is a condition where a lobe of the lung becomes solid instead of filled with air."

entities.name: "CARDIOMEGALY"
entities.description: "Cardiomegaly refers to an enlarged heart, which can be a sign of various heart conditions."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a serious lung condition that primarily affects premature infants and causes difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "PLEURISY"
entities.description: "Pleurisy is an inflammation of the pleura, the lining surrounding the lungs, which can cause chest pain when breathing."

entities.name: "THORACOTOMY"
entities.description: "Thoracotomy is a surgical procedure where an incision is made into the chest wall to access the organs inside the chest cavity."

entities.name: "OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Oedema is a symptom characterized by the swelling of body tissues due to fluid accumulation."

entities.name: "CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Cardiogenic Pulmonary Oedema is a disease caused by heart failure resulting in fluid accumulation in the lungs."

entities.name: "NON-CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Non-cardiogenic Pulmonary Oedema is a disease not caused by heart failure, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL LUNG DISEASE (ILD)"
entities.description: "Interstitial Lung Disease is a category of lung diseases affecting the interstitium of the lungs, leading to inflammation and fibrosis."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a type of cancer that originates in the lungs, often categorized into subtypes based on histological features."

entities.name: "ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS)"
entities.description: "Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a severe lung condition that causes fluid to leak into the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and low oxygen levels in the blood."

entities.name: "KIDNEY DISEASE"
entities.description: "Kidney Disease is a condition that affects the kidneys' ability to filter waste and excess fluids from the blood, leading to various complications like fluid retention."

entities.name: "LIVER CIRRHOSIS"
entities.description: "Liver Cirrhosis is a late stage of scarring of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions, leading to fluid accumulation in the abdomen and other parts of the body."

entities.name: "VENOUS INSUFFICIENCY"
entities.description: "Venous Insufficiency is a condition in which the veins have problems sending blood from the limbs back to the heart, leading to swelling and fluid accumulation."

entities.name: "HYPOTHYROIDISM"
entities.description: "Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, leading to various symptoms including fluid retention."

entities.name: "AVASCULAR PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description:
"Avascular Pulmonary Metastases are a type of metastatic lung disease characterized by the absence of blood supply, affecting the lungs."
"Lung Cancer Screening"

entities.name: "CYSTIC PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description:
"Cystic Pulmonary Metastases are a type of metastatic lung disease characterized by the presence of cysts in the lungs."
"Lung Cancer Screening"

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER SCREENING"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer Screening refers to the process of using medical technology to detect lung cancer in its early stages for better treatment outcomes."

entities.name: "LUNG-RADS"
entities.description: "Lung-RADS is a radiology reporting system used to standardize lung cancer screening and facilitate communication between healthcare providers."

entities.name: "IASLC (INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LUNG CANCER) 8TH EDITION"
entities.description: "IASLC 8th Edition is the current version of guidelines provided by the International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer for lung cancer management and treatment."

entities.name: "IASLC (INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LUNG CANCER) 7TH EDITION"
entities.description: "IASLC 7th Edition is a previous version of guidelines provided by the International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer for lung cancer management and treatment."

entities.name: "1996 AJCC-UICC REGIONAL LYMPH NODE CLASSIFICATION FOR LUNG CANCER STAGING"
entities.description: "The 1996 AJCC-UICC Regional Lymph Node Classification is a system used for staging lung cancer based on the involvement of regional lymph nodes."

entities.name: "PROMOTED ARTICLES"
entities.description: "Promoted Articles are pieces of content sponsored by advertisers for increased visibility and reach on a platform."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER STAGING"
entities.description:
"1996 AJCC-UICC Regional Lymph Node Classification for Lung Cancer Staging"
"IASLC (International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer) 8th Edition"

entities.name: "PULMONARY NODULE"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Nodule is a small, round or oval-shaped growth in the lungs that may be benign or malignant."

entities.name: "ADENOCARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Adenocarcinoma is a type of non-small cell lung cancer that starts in the cells that line the alveoli of the lungs."

entities.name: "SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA OF LUNG"
entities.description: "Squamous Cell Carcinoma of Lung is a type of non-small cell lung cancer that begins in the flat cells lining the airways of the lungs."

entities.name: "LARGE CELL CARCINOMA OF LUNG"
entities.description: "Large Cell Carcinoma of Lung is a type of non-small cell lung cancer that grows and spreads quickly in the lungs."

entities.name: "SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Small Cell Lung Cancer is a fast-growing type of lung cancer that usually starts in the bronchi and can quickly spread to other parts of the body."

entities.name: "PLEURAL EFFUSION"
entities.description: "Pleural Effusion is a condition characterized by the build-up of excess fluid between the layers of the pleura, the thin lining of the lung and chest cavity."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by a blood clot that travels to the lungs from another part of the body."

entities.name: "PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Pneumothorax is a condition in which air leaks into the space between the lung and chest wall, causing the lung to collapse partially or fully."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a progressive lung disease that makes it hard to breathe, often caused by long-term exposure to irritants like cigarette smoke."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease that causes scarring and stiffening of the lung tissue, making it difficult to breathe."

entities.name: "LUNG BIOPSY"
entities.description: "Lung Biopsy is a procedure in which a sample of lung tissue is removed and examined under a microscope to diagnose lung conditions such as cancer or infection."

entities.name: "THORACENTESIS"
entities.description: "Thoracentesis is a procedure to remove excess fluid from the pleural space between the lungs and chest wall using a needle and syringe."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FUNCTION TEST (PFT)"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Function Test (PFT) is a series of non-invasive tests that measure how well the lungs are functioning, including the ability to breathe in and out, and the efficiency of oxygen exchange."

entities.name: "BRONCHOSCOPY"
entities.description: "Bronchoscopy is a procedure that allows a doctor to view the airways of the lungs and take tissue samples or remove obstructions using a thin, flexible tube with a camera attached."

entities.name: "RADIATION THERAPY"
entities.description: "Radiation Therapy is a cancer treatment that uses high doses of radiation to kill cancer cells and shrink tumors in the lungs."

entities.name: "CHEMOTHERAPY"
entities.description: "Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing them or inhibiting their ability to divide."

entities.name: "IMMUNOTHERAPY"
entities.description: "Immunotherapy is a cancer treatment that helps the immune system fight cancer by boosting its ability to identify and kill cancer cells."

entities.name: "TARGETED THERAPY"
entities.description: "Targeted Therapy is a cancer treatment that targets specific genes, proteins, or tissue environments that contribute to the growth and survival of cancer cells in the lungs."

entities.name: "STEREOTACTIC BODY RADIATION THERAPY (SBRT)"
entities.description: "Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy (SBRT) is a type of radiation therapy that delivers high doses of radiation to lung tumors with extreme precision, minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue."

<data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing them or inhibiting their ability to divide."</data>      <data key="d2">f13e18ea6f0bc61535bc7103bc63ff0b</data>    </node>    <node id=""IMMUNOTHERAPY"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Immunotherapy is a <node id=""TARGETED THERAPY"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Targeted Therapy is a cancer treatment that targets specific genes, proteins, or tissue environments that (SBRT)"">      <data key="d0">"TREATMENT"</data>      <data key="d1">"Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy (SBRT) is a type of radiation therapy that delivers high doses of radiation to lung tumors with extreme precision, minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue."</data>      <data key="d2">f13e18ea6f0bc61535bc7103bc63ff0b</data>    </node>  </graph></graphml>

synonyms:
gravity dependent atelectasis
dependant lung atelectasis
dependent lung atelectasis
gravity dependent atelectasis
gravity-dependent atelectasis refers to a form of lung atelectasis that occurs in the dependent portions of the lungs.
on this page:
article:
pathology
pathology
differential diagnosis
related articles
references
images:cases and figures
pathologygravity-dependent atelectasis occurs due to a combination of reduced alveolar volume and increased perfusion. due to gravity, it usually has a dependent and subpleural distribution. it is very commonly seen in the posterior lung bases on ct, particularly in elderly individuals.in normal lung, gravity gradients exist in end-inspiration between the apex and lung base of 4:1 in the erect patient and between the anterior and posterior lung of 2.5:1 in the supine patient 1. these gradients increase in the presence of lung disease that increases the weight of the lung causing atelectasis.pathologyaetiology
bedridden patients
patients with prolonged shallow breathing
impaired mucociliary clearance
pneumonia
pulmonary oedema
differential diagnosisearly interstitial lung disease: prone ct chest can usually differentiate 2

1. woodring j & reed j. types and mechanisms of pulmonary atelectasis. j thorac imaging. 1996;11(2):92-108. doi:10.1097/00005382-199621000-00002 - pubmed
2. kashiwabara k & kohshi s. additional computed tomography scans in the prone position to distinguish early interstitial lung disease from dependent density on helical computed tomography screening patient characteristics. respirology. 2006;11(4):482-7. doi:10.1111/j.1440-1843.2006.00869.x - pubmed

entities.name: "GRAVITY-DEPENDENT ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Gravity-Dependent Atelectasis refers to a form of lung atelectasis that occurs in the dependent portions of the lungs."

entities.name: "CHEST"
entities.description: "Chest is a system where gravity-dependent atelectasis primarily occurs, affecting respiratory function."

entities.name: "BEDRIDDEN PATIENTS"
entities.description: "Bedridden Patients are identified as individuals at risk for gravity-dependent atelectasis due to prolonged immobility and shallow breathing."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is a condition that can contribute to gravity-dependent atelectasis due to inflammatory processes in the lungs."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is linked to gravity-dependent atelectasis, potentially causing impaired alveolar function and atelectasis formation."

entities.name: "ALVEOLI"
entities.description: "Alveoli are tiny air sacs within the lungs where gravity-dependent atelectasis may occur, affecting gas exchange."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY FUNCTION"
entities.description: "Respiratory Function is compromised in gravity-dependent atelectasis, leading to decreased oxygenation and ventilation."

entities.name: "IMMOBILITY"
entities.description: "Immobility contributes to gravity-dependent atelectasis by limiting movement and promoting lung collapse in dependent areas."

entities.name: "SHALLOW BREATHING"
entities.description: "Shallow Breathing is a common sign seen in gravity-dependent atelectasis, resulting in inadequate lung expansion."

entities.name: "GAS EXCHANGE"
entities.description: "Gas Exchange is impaired in gravity-dependent atelectasis, affecting the transfer of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the lungs."

entities.name: "INFLAMMATORY PROCESSES"
entities.description: "Inflammatory Processes in the lungs can trigger gravity-dependent atelectasis by causing tissue damage and obstruction."

key="d2">ff831d63ad593edabb8d55246d5c7402</data>    </node>    <node id=""THORACIC SURGERY"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Thoracic Surgery refers to surgical procedures performed on organs or structures within the chest cavity."</data>      <data key="d2">ff831d63ad593edabb8d55246d5c7402</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EMBOLISM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by blood clots."</data>      <data key="d2">ff831d63ad593edabb8d55246d5c7402</data>    </node>    <node id=""BRONCHOSCOPY"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Bronchoscopy is a diagnostic procedure that allows visualization of the airways and collection of samples for testing."</data>      <data key="d2">ff831d63ad593edabb8d55246d5c7402</data>    </node>    <node id=""VASCULAR IMAGING"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Vascular Imaging involves techniques used to visualize blood vessels for diagnostic purposes."</data>      <data key="d2">ff831d63ad593edabb8d55246d5c7402</data>    </node>    <node id=""CARDIAC CATHETERIZATION"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Cardiac Catheterization is a procedure <node id=""ENDOVASCULAR SURGERY"">      <data key="d0">"PROCEDURE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Endovascular Surgery refers to minimally invasive surgical procedures performed inside blood vessels or hollow organs."</data>      <data key="d2">ff831d63ad593edabb8d55246d5c7402</data>    </node>    <node id=""COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY (CT)"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d2">ff831d63ad593edabb8d55246d5c7402</data>    </node>    <node id=""ECHOCARDIOGRAPHY"">      <data key="d0">"TECHNOLOGY"</data>      <data key="d1">"Echocardiography is a diagnostic test that id=""PNEUMOTHORAX"">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">ff831d63ad593edabb8d55246d5c7402</data>    </node>    <edge source=""COLLAPSE"" target=""CHEST"">      <data </edge>    <edge source=""IMAGING TECHNIQUES"" target=""CHEST RADIOGRAPH"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Chest Radiograph is a specific technique within the broader category of entities.name: "CYSTIC FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to the production of thick and sticky mucus."

entities.name: "ALLERGIC BRONCHOPULMONARY ASPERGILLOSIS"
entities.description: "Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction to the fungus Aspergillus, leading to respiratory symptoms and lung inflammation."

entities.name: "WILLIAMS CAMPBELL SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Williams-Campbell syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the absence of cartilage in the bronchi, leading to bronchiectasis."

entities.name: "CONGENITAL TRACHEOBRONCHOMEGALY"
entities.description: "Congenital tracheobronchomegaly, also known as Mounier-Kuhn syndrome, is a rare condition characterized by the dilation of the trachea and bronchi, leading to respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "PRIMARY CILIARY DYSKINESIA"
entities.description: "Primary ciliary dyskinesia is a genetic disorder that affects the structure and function of cilia in the respiratory tract, leading to recurrent respiratory infections and bronchiectasis."

entities.name: "BRONCHIECTASIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiectasis is a condition characterized by the permanent dilatation of the bronchi, leading to a productive cough and recurrent respiratory infections."

entities.name: "TRACHEAL STENOSIS"
entities.description: "Tracheal stenosis is a narrowing of the trachea, leading to breathing difficulties and respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary edema is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "INTERSTITIAL OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Interstitial edema is the accumulation of fluid in the interstitial spaces of the lung tissue, leading to symptoms such as shortness of breath and coughing."

entities.name: "CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Cardiogenic pulmonary edema is a type of pulmonary edema caused by heart failure, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs and breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "NON-CARDIOGENIC PULMONARY OEDEMA"
entities.description: "Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema is a type of pulmonary edema not caused by heart failure, often due to conditions like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or high altitude sickness."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE AIRWAY NARROWING"
entities.description: "Diffuse airway narrowing refers to a generalized reduction in the diameter of the airways, leading to breathing difficulties and respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "FIBROTIC PNEUMOCONIOSES"
entities.description: "Fibrotic pneumoconioses are a group of lung diseases caused by the inhalation of mineral dust particles, leading to fibrosis in the lung tissue and breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "NON-FIBROTIC PNEUMOCONIOSES"
entities.description: "Non-fibrotic pneumoconioses are a group of lung diseases caused by the inhalation of mineral dust particles, not resulting in significant fibrosis but still causing respiratory symptoms."

entities.name: "NON-SMALL-CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Non-small cell lung cancer is a type of lung cancer that is not small cell carcinoma, including subtypes like adenocarcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and large cell carcinoma."

entities.name: "CARCINOID TUMOURS OF THE LUNG"
entities.description: "Carcinoid tumors of the lung are rare neuroendocrine tumors that arise from the bronchial or pulmonary tissue, often associated with symptoms like coughing and wheezing."

entities.name: "ADENOCARCINOMA IN SITU"
entities.description: "Adenocarcinoma in situ is a pre-invasive form of lung cancer where abnormal cells are confined to the alveoli, typically detected incidentally on imaging studies."

entities.name: "SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of lung cancer that originates from the squamous cells lining the airways, often associated with a history of smoking."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE"
entities.description: "Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a progressive lung disease that obstructs airflow and causes breathing difficulties. It includes conditions such as emphysema and chronic bronchitis."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary fibrosis is a lung disease that causes scarring and thickening of the lung tissue, leading to progressive and irreversible damage to the lungs."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, causing cough, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by blood clots that travel to the lungs from the legs or other parts of the body."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart, leading to symptoms like shortness of breath and chest pain."

entities.name: "LUNG ABSCESS"
entities.description: "A lung abscess is a pus-filled cavity in the lung caused by infection, resulting in symptoms like fever, cough with foul-smelling or bloody sputum, and chest pain."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary edema is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the lungs, leading to difficulty breathing and respiratory distress."

entities.name: "ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a severe lung condition that causes fluid to accumulate in the lungs, leading to low oxygen levels in the blood and difficulty breathing."

key="d5">"Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema can result in diffuse airway narrowing, contributing to respiratory symptoms."</data>      <data key="d6">d83dd5547054e486b93b0e0a28c5a82a</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""FIBROTIC PNEUMOCONIOSES"" target=""NON-FIBROTIC PNEUMOCONIOSES"">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">"Fibrotic and non-fibrotic pneumoconioses are two distinct categories of lung diseases caused by occupational dust exposure, with differing outcomes and clinical presentations."</data>      <data key="d6">d83dd5547054e486b93b0e0a28c5a82a</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""NON-SMALL-CELL LUNG CANCER"" target=""CARCINOID TUMOURS OF THE LUNG"">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">"Non-small cell lung cancer and carcinoid tumors of the lung are two types of lung neoplasms with different histological origins and clinical behaviors."</data>      <data key="d6">d83dd5547054e486b93b0e0a28c5a82a</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""ADENOCARCINOMA IN SITU"" target=""SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA"">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">"Adenocarcinoma in situ and squamous cell carcinoma are two different types of pre-invasive and invasive lung cancers, each with distinct pathological features and prognosis."</data>      <data key="d6">d83dd5547054e486b93b0e0a28c5a82a</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a type of cancer that can spread through air spaces and invade surrounding tissues, along with specific invasion patterns and locations."

entities.name: "TUMOUR"
entities.description: "Tumour is a growth that can exhibit non-lepidic patterns and be associated with specific stromal elements such as myofibroblasts."

entities.name: "STROMA"
entities.description: "Stroma is a supporting tissue that can be myofibroblastic and associated with the invasive behavior of tumour cells."

entities.name: "PLEURAL INVASION"
entities.description: "Pleural Invasion refers to the spread of cancer into the pleura, a characteristic feature of advanced lung cancer."

entities.name: "VASCULAR INVASION"
entities.description: "Vascular Invasion is the invasion of blood vessels by cancer cells, indicating aggressive tumor behavior."

entities.name: "PANCOAST TUMOUR"
entities.description: "Pancoast Tumour is a type of lung cancer located at the top of the lungs, with unique invasion patterns and clinical features."

entities.name: "BENIGN NEOPLASMS"
entities.description: "Benign Neoplasms are noncancerous growths that can mimic the behavior of malignant tumors in imaging studies."

entities.name: "CYSTIC PULMONARY METASTASES"
entities.description: "Cystic Pulmonary Metastases are secondary cancer deposits in the lungs that present as cystic lesions on imaging."

entities.name: "ADENOCARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Adenocarcinoma is a common type of lung cancer that originates in the mucus-secreting glands in the lungs, with distinct growth patterns and treatment strategies."

entities.name: "SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA"
entities.description: "Squamous Cell Carcinoma is a type of lung cancer that typically arises in the larger airways of the lung, associated with smoking and certain genetic mutations."

entities.name: "SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Small Cell Lung Cancer is an aggressive form of lung cancer that is characterized by small, round cells and tends to spread quickly to other parts of the body."

entities.name: "NON-SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer is a group of lung cancers that includes adenocarcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and large cell carcinoma, with different treatments based on cell type."

entities.name: "METASTASIS"
entities.description: "Metastasis is the spread of cancer cells from the primary site to distant organs or tissues, leading to the formation of secondary tumors."

entities.name: "EPITHELIAL-MESENCHYMAL TRANSITION"
entities.description: "Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition is a process in which epithelial cells transform into mesenchymal-like cells, promoting cancer metastasis and invasion."

entities.name: "LYMPH NODE INVOLVEMENT"
entities.description: "Lymph Node Involvement occurs when cancer cells spread to the lymph nodes, indicating a more advanced stage of the disease."

entities.name: "EGFR MUTATION"
entities.description: "EGFR Mutation is a genetic alteration often found in non-small cell lung cancer, influencing treatment response to targeted therapies like tyrosine kinase inhibitors."

entities.name: "ALK REARRANGEMENT"
entities.description: "ALK Rearrangement is a genetic abnormality in non-small cell lung cancer that can be targeted with specific medications like ALK inhibitors."

chunk:
peribronchial cuffing, also referred to as peribronchial thickening or bronchial wall thickening, is a radiologic sign which occurs when excess fluid or mucus buildup in the small airway passages of the lung causes localized patches of atelectasis (lung collapse). this causes the area around the bronchus to appear more prominent on an x-ray. it has also been described as donut sign, considering the edge is thicker, and the center contains air.
== examples ==
peribronchial cuffing is seen in a number of conditions including:
acute bronchitis
asthma following exercise or during an acute episode
bronchiolitis
bronchopulmonary dysplasia
congestive heart failure
cystic fibrosis
diffuse parenchymal lung disease
extreme exertion through physical exercise
hantavirus pulmonary syndrome
human metapneumovirus
kawasaki disease
lung cancer
pneumonia
pulmonary edema
smoke inhalation
== treatment ==
as peribronchial cuffing is a sign rather than a symptom or condition, there is no specific treatment except to treat the underlying cause.
== references ==

entities.name: "PERIBRONCHIAL CUFFING"
entities.description: "Peribronchial Cuffing is a radiologic sign of excess fluid or mucus in the small airway passages of the lung causing atelectasis."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is lung collapse caused by excess fluid or mucus in the small airway passages."

entities.name: "ACUTE BRONCHITIS"
entities.description: "Acute Bronchitis is one of the conditions associated with peribronchial cuffing, characterized by inflammation of the bronchial tubes."

entities.name: "ASTHMA"
entities.description: "Asthma is a condition that can lead to peribronchial cuffing during exercise or acute episodes, causing airway constriction."

entities.name: "BRONCHIOLITIS"
entities.description: "Bronchiolitis is a condition where the small airways in the lungs become inflamed, leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "BRONCHOPULMONARY DYSPLASIA"
entities.description: "Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia is a chronic lung condition that affects newborns, leading to respiratory issues."

entities.name: "CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE"
entities.description: "Congestive Heart Failure is a condition where the heart fails to pump blood effectively, leading to fluid buildup in the lungs."

entities.name: "CYSTIC FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Cystic Fibrosis is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system, causing mucus buildup."

entities.name: "DIFFUSE PARENCHYMAL LUNG DISEASE"
entities.description: "Diffuse Parenchymal Lung Disease is a group of lung conditions that cause inflammation and scarring of the lung tissue."

entities.name: "HANTAVIRUS PULMONARY SYNDROME"
entities.description: "Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome is a rare but serious respiratory disease caused by hantavirus infection."

entities.name: "HUMAN METAPNEUMOVIRUS"
entities.description: "Human Metapneumovirus is a common cause of respiratory infections in children and adults."

entities.name: "KAWASAKI DISEASE"
entities.description: "Kawasaki Disease is a childhood illness that causes inflammation in the blood vessels, including those of the lungs."

entities.name: "LUNG CANCER"
entities.description: "Lung Cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the lungs, usually in the cells lining the air passages."

entities.name: "PNEUMONIA"
entities.description: "Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, leading to cough, fever, and difficulty breathing."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EDEMA"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Edema is a condition where fluid accumulates in the lungs, making it difficult to breathe."

entities.name: "SMOKE INHALATION"
entities.description: "Smoke Inhalation is the inhalation of harmful gases and particulate matter from fires, leading to respiratory issues."

entities.name: "TUBERCULOSIS"
entities.description: "Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs, leading to cough, weight loss, and fatigue."

entities.name: "SILICOSIS"
entities.description: "Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, resulting in inflammation and scarring of the lung tissue."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease is a chronic lung disease that causes obstructed airflow to the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "PULMONARY FIBROSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease that results in lung tissue scarring and stiffness, making it difficult to breathe."

entities.name: "PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart."

entities.name: "PULMONARY EMBOLISM"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by a blood clot."

entities.name: "PULMONARY SARCOIDOSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Sarcoidosis is a rare inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the lungs."

entities.name: "PULMONARY TUBERCULOSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Tuberculosis specifically refers to tuberculosis that affects the lungs, causing symptoms like coughing and chest pain."

entities.name: "PULMONARY ALVEOLAR PROTEINOSIS"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis is a rare lung disease characterized by abnormal accumulation of surfactant in the alveoli."

entities.name: "PULMONARY INFARCTION"
entities.description: "Pulmonary Infarction is a condition where a region of the lung tissue dies due to loss of blood supply, often associated with pulmonary embolism."

entities.name: "ASBESTOSIS"
entities.description: "Asbestosis is a chronic lung condition caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers, leading to lung scarring and breathing difficulties."

entities.name: "LYMPHANGIOLEIOMYOMATOSIS (LAM)"
entities.description: "Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare lung disease that primarily affects women, causing the growth of abnormal smooth muscle-like cells in the lungs."

key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""PNEUMONIA"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Edema is a condition where fluid accumulates in the lungs, making it difficult to breathe."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""SMOKE INHALATION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Smoke Inhalation is the inhalation of harmful gases and particulate matter from fires, leading to respiratory issues."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""TUBERCULOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs, leading to cough, weight loss, and fatigue."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""SILICOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica (COPD)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease is a chronic lung disease that causes obstructed airflow to the lungs, leading to breathing difficulties."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY FIBROSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Fibrosis is a lung disease that results in lung tissue scarring and stiffness, making it difficult to breathe."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY HYPERTENSION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Hypertension is a type of high blood pressure that affects the arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY EMBOLISM"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by a blood clot."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY SARCOIDOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Sarcoidosis is a rare inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY TUBERCULOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Tuberculosis specifically refers to tuberculosis that affects the lungs, causing symptoms like coughing and chest pain."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY ALVEOLAR PROTEINOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis is a rare lung disease characterized by abnormal accumulation of surfactant in the alveoli."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""PULMONARY INFARCTION"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Pulmonary Infarction is a condition where a region of the lung tissue dies due to loss of blood supply, often associated with pulmonary embolism."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""ASBESTOSIS"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Asbestosis is a chronic lung condition caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers, leading to lung scarring and breathing difficulties."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <node id=""LYMPHANGIOLEIOMYOMATOSIS (LAM)"">      <data key="d0">"DISEASE"</data>      <data key="d1">"Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare lung disease that primarily affects women, causing the growth of abnormal smooth muscle-like cells in the lungs."</data>      <data key="d2">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </node>    <edge source=""PERIBRONCHIAL CUFFING"" target=""ATELECTASIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Peribronchial Cuffing leads to localized patches of atelectasis in the lung, causing collapse of lung tissue."</data>      <data key="d5">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PERIBRONCHIAL CUFFING"" target=""ACUTE BRONCHITIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Peribronchial Cuffing is seen in conditions like Acute Bronchitis, indicating inflammation of the bronchial tubes."</data>      <data key="d5">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PERIBRONCHIAL CUFFING"" target=""ASTHMA"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Peribronchial Cuffing can occur during asthma episodes, contributing to airway constriction."</data>      <data key="d5">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PERIBRONCHIAL CUFFING"" target=""BRONCHIOLITIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Bronchiolitis leads to inflammation of the small airways in the lungs, correlating with peribronchial cuffing."</data>      <data key="d5">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PERIBRONCHIAL CUFFING"" target=""BRONCHOPULMONARY DYSPLASIA"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Peribronchial Cuffing is associated with chronic lung conditions like Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia."</data>      <data key="d5">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PERIBRONCHIAL CUFFING"" target=""CYSTIC FIBROSIS"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Peribronchial Cuffing can be seen in individuals with Cystic Fibrosis, indicating mucus buildup."</data>      <data key="d5">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PERIBRONCHIAL CUFFING"" target=""PNEUMONIA"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Peribronchial Cuffing may occur in cases of pneumonia, leading to lung inflammation."</data>      <data key="d5">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </edge>    <edge source=""PERIBRONCHIAL CUFFING"" target=""PULMONARY EDEMA"">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">"Peribronchial Cuffing can cause fluid accumulation in the lungs, potentially resulting in pulmonary edema."</data>      <data key="d5">e9efba34c802538164765a03f84792d3</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
intermittent positive pressure breathing (ippb) is a respiratory therapy treatment for people who are hypoventilating. while not a preferred method due to cost, ippb is used to expand the lungs, deliver aerosol medications, and in some circumstances ventilate the patient.
== indications ==
ippb may be indicated for patients who are at risk for developing atelectasis and who are unable or unwilling to breathe deeply without assistance. in patients with severe lung hyperinflation, ippb may decrease dyspnea and discomfort during nebulized therapy.
== contraindications ==
most contraindications are relative, such as nausea, hemodynamic instability, tracheal fistula, singulation and hemoptysis. untreated tension pneumothorax is an absolute contraindication.
implementation
when treating atelectasis -
therapy should be volume-oriented
2. tidal volumes(vt) must be measured
3. vt goals must be set
4. vt goal of 10-15ml/kg ofbody weight
5. pressure can be increased to reach vt goal if tolerated by patient.
when treating atelectasis, ippb is only useful in the treatment of atelectasis if the volume delivered exceeds those volumes achieved by the patient's spontaneous efforts.
== references ==

entities.name: "INTERMITTENT POSITIVE PRESSURE BREATHING (IPPB)"
entities.description: "IPPB is a respiratory therapy treatment used to expand the lungs, deliver aerosol medications, and assist ventilation in hypoventilating patients."

entities.name: "ATELECTASIS"
entities.description: "Atelectasis is a condition where parts of the lung collapse, leading to potential complications in breathing and oxygen exchange."

entities.name: "DYSPNEA"
entities.description: "Dyspnea is a symptom characterized by difficulty breathing or shortness of breath."

entities.name: "TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX"
entities.description: "Tension Pneumothorax is a serious condition where air accumulates in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse and potentially life-threatening consequences."

entities.name: "RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (RDS)"
entities.description: "Respiratory Distress Syndrome is a breathing disorder that affects premature babies with underdeveloped lungs."

entities.name: "CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)"
entities.description: "Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs."

entities.name: "HYPOXEMIA"
entities.description: "Hypoxemia is a condition characterized by low oxygen levels in the blood."
